notes: On 8 February 2024, in Petit-Goave, Ouest, overnight, people held a demonstration and erected barricades of burning tires. During the mobilization, rioters looted and set fire to a First Instance Court. They also tried to burn the house of a government commissioner, although they did not success. Stones were thrown against the property of a doctor, causing material damages. This is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 16 January 2024, in Carrefour Zaboca, Grande-Anse,an anti-government demonstration took place on the Route Nationale #7 which was blocked. Five barricades were registered between Duchity and Carrefour Zaboka on that road. Armed individuals were registered near the barricades, but no specific activity was reported. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 8 June 2024, in Fonds-Parisien, Ouest, a mob of residents stoned to death a member of the 400 Mawozo Gang who had been arrested by the Dominican forces and transferred to the Haitian authorities earlier that day. The body of the victim was burned. 1 fatality.
Other: On 6 June 2024, in Roseaux, Grande-Anse, a roadblock was set up in Gommier. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

On 30 January 2024, in Petit-Goave, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. As protesters tried to close the entrance of the Port (methods unspecified), police forces used tear gas and opened fire on the crowd to disperse them. At least two protesters were shot and injured. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). At least 2 injured.

Property destruction: On 31 January 2024,in Petit-Goave, Ouest, a group of armed men broke into the facilities of the National Direction of Potable Waters which also serves to the Ministry of Infrastructure and destroyed two water cisterns.

On 14 March 2024, in Rode, Centre, people, accompanied by members of the BSAP, protested on the road. Although there is no information on the motivation for the protest, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations and calls for the resignation of Ariel Henry that have been ongoing since January.

source: Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 5 February 2024, in Petit-Goave, Ouest, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters burned tires and erected barricades on Simonds Avenue. They also set fire to the National Directorate of Drinking Water and Sanitation office (DINEPA) and two vehicles belonging to the institution. Police forces intervened and shot and injured two demonstrators. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 2 injured.

On 5 February 2024, in Saint-Michel-de-l'Atalaye, Artibonite, residents and armed members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Protesters set up roadblocks on the National Road 1 and used metal welds to block public institutions' doors. The protest, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).
On 14 January 2024, in Saint-Michel-de-l'Atalaye, Artibonite, an unknown number of armed men attacked a police station (methods unspecified), allowing several inmates to escape. Casualties unknown.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 6 February 2024, in Petit-Goave, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Police forces intervened and shot and injured two protesters as they fired at the crowd. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 2 injured.

source: Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Ordre des Defenseurs des Droits Humains (ORDEDH)
notes: On 25 January 2024, in Fonds-des-Negres, Nippes, police forces killed an unarmed man accused of being a gang member. The killing was described as an extrajudicial execution led by the Miragoane police commissioner, Ernst Muscadin. The police commissioner claimed the victim as being part of the Grand-Ravine gang. 1 fatality.
On 1 July 2024, in La Vallee, Sud-Est, people protested against the killing of a minibus driver in Gressier the previous day (coded separately) by blocking the Route Nationale #4.
Other: On 4 March 2024, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, roadblocks were set up on the Route Nationale #6. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.

Around 21 January 2024 (weekend of), in Jeremie, Artibonite, Grande-Anse, residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

Around 1 February 2024 (as reported), in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Herny. On the Source-Dommage street, rioters set up barricades of burning tires and police forces intervened using tear gas to disperse them. Some elderly people, pregnant women, and kids fainted due to tear gas (not clarified if they were taking part in the demonstration). This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 8 February 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, people held a demonstration and roadblocks were set in the downtown area. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 17 February 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, people held a demonstration and roadblocks were set on the Airport Road. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the barricade or who set it up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations and calls for the resignation of Ariel Henry that have been ongoing since January.

On 6 February 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, for the third consecutive day, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 7. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 17 February 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, overnight, an unknown number of armed individuals on motorcycles opened fire indiscriminately as they rode through the commune (drive-by). A boy who was at a house was shot and injured by a stray bullet. At least 1 injured.

On 18 February 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, a group of unidentified individuals demonstrated and set up a makeshift barricade on the Airport Road, blocking access to vehicles. This part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 11 July 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, members of the 400 Mawozo Gang killed four men as they attacked and took refuge in the commune. The victims, who were members of the same family, were decapitated. According to residents, members of this gang are seeking refuge from the operations of the Kenyan police. 4 fatalities.
On 20 July 2024, in Buvette, Grande-Anse, residents set up a roadblock to demand the reparation of the road that has been damaged by mud and water.
Other: On 3 January 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Duval. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
On 8 January 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, unidentified armed groups clashed. There is no information on the circumstances of the clashes. Casualties unknown.

On 18 January 2024, in Marin, Ouest, roadblocks and barricades were set up on the streets. This is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). Police forces intervened to remove the roadblocks, although no interaction with the armed individuals was mentioned.
Other: On 17 January 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Marassa Crossroad. There is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators of the gunshots.

Other: On 20 January 2024, in Santo, Ouest, barricades were set up. The Cul-de-Sac area was also barricaded. Another report indicates that the police intervened to unblock the area. There is no information on the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up.
Other: On 30 January 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, the Route Nationale #1 was blocked in Canaan. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

Other: On 7 January 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gunshots were heard near the Remy Colimon post. The report also indicates that several houses were burned. There is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators of the gunshots or the fire setting.
Other: On 19 January 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Shadda neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 27 January 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Duval. There is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators of the gunshots.
Other: On 30 January 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Duval. There is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators of the gunshots.

On 12 February 2024, near Marin, Ouest, gang members from the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang clashed with the rival gang led by Ti Gabriel. Another version states that the clash was between members of the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang. During clashes, residents were attacked and hundreds of houses were burned in La Plaine du Cul-du-Sac area. Some young women were raped in front of their parents. Thousands of civilians fled their homes. This was part of a gang war for territory and for the control of economic activity in the targeted areas. According to one source, more than 20 people were killed amidst gang clashes near Marin and in Sibert. At least 20 bodies were found burned in the Marie Madeleine zone. According to another report, on 12 February more than 30 civilians were killed amidst gang clashes in Carrefour and La Plaine du Cul-du-Sac. At least 20 fatalities split across two events. 10 fatalities coded for this event.
Other: On 4 February 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Duval. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Non-violent activity: On 5 February 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, roadblocks were set up at different points of the Route Nationale #1, including Lizon and Shada. They were also registered in areas like Lizon and Marin. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks, a music band as well as armed individuals were present.

Other: On 6 February 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Plaine du Cul de Sac and Lizon. Also, roadblocks were set up on the Route Nationale #1 in Lizon and Shada Crossroad. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots and the roadblocks.
Other: On 6 February 2024, in Marin, Ouest, roadblocks were set up on the Route Nationale #1 in Marin Crossroad. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.

Other: On 8 February 2024, in Santo, Ouest, barricades of tree trunks were erected in different parts of the Santo road. There is no information on the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up.
Other: On 24 February 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Carrefour Shada. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
