Other: On 6 March 2024, in Marin, Ouest, roadblocks were set up. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.

Other: On 6 March 2024, in Santo, Ouest, trucks were used to set up roadblocks in Santo 17. Armed individuals were also registered in Santo 19, but no activity was mentioned. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.
Other: On 2 March 2024, in Marin, Ouest, gunshots were heard. Roadblocks were also registered. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or the authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 2 March 2024, in Santo, Ouest, gunshots were heard. Roadblocks were also registered. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or the authorship of the gunshots.

On 5 March 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, unidentified gangs looted several banks. They took one of the banks' safe and kidnapped the security guards after seizing their weapons. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.
Other: On 11 March 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest gunshots were heard in Shada. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 25 March 2024, in Santo, Ouest, roadblocks were set up in Santo 14 and 17. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.

Other: On 2 April 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, roadblocks were set up on the Route Nationale #1 in Lizon and Shada. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.
Other: On 4 April 2024, in Santo, Ouest, roadblocks were set up between Santo 25 and 17. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.

source: Alterpresse; Loop News Haiti; Loop News St. Lucia; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Trinidad and Tobago Guardian
notes: On 6 April 2024, off the Coast of Port-au-Prince, Ouest, coast guards and police forces clashed with members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) and with affiliates of the Canaan Gang as they carried out a security operation aiming at recovering a cargo ship which had been hijacked by the gangsters on 4 April (coded separately). During clashes, two police officers were injured while several gang members were killed. The rice cargo was recovered. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Property destruction: On 6 March 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, overnight, gang members fired shots at the city hall, breaking several windows. Several offices were looted.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 15 January 2024 (month of), in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, members of the 400 Mawozo Gang clashed with members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) in the Nan Remy village. Casualties unknown.

Around 1 May 2024 (as reported), in Santo, Ouest, gang members attacked disabled people from the Foyer Saint-Vincent in Santo 17. The report indicates that the people have had to evacuate the premises towards other refuges. There is no further information on the nature of the attack.
Other: On 10 May 2024, in Santo, Ouest, a roadblock was set up in Santo 23 and one in 25. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 8 March 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, armed men attacked the Calvaire sub-police station in unreported circumstances. Casualties unknown.
Non-violent activity: On 21 May 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, armed individuals set up roadblocks in Lilavois and Shada. There is no information on the motives for the roadblocks.
Other: On 23 May 2024, in Marin, Ouest, gunshots were heard. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 23 May 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, unidentified gang members kidnapped several employees after breaking into the Bon Espoir orphanage in Lizon 41. The victims have not been identified. Gunshots were heard in Lizon 26, 35, 39, and 41 until late during the night. The report indicates that the incident took place in a gang leader's territory. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

source: Haiti Progres; Loop News Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 20 July 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, police forces clashed with members of the 400 Mawozo Gang as the criminals attacked residents 'areas in the commune. Around 200 armed gang members were noticed in the La Tremblay area (Nan Codastre village). Casualties unknown.
Around 6 August 2024 (between 5 - 6 August), in Fonds-Parisien, Ouest, members of a self-defence group killed a resident whom they accused of being in contact with the 400 Mawozo Gang. 1 fatality.

Non-violent activity: Around 7 August 2024 (as reported), in Fonds-Parisien, Ouest, members of a self-defence group set up roadblocks, booby-trapped streets, and patrolled them in the Miracle Village residential area to prevent gang members from attacking the community.

On 1 February 2024, in Mirebalais, Centre, members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) police held a protest and set up a roadblock on the National Road 3, demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. The BSAP agents also opposed the government's decision to ban them from circulating with fire weapons and the BSAP's uniform. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 29 January 2024, in Peligre, Centre, residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Protesters set up a roadblock on the National Road 3, interrupting road traffic. The protest, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by organizations from the political opposition (coded separately).
Other: On 25 January 2024, in Mirebalais, Centre, the Route National #3 was blocked. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

On 7 February 2024, in Grand-Goave, Ouest, thousands of residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).
Other: On 2 February 2024, near Mirebalais, a roadblock was set up on Route Nationale #3. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

On 5 February 2024, in Mirebalais, Centre, an anti-government demonstration was held and barricades were erected on various streets. The report also indicates that the BSAP agents were present. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the barricades, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).
Other: On 19 February 2024, in Peligre, Centre, a truck was used to set up a roadblock on the Route Nationale #3. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.
Other: On 17 February 2024, between Mirebalais and Peligre, Centre, a roadblock was set up on the Route Nationale #3. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

On 8 February 2024, in Grand-Goave, Ouest, people held a demonstration and erected barricades of burning tires. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks and barricades or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).
Other: On 19 February 2024, in Grand-Goave, Ouest, a makeshift barricade was set up on a road. There is no information on the circumstances of the barricade or who set it up.
Other: On 4 March 2024, near Mirebalais, Centre, a truck was used to set up a roadblock on the road to Mirebalais. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

On 18 April 2024, in Peligre, Mirebalais, in the morning, BSAP police agents held a protest on the National Road 3 demanding the installation of Guy Philippe in the National Palace and as head of the government. Protesters blocked the mentioned road.
Other: On 18 April 2024, in Peligre, Centre, a road block was set up on the Route Nationale #3. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.
On 25 June 2024, in Mirebalais, Centre, residents captured a Taliban gang member and executed him as part of the Bwa Kale Movement after interrogating him on his gang activities. 1 fatality.

On 27 July 2024, around Saint-Mesmin, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members near the zone of Mellier and blocked roads. Drivers stayed out of the road towards Leogane to avoid the clashes. The measure also interfered with the functioning of the tolls installed by gang members in Merger, keeping drivers from moving towards Port-au-Prince. Casualties unknown.
Other: On 6 August 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gang members set up a roadblock using cars as barricades as a means to control the area.
On 3 August 2024, off the coast of Grand-Goave, Ouest, gang members carried out an attack against a boat, killing one passenger. 1 fatality.
On 14 August 2024, in Saint-Michel-de-l'Atalaye, Artibonite, leaders of a social group set up a barricade on the road connecting Ennery and Saint Raphael to demand its reparation.

Around 21 August 2024 (between 20 - 22 August), in Gros-Morne, Artibonite, unidentified gang members kidnapped a 5-year-old girl and asked for the payment of a ransom as a condition for her release. The perpetrators were not identified, although residents accused the Kokorat San Ras Gang and members of this gang attacked the village in reprisal between 23 and 25 August (coded separately). The victim's whereabouts are unknown.

On 21 August 2024, in Leogane, Ouest, local residents and internally displaced citizens from Gressier held a protest at the Arms square against insecurity. The mobilization was joined by several political militants from the Fanmi Lavalas party. They decried the lack of results of the state of emergency declared by the national government (coded separately).

On 19 August 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, a group of people set up barricades with burning tires and blocked the circulation with merchandise trucks to demonstrate for unknown reasons. Police forces were present, although it is not known if they intervened. Gunshots were also heard during the demonstration, but the authorship is unknown.

On 18 August 2024, in Delmas - Carrefour Pean, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Carrefour Pean neighbourhood, likely as part of an attack by the Viv Ansanm Gang. Some families fled their houses. Casualties unknown.
Other: On 17 August 2024, between Mirebalais and Lascahobas, Centre, a roadblock was set up. There is no information on the circumstances or motives of the roadblock.

On 16 August 2024, in Tabarre - Clercine, Ouest, two militants at the PPD party physically aggressed one of the founders of the party during a press conference in Carrefour Rita (Clercine neighbourhood). The perpetrators destroyed the microphones and damaged the decoration. The victim managed to escape unharmed. According to the victim, the perpetrators were supporters of a former senator of the party and were sent by said former senator to try to kill him as he has been denouncing for a year that the former senator has allied with his political adversaries for political gain. There were no casualties.

On 12 August 2024, near Petion Ville - Fort Jacques, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, suspected members of the Kraze Barye (Vitelhomme) Gang carried out attacks (methods unknown) in this area and in different areas, such as Doko and Greffin (coded separately), among others. There are no further information on the circumstances of the attacks. Casualties unknown.

On 11 August 2024, near Petion Ville - Fort Jacques, Ouest, suspected members of the Kraze Barye (Vitelhomme) Gang carried out attacks (methods unknown) in this area and also attacks in different areas, such as Doko and Greffin (coded separately), among others. There are no further information on the circumstances of the attacks. Casualties unknown.

On 11 August 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 32, Ouest, people protested against the current government in Delmas 32. The protest was carried out under the direction of several political figures. The police intervened to interrupt the protest (unspecified methods).
On 8 August 2024, in Petion Ville - Laboule, Ouest, two armed men on a motorcycle opened fire in Laboule 12, killing one man (drive-by). 1 fatality.

Non-violent activity: Around 1 August 2024 (beginning of month), in Gros-Morne, Artibonite, gang members took control of several communal sections, including 5th section Pendu, 6th section Savane Carree, as well as 4th section l'Acul which was completely controlled by 12 August. This situation has caused an increasing state of restlessness and fear among residents.

On 30 July 2024, in Petion Ville - Thomassin, Ouest, an unknown number of people were kidnapped in Thomassin. The police later intercepted the kidnappers at the height of Montagne Noire. There is no information on the nature of the interaction between the officers and the kidnappers.

source: Haiti Progres; Haiti Standard; Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 21 July 2024, in Carrefour - Centre Sportif de Carrefour, Ouest, armed gang members entered the Carrefour Sports Center and opened fire on a crowd as a football match was being played. A man was shot and killed. He was the former goalkeeper of the Association sportive de Carrefour (ASCAR) for the Don Bosco Football Club and for the national Haitian team. Several people were shot and injured. It is unknown whether the fatal victim was the intended target. 1 fatality, several injured.

On 12 July 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 19/Mackandal, Ouest, an unknown number of people were abducted in Delmas 19. There is no information on the perpetrators and circumstances of the abduction, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

On 8 July 2024, in Petion Ville - Jacquet Toto, Ouest, unidentified men wearing bulletproof vests kidnapped a merchant in a market in the Telele market (Jacquet neighborhood). Latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victim's whereabouts are unknown.

On 22 June 2024, in Carrefour - Fontamara; 'Janjan Ti Paste' (killed), Ouest, the Ti Bwa Gang leader (alias Krisla) engaged in armed clashes with members of a rival gang in the Fontamara neighbourhood. Clashes erupted after the Ti Bwa gang held a member of the rival organization the day prior. During clashes, a Ti Bwa Gang affiliated was shot and killed. 1 fatality.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 15 June 2024 (month of), in Delmas - Pele Simon, Ouest, a member of the Simon-Pele Gang shot and killed a 13-year-old girl whose corpse was found in late June in the Pele Simon neighbourhood. The attacker used to abuse the now deceased. 1 fatality.

On 11 June 2024, in Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13, Ouest, a group of people held a demonstration in the Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13 neighbourhood to decry the killing of three police officers by gang members on 9 June (coded separately). Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires.

On 4 June 2024, in Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members near the Carrefour Aeroport neighbourhood as they intervened to prevent the criminals from hijacking vehicles in the mentioned area and in Delmas 3 (located in Delmas 5 neighbourhood). It is known that the gangsters had forced the driver of a tanker truck transporting gasoline to divert the march towards Delmas 18. In the Carrefour Aeroport neighbourhood, the gang members opened fire on a driver and his vehicle, and set it on fire. Casualties unknown.

On 4 June 2024, in Petion Ville - Morne Hercule, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members around Rue Geffrard (Morne Hercule neighborhood) and Rue Oge (Centre Ville (Sud) neighborhood, coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 23 May 2024, in Delmas - Musseau, Ouest, people protested in Musseau. There is no information on the circumstances or motives of the protest.

On 18 May 2024, in Petion Ville - Laboule, Ouest, gang members attacked the Laboule neighbourhood. According to residents, the gangsters remained present in the neighbourhood for several days. Casualties unknown.

On 15 May 2024, in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, members of the population lynched a member of the Kraze Barye Gang in Pernier 12. The gangster was using a truck to kidnap people when he was stopped by the residents who attacked him. 1 fatality.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 12 May 2024, in Gressier - Boko, Ouest, armed gang members shot and killed a 78-year-old woman vendor as she tried to recover some of her goods from the Gressier Market, in the Boko neighbourhood. She died later that day. In the Sous Fort neighbourhood, gang members also killed a man (coded separately). 1 fatality.
Around 6 May 2024 (as reported), in Tabarre - Clercine, Ouest, gang members attacked the Clercine neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 4 May 2024, in Carrefour - Mariani, Ouest, in the morning, gang members killed a moto-taxi driver man in the Mariani neighbourhood. 1 fatality.

On 2 May 2024, in Tabarre - Mais Gate/Clercine 2, Ouest, armed individuals clashed with officers from the Motorized Response Brigade (BIM). Gunshots were registered near the airport (coded to Mais Gate/Clercine 2). There is no information on the circumstances of the clash. Casualties unknown.

On 1 May 2024, in Tabarre - Aeroport Toussaint Louverture, Ouest, overnight, gang members attacked the Toussaint Louverture Airport facilities and clashed with police and military forces, who intervened and expelled them from the area. Gunshots were also heard in Tabarre 27. Casualties unknown.

On 30 April 2024, in Carrefour - Arcachon/Mon-Repos, Ouest, Bout Ba gang members hijacked some boats in the port in Mon Repos neighborhood while they were going to Cayemites island. They also kidnapped the owners of the boats. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

Around 18 April 2024 (as reported), in Carrefour - Le Lambi, Ouest, members of the Ti Bwa Gang clashed with affiliates of a local gang operating in the Lambi area. Clashes took place as the Ti Bwa Gang attacked the local gang's positions to remove gang roadblocks set up in the area. Casualties unknown.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 15 April 2024, in Carrefour - Mariani, Ouest, members of the Bout Ba Gang engaged in armed clashes with police forces in the Mariani neighbourhood. A 31-year-old woman who was outside her home was shot in the back. Her health state is unknown. 1 injured.

On 5 April 2024, around Delmas - Delmas 48, Ouest, people protested from Delmas 32 to Delmas 48 to demand the respect of the constitution. They also requested that a judge from the court of appeal is assigned as president while also rejecting the proposed Presidential Transitional Council (PTC).

On 5 April 2024, in Petion Ville - Delmas 95, Ouest, a lynching was carried out against a suspected thief in Delmas 103 (Delmas 95 neighborhood) on the Delmas Road. His body was burned. There is no information on the perpetrators or circumstances of the lynching. 1 fatality.

On 2 April 2024, in Tabarre - Clercine II/Carrefour Clercine, Ouest, police forces clashed with members of the Chien Mechant Gang as they intervened to expel them from the vicinity of the BIM police station (in Clercine II neighbourhood). In reprisal, the gangsters looted scores of houses and stole at least five vehicles in the Village Thomas Theodat and Tercina residential areas. Residents were forced to flee. Gunshots were also heard in Cite Doudoune near Tabarre 27. Casualties unknown.

On 2 April 2024, in Carrefour - Fontamara, Ouest, people gathered to protest in Fontamara. The circumstances or motives of the protest are unknown. In the morning, the Ti Bwa gang leader called on people to mobilize and gather at Plaza Fontamara, although it is unknown if the protest was related.

On 27 March 2024, in Tabarre - Clercine II/Carrefour Clercine, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, the police clashed with members of the Chien Mechant Gang in Clercine neighborhood. According to the source the gang started attacking and looting police bases in the area in response to the police announcing the destruction of about a hundred houses located next to the international airport (coded separately). This resulted in clashes between the two parties. Casualties unknown.

On 27 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Freres/Nan Kajou, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members in Freres neighborhood. Gunshots were heard in the area. A driver died as result of the incident. Gunshots of unspecified authorship were also heard in Puits Blain 4 neighborhood. 1 fatality.

On 26 March 2024, in Tabarre - Clercine II/Carrefour Clercine, Ouest, overnight, the police clashed with members of the Chien Mechant Gang in Clercine neighborhood. According to the source the gang started attacking and looting police bases in the area in response to the police announcing the destruction of about a hundred houses located next to the international airport. This resulted in clashes between the two parties. Gunshots were still being heard in the area the following day (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 22 March 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 60, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in Delmas 60. Around 10 bodies were found scattered in Delmas and Petionville. Some of them were burned. At least 10 fatalities split across two events.

On 22 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Delmas 95, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in Delmas 95. Around 10 bodies were found scattered in Delmas and Petionville. Some of them were burned. At least 10 fatalities split across two events.

On 20 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Delmas 95, Ouest, suspected members of the Bwa Kale movement lynched at least four Mackandal gang members and in Delmas 95 and 97. This happened amid clashes between police forces and gang members (coded separately). At least 4 fatalities.

On 15 March 2024, in Carrefour - Fontamara, Ouest, hundreds of people holding signs in favor of Guy Philippe protested by marching towards Fontamara 43 (Fontamara Ouest neighbourhood). The protestors were calling for Guy Philippe to return to the National Palace, where he had lead a coup and ousted the previous Prime Minister in 2004.

On 13 March 2024, in Tabarre - Torcelle, Ouest, gang members attacked the Torcelle neighbourhood. Gunshots were heard there and near the Toussaint Louverture International Airport, in Mais Gate/Clercine 2. Casualties unknown.

On 12 March 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 32, Ouest, people demonstrated in Delmas 32. They erected burning tires in different areas such as Delmas 30, Delmas 21 (Delmas 19/Mackandal) (both coded separately), and Delmas road. There is no information on the motives of the demonstration.

On 12 March 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, people demonstrated in Delmas 32 (coded separately). They erected burning tires in different areas such as Delmas 30, Delmas 21 (Delmas 19/Mackandal, coded separately), and Delmas road. There is no information on the motives of the demonstration.

On 12 March 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 19/Mackandal, Ouest, people demonstrated in Delmas 32 (coded separately). They erected burning tires in different areas such as Delmas 30 (coded separately), Delmas 21 (Delmas 19/Mackandal), and Delmas road. There is no information on the motives of the demonstration.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Vant Bef Info
notes: On 8 March 2024, in Carrefour - Do Karyann, Ouest, gang members killed a pastor of the 'Tabernacle de la Grace' church (Evangelical Christian). The perpetrators beheaded the victim and took his head, which was later found in a bucket. 1 fatality.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 7 March 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 5, Ouest, gangs set fire to residents' houses in Delmas 3 and 5 (in Delmas 5 neighbourhood). The Public Company for the Promotion of Social Housing (EPPLS) and the Dadaou Sport Centre, both located in Delmas 3, were also looted and burned. An UNIBANK branch was looted in Delmas 18 (located in Cite Numero Un neighbourhood). Casualties unknown.

On 6 March 2024, in Tabarre - Mais Gate/Clercine 2, Ouest, for the third consecutive day, gang members fired shots against the Toussaint Louverture International Airport (Mais Gate/Clercine 2 neighbourhood) and clashed with police forces in the area. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Loop News Haiti
notes: On 5 March 2024, in Tabarre - Mais Gate/Clercine 2, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, gang members fired shots against the Toussaint Louverture International Airport (Mais Gate/Clercine 2 neighbourhood). Overnight, armed clashes were mentioned between the gangsters and police forces. Casualties unknown.

On 4 March 2024, in Carrefour - Bizoton/Mont-Carmel-Diquini, Ouest, armed gang members opened fire on a national police convoy in the Bizoton neighbourhood. There were several injured (affiliation unspecified). There were no fatalities.

source: Gazette Haiti; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 2 March 2024, in Tabarre - Cazeau/Tabarre 14, Ouest, gang members aligned to the Living Together gang-led initiative (aka Viv Ansanm gang) set fire to a police station in the Cazeau neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.

On 19 February 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, a demonstration was held and roadblock with burning tires were set in Delmas 30 and Delmas 33 (coded separately). Trucks were also used to block roads in Delmas 19 and 21 (coded separately). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations and calls for the resignation of Ariel Henry that have been ongoing since January.

On 19 February 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 33, Ouest, a demonstration was held and roadblock with burning tires were set in Delmas 30 (coded separately) and Delmas 33. Trucks were also used to block roads in Delmas 19 and 21 (coded separately). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations and calls for the resignation of Ariel Henry that have been ongoing since January.

On 19 February 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 19/Mackandal, Ouest, trucks were also used to block roads in Delmas 19 and 21 during a demonstration. Similarly, roadblock with burning tires were set in Delmas 30 (coded separately) and Delmas 33 (coded separately) during demonstrations. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations and calls for the resignation of Ariel Henry that have been ongoing since January.

On 17 February 2024, around Delmas - Zone Predailler/Charbonnie, Ouest, people demonstrated in Delmas 33. They erected burning tires and marched towards Gerald Bataille (near Zone Predailler/Charbonnie). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the demonstration, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations and calls for the resignation of Ariel Henry that have been ongoing since January.

On 13 February 2024, in Tabarre - Cazeau/Tabarre 14, Ouest, clashes were registered in Cazeau. Gunshots were also registered in Butte Boyer and Croix-des-Missions. There is no information on the circumstances or people involved in the clashes.

On 13 February 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 48, Ouest, people held a demonstration in Delmas 48 which was dispersed, though there is no further information on the responsible and the circumstances of the intervention (coded A2 as Police forces). Burning tires were registered in Delmas 32 (coded separately). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the demonstration, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations and calls for the resignation of Ariel Henry that have been ongoing since January.

On 13 February 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 32, Ouest, people held a demonstration and burned tires in Delmas 32. A similar event took place in Delmas 48 which was dispersed (coded separately). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the demonstration, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations and calls for the resignation of Ariel Henry that have been ongoing since January.

Around 12 February 2024 (as reported), in Tabarre - Duvivier/Galette Goureau, Ouest, gang members from the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang clashed with the rival gang led by Ti Gabriel in Duvivier neighbourhood. Another version states that the clash was between members of the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang. This was part of a gang war for territory and for the control of economic activity in the targeted areas. Some residents fled their homes. More than 15 people were killed and an unknown number were injured as a result of gang clashes in Duvivier, Terre Noire (Cite Soleil), and Blanchard neighborhoods (Cite Soleil) (coded separately). At least 15 fatalities split across two events.

On 12 February 2024, in Cite Soleil - Terre Noire/ Blanchard, Ouest, gang members from the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang clashed with the rival gang led by Ti Gabriel in Terre Noire, Barye Fe, and Blanchard neighborhoods. Another version states that the clash was between members of the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang. This was part of a gang war for territory and for the control of economic activity in the targeted areas. Some residents fled their homes. More than 15 people were killed and an unknown number were injured as a result of gang clashes in Terre Noire, Blanchard, and Duvivier neighborhoods (Tabarre) (coded separately). At least 15 fatalities split across two events.

On 12 February 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 30, people demonstrated. They marched from Delmas 30 towards Carrefour Aeroport. Demonstrators threw stones at cars and burning tires were erected. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the demonstration, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations and calls for the resignation of Ariel Henry that have been ongoing since January.

On 8 February 2024, in Petion Ville - Peguy-Ville, Ouest, people held a demonstration and roadblocks were set in Peguy-Ville and Freres Road. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 7 February 2024, in Delmas - Musseau, Ouest, hundreds of government opponents and members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade police (BSAP) held a march demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires and looted several businesses. Police forces used tear gas to disperse them. At least one demonstrator was injured. Tens of demonstrators on motorcycles rode to the PM residence (in Musseau). The demonstration, which was called by the PPD Party, was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). One source stated that he was seen among the crowd. At least 1 injured.

On 5 February 2024, in Tabarre - Clercine II/Carrefour Clercine, Ouest, vehicles were used to barricade roads in Clercine Crossroad, while people were protesting in Croix-des-Missions and marching towards Sarthe (coded separately). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the protest, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). The report also indicates that gunshots were heard, but there is no information about their circumstances or authorship. Roadblocks were also set up on the Route Nationale #1 in the same area.

On 5 February 2024, in Tabarre - Croix des Missions, Ouest, people protested in Croix-des-Missions. They marched towards Sarthe. Vehicles were used to barricade roads in Clercine Crossroad (coded separately). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the protest, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). The report also indicates that gunshots were heard, but there is no information about their circumstances or authorship. Roadblocks were also set up on the Route Nationale #1 in the same area.

On 24 January 2024, in Carrefour - Bizoton/Mont-Carmel-Diquini, Ouest, there were armed clashes in the Diquini and Christophe Chanel areas. The report also indicates that residents have been forced to flee the area. There is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators involved in the clashes. Casualties unknown.

On 19 January 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 60, Ouest, an anti-government demonstration took place in Delmas 47 (Delmas 41 neighborhood, coded separately), and 75 (coded separately). The demonstrators set up barricades with burning tires. Another report indicates that the police was present, but no specific activity was reported. Another report indicates that barricades were erected with burning tires in Delmas 60. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the demonstration, and the barricades or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 18 January 2024, in Cite Soleil - Boston, Ouest, clashes were registered in Boston, Brooklyn (coded separately), and Jeremie Wharf (coded separately). There is no information on the circumstances of the clashes. Casualties unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 15 January 2024 (month of), in Tabarre - Torcelle, Ouest, members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) clashed in their stronghold, in Tabarre 70 (Torcelle neighbourhood), over internal disputes. Up to 63 gang members were killed. At least 63 fatalities.

On 8 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, members of a self-defense group from the Fort-Jacques area killed at least six members of the Vitelhomme gang, including a local leader of the gang in Metivier. Some firearms and materials belonging to the gangsters were seized and submitted to the police. Gunshots were also heard in areas like Vivy Mitchell and Freres Road. At least 6 fatalities split across 2 events, coded as 3

On 16 January 2024, Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, residents held a protest on the Carrefour Aeroport (Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13) demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).
On 8 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, unidentified armed groups clashed in Torcelle. There is no information on the circumstances of the clashes. Casualties unknown.

source: Amerique Info 7; Ordre des Defenseurs des Droits Humains (ORDEDH); PNH: National Police of Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Trip Foumi
notes: On 19 January 2024, in Tabarre - Cazeau/Tabarre 14, Ouest, the police clashed with unidentified armed men in Tabarre 14 and the Cazeau neighborhood. At least one police officer was injured during an exchange of gunfire in Tabarre 14. Gunshots were heard in Croix des Missions, where there was also a roadblock. Another report indicates that armed individuals held a roadblock in Clercine and seized the keys of the motorcycles from the Haojin business. Initial reports claimed that two people were killed, but this information was not confirmed by the police. At least one was injured.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 10 May 2024, in Gressier - Boko, Ouest, armed gang members killed a man and burned him inside his cousin's house in the Boko neighbourhood. The victim was identified as a member of the Gathering of the Madan Sara of Haiti (labor group). The gang members accused him of being a police informant. This happened amidst clashes between the Grand-Ravine Gang and police forces in the vicinity of the Cite Gressier police station (coded separately). 1 fatality.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 10 May 2024, in Gressier - Boko, Ouest, armed gang members shot and killed a woman near the Gressier Market (in Boko neighbourhood). This happened amidst clashes between the Grand-Ravine Gang and police forces in the vicinity of the Cite Gressier police station (coded separately). 1 fatality.

source: Haiti Progres; Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 24 August 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 32, Ouest, overnight, police forces on patrol clashed with gang members who tried to hijack a vendor's truck in Delmas 32. During the assault of the truck, the criminals beat up the driver (health state unknown) and stole his phone. One of the gang members who was identified as a police officer was arrested. Casualties unknown.

On 17 January 2024, in Tabarre - Chateau Blond, Ouest, an unknown number of people were kidnapped near the OAVCT. Armed individuals were also seen in the area. The report indicates that the victims might have been taken to the Truitier area in Carrefour. Although there is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators of the kidnapping, latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, armed gang members killed a woman in Delmas 24 (Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28 neighborhood). Also, gunshots were heard in Delmas 19 and 32, and Carrefour Aeroport. There is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators of the gunshots. 1 fatality.

On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, an anti-government barricade was registered in Pelerin 7. Reports also indicate that people were throwing stones in the area as well as in Pelerin 5. Another report indicates burning tires were erected in front of the Peace Court of Petionville (Bois Greffin neighborhood). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 9 January 2024, in Petion Ville - Gerardeau, Ouest, two individuals accused of being members of the 400 Mawozo Gang were killed and their burned bodies were found in the area of Moulin Sable (Gerardeau neighborhood). The residents have expressed that they are willing to take measures to prevent gangs from re-taking control over the area which has been pretty calm. According to the source the area is controlled by the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang). 2 fatalities.

On 24 January 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 65, Ouest, an unknown number of armed individuals shot above the head of an NGO aid worker near Delmas 65, although he escaped unharmed. The perpetrators stole his backpack with a laptop and cash. There were no casualties.

On 5 February 2024, in Tabarre - Chateau Blond, Ouest, members of the Vitelhomme gang (Kraze Barye Gang) entered the government office for vehicles assurance (OAVCT), located on Mais Gate Avenue (Chateau Blond neighbourhood). They looted the place and kidnapped at least one employee from the premises. The OAVCT union representative described how the kidnappers were requesting a 300 000$ ransom for the employee. The abductee's whereabouts are unknown.

On 3 March 2024, in Delmas - Hatt Thomas, Ouest, overnight, unidentified armed individuals stormed the Delmas 33 police station (Hatt Thomas neighborhood), forcing six policemen who were inside to abandon the building. 21 arrested individuals managed to escape. Casualties unknown.

source: El Nacional (Dominican Republic); Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 7 March 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 75, Ouest, several dozens of citizens, called by the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party, held a demonstration along the Delmas Road demanding the departure of Prime Minister Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires in different areas. Police forces intervened using tear gas near the Canada Embassy (Delmas 75 neighborhood). Another report also indicates that gunshots were fired in the area as well as in Delmas 3 (in Delmas 5 neighbourhood).

On 7 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Juvenat, Ouest, citizens held a demonstration in the Juvenat neighbourhood demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up roadblocks. A group of motorcycle drivers gathered to ask for the barricade to be removed. Another demonstration took place in Centre Ville (Ouest) (coded separately).

On 11 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Academie, Ouest, gang members opened fire on the National Police Academy. The shooting took place as the graduation ceremony of the 33rd police promotion was being held at the Academy. Casualties unknown.

On 13 March 2024, around Petion Ville - Centre Ville (Ouest), Ouest, a small group of people protested by marching from Aubrand Street (Sainte Therese neighbourhood), through Darguin Street, to Faubert and Villate streets (Centre Ville (Ouest) neighborhood). Some people also marched towards Boyer Square (Centre Ville (Nord) neighbourhood, coded separately). There is no information on the motives of the protest.

On 15 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Academie, Ouest, police forces clashed with unidentified armed men, answering an attack against the National Police Academy (Academie neighbourhood). Casualties unknown.

On 23 March 2024, in Delmas - Maguana, Ouest, a person was killed in Delmas 31 (Maguana neighborhood) and gunshots were heard in Delmas 19, as well as in Delmas 3 (Delmas 5 neighborhood) and near Village Solidarite. Though the perpetrators remain unknown, both events happened amidst gang violence taking place in the area. 1 fatality.

On 6 March 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, police and military forces clashed with armed group members in Delmas 28. During clashes, the armed individuals set fire to several vehicles. Casualties unknown.
On 29 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Juvenat, Ouest, people protested in Juvenat. There is no information on the circumstances or motives of the protest.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 22 January 2024, in Tabarre - Chateau Blond, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals kidnapped a police officer near the US Embassy (Chateau Blond neighbourhood). He was released under unclarified circumstances.

Around 29 April 2024 (week of), in Tabarre - Chateau Blond, Ouest, members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) attacked a residential neighbourhood near the US Embassy (in Chateau Blond neighbourhood), forcing more than 150 civilians to flee their homes. According to a witness, a man was shot and killed. 1 fatality.

On 14 May 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, the Belair Gang attacked residents in the Delmas 24 area (located in the Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28 neighbourhood) and clashed with police forces, who intervened and expelled the criminals from the area. Several civilians and several gang members were killed. Houses were set on fire. Gunshots were also heard in Delmas 31 road. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 3 May 2024, Petion Ville - Centre Ville (Sud), Ouest, armed men on a motorcycle killed a man near Saint Pierre Square (Centre Ville (Sud) neighborhood) (drive-by). There is no information on the motives of the attack. 1 fatality.

source: MetroNome; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 11 May 2024, in Gressier - Sous Fort, members of the 103 Zombies Gang attacked the population, set fire to residents' houses, and looted the city hall facilities (in Sous Fort neighbourhood). Several official vehicles were burned. On the same day, unidentified gang members set fire to the Gressier Civil Protection Office. They also attacked the police station while trying to take over the area (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 30 May 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they attacked residents and set fire to houses in Delmas 24 (Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28 neighbourhood). Gunshots were heard for several hours. According to witnesses, several gang members were killed and some residents were injured. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 4 June 2024, in Petion Ville - Centre Ville (Sud), Ouest, the police clashed with gang members around Rue Oge (Centre Ville (Sud) neighborhood) and Rue Geffrard (Morne Hercule neighborhood, coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 20 July 2024, in Gressier - Sous Fort, Ouest, for a third consecutive day, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members in the commune. Between 20 and 21 July, police forces killed around 10 gang members as they carried out anti-gang operations in La Conille area (Sous Fort neighbourhood). More than 40 gangsters were killed in Gressier since a state of emergency was declared on 17 July (coded separately). At least 10 fatalities split across two events.

On 22 July 2024, in Gressier - Sous Fort, Ouest, for a fifth consecutive day, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members in the commune. Clashes took place in La Conille area (Sous Fort neighbourhood) as a hundred gang members had disembarked from a yacht to support other gangsters who had been targeting the commune over the weekend (coded separately). Between 18 and 25 July, several dozen gangsters were killed by police forces. Around ten of them were killed between 20 and 21 July in the La Conille area and in total, more than 40 were killed since a state of emergency was declared on 17 July (coded separately). At least 30 fatalities split over six events.

On 16 August 2024, Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, in the morning, gunshots were heard in the Delmas 24 (Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28) likely to be part of armed clashes between the Viv Ansanm Gang and police forces, who clashed in the neighbourhood the day prior (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 11 August 2024, in Petion Ville - Bois Greffin, Ouest, suspected members of the Kraze Barye (Vitelhomme) Gang carried out attacks (methods unknown) in different areas, such as Doko, Greffin, and near Fort Jacques (coded separately), among others. There are no further information on the circumstances of the attacks. Casualties unknown.

On 12 August 2024, in Petion Ville - Bois Greffin, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, suspected members of the Kraze Barye (Vitelhomme) Gang carried out attacks (methods unknown) in different areas, such as Doko, Greffin, and near Fort Jacques (coded separately), among others. There are no further information on the circumstances of the attacks. Casualties unknown.

On 9 August 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, clashes and attacks were registered in Delmas 24 (Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28 neighborhood). There is no information on the circumstances or actors involved of the confrontations. Casualties unknown.

On 14 August 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, armed gang members (likely to be affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang as members of this gang attacked the same area the day after) attacked Delmas 24 (Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28 neighbourhood). Casualties unknown.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 12 May 2024, in Gressier - Sous Fort, Ouest, armed gang members killed a 65-year-old man in the Cabrache area (a.k.a. Kabrach), in the Sous Fort neighbourhood. In the Boko neighbourhood, a woman was also killed by the gang members (coded separately). 1 fatality.

On 18 January 2024, in Cite Soleil - Brooklyn, Ouest, clashes were registered in Boston (coded separately), Brooklyn, and Jeremie Wharf (coded separately). There is no information on the circumstances of the clashes. Casualties unknown.

On 18 January 2024, in Cite Soleil - Waaf Jeremie, Ouest, clashes were registered in Boston (coded separately), Brooklyn (coded separately), and Jeremie Wharf. There is no information on the circumstances of the clashes. Casualties unknown.

On 24 January 2024, in Petion Ville - Juvenat, Ouest, people protested near the courthouse, in Sainte Therese (coded separately), and Juvenat. A group of people was also seen gathering around Boyer Square (coded separately). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the protest, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). The report indicates that the police was present, but no specific activity was reported.

On 18 January 2024, in Petion Ville - Bois Greffin, burning tires were erected in front of the Peace Court of Petionville (Bois Greffin neighborhood), while an anti-government barricade was registered in Pelerin 7. Reports also indicate that people were throwing stones in the area as well as in Pelerin 5 (coded separately). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 19 January 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 75, Ouest, an anti-government demonstration took place in Delmas 47 (Delmas 41 neighborhood, coded separately), and 75. The demonstrators set up barricades with burning tires. Another report indicates that the police was present, but no specific activity was reported. Another report indicates that barricades were erected with burning tires in Delmas 60 (coded separately). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the demonstration, and the barricades or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Centre Ville (Ouest), Ouest, citizens burned tires during a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry, in Faubert and Villate streets, while a rara group was also registered between Faubert and Rigaud streets. Another demonstration also took place in demonstration in the Juvenat neighbourhood (coded separately).

On 13 March 2024, around Petion Ville - Centre Ville (Nord), Ouest, a small group of people protested by marching from Aubrand Street (Sainte Therese neighbourhood), through Darguin Street, to Faubert and Villate streets (Centre Ville (Ouest) neighborhood, coded separately). Some people also marched towards Boyer Square (Centre Ville (Nord) neighbourhood). There is no information on the motives of the protest.

On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, an anti-government barricade was registered in Pelerin 7. Reports also indicate that people were throwing stones in the area as well as in Pelerin 5. Another report indicates burning tires were erected in front of the Peace Court of Petionville (Bois Greffin neighborhood). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 24 January 2024, in Petion Ville - Centre Ville (Nord), Ouest, people protested near the courthouse, in Sainte Therese, and Juvenat (coded separately). A group of people was also seen gathering around Boyer Square (Centre Ville (Nord) neighborhood) calling for Prime Minister Ariel Henry's resignation. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the protest, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). The report indicates that the police was present, but no specific activity was reported.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 5 April 2024, in Carrefour - Arcachon/Mon-Repos, Ouest, in the morning, an unknown number of individuals kidnapped a 45-year-old woman in Mon Repos area and took her to the so called 'Abattoir de Mariani' zone. She was raped and beaten up repeatedly before being released. There were no fatalities.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 10 May 2024, in Carrefour - Mariani, Ouest, armed gang members raped a 29-year-old woman in the Mariani neighbourhood. She was intercepted and attacked as she was on her way to the Lambi area.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 10 May 2024, in Gressier - Sous Fort, Ouest, armed members of the 103 Zombies Gang raped a 30-year-old vendor woman who had her business establishment next to the Gressier city hall, in the Sous Fort neighbourhood. This was described as a collective rape that happened during other gang actions in Gressier on the same day (coded separately).

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 12 May 2024, in Gressier - Santo, Ouest, three gang members raped a 32-year-old woman at her home, in Santo 12, and in front of her mother. This event happened after other gang actions in Gressier on 10 May (coded separately).

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 13 May 2024, in Gressier - Boko, Ouest, unidentified armed group members killed a 51-year-old woman at a house near the Gressier Market, in the Boko neighbourhood. The body was found by the victim's niece, who was raped and beaten up by the armed group members at the property. This event happened after other gang actions in Gressier on 10 May (coded separately). 1 fatality.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 14 May 2024, in Merger, Ouest, armed gang members killed a 60-year-old man (methods unknown). The corpse of the victim was not recovered. 1 fatality.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 15 May 2024, in Merger, Ouest, armed members of the 103 Zombies Gang shot and killed a man as he rode a motorcycle along the Saint Tilus street. The criminals set fire to the victim's body and vehicle. The cousin of the deceased witnessed the attack. 1 fatality.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 20 May 2024, in Gressier - Cite Gressier, Ouest, overnight, armed gang members killed a 64-year-old man with reduced mobility at his home and set fire to the property, located in Kay Mason area (near the Gressier police station). The victim's niece managed to escape. 1 fatality.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Around 15 June 2024 (month of), in Gressier - Cite Gressier, Ouest, the 103 Zombies Gang kidnapped four Madan Sara (labor group) trader women near the Gressier police station. They were held at a house for an unspecified period before being released. The gang members stole their goods.

Around 19 August 2024 (between 19 - 20 August), in Moron, Grande-Anse, police forces supported by members of the population affiliated to a local self-defence group killed at least seven gang members, including the leader of the Mostly Lindor Gang, during an anti-gang operation in the Moron, Chambellan, and Anse-d'Hainault communes. Several houses used as shelters by the gang members were set on fire. At least 7 fatalities split across three events.

On 28 August 2024, in Limonade, Nord, students from the Henry Campus of the State University of Haiti (UEH) took to the streets to denounce the bad governance of their university, and the lack of elections for a new governing council, despite their mandate having expired in 2022. The students also denounced the dilapidated conditions of the university and its work spaces. The protestors also demanded an end to the ongoing insecurity in Gonaives.
On 28 August 2024, in Delmas - Cite Numero Un, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in Delmas 18. Casualties unknown.
On 29 August 2024, in Cite Soleil - Hasco/Village Democratie, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members near the Varreux oil terminal. Casualties unknown.

On 29 August 2024, in Tabarre - Chateau Blond, Ouest, a truck driver was shot and killed after he heard gunshots and tried to run away. Gunshots were heard near the Third Party Vehicle Insurance Office (OAVCT) (Chateau Blond neighborhood). There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots. 1 fatality.

Around 1 September 2024 (weekend of), in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) attacked residents in Pernier. According to witnesses, the gang members beat up and violently dragged some civilians from their homes. Casualties unknown.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 15 January 2024, in Delmas - Carrefour Pean, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, members of the Belair Gang clashed with rival gang members in the Solino (coded separately) and Carrefour Pean (Delmas - Carrefour Pean) neighborhoods. During clashes, Belair gangsters set fire to several houses. Some residents fled and took refuge elsewhere. The National Human Rights Defense Network's director claimed that at least 20 people were killed between 14 and 18 January as a result of gang clashes in Port-au-Prince. The Organization of Hearts for Change for Deprived Children (OCCED'H) stated that at least 7 children were shot and injured in the same period. At least 7 injured split across ten events. At least 20 fatalities split across ten events, 2 fatalities coded here.
Other: On 19 January 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, Marassa Crossroad was blocked. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.
Other: On 20 January 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, trucks were used to block the Marassa Crossroad. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.

Other: On 26 January 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Marass crossroad. Although there is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators of the gunshots, another report indicates that the police was present and order was restored in the area.
Other: On 6 February 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, vehicles were used to set up roadblocks in Marassa Crossroad. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.
Other: On 13 March 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Carrefour Marassa. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 14 March 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Carrefour Marassa. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 15 March 2024, near Marassa, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Pont de Tabarre/Marassa. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 18 March 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, roadblocks were set up which affected transportation from Carrefour Shada and Marassa. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.

Other: On 3 April 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, tires and vehicles were used to set up roadblocks in Carrefour Marassa. The report indicates that the police was present, but not activity was mentioned. The area was cleared shortly after. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.
Other: On 3 July 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, gunshots were heard. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Around 20 August 2024 (as reported), in Quartier de Camp-Louis, Nord, members of rival gangs clashed in Lafon et Pont Taureau areas, leaving one person dead after being injured with a bladed weapon. 1 fatality.
Other: On 3 September 2024, in Cange, Centre, a roadblock was set up on the Route Nationale #3. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.
On 4 September 2024, in Beaumont, Grande-Anse, members of the population killed seven gang members. There is no information on the circumstances of the event. 7 fatalities.
On 4 September 2024, overnight, in Quartier de Camp-Louis, Nord, the police carried out an operation during which they killed two gang members, arrested three, and seized weapons. 2 fatalities.

On 5 September 2024, in Gressier - Nan Reserve, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members in several areas, such as La Colline, Bazelais, and Zone 12. The confrontations forced residents to abandon their homes while gunshots were heard throughout the day. An unknown number of gang members were killed. Unknown casualties coded as 3.

On 6 September 2024, near Saint-Mesmin, Ouest, residents lynched two moto-taxi drivers in an unknown area of the Grande Riviere section. The drivers were suspected of being gang informants. 2 fatalities.

On 12 September 2024, in Delmas - Pele Simon, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, Nan Boston and Simon-Pele gang members clashed. The clashes started the previous day as a result of a football match where one of the two teams from Boston and Pele Simon refused to admit they lost (coded separately). Residents have had to flee their homes. At least 20 people, the majority suspected to be members of the Simon Pele gang were killed during clashes recorded from 11 to 13 September. At least 20 fatalities split into five clashes recorded by ACLED between 11 and 13 September in Simon Pele and Village Solidarite neighborhoods.

On 12 September 2024, in Delmas - Village Solidarite, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, Nan Boston and Simon-Pele gang members clashed. The clashes started the previous day as a result of a football match where one of the two teams from Boston and Pele Simon refused to admit they lost (coded separately). Residents have had to flee their homes. At least 20 people, the majority suspected to be members of the Simon Pele gang were killed during clashes recorded from 11 to 13 September. At least 20 fatalities split into five clashes recorded by ACLED between 11 and 13 September in Simon Pele and Village Solidarite neighborhoods, 4 fatalities coded here.

On 13 September 2024, between Delmas - Pele Simon and Delmas - Village Solidarite, Ouest, for the third consecutive day, Nan Boston and Simon-Pele gang members clashed. The clashes started on 11 September as a result of a football match where one of the two teams from Boston and Pele Simon refused to admit they lost (coded separately). Residents have had to flee their homes. At least 20 people, the majority suspected to be members of the Simon Pele gang were killed during clashes recorded from 11 to 13 September. At least 20 fatalities split into five clashes recorded by ACLED between 11 and 13 September in Simon Pele and Village Solidarite neighborhoods, 4 fatalities coded here.

On 13 September 2024, in Delmas - Village Solidarite, Ouest, for the third consecutive day, Nan Boston and Simon-Pele gang members clashed. The clashes started on 11 September as a result of a football match where one of the two teams from Boston and Pele Simon refused to admit they lost (coded separately). Residents have had to flee their homes. At least 20 people, the majority suspected to be members of the Simon Pele gang were killed during clashes recorded from 11 to 13 September. At least 20 fatalities split into five clashes recorded by ACLED between 11 and 13 September in Simon Pele and Village Solidarite neighborhoods, 4 fatalities coded here.

On 21 January 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, overnight, residents set fire to a set of pre-carnival stands. The arson attack was described as a symbolic action against the government's plans to celebrate carnival festivities while the country is passing through a political and security crisis.

On 17 February 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, thousands of citizens, called by the Platform Pitit Desalin Party (PPD) and the Committed to Development Party (EDE), held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Protesters claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti in January 2024).

On 8 February 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, people held a demonstration and erected barricades of burning tires in Alternative Crossroad in the downtown area. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the barricades, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 12 September 2024, in the Mirebalais commune, Centre, residents set up barricades across the road in an area known as 'Mon Wouj' using two cars to demand that the electricity company provides them with electricity service.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 11 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, residents, political leaders, members of civil society organizations, and taxi drivers' unions held a protest with banners demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Protesters tried to vandalized the airport terminal, although no destructive behavior was mentioned. Protesters claimed to support Guy Philippe, a former convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti.

source: Haiti Press Network; Metropole; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: Other: On 15 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, in the morning, gunshots were heard in the Mon Repos and Arcachon neighborhoods. The perpetrators were not clarified, although it happened as the former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord, Guy Philippe, had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti hours earlier (coded separately). Gunshots were also heard in areas such as La Saline, Aviation Crossroad, and Jeremie Wharf (coded separately). The report indicates that barricades were registered and armed individuals seen, but there are no specifics on the circumstances.

Other: On 2 January 2024, near Port-au-Prince - Gressier, a container was used to set up a roadblock on the Route Nationale #2 in the Le Lambi area. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

On 20 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members and gunshots were heard in Bizoton, Lamentin, and Diquini neighborhoods. The gangsters were described as allies of the Ti Bwa Gang. Some residents fled their homes. Casualties unknown.

On 21 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, police forces clashed with gang members and gunshots were heard in Bizoton, Lamentin, and Diquini neighborhoods. The gangsters were described as allies of the Ti Bwa Gang. Some residents fled their homes. Casualties unknown.
Other: On 4 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard near the U.S. embassy. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 16 January 2024, in the Cite Soleil commune, Ouest, several tens of armed men wearing balaclavas and t-shirts from the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) blocked the National Road 9, near Carrefour Fouji (a.k.a. Fougy). This was likely part of BSAP mobilizations taking place on that day (coded separately) to demand the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry.

source: Haiti Press Network; Metropole; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: Other: On 15 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in areas such as Aviation Crossroad, and Jeremie Wharf. The report indicates that barricades were registered and armed individuals seen, but there are no specifics on the circumstances. Gunshots were also hear in La Saline (coded separately).
Other: On 15 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 6. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 16 January 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, gunshots were heard in Mombin Lataille. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard on Freres Road. There is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators of the gunshots.
Other: On 15 January 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, burning tires were registered downtown on 16 and 17A streets. There is no information on the motivation for the roadblock.

Other: On 22 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, burning tires were erected at the intersection of Delmas 19 and Airport Road, as well as Delmas 73 (Delmas 75 neighborhood). There is no information on the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up.

Other: On 25 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, burning tires were registered in Delmas 42-57 (Delmas 65 neighborhood). There is no information on the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up.

Other: On 31 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, the Route Nationale #1 was blocked at Croix des Missions. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

On 6 February 2024, Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, unidentified armed individuals opened fire on the vehicle where the leader of the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party was travelling in. He escaped unharmed, although his driver was shot and injured. This happened as an anti-government mobilization called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti) was being held in the commune. 1 injured.

Other: On 19 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, gunshots were registered on the Rail Road. A lot of burning tires were also registered in the area. There is no information on the circumstances of the gunshots or barricades.

Non-violent activity: On 19 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, the Route Nationale #1 was blocked around Vincent Crossroad, Damiens, and Drouillard. Armed men were registered in the area, but no specific activity was reported. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock.

On 8 February 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, people held a demonstration and roadblocks were set in the downtown area and in the Sainte-Philomene neighborhood. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

notes: Property destruction: On 1 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, armed gang members set fire to the Central Office of the Vehicle Insurance Office Against Third Parties (OAVCT), a public institution, located in the intersection between Mais Gate Avenue and 15 October Boulevard (Tapage). Another version stated that the arsonists were armed members of the population. Overnight, gang members vandalized the MSC Plus company offices for the second time since 1 March (HT Monquette neighbourhood). They also looted the Sun Auto company offices. Looting scenes against this company persisted until 3 March.

notes: Looting: On 15 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, armed gang members looted the offices of the El Salvador consulate, in 1er Cite Saint Martin neighbourhood. They stole several pieces of equipment from the premises. A Toyota car sales agency in Delmas A-1 and the Kay Dupuy business, in Delmas 12, were looted (Cite Numero Un neighbourhood).

On 15 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members in Bas Delmas. Some gangsters were killed, although there is no information on a specific number. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 11 March 2024, in Carrefour - Mahothiere, Ouest, barricades of burning tires were erected in front of the General Tax Department (DGI) office (near Carrefour - Mahothiere). It was later confirmed that these barricades were erected by rioters who were demanding the resignation of Prime Minister Ariel Henry.

Non-violent activity: On 5 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, unidentified gangs blocked the Route Nationale #1 near Carrefour Vincent (Sarthe neighborhood). Although the report indicates that there were possible threats against businesses in Sarthe and Drouillard, the circumstances and motives of the blockade are unclear.

On 17 January 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires. They claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

Other: On 9 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Sarthe, Damiens, Blanchard, and Wharf Jeremie. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots, although this was likely to be part of armed clashes between rival gang members.

On 3 March 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, several opposition militants of the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party held a demonstration in the vicinity of the Cap-Haitien International Airport demanding that the flight of Prime Minister Ariel Henry not be hosted. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires in several neighborhoods.

source: Haiti Progres; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 9 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, members of a gang operating in Maceline (Bizoton neighbourhood) lynched a voodoo priest inside his residence and killed his minor daughter as she tried to intervene and prevent her father's death. 2 fatalities.

source: Haiti Progres; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 12 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, armed civilians and members of a communal militia from the 'Do Karyann' community burned to death a former local elected official from the Carrefour 10th municipal section whom they accused of being a gang informant. The attack took place after suspected messages were found on his phone. The attack was described as a case of vigilante justice. 1 fatality.

Other: On 16 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard along the National Road 1 at the height of the Drouillard neighbourhood. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 13 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Pele Simon. Another report indicates that armed men were seen in the area. Gunshots were also heard in Carrefour Drouillard, where armed men as well as the police were seen. A third report indicated that gunshots were heard in Carrefour Aeroport, where burning tires were also set up. There is no information on the circumstances of the gunshots or who set up the barricades.
Other: On 15 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Butte Boyer. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
