Another report indicates that there were also unspecified truck hijacking attempts and the police was present. Casualties unknown.

On 21 April 2024, in Petion Ville - Meyotte, Ouest, in the morning, members of the Kraze Barye gang attacked the neighborhood and killed one person. The police forces intervened, shot and killed at least five members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) and injured several others. At least 6 fatalities, several injured.
Other: On 17 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Waaf Jeremie. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
On 17 April 2024, in Carrefour - Waney Bijou, Ouest, gang members attacked residents of the Waney 93, injuring several people. Gunshots were also heard in the Brochette neighborhood. Several injured.
Other: On 17 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, gunshots were heard in Carrefour Aeroport and near Village Solidarite. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
On 16 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, members of the Bwa Kale Movement militia killed 10 gang members from Martissant. 10 fatalities.
Other: On 22 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Damiens. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Non-violent activity: On 23 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, gang members blocked access to the Varreux terminal premises (Village Democracie neighborhood) and to the Caribbean Port Services (Wharf de la Saline neighborhood). The roadblocks were erected between Station Gonaives (Village Democratie neighborhood) and Chancerelles. The report also indicates that unspecified operations were being carried out at the location.
Other: On 25 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Drouillard. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

notes: Looting: Around 15 March 2024 (month of), in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, members of the Delmas 6 Gang and the Base Nan Tokyo Gang looted and vandalized at least seven business establishments in Bas Delmas. The event happened amidst gang violence taking place in the area.

On 13 May 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, in the morning, agents of the Departmental Service of the Judicial Police (SDPJ) held a protest outside the Cap-Haitien prosecutor's office demanding the departure of the dean of the court. Protesters claimed that the dean would free the killer of a SDPJ agent, among other issues.

Around 23 May 2024 (week of), in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, members of the Living-Together gang-led initiative (a.k.a. Viv Ansanm Gang) attacked the Carrefour police station. Casualties unknown.
On 14 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, unidentified gang members attacked the population by breaking into people's homes and setting fire to their houses. Casualties unknown.

On 25 June 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, three armed civilians (described as police officers by one source) entered a police station in the aim of releasing two individuals who had been arrested moments before. Within the station, the three rioters assaulted an unknown number of on-duty officers, and robbed them. The rioters were eventually arrested. Their arms were seized.

notes: On 7 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, a known political activist was arrested and imprisoned at the Delmas civil prison. He had previously escaped from prison. He was released from prison on 13 August 2024 in unspecified circumstances.

On 18 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members in the commune. Between 18 and 25 July, several dozen gangsters were killed by police forces. Around ten of them were killed between 20 and 21 July in the La Conille area and in total, more than 40 were killed since a state of emergency was declared on 17 July (coded separately). At least 30 fatalities split over six events.

On 19 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members in the commune. Between 18 and 25 July, several dozen gangsters were killed by police forces. Around ten of them were killed between 20 and 21 July in the La Conille area and in total, more than 40 were killed since a state of emergency was declared on 17 July (coded separately). At least 30 fatalities split over six events.

On 23 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, for a sixth consecutive day, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members in the commune. Between 18 and 25 July, several dozen gangsters were killed by police forces. Around ten of them were killed between 20 and 21 July in the La Conille area and in total, more than 40 were killed since a state of emergency was declared on 17 July (coded separately). At least 30 fatalities split over six events.

On 24 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, for a seventh consecutive day, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members in the commune. Between 18 and 25 July, several dozen gangsters were killed by police forces. Around ten of them were killed between 20 and 21 July in the La Conille area and in total, more than 40 were killed since a state of emergency was declared on 17 July (coded separately). At least 30 fatalities split over six events.

On 25 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, for a eighth consecutive day, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members in the commune. Around ten of them were killed between 20 and 21 July in the La Conille area and in total, more than 40 were killed since a state of emergency was declared on 17 July (coded separately). Other: On 5 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 40B. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

notes: On 6 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, armed gang members attacked residential areas along the Mariani 2 Avenue. During the gang offensive, a woman was killed as the criminals set fire to her home. A 50-year-old man was taken away by the gang members. An elderly man who tried to flee his home, among other residents, went missing. 1 fatality.
Other: On 11 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Simon Pele. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

notes: Property destruction: Around 22 March 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, gang members set fire to residents' houses (likely empty) in Sapotille.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 16 April 2024, near Gressier (coded to Port-au-Prince - Gressier), Ouest, armed gang members intercepted a public transport bus and forced all the passengers to exit the vehicle. All the female passengers were raped. Four gang members killed one of the women after raping her. 1 fatality.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Property destruction: On 3 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, armed gang members set fire to a resident's house (likely empty) and stole a motorcycle that was parked within the property, in an area known as 'Melier'.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 10 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, gang members also killed a blind man and raped her two nieces in Quatre Gendarmes area. Also, an armed individual raped a 34-year old woman at her home. She got pregnant. These events happened amidst clashes between the Grand-Ravine Gang and police forces in the vicinity of the Cite Gressier police station (coded separately). 1 fatality.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 10 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, gang members killed a 25-year-old man in Cite FLN. This happened amidst clashes between the Grand-Ravine Gang and police forces in the vicinity of the Cite Gressier police station (coded separately). 1 fatality.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Looting: On 11 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, armed gang members looted a house and a business establishment belonging to the same man, in Colombier 9 (near Gressier - Cite Gressier). A vehicle was stolen.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 15 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, overnight, armed group members killed a man at a house and set fire to his body, in Ti Sitron area. A relative who witnessed the attack managed to escape. 1 fatality.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 24 June 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, overnight, gang members raped a 17-year-old girl in an area known as 'Maracania'.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Looting: On 22 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, armed gang members stole a transport vehicle and forced the driver to give them the truck's registration card and the key before allowing him to leave.

Other: On 26 August 2024, overnight, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard until four in the morning of the following day in Pelerin 9. A body was also lying on the floor, but it is unclear if the death is related to the gunshots heard. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 31 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Vivy Mitchell as armed individuals tried to enter the area.
Other: On 3 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, burning tires were erected in Delmas 33. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.

Other: On 6 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, gunshots were heard in La Colline (Nan Reserve neighborhood). There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 6 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, gang members shot and killed a truck driver. The body was partially burned and missing the right arm when retrieved by the driver's parents. 1 fatality.

Other: On 10 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, a roadblock was set up on the Route 9 in Carrefour Fougy of Duviviers. There is no information on the motives of the roadblock or who set it up.

Other: On 7 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Laboule 12. The police was on site, but no specific action was mentioned. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 13 September 2024, in Delmas - Maguana, Ouest, armed men kidnapped a man in front of his home. He was taken away in a vehicle. There is no information on the perpetrators of the abduction, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

On 13 September 2024, between Petion Ville - Pelerin and Petion Ville - Pelerin 2, Ouest, two people were abducted from a vehicle. There is no information on the perpetrators or circumstances of the abduction, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

Other: On 17 September 2024, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Terre Noire and Barriere Fer (near Blanchard and Duviviers neighborhoods). There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 17 September 2024, in Port-Salut, Sud, a roadblock was set up using rocks and a truck. There is no information on the motives for the roadblock or who set it up.
On 20 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, people marched from Delmas 40 towards Petion Ville. There is no information on the motives of the demonstration.

On 27 September 2024, in the commune of Mirebalais, Centre, the police clashed with gang members to repel them from different localities of Mirebalais and Saut-d'Eau (coded separately) such as Ka Micho, Ka Michel, Ka Ti Ben and Grosse Pierre among others . Casualties unknown.

On 17 September 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 19/Joseph Janvier, Ouest, armed individuals got off a motorcycle and kidnapped a father and his son as he was opening the gate of his home to drive in. The kidnappers took off with them in the father's car. There is no information on the perpetrators or circumstances of the abduction, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

On 20 September 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 75, Ouest, people demonstrated and erected burning tires on the road. Burning tires were also registered in Delmas 48 across the Delmas highway (likely part of the same event since both places are close by). There is no information on the motives of the demonstration.
Other: On 16 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Turgeau. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 17 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Vincent Crossroad. The Route Nationale #1 was also blocked in that area and Drouillard Crossroad, where armed individuals were seen on house roofs. There is no information about the circumstances of the blockade or the gunshots.

On 29 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They set up barricades of burning tires on Martin Luther King Avenue, among others. Commercial and school activities were paralyzed. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by organizations from the political opposition (coded separately).

Other: On 30 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a roadblock was registered in Dalencourt road between Canape-Vert and Bourdon. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres
notes: Strikes: On 5 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the Anti-Corruption Union Brigade (BSAC) called on two days of nationwide general strike (until 6 February) to demand that national authorities provide solutions to the security crisis in Haiti. As a consequence, school activities were suspended in several locations across Haiti as anti-government mobilizations continued on 5 February. This was the second strike called by the BSAC after the one called on 29 January (coded separately).

Other: Around 3 February 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, several political actors and allies of former President, Jovenel Moise, created the Democratic Resistance Platform (RED) as a new political structure engaged to demand justice and compensation for the victims of violence in Haiti. The platform is integrated by the Committed to Development Party (EDE), the Haitians for Haiti party, and the National Emergency Movement (MOUN), among others.
Other: On 22 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Grand Rue downtown and Lalue. There is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators of the gunshots.

On 12 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, residents and gang members held a demonstration over unspecified claims a day after Prime Minister, Ariel Henry, announced his resignation and that of his government (coded separately). During the demonstration, barricades of burning tires were set up and a drugstore was set on fire.
On 7 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members set fire to a store in the down town. Casualties unknown.

notes: On 14 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang kidnapped a US citizen (described as a well-known youtuber) and a Haitian man. The abduction took place as the US citizen flew to Port-au-Prince to interview the G-9 Gang leader. The abductors demanded a ransom of 600,000 USD for their release. On 30 March, the US youtuber and the Haitian man were released after 40,000 dollars were paid.

source: Haiti Libre; Haiti Progres; Loop News Haiti; Vant Bef Info
notes: On 28 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, armed gang members killed the accountant of the Office of the Secretary of State for Literacy as they opened fire on the vehicle he was travelling in with his wife, on the Capois street. There is no information on the wife's health state. The perpetrators were described as affiliates of the Living Together gang-led coalition (aka Viv Ansanm gang). 1 fatality.

source: Trinidad and Tobago Guardian; Vi Free Press
notes: On 2 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a handful of citizens held a protest over the political situation in Haiti. No further information was mentioned.

The barricades were set up as the bodies of three young men were found in Nazon (coded separately).

Other: On 3 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard near the Salomon market (Bas Peu de Choses neighborhood), as well as other areas of downtown. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Non-violent activity: On 14 January 2024, in the arrondissement of Port-au-Prince, Ouest, armed gang members used vehicles to block the Aviation Road. There is no information on the motives for the roadblocks.

Around 21 January 2024 (weekend of), in the arrondissement of Port-au-Prince, Ouest, residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

Security measures: On 25 September 2024, in Mirebalais, Centre, a curfew was imposed to reestablish order in the area starting on 25 September 2024 from 8pm to 6am. There is no information on when the curfew will end.

On 1 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, citizens held a march towards the Champs-de-Mars Avenue, next to the National Palace, against Prime Minister, Ariel Henry, and calling for his departure. Police forces intervened using tear gas. No one was arrested or injured. The mobilization was held on the occasion of the 220th anniversary of the political independence of Haiti. There were reports of barricades with burning tires on the road in Christophe Avenue and Saint Geraud bridge.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 15 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, members of the Belair Gang clashed with rival gang members in the Solino and Carrefour Pean neighborhoods (coded separately). During clashes, Belair gangsters set fire to several houses. Some residents fled and took refuge elsewhere. The National Human Rights Defense Network's director claimed that at least 20 people were killed between 14 and 18 January as a result of gang clashes in Port-au-Prince. The Organization of Hearts for Change for Deprived Children (OCCED'H) stated that at least 7 children were shot and injured in the same period. At least 7 injured split across ten events. At least 20 fatalities split across ten events, 2 fatalities coded here.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 17 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, for the fourth consecutive day, members of the Belair Gang attacked the Solino neighborhood as they clashed with rival gang members. The National Human Rights Defense Network's director claimed that at least 20 people were killed between 14 and 18 January as a result of gang clashes in Port-au-Prince. The Organization of Hearts for Change for Deprived Children (OCCED'H) stated that at least 7 children were shot and injured in the same period. At least 7 injured split across ten events. At least 20 fatalities split across ten events, 2 fatalities coded here.
On 12 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, armed individuals clashed with soldiers in Champ-de-Mars. There is no information on the circumstances of the clash. Casualties unknown.

Around 22 January 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a person was killed (methods unknown) and his body was found calcined and abandoned on the street at the height of the Tag Market, in Canape-Vert neighborhood. Perpetrators and motivation unknown. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network
notes: On 31 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, rival gang members engaged in armed clashes in several neighborhoods, including Lalue area. During clashes, a stray bullet entered the premises of the Sainte Rose de Lima school, although no one was injured. The institution suspended its activity after this. Casualties unknown.

On 22 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, people protested by marching towards Turgeau. Roadblocks were set up in Oswald Durand Street and Champ de Mars. Although there is no information on the motives of the protest, or the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 19 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bourdon, Ouest, there was an anti-government demonstration in which tires were burned in Bourdon and Canape Vert (coded separately). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 25 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Turgeau, Ouest, armed individuals traveling in a vehicle shot and killed a man in Faustin 1er Street (drive-by) in Turgeau neighbourhood. There is no information on the motives of the attack. 1 fatality.

Around 21 February 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Portail Leogane/Cite Louverture, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals abducted several transport drivers and passengers in Portail Leogane sector. There is no information on the perpetrators, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. Their whereabouts are unknown.

On 8 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, clashes were registered in the area. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the clashes. Also, clashes took place in Fort National and Sans Fil Street (both coded separately), while bags and empty vehicles were used to erect barricades on Canape-Vert road. Barricades were also registered in Bois Verna near Berne street. There is no information on the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up. Casualties unknown.

On 21 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, members of the Belair Gang shot and killed two civilians and injured several others as they attacked residents in the Fort National neighbourhood. This was part of a gang offensive aiming at taking control of the neighbourhood. 2 fatalities, several injured.

On 23 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, members of the Grand-Ravine Gang set fire to several civilian properties on Cameau street (Bas Peu de Choses neighbourhood). Some residents fled their homes. Casualties unknown.

source: Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 1 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, armed gang members kidnapped a Catholic priest at the Saint Anne parish (Morne a Tuf). He was released later that same day. It was not clarified if a ransom was paid for the release.

On 7 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, people gathered to protest in Champs de Mars. Although this was a result of a call for mobilization, there is no information on the motives of the protest.

source: Alterpresse; Jamaica Gleaner; Jamaica Observer; Vi Free Press; Xinhua
notes: On 9 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, for the third consecutive day, police forces clashed with gang members as they tried to expel the criminals from the vicinity of the National Palace (Champs de Mars), which had been attacked the day before (coded separately). During clashes, at least a woman was shot and injured by a stray bullet, and a journalist was hit and wounded by a police tear gas canister. At least 2 injured.

source: Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 29 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, police forces shot and killed an unspecified number of gang members near the National Palace (Champs de Mars neighbourhood). The deceased were described as affiliates of the Living Together gang-led coalition (Viv Ansanm gang). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 26 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, an unknown number of armed individuals kidnapped a trader woman as she was working on the Monseigneur Guilloux street (Morne a Tuf neighbourhood). There is no information on the perpetrators, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. Her whereabouts are unknown.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 28 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members on the Magasin de l'Etat street. During clashes, a woman was shot and injured in the face. 1 injured.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 14 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Portail Leogane/Cite Louverture, Ouest, an unknown number of armed men in a moving vehicle shot and killed more than five people in the Portail Leogane neighbourhood (drive-by). There was a photographer among the fatal victims. Motivation unknown. At least 5 fatalities.
On 15 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, government opponents held a protest on the Capois street demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 9 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Turgeau, Ouest, police forces intervened the premises of the Social Welfare and Research Institute (IBSR) (public institution) and forced a group of displaced residents who had taken refuge there to leave the building. During the police intervention, a 14-year-old boy was killed. In Bourdon neighbourhood (coded separately), police forces chased displaced population taking refuge at the Citizen Protection Office (OPC), forcing them to leave. 1 fatality.

On 5 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative (Viv Ansanm gang), led by the G-9, shot and injured a national police officer in the Solino neighbourhood. 1 injured.
On 10 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, armed members of the Living Together gang-led alliance attacked the Solino neighbourhood and nearby areas. Casualties unknown.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Around 5 January 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Bois Verna, Ouest, a police officer was killed and his body was found on the streets of the Bois Verna neighbourhood. The officer was thought to have been killed in unreported circumstances after leaving his home (assumed off-duty). Perpetrators and motivation unknown. 1 fatality.

On 12 June 2024, around Port-au-Prince - Christ-Roi, Ouest, people demonstrated in Bourdon. According to the report, police was present, but no specific actions were reported. Another report indicates that gunshots were heard on the Bourdon road, but it is not clear if they were related to the demonstration. The demonstrators continued towards Christ-Roi and Delmas 32. Burning tires were registered between the two areas. There is no information on the motives of the demonstration.
On 27 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bourdon, Ouest, around 30 people marched protested on the Bourdon road. There is no further information on the circumstances of the protest.

On 29 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bicentenaire, Ouest, gang members shot and injured three employees of the Port-au-Prince city hall's road services section as they perpetrated an attack in the Bicentenaire neighbourhood. 3 injured.

On 9 June 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, police forces clashed with members of the Living Together gang-led initiative (a.k.a. Viv Ansanm Gang) in the Solino neighbourhood. Several civilians were injured. Clashes took place moments after the criminals had ambushed police officers in an armored vehicle in nearby Delmas 18 Avenue, in Cite Numero Un neighbourhood (coded separately). Several injured.

On 11 June 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, a group of residents held a demonstration in the Nazon neighbourhood to decry the killing of three police officers by gang members on 9 June (coded separately). Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires.
On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, armed clashes were registered in La Saline. There is no information on the circumstances of the clashes. Casualties unknown.

On 5 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, the Belair Gang shot and injured several people as they attacked the Fort-National and Solino neighborhoods (coded separately) . Several injured.

On 4 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, the Belair Gang shot and injured several people as they attacked the Fort-National and Solino neighborhoods (coded separately). Several injured.

On 17 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour Feuilles, Ouest, police forces shot and killed four armed men during a clash in the Carrefour Feuilles neighbourhood. The now deceased were described as suspect abductors. They were intercepted as they were moving in a vehicle which was set on fire (no further details reported). One of the bodies was found burned. 4 fatalities.
On 23 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, members of the Belair Gang attacked the Solino neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.

Around 14 July 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, overnight, armed gang members attacked several areas of the capital, such as Rue Cameau, Place Jeremie, Impasse Beauboeuf in the Bas Peu de Choses neighborhood and Avenue Magloire Ambroise. The gangsters broke into and ransacked residents' homes whom they threatened. The attacks mostly happened during the night. Casualties unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 28 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bicentenaire, Ouest, lawyers and members of the Port-au-Prince Bar Association held a protest in the Bicentenaire neighbourhood to decry the lack of progress in the investigation around the killing of the former president of the institution in August 2020 (coded separately).

On 7 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, an attack was carried out against a supermarket as gunshots were fired in Champs de Mars. There is no further information on the perpetrators, circumstances or motives of the attack. Casualties unknown.

On 16 August 2024, Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, in the morning, gunshots were heard in the Solino neighbourhood, likely to be part of armed clashes between the Viv Ansanm Gang and police forces, who clashed in the neighbourhood the day prior (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 9 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, clashes and attacks were registered in Solino. There is no information on the circumstances or actors involved of the confrontations. Casualties unknown.

On 14 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, armed gang members (likely to be affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang as members of this gang attacked the same area the day after) attacked the Solino neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.

On 18 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, armed members of the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked the Solino neighbourhood and set fire to several houses. Gunshots were heard in the area. Some families fled their houses. Casualties unknown.

On 20 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, residents took to the streets in the Solino neighbourhood to decry insecurity and gang violence. The mobilization was held after a set of gang attacks against the Solino neighbourhood in recent days (coded separately).

On 29 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, in the morning, a gang member was killed (methods unknown) and his body was set on fire on the Martin Luther King Avenue, at the height of the Nazon neighbourhood. There is no information regarding the perpetrators. 1 fatality.

On 1 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, citizens held a march towards the Champs-de-Mars Avenue, next to the National Palace, against Prime Minister, Ariel Henry, and calling for his departure. Police forces intervened using tear gas. No one was arrested or injured. The mobilization was held on the occasion of the 220th anniversary of the political independence of Haiti. There were reports of barricades with burning tires on the road in Christophe Avenue and Saint Geraud bridge.

On 22 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, people protested by marching towards Turgeau. Roadblocks were set up in Oswald Durand Street and Champ de Mars. Although there is no information on the motives of the protest, or the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 19 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Canape-Vert, Ouest, there was an anti-government demonstration in which tires were burned in Bourdon (coded separately) and Canape Vert. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 8 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, clashes were registered in the area. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the clashes. Also, clashes took place in Champs de Mars and Sans Fil Street (both coded separately), while bags and empty vehicles were used to erect barricades on Canape-Vert road. Barricades were also registered in Bois Verna near Berne street. There is no information on the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up. Casualties unknown.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 9 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bourdon, Ouest, police forces chased displaced population taking refuge at the Citizen Protection Office (OPC), forcing them to leave. This took place after police forces intervened the premises of the Social Welfare and Research Institute (IBSR) (public institution), in Turgeau neighbourhood, and forced a group of displaced residents who had taken refuge there to leave the building (coded separately).

On 5 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, the Belair Gang shot and injured several people as they attacked the Fort-National (coded separately) and Solino neighborhoods. Several injured.
On 4 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, the Belair Gang shot and injured several people as they attacked the Fort-National (coded separately) and Solino neighborhoods. Several injured.

On 30 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Avenue Christophe, Ouest, gang members carried out attacks in the area, shooting at motorcycles when the drivers refused to stop. These activities also affected people from Bas Peu de Choses. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Loop News Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 5 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, in the morning, police forces clashed with members of the Viv Ansanm Gang as they carried out anti-gang operations in Bas Peu de Choses and Carrefour Feuilles (coded separately) neighbourhoods. Clashes took place along the Magloire Ambroise Avenue (which crosses both neighbourhoods). Casualties unknown.
On 3 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Portail Leogane/Cite Louverture, Ouest, the police killed several gang members during an operation. Unknown casualties coded as 3.

On 5 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Avenue Christophe, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Avenue N and Rue 4 (Avenue Christophe neighborhood) likely related to the clash between police officers and members of the Viv Ansam gang. Similar clashes were reported nearby in Carrefour Feuilles and Bas Peu des Choses. Casualties unknown.

On 9 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour Feuilles, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members. Gunshots were heard across several roads, such as Magloire Ambroise, Alerte, Dalles roads, and Mgr. Guilloux Avenue. Casualties unknown.
Other: On 24 September 2024, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard on Route Freres. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 25 September 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Village Solidarite. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 25 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard downtown and near the National Port Authority (APN) (Wharf de la Saline). There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 26 September 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Village Solidarite. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 27 September 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Village Solidarite and Pele Simon. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 27 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in La Saline. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 30 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, citizens and members of the political opposition held a demonstration demanding better living conditions and the departure of Prime Minister, Garry Cornille. They set fire to materials in the road. Police forces intervened using tear gas against demonstrators.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 5 October 2024, in Hautes Feuilles, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif the Savien Gang shot and killed a truck driver along the National Road 1. 1 fatality.

On 2 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, a person was shot and killed on Mgr Guilloux street near the General Hospital (likely related to gang violence in the area). Although armed men were registered in the area, there is no information on the circumstances of the incident. 1 fatality.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Property destruction: On 27 September 2024, in Grasse, Artibonite, in the morning, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang set fire to a truck, stole some motorcycles, and fired shots before living the area.
Other: On 30 September 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 75. There is no information on the circumstances and authorship of the gunshots.
On 30 September 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 32, Ouest, people demonstrated. There is no information on the motives for the demonstration.
On 2 October 2024, in Petionville, Ouest, people protested on Panamericaine Avenue in direction of Musseau. There is no information on the motives for the protest.
On 4 October 2024, in Mirebalais, Centre, people protested. A roadblock was set up on the Route Nationale #3. There is no information on the motives for the protest.
On 4 October 2024, in Saint-Louis du Sud, Sud, people protested. There is no information on the motives for the protest.
On 30 September 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 40b, Ouest, people demonstrated and set barricades of burning tires. There is no information on the motives for the demonstration.
On 30 September 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 44, Ouest, people demonstrated and set barricades of burning tires. There is no information on the motives for the demonstration.
On 5 October 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, the police clashed with armed individuals in Duval. There is no information on the circumstances of the clash. Casualties unknown.

Other: Around 5 October 2024 (between 5 - 7 October), in Marassa, Ouest, gunshots were heard over three days. Although there is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots, it is possible they were related to a clash in Duval (coded separately).

On 5 October 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 40b, Ouest, an unknown number of people were kidnapped from the vehicle in which they were traveling. Although there is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators, latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.
On 5 October 2024, in Petion Ville - Centre Ville (Sud), Ouest, people protested in Saint Pierre Square. There is no information on the motives for the protest.
Other: On 7 October 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gunshots were heard. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
On 7 October 2024, in Delmas - Musseau, Ouest, people protested. There is no information on the circumstances or motives of the protest.
On 8 October 2024, in Tabarre - Clercine II/Carrefour Clercine, Ouest, people demonstrated while throwing stones near the police station. There is no information on the motives for the demonstration.
Other: On 10 October 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Carrefour Similien between Delmas 75 and Faustin 1er. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 10 October 2024, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard near the airport. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 11 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Turgeau, Ouest, an unknown number of people were kidnapped near a school. Although there is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators, latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. Another report indicates that the kidnapping attempt might have been stopped by the police. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.
Around 13 October 2024 (between 12 - 14 October), in the commune of Gressier, Ouest, police forces clashed with several gang members in the commune. Three weapons were seized. Casualties unknown.

On 17 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Christ Roi - Lalue, Ouest, overnight, police forces clashed with members of the Belair Gang in Christ-Roi neighbourhood. The gang members had attacked several Port-au-Prince's neighborhoods on that day (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 17 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, overnight, police forces clashed with members of the Belair Gang in Nazon. Gunshots were heard on Martin Luther Kings Avenue and Poupelard Avenue. The gang members had attacked several Port-au-Prince's neighborhoods on that day (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 18 October 2024, in Delmas - Carrefour Pean, Ouest, in the morning, police forces clashed with gang members (likely Belair Gang members) in Carrefour Pean neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.

Other: On 18 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, residents in the Nazon neighbourhood set up roadblocks by parking vehicles on the roadway. They also erected barricades with burning tires. It happened after the Belair Gang attacked residents in several Port-au-Prince's neighborhoods the day prior (coded separately).

Around 5 January 2024 (week of), in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, residents held a protest and blocked a road leading to the site where the irrigation canal is being built around the Massacre River, in the 'Anba Gaya' neighbourhood, to demand that departmental authorities commit to maintaining that road section.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 11 January 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires and threw stones and bottles in the direction of the Public Market. This one and other public buildings closed their doors due to the riots. Police forces intervened using tear gas to disperse the crowd. Demonstrators claimed to support Guy Philippe, a former convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 12 January 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, for the second consecutive day, hundreds of residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Demonstrators, who were joined by moto taxi drivers and members of the Surveillance Brigade for Protected Areas (BSAP) police, set up barricades of burning tires and threw stones against the house of a former senator. The demonstrators claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 9 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, health workers, students, and patients from the GHESKIO health centers, as well as relatives, held a sit-in protest with banners at the institution's facilities (Bicentenaire neighborhood) to demand the release of a doctor who had been kidnapped on 28 November (coded separately). The abducted is the son of the GHESKIO health center's owner.

On 10 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, health workers from the GHESKIO health centers (Bicentenaire neighborhood) held a protest to demand the release of a doctor who had been kidnapped on 28 November (coded separately). The abducted is the son of the GHESKIO health center's owner.

source: Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 11 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, armed gang members kidnapped a doctor on the Reunion Street (near Champs de Mars). He was released on 13 January after a ransom was paid.

source: Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: On 11 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members kidnapped a peace judge of the Carrefour commune court. The abduction took place as the victim got off a bus in the Martissant neighborhood. He was liberated on 15 January after the payment of a ransom. It is known that kidnappers had demanded 500,000 USD.

Around 7 January 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, at least nine people were killed (methods unspecified) and their bodies were found partially burned at a dump site, in Delmas 19. Among the victims, there were seven men and two women, although only one of the men was identified. The scene was recorded and shared on social media. The perpetrators and the motivation for the attack are unknown. At least 9 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 2 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, an unknown number of armed individuals on motorcycles kidnapped two women when they were moving in a vehicle on their way home, in Tabarre 25. A boy who was travelling with the victims was not abducted. The kidnappers asked for a ransom of 600,000 USD as a condition for their liberation. The victims were released on 6 January as a result of a police intervention. A kidnapper was arrested.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 16 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, for the third consecutive day, the Belair Gang, supported by the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) attacked the Solino neighborhood and close areas in Delmas such as Carrefour Pean, Delmas 18, and Delmas 24 (coded separately) as they clashed with rival gang members. The gangsters, who aimed at taking control of the public markets, chased residents and set fire to several houses. At least a person was killed and several were injured. Police forces intervened and expelled the criminals (coded separately). An unknown number of residents fled their homes. The National Human Rights Defense Network's director claimed that at least 20 people were killed between 14 and 18 January as a result of gang clashes in Port-au-Prince. The Organization of Hearts for Change for Deprived Children (OCCED'H) stated that at least 7 children were shot and injured in the same period. At least 7 injured split across ten events. At least 20 fatalities split across ten events, 2 fatalities coded here.

On 16 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces clashed with members of the Belair Gang as they intervened to expel the criminals from the Solino neighborhood and several nearby areas which had been the target of an armed offensive in the last days (coded separately). During clashes, an unknown number of gangsters were killed. Unspecified fatalities coded as 3.

On 7 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighborhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.

On 8 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighborhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.

On 9 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the third consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighborhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.

On 10 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the fourth consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighborhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.

On 11 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the fifth consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighborhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.

On 12 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the sixth consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighborhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.

On 13 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the seventh consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighborhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.

On 17 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, unidentified gang members attacked residents on the Laraque street (Carrefour - Cote Plage) and its surrounding areas. Tens of families got trapped at their houses as the attack took place. Casualties unknown.

Other: On 16 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, residents set up barricades and roadblocks of burning tires on the Airport Road as they fled their homes from the Belair Gang, who had attacked their communities on several occasions in the last days (coded separately).

Around 15 January 2024 (month of), in Grand-Goave, Ouest, residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Some public institutions closed their doors due to the mobilization. Protesters claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 15 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, hundreds of residents held a protest with banners demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Protesters claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 16 January 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, for the second consecutive day, thousands of residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Some protesters were armed with machetes, although no violent or destructive behavior was mentioned. They claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). Police forces were present, although no intervention on their side was mentioned.

On 16 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, several dozen citizens, patients, and health workers from the GHESKIO health centers (Bicentenaire neighborhood) held a protest to demand the release of a doctor who had been kidnapped on 28 November (coded separately). The abducted is the son of the GHESKIO health center's owner.

On 17 January 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, for the third consecutive day, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 6 and threw stones against drivers trying to circulate. They claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).Between the 15th and the 18th of January, one person was killed during the demonstrations against the Prime Minister. 1 fatality split over four events.

On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, unidentified individuals, armed with heavy weapons, set up barricades in Clercine and Croix-des-Missions areas. These individuals threw tear gas and intimidated traders on the 15 October Boulevard (Carrefour Fleuriot neighborhood)), forcing them to leave the area. This is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 18 January 2024, in Santo, Ouest, roadblocks and barricades were set up on the streets. This is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 15 January 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, several hundreds of residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires on the Airport road, among others, and threw stones against the house of a former senator whom they accused of supporting the repression of demonstrators. Clashes were mentioned between the rioters and security guards from the former senator's private residence. Police forces intervened (methods unspecified) and restored order. Public and private institutions kept their doors closed during the mobilization. Demonstrators claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 16 January 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, for the second consecutive day, residents and members of the Surveillance Brigade for Protected Areas (BSAP) police held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Demonstrators, who claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), set up barricades of burning tires. Some of them were armed with firearms and machetes. Unidentified individuals threw stones against the BSAP agents. Between the 15th and the 18th of January, one person was killed during the demonstrations against the Prime Minister. 1 fatality split over four events.

On 17 January 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, for the third consecutive day, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). During the mobilization, clashes were mentioned between the demonstrators and residents from the Mackandal neighbourhood. Several people were injured.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 15 January 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, residents and members of the Surveillance Brigade for Protected Areas (BSAP) police held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They burned tires and used containers and trucks to set up roadblocks. Some of them were seen with pointed weapons and gunshots were heard (authorship unknown). Access to several public institutions was blocked, including the Peace Court. They claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). Police forces were present, although no intervention on their side was mentioned. Between the 15th and the 18th of January, one person was killed during the demonstrations against the Prime Minister. 1 fatality split over four events.

On 18 January 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, for the fourth consecutive day, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set fire to the city hall main door as they decried the new interim executive officers appointed by PM. Demonstrators claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 18 January 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, for the fourth consecutive day, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 6 as they threw stones and bottles. Gunshots were heard (authorship unspecified) and it is known that a person was shot during anti-government mobilizations (unspecified if he/she was taking part in the demonstration). Demonstrators claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). Between the 15th and the 18th of January, one person was killed during the demonstrations against the Prime Minister. 1 fatality split over four events.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, masked individuals set up roadblocks and barricades of burning tires, tree trunks, and pieces of vehicles in Canape-Vert, Lalue, Solino, Nazon, and other areas. Although several sources state that the people behind these actions were not identified, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, masked individuals, some of them armed with machetes, set up roadblocks and barricades in Delmas 31, 33, and 40B (coded separately), among other areas. On the Airport Road (Barbancourt neighborhood), stones and bottles were thrown (coded separately). This is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 19 January 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, for the fifth consecutive day, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Demonstrators burned tires. They claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 22 January 2024, in Ennery, Artibonite, overnight, residents held a protest on the National Road 1 to decry the arrest of a former deputy over corruption accusations and asking for his release. Protesters blocked the road with trucks, interrupting road traffic. They also welded a bridge with iron bars. The roadblock persisted for several days.

On 23 January 2024, in Hinche, Centre, hundreds of protesters and several members of the Surveillance Brigade for Protected Areas (BSAP), armed with heavy weapons, held a march demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. The BSAP members, accompanied by former head of the National Agency for Protected Areas (ANAP), closed the Hinche Administrative Complex, rejecting the decision issued by Henry's government of revoking the former director of the ANAP on 22 January. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Phillipe (former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). The march was expected to end in Port-au-Prince, although this was not confirmed by any source.

Non-violent activity: On 21 January 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, armed civilians were seen patrolling the village. They were described as pro-government supporters aiming at preventing anti-government mobilizations in the area.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: On 22 January 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. During the mobilization, at least two protesters were killed and at least three were injured (other sources stated up to five killed). According to one version, masked armed individuals in a moving vehicle opened fire on the crowd (drive-by). The individuals were described as supporters of the new departmental delegate, who was designated and installed on 19 January. Another version stated that the shooter was a public official, while a third theory stated that police forces trying to prevent protesters from taking tires from a police station and erecting barricades opened fire on them. The protest was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). Between 22 and 23 January, at least four male protesters died as a result of the gunshot wounds. At least 4 fatalities, several injured.
On 26 January 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, supporters of the Platfom Pitit Desalin party held a sit-in protest in the Arms Square demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry.

On 25 January 2024, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires in the Sica neighbourhood. Some public schools closed their doors. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: On 21 January 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, members of the 400 Mawozo Gang opened fire on the three occupants of a vehicle, killing a man and injuring a 12-year-old boy. A 17-year-old woman who was in the car was kidnapped. The victims were members of the same family. The abducted woman was released on 23 January. 1 fatality, 1 injured.

On 22 January 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They threw stones against the facilities of several banks and companies, forcing them to close doors, and set up roadblocks of burning tires on the National Road 6. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). Police forces intervened to restore order, although no interaction with the demonstrators was mentioned.

On 23 January 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, for the second consecutive day, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. During the mobilization, rioters who were described as 'very violent' tried to set fire to the Public Market, although police forces intervened (methods unspecified) and prevented it. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole
notes: On 24 January 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, for the third consecutive day, several hundreds of residents, supported by members of the Surveillance Brigade for Protected Areas (BSAP) police, held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters tried to occupy a departmental customs office and clashed with police forces, who intervened (methods unspecified) and dispersed the mobilization, preventing the occupation. The BSAP members fired shots in all directions on the National Road 6 as they tried to intimidate business owners. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). The BSAP members also demonstrated against the ANAP former director's revocation by a government decree the day prior.

On 24 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, around 10 patients and health workers from the GHESKIO health centers (Bicetenaire neighborhood) held a protest to demand the release of a doctor who had been kidnapped on 28 November (coded separately). The abducted is the son of the GHESKIO health center's owner.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 24 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces shot and killed a gang member during a clash near Champs de Mars. A firearm was seized. 1 fatality.

On 24 January 2024, in the arrondissement of Port-au-Prince, Ouest, members of several socio-political organizations from the opposition held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Police forces were present, although no intervention on their side was mentioned.
On 25 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, in the morning, armed men on a motorcycle shot and killed two young men in Bourdon (drive-by). Motivation unknown. 2 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Scholars at Risk
notes: Non-violent activity: On 23 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, overnight, armed members of the Ti Bwa Gang occupied a campus of the Adventist University of Haiti (Unah), in the Diquini neighbourhood, and threatened security guards with attacking them if they facilitated a police intervention. No violent behaviour by the gangsters was mentioned.

On 29 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, unidentified individuals lynched three young women and set fire to their corpses on the Brun Ricot Street, in Nazon neighbourhood. The circumstances and motivation for the attack are unknown. 3 fatalities.

On 1 February 2024, in Trou-du-Nord, Nord-Est, a group of young men who identified themselves as members of the FMT, some of them armed with firearms, gathered on the Route 6 shooting into the air and throwing bottles and stones against people who attempted to demonstrate against the government. The action sought to prevent demonstrations to demand the departure of Prime Minister Ariel Henry called by local organizations. There were no fatalities.

On 30 January 2024, in Santo, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang engaged in armed clashes with members of the Vitelhomme Gang (a.k.a. Kraze Barye Gang). Several civilians were killed. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 16 January 2024, in Delmas - Cite Numero Un, Ouest, gang members set fire to residents' houses in Delmas 18 (Cite Numero Un neighbourhood), killing an unspecified number of civilians. Gunshots were heard also heard in Delmas 24 (Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28 neighborhoods). Residents were fleeing the area. People had already fled their homes towards Delmas after their communities were attacked by the Belair Gang on several occasions in the last days (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 28 January 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, high school students held a march demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry, against insecurity and corruption, among other claims. The students took to the street as they joined anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 30 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang engaged in armed clashes with members of the Vitelhomme Gang (a.k.a. Kraze Barye Gang) in the Torcelle neighborhood. Gunshots were heard near the US Embassy (Chateau Blond neighborhood). Several civilians were killed. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 28 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, gang members from different factions of the G-9 alliance that operate in La Saline and Wharf Jeremie clashed in La Saline neighborhood and nearby areas as part of a fight for territory and for the control of passage fees imposed on trucks leaving Varreux Oil Terminal. The gangsters were described as members of the Base Nan Chabon Gang (led by Marc) who had engaged in an internal plot against their leader, other reports suggest that members of Base Nan Tokyo and Base Krache Dief participated in clash (all affiliated with the G-9). Between 27 and 30 January, more than 20 fatalities were counted among the gang members. At least 9 civilians were killed, and more than 30 were injured as a result of clashes between gangsters from Wharf Jeremie and La Saline. At least 29 fatalities and 30 injured split across four related armed clash events coded between 27 and 30 January.

On 2 February 2024, in Saint-Louis du Nord, Nord-Ouest, hundreds of people protested demanding the departure of Prime Minister Ariel Henry. This is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti)

On 27 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members from different factions of the G-9 alliance that operate in La Saline and Wharf Jeremie clashed in La Saline neighborhood and nearby areas as part of a fight for territory and for the control of passage fees imposed on trucks leaving Varreux Oil Terminal. The gangsters were described as members of the Base Nan Chabon Gang (led by Marc) who had engaged in an internal plot against their leader, other reports suggest that members of Base Nan Tokyo and Base Krache Dief participated in clash (all affiliated with the G-9). Between 27 and 30 January, more than 20 fatalities were counted among the gang members. At least 9 civilians were killed, and more than 30 were injured as a result of clashes between gangsters from Wharf Jeremie and La Saline. At least 29 fatalities and 30 injured split across four related armed clash events coded between 27 and 30 January.

On 29 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the third consecutive day, gang members from different factions of the G-9 alliance that operate in La Saline and Wharf Jeremie clashed in La Saline neighborhood and nearby areas as part of a fight for territory and for the control of passage fees imposed on trucks leaving Varreux Oil Terminal. The gangsters were described as members of the Base Nan Chabon Gang (led by Marc) who had engaged in an internal plot against their leader, other reports suggest that members of Base Nan Tokyo and Base Krache Dief participated in clash (all affiliated with the G-9). Between 27 and 30 January, more than 20 fatalities were counted among the gang members. At least 9 civilians were killed, and more than 30 were injured as a result of clashes between gangsters from Wharf Jeremie and La Saline. At least 29 fatalities and 30 injured split across four related armed clash events coded between 27 and 30 January.

source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 29 January 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, for the second consecutive day, residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Police forces intervened using tear gas to disperse the mobilization. A radio journalist who was covering the event on Edmond Laforest street was injured on his foot by a tear gas grenade. The protest, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by organizations from the political opposition (coded separately). 1 injured.

On 1 January 2024, in Cite Soleil - Nanraguette/Drouillard, Ouest, armed men attacked the premises of the company E-Power (Nanraguette/Drouillard neighborhood). At least one employee was injured. At least 1 injured.

On 1 February 2024, in Hinche, Hinche, in the morning, armed members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) police and several socio-political organizations held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Herny. The BSAP agents also opposed the government's decision to ban them from circulating with fire weapons and the BSAP's uniform. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires in the vicinity of several public institutions. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 29 January 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, several thousands supporters of the Platfom Pitit Desalin party held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. They set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 1. Police forces used tear gas to disperse them. The crowd was called by the PPD party leader, who encouraged his supporters to barricade in front of the ministers' residences if PM does not leave power before 7 February. The riot, which was also part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by organizations from the political opposition (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 29 January 2024, in Roseaux, Grande-Anse, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters burned tires and parked trucks along the National Road 7. Police forces intervened with fire arms and tear gas, killing a demonstrator and injuring several people, including a 5-year-old boy. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by organizations from the political opposition (coded separately). 1 fatality, several injured.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: On 29 January 2024, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They set up barricades of burning tires, stones, pieces of bottles, and tree trucks on several highways. Some public institutions were vandalized with graffiti. Commercial and school activities were paralyzed. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by organizations from the political opposition (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 29 January 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires and blocked the Kanari River bridge with iron bars. Armed individuals looted and set fire to the National Old Age Insurance (ONA) office. Gunshots of unknown authorship were heard. A woman and a young man were killed by the bullets (not clarified if they were demonstrators or passers-by). The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by organizations from the political opposition (coded separately). 2 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: On 29 January 2024, in Terrier Rouge, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They set up barricades of burning tires on several highways (nature unspecified). Commercial and school activities were paralyzed. Rioters damaged the premises of a school.
