The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by organizations from the political opposition (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: On 29 January 2024, in Trou-du-Nord, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up roadblocks on the National Road 6 and erected burning barricades in the vicinity of public institutions, including next to the city hall. The communal market was burned. Commercial and school activities were paralyzed. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by organizations from the political opposition (coded separately).

On 31 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, citizens and political militants held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters burned tires. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 31 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, hundreds of citizens of several socio-political organizations held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires. Police forces intervened using tear gas and dispersed the crowd at the height of Delmas 73 (Delmas 75 neighborhood) and Delmas 60. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Gros-Morne, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang operating in the Tibwadom neighbourhood opened fire on a police station. There were no police officers in the building at the moment of the shooting, as it had been abandoned by the officers. A radio journalist was shot and injured in his testicles during the attack. It is unknown if the journalist was targeted intentionally. On 9 February, the police took the control of the building. 1 injured.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 7 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, police forces shot and killed three gang members during a clash on the Freres Road. Several firearms were seized. 3 fatalities.

On 6 February 2024, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, for the second consecutive day, hundreds of residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 6 February 2024, in Trou-du-Nord, Nord-Est, for the second consecutive day, hundreds of residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. The protest was called by the Committed Citizens of Trou-du-Nord Group (Recipe). This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, for the third consecutive day, residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Trou-du-Nord, Nord-Est, for the third consecutive day, thousands of residents, called by the Committed Citizens of Trou-du-Nord Group (Recipe), held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Protesters marched from the Saint-Baptiste Church to the National Road 6. When they arrived to the vicinity of a police station, the organizers had to use the force (nature unknown) to change the march's path and prevent the crowd from assaulting the police institution. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 5 February 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, several hundreds of residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. They accused him of being involved in the killing of former President, Jovenel Moise, and asked for justice. They also opposed the Natcom and Digitel companies and described them as accomplices of PM. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires and threw stones. Police forces intervened (methods unspecified) and dispersed the crowd. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 8 February 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 17, Ouest, government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Demonstrators barricaded the Delmas Road with burning tires. Police forces used tear gas to disperse the crowd. During the police intervention, a journalist covering the event was shot and injured by a rubber bullet in Delmas 38 (Delmas 17 neighborhood). His lost an eye. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 1 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 5 February 2024, around Delmas - Delmas 60, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, dozens of government opponents, called by the Committed to Development Party (EDE), held a march demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Barricades of burning tires were set up in Champ de Mars, Lalue, Canape-Vert, and Bourdon. Unidentified individuals spilled oil along the road leading to Delmas 32. Gunshots were heard in La Saline, Lalue, Bel Air, Nazon, Christ-Roi, and Solino. When the crowd reached Petionville, a sit-in was held in front of the PM's residence, in Delmas 60. Police forces fired tear gas, hitting the EDE party leader who was among the crowd. At least five demonstrators were injured. The PM was escorted and transferred to another location. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by the Anti-Corruption Union Brigade (coded separately). At least 5 injured.

On 7 February 2024, in Hinche, Centre, for the third consecutive day, dozens of government opponents, called by the EDE Party, held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters threw stones and looted the departmental office of the Economy and Finance Ministry and the City Hall. Some items were stolen. Police forces intervened with tear gas and arrested several individuals. Another group of rioters, armed with knives and machetes, entered the Communal Market and burned tires. Gunshots were heard through the day. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole
notes: On 4 February 2024, in Delmas - Musseau, Ouest, hundreds of government opponents called by the Committed to Development Party (EDE) and the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party (PPD) held a march with banners demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. The march, which had initiated in Carrefour Aeroport (Delmas) and in Champs de Mars (Port-au-Prince), ended in Musseau (Delmas). In Musseau, rioters tried to set fire to carnival stands and a sit-in was staged in front of the PM's residence. A dozen police forces intervened using tear gas and dispersed it. The mobilization was attended by the PPD party leader (hit by the tear gas), several representatives of the EDE party, and unionist leaders.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: On 6 February 2024, in Hinche, Centre, for the second consecutive day, hundreds of government opponents and members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) police, called by the Committed to Development Party (EDE) and the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party (PPD), held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters threw stones, tried to set fire to the city hall, and burned several motorcycles. Police forces used tear gas to disperse them. At least one demonstrator was shot and injured (likely during the police intervention). The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). At least 1 injured.

On 7 February 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, for the fourth consecutive day, thousands of government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires and looted the Grande-Anse Civil Protection warehouse. They also threw stones and pieces of bottles against private residences in Nan Site, among other neighborhoods. Pro-government supporters who opposed the mobilization opened fire on the crowd, shooting and injuring more than 10 demonstrators and journalists. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). At least 10 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: On 6 February 2024, in Mirebalais, Centre, government opponents and members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade police (BSAP) held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. During the mobilization, police forces clashed with BSAP agents, resulting in one demonstrator killed and four others injured. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 1 fatality, 4 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 5 February 2024, in Hinche, Centre, residents and armed members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) police held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. They set up a roadblock on the Celimene Louverture street, where rioters were seen throwing stones and pieces of bottles. They also looted a customs office. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). It was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by the Anti-Corruption Union Brigade (coded separately). Another report indicates that gunshots were heard and possibly related to the presence of the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP), although it is not clear if it was directly related to the demonstration.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 6 February 2024, between Delmas, Port-au-Prince, and Petionville (coded to Port-au-Prince - Petionville), Ouest, for the third consecutive day, hundreds of citizens (some of them armed with machetes), agents from the Protected Areas Security Brigade police (BSAP), and supporters of the National Awakening for the Sovereignty of Haiti movement held a march demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires. In Bourdon (Port-au-Prince), police forces fired tear gas. At least one demonstrator was injured. When the crowd reached Petionville, rioters looted the Tiger gas station and gunshots were heard in the Juvenat neighbourhood. In the Saint-Pierre square, the presence of Guy Philippe (leader of the National Awakening for the Sovereignty of Haiti movement, and a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on a revolution in Haiti) attracted hundreds of supporters (up to 600 according to one source). At least 1 injured.

On 7 February 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, for the third consecutive day, thousands of government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters threw stones and looted several private companies. Police forces used tear gas to disperse them. During the police intervention, two journalists were physically aggressed by agents of the Anti-Narcotics Brigade and got their equipment damaged. According to a report, the journalists were accused by the police of making the population hostile towards them and favoring their sympathy with the BSAP. The demonstration, which was joined by many supporters of the Platform Pitit Desalin Party, was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 5 February 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, hundreds of militants from the Platform Pitit Desalin Party (PPD) and members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) police held a demonstration with banners demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 6. The demonstration was called by the PPD party in the context of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: On 6 February 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, for the second consecutive day, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. During the mobilization, heavily armed individuals fired shots in all directions and attacked a police station. Several people were injured by the bullets (affiliation unknown). In response, police forces intervened shot and killed a suspected perpetrator. A group of masked rioters vandalized the city hall and set fire to several vehicles belonging to the institution. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 1 fatality, several injured.

On 7 February 2024, in Petit-Goave, Ouest, thousands of residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Three journalists who were covering the mobilization were beaten up by rioters participating in the demonstration. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Gazette Haiti; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 4 February 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, hundreds of residents participating in pre-carnival activities held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They shouted anti-government slogans and spoke out against police forces and the departmental delegate. Police forces used tear gas and dispersed them. Clashes between both sides were mentioned. Overnight, rioters set up barricades of burning tires on the Mackandal Street. This happened in the context of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 5 February 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, for the second consecutive day, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires on the 'Nan Site' Road, among others. A vehicle belonging to a civil employee of the police was set on fire. Police forces intervened using tear gas to disperse the crowd. Gunshots from tear gas were heard on the Source-Dommage street, among others. The Communal Market and several public institutions remained closed. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 6 February 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, for the second consecutive day, thousands of residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires, threw stones, and clashed with police forces, who fired tear gas against the crowd. Gunshots were heard (authorship unspecified). The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Terrier Rouge, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. As a group of rioters attacked a police station, police officers intervened using tear gas and firing into the air to disperse them. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 5 February 2024, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 6. Public institutions remained closed. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 5 February 2024, in Terrier Rouge, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 6. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 5 February 2024, in Trou-du-Nord, Nord-Est, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 6. Public institutions remained closed. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, for the third consecutive day, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 6. Several public institutions were looted and set on fire, like the Croix-Rouge Peace Court and the Ouanaminthe City Hall. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 26 January 2024, in Petion Ville - Thomassin, gang members kidnapped around 20 women vendors in Thomassin. The abduction took place as the group was travelling in a truck back home to Kenscoff. The kidnappers demanded a ransom of USD 250,000 in exchange for their release. There is no information on the victims' whereabouts.

On 5 February 2024, in Carrefour - Clocher/Ti Source, Ouest, armed gang members attacked residents in Ti Sous (near Clocher), and in other nearby neighborhoods including La Grenade and Sapotille (coded separately). According to witnesses, at least two civilians were killed (a resident and a moto taxi driver). Several others were injured. The gangsters were said to be based in Mariani. At least 2 fatalities split across three events. 1 fatality coded for this event.

On 14 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, for the eighth consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 15 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, for the ninth consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood and in nearby Waaf Jeremie neighbourhood, in the Cite Soleil commune(coded separately) as part of a fight for territory. At least five people were killed in the crossfire. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. According to one of the sources, the gang members involved in the clashes were from the Grand-Ravine Gang, Base Project La Saline Gang, and the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang), against the Micanord Gang (a.k.a. Whart Jeremie Gang). At least 5 fatalities split across two events.

On 16 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, for the tenth consecutive day, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood as part of a fight for territory. Armed clashes persisted for at least 10 consecutive days. Casualties unknown.

Around 8 February 2024 (between 5 - 11 February), in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, gang members attacked residents in the commune. An unknown number of people fled the area and took refuge elsewhere. Casualties unknown.

Around 9 February 2024 (between 5 - 14 February), in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, rival gang members engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood. During clashes, residents were attacked and an unknown number of people fled the area and took refuge elsewhere. According to the sources, the clashes have been ongoing several days during the week, although the exact days are not specified. The clashes prevented the circulation of trucks and the work of custom officers and has also contributed to fuel scarcity. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: Around 11 February 2024 (weekend of), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members shot and killed at least two children as they tried to flee from gang-controlled areas in the downtown. It was not clarified if this happened amidst clashes between rival gangs. At least 2 fatalities.

On 12 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, in the morning, rival gang members engaged in armed clashes in the commune. During clashes, the gangsters attacked and killed residents and set fire to hundreds of houses. Some young women were raped in front of their parents. Thousands of civilians fled their homes. On 12 February, more than 30 civilians were killed amidst gang clashes in Carrefour and La Plaine du Cul-du-Sac. At least 30 fatalities split across three events. 10 events coded for this event.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 13 February 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, overnight, two police agents of the Departmental Law Enforcement Unit (UDMO) beat up and injured the government commissioner at the Cap-Haitien Court of First Instance during a traffic incident on the street. As the policemen asked the commissioner to move his vehicle (improperly parked), and he refused to obey, the officers attacked him. The police version stated that the commissioner tried to slap one of the officers. The commissioner was moved to hospital, where he stayed for at least four days. 1 injured.

On 14 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, an unknown number of armed individuals shot and injured a police officer on the Oswald Durand Street near the Stade Sylvio Cator. The victim was transported to hospital by several citizens. He died while undergoing treatment. 1 fatality.

On 15 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, several dozen citizens, called by the Platfom Pitit Desalin party, held a protest on the Delmas Road demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Police forces intervened using tear gas to disperse the crowd. A second report indicates that demonstrations were also registered in Carrefour Aeroport (coded separately) and Delmas 65 (coded separately), where demonstrators threw stones at vehicles.

On 15 February 2024, in Tiburon, Sud, overnight, police forces killed two gang members operating in Tiburon. A woman who was also killed. Another version of the event suggest that the gang members were lynched by armed residents. 3 fatalities.

On 21 February 2024, in Ennery, Artibonite, several dozens residents and supporters of the Alliance for a Society Without Exclusions Party (ASE) held a protest demanding the release of the party leader who was accused of misappropriation of public property. Protesters held tree branches and banners, and claimed that they would keep protesting until the politician's release.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 19 February 2024, in Mirebalais, Centre, police forces shot and killed two gang members during a clash in the commune. It happened during a police operation that was carried out a day after gang members attacked a police station in Terre Rouge (coded separately). 2 fatalities.

On 19 February 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, an unknown number of gang members on motorcycles shot and killed a police officer and injured his wife as they opened fire on the vehicle they were travelling with their son in the Petite Anse neighbourhood (drive-by). The officer shot and killed a gangster before succumbing to his injuries. The minor escaped unharmed. The attack took place when the victims were returning from a commercial bank. Several gangsters were arrested for his involvement in the shooting. 2 fatalities, 1 injured.

Property destruction: Around 18 February 2024 (weekend of), in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, an unknown number of armed men were seen firing shots in the direction of the Saint-Francois Xavier School. The school has been closed due to the ongoing anti-government demonstrations. The motivation of the shooting was not clarified, although it is known that there were rumours of further anti-government mobilizations in the commune.

On 19 February 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, an man, armed with a machete, hit and injured a tele-radio journalist as he was returning from work. The attack was described as an assassination attempt. 1 injured.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Radio Television Caraibes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 19 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bicentenaire, Ouest, gang members abducted a man in the Bicentenaire neighbourhood as he was making his way to work. The victim was a teacher at the Faculty of Law and Economic Sciences. The whereabouts of the victim are unknown.

On 19 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, residents held a demonstration in the Fort National neighbourhood against rumors stating the transfer of agents of the Departmental Operation and Intervention Brigade (BOID) assigned to this community. Demonstrators set up barricades (nature unknown) and gunshots were heard during the mobilization. Residents claimed that the agents' presence persuades gang attacks. The rumors were later denied.

Other: On 19 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, in the morning, gunshots were heard at the height of Samida crossroad, in the Nazon neighbourhood. Armed men were seen in the area. Trucks were also used to block the crossroad. There is no information on the circumstances of the gunshots or roadblocks.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 23 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, armed gang members kidnapped six Brothers of the Sacred Heart Congregation and a teacher near the Jean XXIII School (Catholic Christian Group), in Morne a Tuf neighbourhood. The abductors asked for a ransom as a condition for their release. In another area a Catholic priest and 10 other people were kidnapped in the capital, including two cameramen from Tele Amen (coded separately). Around 9 March 2024, the mentioned teacher and four Brothers of the Sacred Heart Congregation were released. The other two religious Brothers were released on 26 March under unknown circumstances.

On 22 February 2024, in Carrefour - Terrain Ti Carme, Ouest, overnight, gang members carried out several attacks, killing at least six people. One of the victims was a police officer who was shot by three armed gang members and his body was mutilated and set it on fire, in Mahotiere 85 (Terrain Ti Carme neighbourhood). A civilian riding a motorcycle was decapitated on the road. An unspecified number of other residents were killed. As part of the attacks, gang members looted a hotel in Brochette neighbourhood. The perpetrators were later lynched by a mob of residents (coded separately). At least 6 fatalities.

On 21 February 2024, in Delmas - Petite Place Cazeau, Ouest, employees of the National Solid Waste Management Services (SNGRS) held a demonstration over labor demands and asking for the payment of due salaries. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires in front of the institution's facilities (Petite Place Cazeau neighborhood).

On 18 February 2024, in Petion Ville - Bouk Chanpay, Ouest, overnight, an unknown number of armed individuals shot and killed four people in the Bouc-Champagne area. Their corpses were found in the morning of 19 February. Perpetrators and motivation are unknown. 4 fatalities.

source: Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 18 February 2024, in Petion Ville - Peguy-Ville, Ouest, an explosive device was activated in the house where the Catholic Christian Bishop of Anse-a-Veau/Miragoane was being hosted, in Peguy-Ville neighbourhood. The bishop got injured and burned. The attack was described as an assassination attempt. Perpetrators and motivation are unknown. 1 injured.

On 19 February 2024, in Petion Ville - Juvenat, Ouest, dozens of members of the organization Gathering of Citizens Committed to the Security and Development of the Country held a sit-in protest with banners in front of the United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti (BINUH) headquarters, in the Juvenat neighbourhood, demanding the arrival of a Multinational Security Support Mission to Haiti to fight insecurity.
On 23 February 2024, in Tabarre - Chateau Blond, Ouest, police forces clashed with unidentified armed men near the US Embassy. The police fired tear gas and real bullets. Casualties unknown.

On 20 February 2024, in Cavaillon, Sud, several hundreds of residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Protesters also called on the release of an opposition activist who was arrested on 12 February after his participation in anti-government mobilizations.

On 28 February 2024, near Gilbert, Artibonite, police forces shot and killed a gang member during a clash in the Granfon village. The deceased was the right hand of the Salami Gang leader. Seven gangsters were arrested, including a woman. A quantity of ammunition and firearms were seized. 1 fatality.

On 29 February 2024, in Hinche, Centre, residents held a demonstration against Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up barricades (nature unspecified) and gunshots were heard near the communal market (authorship unspecified). The mobilization occurred after it was known that the PM plans to stay in power until 2026.
On 25 February 2024, in Grand Boucan, Centre, an unknown number of armed men shot and killed two civilian passengers as they attacked a public transport vehicle in Fonds Cheval area. 2 fatalities.

On 29 February 2024, in Carrefour Zaboca, Grande-Anse, residents held a demonstration against Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires on the National Road 7. The mobilization occurred after it was known that the PM plans to stay in power until 2026. Demonstrators claimed to support Guy Philippe, a former convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 1 March 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, gang members attacked a police station. Police forces intervened and repeal the attack. There were no casualties.

Around 23 February 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, students from the Law and Economic Sciences Faculty (FDSE) and other UEH entities held a protest with banners and set up barricades near the UEH university (nature unspecified) demanding the liberation of a teacher who was kidnapped around 17 February (coded separately).

On 24 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in the vicinity of the Salomon Market and in Portail Leogane sector (coded separately). An unspecified number of victims were reported (not clarified if wounded or killed). Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 26 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, police forces shot and killed at least four members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) during clashes in Fort St. Claire area (Morne a Tuf neighbourhood). Their corpses were burned by residents (coded separately). The gang members had set fire to some houses on the Saint-Honore street and gunshots were heard in Portail Leogane sector and in Chareron, Reunion, and Joseph Janvier streets (Morne a Tuf). Between 26 and 27 February, at least 20 people were shot and injured as a result of clashes between the police and the gang members. 4 fatalities and at least 20 injured split across two armed clashes coded by ACLED in central Port-au-Prince.

On 26 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a mob of residents set fire to the corpses of four gang members who had been killed amidst clashes with police forces moments before in areas of Portail Leogane and Morne a Tuf neighborhoods (coded separately). The deceased were affiliates of the Base 5 Secondes Gang.

On 27 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, police forces clashed with members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) in the down town. Between 26 and 27 February, at least 20 people were shot and injured as a result of clashes between the police and the gang members. At least 20 injured split across two armed clashes coded by ACLED in central Port-au-Prince.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Scholars at Risk
notes: On 29 February 2024, in Cite Soleil - Damiens/Macaya, Ouest, gang members (likely G-9 Gang members due to ongoing coordinated attacks) attacked the Ministry of the Agriculture and occupied the Agronomy and Veterinary Medicine Faculty (UEH University), in Damiens neighbourhood. Students were taken as hostages. One student was shot and injured in the ear, while a young girl was grazed by a bullet. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. 1 injured.

On 25 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, supporters of several socio-political organizations held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister Ariel Henry. Burning tires were registered in Delmas 34 and 65. Demonstrators, who were called by the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party (PPD), decried the international community's interference in Haitian political affairs.

On 29 February 2024, in Delmas - Village Solidarite, Ouest, gang members (likely G-9 members due to ongoing coordinated attacks) clashed with police forces on the Airport Road and near the Bernard Mevs Hospital (Village Solidarite neighbourhood). At least six civilians (two women) were injured by the bullets. Gunshots were heard in Pele Simon neighbourhood. Between 29 February and 1 March, at least 33 people were received in La Paix Hospital (Delmas - Kernizan) due to gunshot wounds. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. At least 33 injured split across two events.

source: Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 1 March 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 5, Ouest, gang members (likely G-9 members due to ongoing coordinated attacks) set fire to a police station in Delmas 3 (Delmas 5). Gunshots were heard in Simon Pele. Another report indicates that the gunshots might have been aimed at vehicles. Gunshots were also registered in Carrefour Drouillard and Delmas 24, as well as the Airport Road, among other areas. This was the second consecutive day of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader with the support of gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. Between 29 February and 1 March, at least 33 people were received in La Paix Hospital (Cite Saint-Georges) due to gunshot wounds caused amidst clashes between the police and the gangsters. At least 33 injured split across two events.

On 1 March 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 40b, Ouest, several dozens of citizens held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Another report indicates that barricades of burning tires in Delmas 40B, 48 (coded separately), and 75 (coded separately), which might possibly related to the demonstration.

On 1 March 2024, between Delmas and Tabarre (coded to Tabarre - Clercine II/Carrefour Clercine), Ouest, dozens of police officers on motorcycles marched along the Delmas Road and demonstrated in front of the Police General Direction, in the Clercine neighbourhood, to demand the recovery of the corpses of those officers who were killed by gang members the day before in Bon Repos (coded separately). They also decried the lack of proper equipment at work. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires and threw stones.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 2 March 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gang members occupied and set fire to the Calvaire police station. Casualties unknown.

On 5 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, gang members attacked and looted the Higher National Institute for Midwifery Training, on the Monseigneur Guilloux street (Bas Peu de Choses neighbourhood). Solar panels and vehicles were stolen. Casualties unknown.

On 2 March 2024, in Tabarre - Mais Gate/Clercine 2, Ouest, gang members fired shots against the Toussaint Louverture International Airport, in Mais Gate/Clercine 2 neighbourhood. An aircraft belonging to the Sunrise Airways Company was damaged by the bullets. Overnight, gunshots were heard in the Carrefour Fleuriot neighbourhood as some videos showed several gang members coming back to their strongholds after having escaped from the Civil Prison, assaulted by other gangs earlier that day (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; InSight Crime; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 2 March 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, overnight, the 400 Mawozo Gang assaulted the Civil Prison and released thousands of inmates. As police forces intervened and clashed with the gangsters, an unspecified number of police officers, penitentiary staff members, and prisoners were killed and injured. A prison officer was shot in the stomach. The jail's assault was part of coordinated attacks against the two major Haiti prisons led by the G-9 Gang with the support of gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). A nearby police station, the Croix-des-Bouquets Peace Court, a funeral company, and several vehicles were set on fire. Three bank branches were looted and two security guards were kidnapped. Their whereabouts are unknown. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.
On 8 March 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang opened fire and looted the city hall. The scene was recorded on video. Casualties unknown.

On 4 March 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, for the second consecutive day, in the morning, several opposition militants of the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party held a demonstration in front of the Cap-Haitien International Airport demanding that the flight of Prime Minister Ariel Henry not be hosted. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires in several neighborhoods.

On 4 March 2024, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, rioters gathered near the Jacmel airport, following rumours that Prime Minister Ariel Henry may be returning to the country through the airport. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires along the St-Cyr Road, in front of the airport.

On 4 March 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang clashed with members of the Chien Mechant Gang. During clashes, armed members of the population were present in the Carrefour Marassa area, where several vendors were stripped and some motorcycles were stolen (authorship unspecified). Clashes between these gangs were also reported in several neighborhoods in Croix-des-Bouquets (coded separately) and in Santo (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 4 March 2024, in Santo, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang clashed with members of the Chien Mechant Gang. Clashes between these gangs were also reported in several neighborhoods in Croix-des-Bouquets (coded separately) and in Marassa (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
Other: On 4 March 2024, in Trou-du-Nord, Nord-Est, in the morning, residents from Fort-Dauphinois and Truviens set up roadblocks for unknown reasons.

source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Property destruction: On 7 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, gang members set fire to several containers belonging to the so called Flamengo Company, in the Drouillard neighbourhood. Two power generators and motorcycles were burned. Overnight, gang members looted and set fire to a branch of the Unibank bank, in Damiens neighbourhood. According to residents, scenes of looting persisted in the bank branch until 8 March.

Security measures: Around 28 February 2024 (as reported), in Mirebalais, Centre, local authorities imposed a night curfew starting at 6 p.m. The measure was taken as a response to violence by gangsters from Fonds Cheval area.

On 4 March 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang clashed with members of the Chien Mechant Gang in Duval and Cite Doudoune neighborhoods. During clashes, a branch of the BNC bank was looted. Clashes between these gangs were also reported in Santo (coded separately) and Marassa (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

Other: On 29 February 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, roadblocks and barricades were erected up in the commune, including Lizon. This was likely to be the authorship of residents to prevent gang members from attacking their communities. These roadblocks were set up after a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader with the support of gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Haiti Standard; InSight Crime; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Trip Foumi
notes: On 2 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang fired shots against the National Palace (Champs de Mars) and assaulted the Civil Prison (a.k.a. National Penitentiary), in Centre Ville neighbourhood (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; GardaWorld; Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: Security measures: On 3 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, national authorities declared a 72-hour state of emergency in the Ouest department and a night curfew from 6 p.m. to 5 a.m. ending on 6 March. On 7 March, the curfew was renewed and additional night curfews were then established every 72 hours until 3 April, when it was extended for 10 days (until 10 April). Several 7-day extensions were later announced (first until 17 April, then until 24 April). As of 22 May, the curfew hours were from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. until 28 May. It was later extended up to 3 June. The state of emergency was extended up to 3 April and then up to 3 May. On 22 May, a new state of emergency was officially declared up to 8 June. Demonstrations on public roads were prohibited. These measures were taken as a response to a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). The decision aimed at restoring order and security and taking appropriate measures to regain control of the situation.
On 4 March 2024, in Belladere, Centre, in the morning, a mob of residents lynched the leader of the Salami Gang. 1 fatality.

Other: On 2 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, overnight, gunshots were heard as some videos showed several gang members coming back to their strongholds after having escaped from the Civil Prison, assaulted by other gangs moments before (coded separately). The gunshots were registered in areas such as Pele Simon, Cite Militaire, and Carrefour Drouillard. Barricades were also registered in different areas of Delmas.

On 3 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Saint Antoine/Lalue, Ouest, gang members set fire to the Poste Marchand police station, in Lalue neighbourhood. The police officers who were inside fled the premises. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole
notes: On 4 March 2024, in Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13, Ouest, gang members aligned to the Living Together gang-led initiative (a.k.a. Viv Ansanm gang) set fire to a police station in the Carrefour Aeroport neighbourhood. Several vehicles were burned. Policemen who were inside were forced to abandon the building. Police officers coming from Solino tried to expel the criminals, although they did not succeed. Residents living nearby fled their homes. Casualties unknown.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 29 February 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gang members (likely G-9 members due to ongoing coordinated attacks) attacked the National Old Age Insurance Office (ONA) in the Shada neighbourhood. No further details on the event were mentioned. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks against public institutions led by the G-9 Gang leader and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 4 March 2024, in Tabarre - Aeroport Toussaint Louverture, Ouest, gang members fired shots against the Toussaint Louverture International Airport and tried to occupy the airport's runway entering the compound through a hole in the airport's wall. Police and military forces deployed to reinforce security clashed with the gangsters, who aimed at preventing Prime Minister, Ariel Henry, from landing and returning to Haiti. The gang members were expelled. Moments later, the gang members set fire to a police checkpoint that had been installed to access the airport. Gunshots were heard in the Guy Malary Terminal, the National Police General Direction, and the Central Judicial Police Direction (Mais Gate/Clercine 2 neighbourhood). Gang members vandalized the MSC Plus company offices (HT Monquette neighbourhood). Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Progres; Jamaica Gleaner; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 8 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, police forces clashed with members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) as they attacked the National Palace and three police stations in Champs de Mars. Several gang members and people (unspecified affiliation) were killed. An unknown number of police officers were killed and injured. The criminals set fire to several vehicles at the Ministry of the Interior and Territorial Communities (Champs de Mars), although the police intervention prevented the burning of the building. In Bas Peu de Choses, the Ministry of National Education and Vocational Training (MENFP) was looted. Gunshots were heard in Turgeau, Poste Marchand, Pacot, Lalue, Canape-Vert, and Nazon. The attack on the National Palace was part of coordinated attacks by the G-9 Gang leader and the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 5 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Academie, Ouest, armed members of the Vitelhomme gang opened fire and vandalized the National Police Academy, located on the Freres Road (in Academie neighbourhood). Police forces intervened and repelled the attack. Casualties unknown.
On 5 March 2024, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, overnight, members of the 'Rezistans' socio-political organization held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: Property destruction: On 14 March 2024, in Santo, Ouest, members of the Canaan Gang looted and set fire to the house of the director general of the national police, in Santo 17 (La Plaine du Cul-de-Sac area). The property was empty at the moment of the attack. According to the police director, some politicians could be behind the arson attack. The G-9 Gang leader had threatened to attack him for collaborating with the government.
Other: On 11 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, residents set up roadblocks in Bas Delmas to prevent armed attacks in their communities.

Other: On 11 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, residents set up roadblocks near the Toussaint Louverture International Airport (Mais Gate/Clercine 2), to prevent armed attacks in their communities.

Non-violent activity: On 29 February 2024, in Santo, Ouest, gang members (likely G-9 gang members due to ongoing coordinated attacks) set up roadblocks to prevent police forces from entering the area.

Non-violent activity: On 29 February 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gang members (likely G-9 gang members due to ongoing coordinated attacks) set up roadblocks in the Shada neighbourhood to prevent police forces from entering the zone.

source: GardaWorld; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News St. Lucia; Trinidad and Tobago Guardian
notes: Other: On 11 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, Prime Minister (PM) Ariel Henry announced his resignation and that of his government, as well as that a Transition Presidential Council (TPC) would be formed (integrated by seven representatives from the main political organizations -Fanmi Lavalas and Pitit Desalin parties, among others-). The PM's decision came after gangs demanded his departure and carried out a set of coordinated attacks against multiple public and police facilities in the Ouest department since 29 February (coded separately). On 24 April, PM presented his official resignation in a letter signed in Los Angeles (US). The letter was released a day before the TPC swore in with the mission of choosing a new prime minister. Michel Patrick Boisvert, the Economy and Finance Minister, was chosen as the interim prime minister.

actor2: Police Forces of Haiti (2017-2024) Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP)
notes: On 13 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Laboule, Ouest, armed individuals riding a motorcycle shot and killed a BSAP police agent in Laboule neighbourhood (drive-by). 1 fatality.
Other: On 11 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Bas Delmas. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

source: AFP; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: On 14 March 2024, in Tabarre - Mais Gate/Clercine 2, Ouest, in the morning, gang members fired shots against the Toussaint Louverture International Airport, forcing airport employees to run away (Mais Gate/Clercine 2 neighbourhood). The attack occurred when workers were trying to repair the fence that gangs previously breached. As the gang members fired shots in the area, a police officer was injured by a stray bullet. He was the courtyard of police headquarters, near the airport. 1 injured.

Other: On 11 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard near the Toussaint Louverture International Airport (Mais Gate/Clercine 2) and in Croix des Mission. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 13 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, overnight, gunshots were heard in the Nazon neighbourhood. There is no information on the circumstances of the authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 13 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, overnight, gunshots were heard in Delmas 19 (Village W. Lamothe neighbourhood). Gunshots were also heard on Airport Road and Delmas 30 later in the day. Armed men were seen near Carrefour Aeroport. There is no information on the circumstances of the gunshots.

source: Haiti Progres; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 15 March 2024, between Delmas and Petionville (coded to Port-au-Prince - Petionville), Ouest, members of several socio-political organizations held a march to decry the interference of the CARICOM and the international community in Haiti's internal affairs. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires and threw stones. The march had initiated on the Delmas Road. It had been called by the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party and the National Awakening for the Sovereignty of Haiti movement.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: On 13 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Academie, Ouest, overnight, the Vitelhomme Gang attacked residents and clashed with police forces in the vicinity of the Police National Academy and also in the Vivy Mitchell neighbourhood (coded separately). Gunshots were heard. Casualties unknown.

On 19 March 2024, in Carrefour Zaboca, Grande-Anse, a group of individuals claiming to support Guy Philippe (figure from the political opposition) set up barricades on the National Road 7 (nature of barricades unspecified), interrupting road traffic in the area. The motivations behind the protest action were not clarified.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Vi Free Press
notes: On 18 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bicentenaire, Ouest, police and military forces, together with private security guards, shot and killed at least three gang members as they intervened to repeal an attack against the Bank of the Republic of Haiti, located on Pavee street (Bicentenaire). At least one police officer was shot and injured during the clash. Another version stated that there were four fatalities among the gangsters and two injured among security forces. At least 3 fatalities, at least 1 injured.
On 19 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Savanne Pistaches, Ouest, police forces killed a gang leader in Savane Pistache neighbourhood. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 20 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bourdon, Ouest, in the morning, police forces shot and killed three gang members as they intervened to repel gang attacks in Delmas 40 B and on Reinbold Street (Bourdon neighbourhood). As the officers moved in a police patrol, gangsters moving in two vehicles and opened fire on them, leading to a clash as they returned fire (drive-by). The gangs' vehicles were seized. 3 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 20 March 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 40b, Ouest, in the morning, a person was shot and killed in Delmas 40 B. There is no information on the perpetrators, though reports suggest that this attack is related to gang violence and to clashes recorded in this same area (coded separately). 1 fatality.

On 19 March 2024, in the commune of Delmas, Ouest, several dozens of militants from different socio-political structures, including signatories of the 'Reveil National' movement (National Awakening for the Sovereignty of Haiti), held a protest to decry the involvement of the international community in Haiti's political affairs.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: On 20 March 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 17, Ouest, gang members shot and killed a police officer in Delmas 72 area (Delmas 17 neighborhood). The affiliation of the perpetrators was not clarified, although the killing was described as a gang reprisal for a previous police intervention against the G-9 Gang fief in Delmas 6 (coded separately). 1 fatality.

source: Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 21 March 2024, in Delmas - Aviation Militaire - Sous Piste, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members near the headquarters of the Intervention and Order Maintenance Corps (CIMO), located in the Aviation Militaire - Sous Piste neighbourhood. In nearby Delmas 19 (Delmas 19/Mackandal), a journalist man was shot and injured by the stray bullets. He died on 24 March. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vi Free Press
notes: On 17 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Juvenat, Ouest, overnight, armed gang members on motorcycles opened fire on civilians on the Panamerican Avenue (likely around Petion Ville - Juvenat) , killing more than 10 people (up to 15 according to other sources) (drive-by). Their corpses were found scattered on the streets in the morning of 18 March. One was found inside a pick-up truck vehicle. At least two of the victims were identified as vendors. One deceased was killed while sleeping. Also, a body was found in Juvenat neighborhood, causing a roadblock. At least 10 fatalities

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 18 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Laboule, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they attacked residents, private properties, and companies' facilities in Laboule, Thomassin (coded separately), Boutilliers (coded separately), and Pelerin neighborhoods (coded separately). Around a dozen people were killed and several were injured. One fatal victim was a woman described as the head of Women's Classical School. A bank branch, a gas station, and several houses were attacked and looted, including that of a judge at the Superior Court of Auditors and Administrative Litigation, who had been evacuated before the attack (in Laboule 18). In Laboule 12, gunshots were heard as the gangsters stole some vehicles. The criminals had arrived in three vehicles. Other versions stated that they used four trucks and 27 motorcycles. Several injured, at least 12 fatalities, split across 4 events, 3 fatalities coded.

Non-violent activity: Around 18 March 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, gang members set up roadblocks in the Thomassin neighbourhood to prevent police forces from entering the area.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 19 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Thomassin, Ouest, police forces clashed with the (Kraze Barye Gang) Vitelhomme Gang (supported by the Grand-Ravine Gang) in the Thomassin neighbourhood as they attacked Laboule, Metivier, and Peguy-Ville neighborhoods, among others (all coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 19 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, armed residents identified as members of the Bwa Kale movement lynched at least two gang members of the Kraze Barye Gang (Vitelhomme Gang) and Grand-Ravine Gang. The lynching occurred amid clashes between police officers and gang members as they attacked Thomassin, Laboule, Metivier, and Peguy-Ville neighborhoods, among others (coded separately). At least 2 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 20 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Delmas 95, Ouest, police forces shot and killed the leader of the Mackandal Gang and at least two accomplices as they intervened to repel gang attacks against the population in Delmas 95 and Delmas 97. Gunshots were heard along the Corlette Road (Peguy-Ville), Delmas 95, and Pernier neighbourhood as members of the Vitelhomme Gang (Kraze Barye Gang) were seen circulating through the streets. Also, gunshots were heard near the Police Academy. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots. According to residents, more than 10 gangsters were killed on 20 March. A number of them were killed by mobs of residents (coded separately). At least 3 fatalities.

Other: Around 20 March 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, civilians set up roadblocks near Rebecca and Louverture streets, and near the Panamerican Avenue to prevent gang attacks in their communities. They also erected barricades in Thomassin 32, 38, and 40. Also, report indicates that vehicles were also used to set up roadblocks in Debrosse near Juvenat. This happened after several days of gang attacks against residential neighborhoods in the Petionville commune (coded separately).

source: Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 21 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Morne Hercule, Ouest, police forces shot and killed the leader of the Delmas 95 Gang and two accomplices during a clash in Delmas 66 (Morne Hercule neighborhood). A photo of the gang leader's dead body was shared on social media. One source stated that the deceased was decapitated and then burned (likely by a mob of residents). His killing took place three weeks after he had escaped from the National Penitentiary following a gang assault against the prison's facilities on 2 March (coded separately). Gunshots were heard in the commune. 3 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Vi Free Press
notes: On 29 March 2024, in Mirebalais, Centre, a mob of dozens of residents lynched and burned alive two arrested men who were in custody at a police station in the Desvarieux residential area. One of the victims was a police officer. The other was a former employee of the Provisional Electoral Council (CEP). The mobsters identified them as gang members after both men had been arrested for trafficking of ammunition. Police forces fired shots into the air to prevent the attack, with no success. It was described as a case of vigilante justice by affiliates of the Bwa Kale movement. 2 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 23 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, in the morning, police forces clashed with gang members as they intervened to expel the criminals from the Departmental Operation and Intervention Brigade (BOID) facilities, located in the Fort National neighbourhood. The gangsters set fire to several vehicles and houses in the area. Several corpses were found scattered on Martin Luther King and Poupelard streets (Nazon), in Bois Verna, Champs de Mars, and Jeremie square (Bas Peu de Choses) (all coded separately). Gunshots were heard in Christ-Roi and Canape-Vert. Casualties unknown

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; Vi Free Press
notes: On 25 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, gang members attacked, looted, and set fire to several buildings on the Monseigneur Guilloux street, including at least five pharmacies, several private clinics, an unspecified number of private residences, business establishments, and several vehicles. The National School of Arts (in Morne a Tuf) was looted and some works were stolen. At least one person was killed. His/her dead body was found lying on the street. At least 1 fatality.

On 25 March 2024, in Cite Soleil - Sarthe, Ouest, in the morning, armed gang members shot and killed a police officer and injured two others as they opened fire on a private vehicle they were moving in, in Carrefour Vincent (Sarthe neighbourhood). 1 fatality, 2 injured.

source: Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 23 March 2024, in Tabarre - Clercine II/Carrefour Clercine, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they intervened to expel the criminals from the vicinity of the Motorized Intervention Brigade's facilities (BIM), and from the Tabarre police station (both in Clercine II/Carrefour Clercine neighbourhood). The police station had been shot by the gangsters moments before. According to residents, the gangsters tried to take control of an Armed Forces' antenna, and of the Headquarters of the General Directorate of the National Police of Haiti, near the International Airport. Gunshots were heard in Butte Boyer. The gang members were described as affiliates of the Living Together gang initiative (Viv Asanm). Casualties unknown.

On 26 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Kay Colette, Ouest, five members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) were shot and killed amidst armed clashes with police forces on the Freres Road in the Collette area. The same day, two gang members were killed near the Telele market in Jacquet Toto by members of the population (coded separately). 5 fatalities.

On 25 March 2024, in Tabarre - Croix des Missions, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members. The officers were ambushed as they intervened to clear the Rails Road. Clashes between the police and gang members were also registered in Cazeau (coded separately). Gunshots were heard in Butte Boyer and Carrefour Clercine zones. Casualties unknown.

On 30 March 2024, in Belladere, Centre, a mob of residents killed a man who was described as a prisoner who had escaped jail after gang members assaulted the two major Haitian prisons on 2 March (coded separately). He had been involved in the killing of a police officer. 1 fatality.

On 3 April 2024, in Limbe, Nord, several dozens of women, called by several women's organizations, held a march to decry violence, exclusion and discrimination against Haitian women. The mobilizations was held on the occasion of the National Haitian Women's Day.

source: GardaWorld; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: On 29 March 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, armed gang members occupied and set fire to several buildings at the Digneron Industrial Park, including a 96,000 square foot warehouse containing raw materials. Industrial machines and offices were destroyed. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Progres; Jamaica Observer; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vi Free Press
notes: On 1 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, police and military forces clashed with the Base 5 Secondes Gang near the National Palace. During clashes, the gang members set fire to a police armored vehicle on the Monseigneur Guilloux street, injuring at least four officers who were inside. Scores of civilians got trapped amidst the crossfire. A person whose body was found on the street with gunshot wounds was likely to have been killed in the crossfire. The armed gangsters looted and robbed the National Library (Centre-Ville neighbourhood) (coded separately). They also entered the Saint-Martial Minor Seminary School (Poste Marchand) (coded separately), burned several vehicles and destroyed some materials, although no casualties among the present colleagues were mentioned. Gunshots were heard on Lamarre street, and on Capois street, as well as in Christ-Roi coming from Nazon. The gang members were described as affiliates of the Living Together gang-led coalition led by the G-9 Gang. At least 1 fatality, at least 4 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Trinidad and Tobago Guardian
notes: On 2 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in the vicinity of the National Palace as these ones opened fire on the institution. A number of gangsters entered the premises of the Haiti State University Hospital (HUEH) (a.k.a. Port-au-Prince General Hospital) and shot at the officers from the hospital's facilities. Smoke rose from the Finance Ministry building. Police forces fired tear gas to disperse the scores of civilians who were nearby. During clashes, a moto taxi driver was shot and killed by a stray bullet in front of the Blaise Pascal School, in Bois Verna neighbourhood (coded separately). Gunshots were also heard in Christ-Roi. The gang members were described as affiliates of the Living Together gang-led coalition (Viv Ansanm gang). No casualties.

source: Alterpresse; GardaWorld; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 1 April 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, police forces in an armored vehicle clashed with gang members in Bas Delmas as part of efforts to expel the criminals from the area. A man was shot and killed in Delmas 30 as gunshots were heard in this area, and in Toussaint Louverture Boulevard, as well as in Carrefour Drouillard. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; GardaWorld; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 2 April 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, overnight, gang members tried to enter the Delmas Peace Court building. Police forces intervened and prevented it. Gunshots were heard in nearby Delmas 30 and 28. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: On 1 April 2024, in Petion Ville - Meyotte, Ouest, police forces shot and killed at least four members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) during clashes in the Meyotte neighbourhood. Gunshots were heard in Freres, Vivy Mitchell, Corlette (Meyotte), Metivier, and Doco areas. At least 4 fatalities.

On 2 April 2024, in Petion Ville - Meyotte, Ouest, police forces clashed with members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) in the Meyotte neighbourhood. Several firearms and ammunition were seized. Casualties unknown.

On 2 April 2024, in Petion Ville - Meyotte, Ouest, police forces shot and killed a gang leader during a security operation in the Meyotte neighbourhood. The victim was described as the leader of a gang from Cite Doudoune (in Croix-des-Bouquets). 1 fatality.

On 1 April 2024, in Tabarre - Clercine II/Carrefour Clercine, Ouest, gang members attacked the Carrefour Clercine neighbourhood. No further details were mentioned. Another report indicates that there were clashes near the Comme Il Faut premises (Clercine II neighborhood). Gunshots were also heard in other neighborhoods, such as Butte Boyer, Croix des Missions, Village Thomas Theodat, and Cazeau, as well as near the police station and city hall. Casualties unknown.

On 4 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals kidnapped a man and his wife. He was said to be a known meteorologist. The woman was released on the same day of the kidnapping, while he remained captive until 8 April. His release happened under unknown circumstances. There is no information on the perpetrators, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related.

On 5 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, overnight, unidentified individuals looted and set fire to the house of a former deputy, located on the Enterrement street (Morne a Tuf neighbourhood). Casualties unknown.

On 12 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gang members shot and killed a police officer on the Toussaint Louverture Boulevard, a.k.a. the Airport Road. The attack took place as he was coming back from a relative's house (coded as off-duty). 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News St. Lucia; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Trinidad and Tobago Guardian; Vi Free Press
notes: On 8 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in the vicinity of the National Palace as the gangsters attacked civilian facilities in the area and around, including the Bird School on the Enterrement street, in Centre Ville neighbourhood (coded separately). Material damages were mentioned at the school. Police forces used megaphones to inform citizens to leave the area. Gunshots were heard throughout the day in Nazon and Lalue neighborhoods, as well as in other areas such as Alerte street, Sylvio Cator Stadium (Morne a Tuf neighborhood), Marche Salomon (Bas Peu de Choses neighborhood), Bolosse Avenue. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: Other: On 12 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) was created with the mission of restoring order in Haiti and leading a 22-month political transition until a new President is elected in February 2026. The PTC's constitution by a government decree was contested as its publication in Le Moniteur, the official journal of the Republic of Haiti, took place before authorization by Ariel Henry's government. The council, integrated by seven members of the main political actors and parties and two observer actors, was formed after Prime Minister Ariel Henry announced his resignation and that of his government on 11 March (coded separately). On 16 April, a second decree was published with the nomination of the nine PTC members. On 30 April, the PTC members elected Edgard Leblanc as President of the PTC and Fritz Belizaire as Prime Minister. On 7 May, the PTC members voted in favor of adopting a rotating presidency for the institution. On 28 May, Dr. Garry Conille was elected as President of the Government of Transition. On 11 June, the PTC appointed Garry Conille as Prime Minister of the transitional government and its 14 ministers.

On 10 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, police forces clashed with armed group members in the vicinity of the Haiti State University Hospital, in the Champs de Mars neighbourhood. During clashes, a health worker was killed as he attended the facilities of the hospital. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; InSight Crime; Loop News Haiti; Loop News St. Lucia; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Trinidad and Tobago Guardian
notes: On 4 April 2024, off the Coast of Port-au-Prince, Ouest, masked members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang), together with affiliates of the Taliban Gang, abducted the occupants of a cargo ship known as 'Magalie' and hijacked 10,000 sacks of rice as the vessel was leaving the Varreux Terminal (La Saline neighbourhood) with Cap-Haitien as its destination. The cargo was recovered by police forces on 6 April (coded separately). The captain was killed. The victims' whereabouts are unknown. 1 fatality.
Other: On 8 April 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Duval and Tabarre 27 zones. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 8 April 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, gunshots were heard. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole
notes: Other: Around 8 April 2024 (month of), in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, authorities demolished at least 150 houses located near the Toussaint Louverture Airport (Mais Gate/Clercine 2) which had been used by gang members to fired at the airport's facilities in early March (coded separately).
