The measure aimed at reinforcing the airport's security. More than 350 properties had been demolished on 10 May.
Non-violent activity: On 8 April 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, armed gang members set up roadblocks with barricades in the Lilavois neighbourhood.

Other: On 8 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard near Carrefour Aeroport, as well as in Delmas 30, Delmas 32, and Delmas 19. The perpetrators were likely to be gang members, who had assaulted these areas in recent weeks.

On 11 April 2024, in Petion Ville - Desir-Gabriel, Ouest, a group of citizens held a sit-in protest in front of the National Press of Haiti headquarters, located in the Desir-Gabriel neighbourhood, against the process of establishing a national Presidential Transitional Council. Protesters demanded the institution not to publish the names of the members of the Council. There was a known lawyer among the protesters.

On 12 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, scores of citizens held a protest against the constitution of a Presidential Transitional Council and against international interference in Haiti's political affairs. Protesters claimed to be supporters of Guy Philippe and demanded him to become Haiti's provisional president.

On 29 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) entered the Vincent Gymnasium facilities (in Bas Peu de Choses neighbourhood), kidnapped two girls, and raped them. The victims were part of residents who had fled their homes and had taken refuge at the gymnasium.

On 3 April 2024, in Gressier - Cite Gressier, Ouest, several dozens of women, described as 'Madan Sara' vendors, held a march with banners to the Gressier police station (Gressier neighbourhood) to decry increasing insecurity that they face when developing their work.

On 15 April 2024, in Mirebalais, Centre, in the morning, members of the population killed an individual (methods unknown) and burned his body. The victim had a firearm and ammunition in his possession. The motivation for the attack was not clarified, although it is suspected to be a case of vigilante justice. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole
notes: On 18 April 2024, in Carrefour - Arcachon/Mon-Repos, Ouest, more than 200 Ti Bwa gang members attacked the Mon Repos and Waney Bijou neighborhoods (coded separately) as they carried out an offensive aiming at and taking control of the commune. Seven civilians and a police officer were killed as the gangsters opened fire in the Waney 93 area. There were several injured by gunshots. The criminals assaulted the Omega police station (in Bas Thorland neighbourhood, coded separately) and released the prisoners. Weapons and materials belonging to the police were stolen. Two officers who were present were forced to leave. Another version stated that they were kidnapped and released moments later in Bizoton. Clashes between the gangsters and the police were mentioned. The gangsters forced drivers to stop their march in the Brochette and Lamentin neighborhoods, among others. One source stated that the offensive aimed at establishing a new gang leader in the Cote Plage neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.

Around 14 April 2024 (weekend of), near Gros-Morne, Artibonite, an unknown number of individuals perpetrated several kidnappings on the road leading to the Tibwadom locality. There is no information on the perpetrators, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

Other: On 15 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, overnight, gunshots were heard in the Carrefour Aeroport neighbourhood. The situation persisted until 16 April. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.
On 14 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, in the morning, members of vigilante brigades killed a member of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang). 1 fatality.

On 9 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, armed gang members assaulted a journalist man and stole him a motorcycle, money, and a telephone. No further details were mentioned. There were no fatalities.
Looting: On 17 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, overnight, armed gang members looted several deposits and companies' facilities in Bas Delmas.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 20 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, overnight, gang members looted and vandalized the Faculty of Medicine and Pharmacy of the UEH University, located on the Mgr Guilloux street (Champs de Mars neighbourhood). The criminals looted the faculty's cafe, stole a bus, solar panels, and medical items. During the gang assault, which aimed at using the university's facility as base to confront police forces, a person was shot and killed in nearby Capois street. Looting scenes at the faculty persisted at least until 21 April. The perpetrators were described as affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative (Viv Ansanm gang). 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 21 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, police and military forces clashed with gang members in the vicinity of the National Palace (Champs de Mars neighbourhood) and in nearby Lalue and Bois Verna neighborhoods (coded separately). During clashes, several people were shot and injured by the stray bullets near the Ministry of Culture and Communications (Pacot neighbourhood). The gang offensive was described as an attempt to prevent the installation of a Presidential Transitional Council. One source suggested that the criminals were affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative (Viv Ansanm gang). Gunshots were also heard in La Saline neighborhood and in Waaf Jeremie neighborhood (Cite Soleil). Several injured.

source: Haiti Progres; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: On 22 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, police forces clashed with gang members in the vicinity of the National Palace, in Champs de Mars neighbourhood. Gunshots were heard near the Faculty of Medicine and Pharmacy of the UEH University and near the Haiti State University Hospital (HUEH) (a.k.a. Port-au-Prince General Hospital), in Champs de Mars neighbourhood too. The gang offensive was described as an attempt to take control of the National Palace to prevent the installation of the Presidential Transitional Council. Casualties unknown.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp); The St. Kitts Nevis Observer
notes: On 24 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in the Champs de Mars neighbourhood. The officers fired tear gas in the vicinity of the National Palace to disperse those individuals approaching the area. Gunshots were also heard near the Sylvio Cator Stadium (Morne a Tuf neighborhood). There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots. Casualties unknown.

source: AFP; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 25 April 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members on Delmas 24 street as the criminals attacked and set fire to at least eight residents' houses there and in nearby Delmas 28 and Delmas 30 neighborhoods. During clashes, an unspecified number of gang members were killed and at least 10 civilians were injured by the gunshots. A civilian who was injured claimed to have been shot by police forces. This happened while a ceremony was being held for the installation of a National Transitional Council -TPC-, in Port-au-Prince commune (coded separately). The gang members were described as affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative (Viv Ansanm gang). They had claimed to oppose the installation of the TPC. Gunshots were also heard in Carrefour Aeroport and Carrefour Drouillard. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3, at least 10 injured.

On 15 April 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 75, Ouest, police forces shot and killed two men in Delmas 75 neighbourhood. It happened as the victims, who were riding a motorcycle, tried to flee a police checkpoint on the street. 2 fatalities.

On 23 April 2024, in Pilate, Nord, in the morning, an unknown number of armed individuals shot and killed a peace judge man as they opened fire on the motorcycle he was travelling on between the Palan and Nan Siklet localities. The judge was being driven to the Pilate Peace Court (workplace) when the attack took place. There is no information on the driver's health state. 1 fatality.

On 23 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, in the morning, an unknown number of armed individuals attacked the head of the Jean-Jacques Dessalines high school on the Christophe Avenue (in Bas Peu de Choses neighbourhood). The victim was injured to the head (nature of the wounds unspecified). The motivation for the attack is unknown. 1 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 21 April 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 19/Mackandal, Ouest, gang members clashed with police forces as they looted and set fire to houses in Bas Delmas, in Delmas 19, and in Carrefour Aeroport neighborhoods (coded separately). One source suggested that the criminals were affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative (Viv Ansanm gang). Gunshots were also heard in Delmas 32. Casualties unknown.

actor2: Police Forces of Haiti (2017-2024) Prison Guards
notes: On 28 April 2024, in Hinche, Centre, in the morning, a group of inmates, armed with white weapons, rioted at the Hinche jail as part of an escape attempt. Prison guards, supported by a National Police Special Unit, intervened and clashed with the prisoners for several hours. Two inmates were shot and killed, while at least seven others and three police officers were injured. The riot took place two days after the prison agents decided not to receive food for the prisoners, who engaged in a strike movement to demand proper treatment. 2 fatalities, at least 10 injured.
Other: On 30 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Solino neighbourhood. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.

source: Alterpresse; GardaWorld; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Vi Free Press
notes: On 1 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, overnight, members of the Living-Together gang-led initiative (coded separately), led by the G-9 Gang, attacked the Solino and Nazon neighborhoods (coded separately) and burned residents' houses. Police forces were deployed and clashed with the criminals. There were several injured by the gunshots (affiliation unknown). Gunshots were heard throughout the day and overnight. Some residents fled their homes. According to one source, the criminals were members of the Bel Air Gang, although this was not confirmed by other sources. Several injured.
On 30 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gang members set fire to residents' houses in Bas Delmas. Gunshots were heard in the area. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; GardaWorld; Haiti Press Network; Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Vi Free Press
notes: On 1 May 2024, in Delmas - Cite Numero Un, Ouest, members of the Living-Together gang-led initiative (coded separately), led by the G-9 Gang, attacked Bas Delmas, Delmas 18 (in Cite Numero Un neighbourhood), and Delmas 24 (in Delmas 28 neighbourhood, coded separately). Some residents' houses were burned. Police forces were deployed and clashed with the criminals. There were several injured by the gunshots (affiliation unknown). Gunshots were heard throughout the day and overnight. According to one source, the criminals were members of the Bel Air Gang, although this was not confirmed by other sources. Casualties unknown.

On 3 May 2024, in Delmas - Hatt Thomas, Ouest, employees of the Senate of the Republic held a sit-in protest in front of the Delmas 33 civil prison, in Hatt Thomas neighbourhood, to decry the arrest of the institution's General Secretary over corruption accusations.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 10 May 2024, in Pont Sonde, Artibonite, overnight, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang clashed with affiliates of the Jean-Denis Gang as the first ones occupied the National Road 1 and attacked residents in Pont Sonde and in nearby Moreau Paye area. Two civilians were killed and a Jean-Denis Gang member was injured. Several residents were abducted. The victims' whereabouts are unknown. 2 fatalities, 1 injured.

Other: Around 20 March 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, a roadblock was reported in Delmas 60 neighbourhood. This is part of a set of roadblock set in nearby roads in Petionville commune (coded separately).

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 7 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, police forces shot and killed two gang members during an intervention to thwart a kidnapping attempt on the Marcelin street (Bas Peu de Choses neighbourhood). The intended victim of the abduction was rescued by the police. The gangsters travelled in a vehicle with no plate. The deceased's accomplices managed to run away. 2 fatalities.

On 9 May 2024, in Petion Ville - Centre Ville (Sud), Ouest, employees of the commune's city hall held a demonstration outside the institution to demand the payment of due salaries. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires on the Gregoire Street, in the Centre Ville (Sud) neighbourhood.

Around 10 May 2024 (week of), in Tabarre - Truitier, Ouest, gang members abducted an unknown number of truck drivers working for the Tabarre city hall, in the Truitier neighbourhood. Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 10 May 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, a group of police officers, supported by residents, held a protest in front of the Departmental Police Directorate premises demanding the replacement of the departmental director of the Grande-Anse police. Protesters blocked access to the Grande-Anse police station.

On 6 May 2024, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, students from the Nord-Est Public University (UPNEF) held a march demanding the departure of the institution's administrative council members, among other claims. Protesters used chains to block the entrance of the rectorate.

source: Alterpresse; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Vi Free Press
notes: On 7 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Martissant, Ouest, armed individuals in a police armored tank opened fire on a public transport minibus with 80 passengers on board, in the Martissant neighbourhood. Four people were killed and several others were injured. The attackers were suspected to be Ti Bwa gang members, as the armored tank was identified as a stolen vehicle by members of this gang on 12 October 2022 (coded separately). According to another version, the event was a clash between police officers in an armored vehicle and armed individuals that used the minibus as a shield. At least 4 fatalities, and at least 10 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Vi Free Press
notes: On 8 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bois Verna, Ouest, in the morning, armed gang members shot and killed a police officer woman as she tried to resist a kidnapping attempt, on the Camille Leon Street (in Bois Verna neighbourhood). The attack took place moments after the officer had left her girl at school (likely off-duty). The attackers stole the officer's firearm and fled the scene on a motorcycle. 1 fatality.

On 14 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, the Belair Gang attacked residents in the Fort National and Solino neighborhoods (coded separately) and clashed with police forces, who intervened and expelled the criminals from these areas. Several civilians and several gang members were killed. Houses were set on fire. The gang members were described as affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3, split across 2 events, coded as 1.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 10 May 2024, in Gressier - Cite Gressier, Ouest, overnight, armed members of the Grand-Ravine Gang set fire to the Gressier police station (Cite Gressier neighbourhood). A police vehicle, the houses of an assessor mayor, and a police, as well as a school building were also burned. Police forces intervened and clashed with the gang members in the vicinity of the police station, although they were unable to expel the criminals, who took control of the facility. A police officer was shot and injured. A public transport driver and several civilians were wounded by the bullets. In Bo Lanme area, a 53-year-old woman was killed in front of her two minor daughters at her home. The girls were later raped by the gang members. In Colombier 9 area, gang members looted a property and stole some items. Members of the Bout Ba Gang also participated in the clashes near the Gressier market, and a man was shot and killed as he received a gunshot to the head. Thousands of residents fled their homes to take refuge elsewhere. The gang members are part of the Living Together gang-led initiative. During the offensive, which last until 11 May, several of them were recorded expressing their rejection to the Multilateral Support Security Mission (MMSS). On 12 May, police forces, supported by the Miragoane police commissioner, and BSAP agents, regained control of the police station after the gang members had abandoned it. At least 2 fatalities, at least 2 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 13 May 2024, in Carrefour - Cote Plage, Ouest, armed gang members shot and killed a police officer man in the Cote Plage neighbourhood and took his body to an unknown location. Several people who were around were shot and injured. Several sources stated that the dead officer was a former member of the so called 'Caravane Group' and that the attack was in reprisal for having left the organization. The 'Caravane Group' was described as integrated by police officers aiming at fighting gang violence. Some of its members were said to have joined the gangsters. 1 fatality, several injured.

On 15 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, overnight, the Belair Gang attacked residents in the Fort National neighbourhood. A number of houses were set on fire. Many residents fled their homes. The gang members were described as affiliates of the Living-Together gang-alliance. Casualties unknown.

On 13 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, Belair gang members attacked residents in the Fort National neighbourhood, shooting and killing at least two civilians and injuring several others. Several houses were set on fire. The attack was part of an offensive aiming at taking control of the neighbourhood. The gang members were described as affiliates of the Living Together gang-led alliance. Gunshots were heard in the Solino neighbourhood. At least 2 fatalities, several injured.

On 16 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, affiliates of the Living-Together gang-led alliance (a.k.a. Viv Ansanm Gang) attacked residents in the Fort National neighbourhood. Houses were set on fire. The criminals also targeted state facilities in the Champs de Mars neighbourhood (the Ministry of the Interior and the Finances Palace) (coded separately). In the Centre Ville neighbourhood, they assaulted the Superior Court of Account and Administrative Disputes and stole some materials. They fled moments before the police arrived. Several nearby buildings, including the Palace of Ministries (on the Reunion street) and an Adventist Protestant Church (in Morne a Tuf neighbourhood) were looted and vandalized. Gunshots were heard in Fort National, Poste Marchand, and Poupelard (Port-au-Prince - Saint Antoine/Lalue neighborhood). Casualties unknown.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vant Bef Info
notes: On 13 May 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, in the morning, a group of individuals held a demonstration at the customs office to decry high clearance costs and against the sending of a commission in charge of strengthening the customs' control capacities. Demonstrators blocked access to the office and threatened employees and the members of the mentioned commission. Overnight, the rioters set fire to the customs main barrier.

On 18 May 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in the commune. Clashes took place a day after the 400 Mawozo Gang used an excavator to destroy the Croix-des-Bouquets police station and other facilities (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 19 May 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, police forces clashed with gang members in the commune. Clashes took place after the 400 Mawozo Gang used an excavator to destroy the Croix-des-Bouquets police station and other facilities on 17 May (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 23 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in the commune. Casualties unknown.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 19 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, police forces shot and killed several gang members during an anti-gang operation in the commune. Several firearms and other items were seized. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 21 May 2024, in Cite Soleil - Pont Rouge, Ouest, members of the Living-Together gang-led initiative (a.k.a. Viv Ansanm Gang) attacked a police station in the Pont Rouge neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.
On 22 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Pacot, Ouest, an unknown number of armed individuals shot and killed a businessman on the N Avenue, in the Pacot neighbourhood. Motivation unknown. 1 fatality.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 20 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, armed gang members killed several civilians in the commune and set fire to houses. Among the victims, there was a 60-year-old man who was killed at his home, in an area known as 'Segressier'. The body was found by his daughter, who was later raped by the gang members (coded separately). The gang members beat up several family members and killed an 83-year-old woman who was unable to flee the property. Her body was found at the house three days later. At least 2 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: Property destruction: On 17 May 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, overnight, the 400 Mawozo Gang used an excavator to destroy the Croix-des-Bouquets police station and the Civil Prison building, both located next to each other. The prison's facilities were empty since thousands of inmates were released during a gang assault on 2 March (coded separately). The scene was recorded on video and shared on social media on 19 May. The gang members were described as affiliates of the Living-Together gang-led initiative (a.k.a. Viv Ansanm Gang).

source: Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 20 May 2024, in Mirebalais, Centre, a mob of residents lynched two women and a man who had been arrested by the police earlier that day. The victims, who were taken from a detention centre, were described as members of a gang. The lynching was perpetrated by affiliates of the Bwa Kale Movement. 3 fatalities.

Other: On 21 May 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the area. The circumstances of the gunshots were not clarified, although likely these were related to gang-actions. They were seen in nearby Santo trying to set up roadblocks and in Hatte Lathan, where they burned a police station (coded separately).

Non-violent activity: On 21 May 2024, in Santo, Ouest, armed gang members were seen trying to set up roadblocks. A truck was used to barricade a road. Burning tires were registered and forced street vendors to flee Santo 17 and 19.

On 20 May 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, a group of individuals held a protest outside the customs office to decry high customs costs and against the a training commission that was sent by the main custom direction to strengthened controls. The mobilization was staged as a ceremony was being held inside to name a new head of the office.

On 14 June 2024, in Grande Plaine, Artibonite, around 30 members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang riding motorcycles set fire to around 10 houses and killed four residents in the village. Sources stated that the gang members came from Tibwadon area. Earlier that day, these same gang members had killed six residents during an attack in nearby Terre Neuve (coded separately). These attacks resulted in more than 10 fatalities, at least 15 injured, and around 20 houses burned between Terre Neuve and Grande Plaine. At least 4 fatalities, several injured.

On 14 June 2024, in Terre Neuve, Artibonite, around 30 members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang riding motorcycles attacked residents in the Lagon communal section, shooting and killing six civilians and injuring a woman. Among the fatal victims, there were an Evangelical pastor from the Bethel Church (also described as head of a school), and two other teachers. The religious man had been kidnapped moments before being killed. The house of a former coordinator of the regional Board of Directors of the Municipal Section (CASEC) was set on fire. After the attack, the gangsters left the commune and killed four other civilians in nearby Grande Plaine (coded separately). These attacks resulted in more than 10 fatalities, at least 15 injured, and around 20 houses burned between Terre Neuve and Grande Plaine. At least 6 fatalities, at least 1 injured.

Other: On 14 June 2024, in Terre Neuve, Artibonite, civilians set up barricades near the Lagon communal section to resist gang members trying to enter their communities. The barricades were erected as Tibwadom gang members attacked residents in the area (coded separately).

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 12 June 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in Bas Delmas as they carried out an anti-gang operation launched in response to the killing of three police officers in Delmas 18 on 9 June (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 16 June 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 33, Ouest, overnight, an unknown number of armed masked individuals dressed in police uniforms entered a property in the Delmas 33 neighbourhood and killed three men and a woman. They were brothers and she was a cousin of them. The motivation for the attack was not clarified, although several individuals close to the victims claimed that they were targeted due to their origin. It is known that they had fled Delmas 9 due to the Viv Ansamn Gang violence. 4 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: Around 3 June 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, an unknown number of armed individuals killed three police officers and injured a fourth one while they were on duty on the Freres Road. 3 fatalities, 1 injured.
On 15 June 2024, in Saint-Louis du Sud, Sud, overnight, police forces shot and killed a gang member during a security operation in an area known as 'Mon Zoranje'. 1 fatality.

source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 27 May 2024, in Gressier - Fierte Ville, Ouest, armed members of the 103 Zombies Gang clashed with police forces in the Colombier area (Fierte Ville neighbourhood). Clashes took place after the criminals threw Molotov cocktails and set fire to a broken down police vehicle on the National Road 2. The vehicle had been abandoned by the officers moments before. Several sources stated that a police officer was injured amidst the clashes, while residents claimed that he was killed together with several gang members. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 29 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, in the morning, armed gang members on a motorcycle shot and killed a teacher man and head of the School 'Sisters Saint Mary of the Angels' on the Capois street, where the institution is located (Bas Peu de Choses neighbourhood) (drive-by). The victim was said to be driving next to the school when he got shot and lost the control of the vehicle, crashing with a house. According to several sources, the shooting happened as the victim tried to resist a kidnapping attempt. The perpetrators fled the scene. 1 fatality.

On 30 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they attacked residents and set fire to houses in the Solino neighbourhood. Gunshots were heard for several hours. According to witnesses, several gang members were killed and some residents were injured. One of the deceased gangsters was killed by a mob of residents (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 30 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, a mob of residents killed a gang member in the Solino neighbourhood as police forces clashed with the criminals after they attacked residents and their houses in the area (coded separately). 1 fatality.

Other: On 2 June 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Delmas 75 neighbourhood. A group of armed individuals wearing police uniforms were seen in the area. There were thought to be the shooters.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 2 June 2024, in Belle-Anse, Sud-Est, a mob of residents captured and lynched an armed man in the Mare-Briole neighbourhood. The attack took place moments after the victim had shot and injured a man as he opened fire on a crowd and tried to flee from the police. The firearm was seized. 1 fatality.

Around 3 June 2024 (as reported), in Cerca-Carvajal, Centre, two brothers were stabbed to death with machetes and their bodies were found in the village. The motivation for the attack was said to be a land dispute. 2 fatalities.

On 3 June 2024, in Petit Trou de Nippes, Nippes, police forces shot and killed a gang member and arrested three others during a security operation aiming at seizing them and preventing them from attacking the Anse-a-Veau civil prison in support of a local gang. The criminals belonged to a gang from Mariani. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: On 9 June 2024, in Delmas - Cite Numero Un, Ouest, members of the Living Together gang-led initiative (a.k.a. Viv Ansanm Gang) ambushed a police armored vehicle between Delmas 18 Avenue and Sans Fil Street (in the Cite Numero Un neighbourhood). Three police officers were killed and another one was injured. The bodies of the deceased were decapitated and burned together with the police vehicle. Additional police officers arrived and clashed with the criminals in Delmas 18, in nearby Delmas 24 (Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28 neighbourhood, coded separately), and in Solino neighbourhood (coded separately). The Viv Ansanm Gang, which claimed responsibility for the attack, shared images of the victims' bodies, weapons and ammunition they stole, on social media. At least one of the corpses was taken by the gang members. 3 fatalities, 1 injured.

On 9 June 2024, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, overnight, a mob of residents lynched four gang members. The victims were affiliates of the 6 Men For Hell Gang, which is based in the nearby Watapana village. 4 fatalities.

On 10 June 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, several dozen residents held a demonstration in the Solino and Nazon (coded separately) neighborhoods to decry the killing of three police officers near Delmas 19 the day prior (coded separately). Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires.

On 11 June 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, members of the Living Together gang-led initiative (a.k.a. Viv Ansanm Gang) opened fire on a group of residents in Delmas 24 (Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28 neighbourhood), killing at least 10 and injuring several others. The gang members shot from inside a house. The group of targeted civilians had been escorted by a police armored vehicle moments before the attack. At least 10 fatalities.

On 11 June 2024, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, in the morning, police officers held a protest demanding the departure of the head of the police in the Sud-Est department due to their working conditions. Protesters set up barricades (nature unspecified) and blocked the roadway. The head of the police resigned later that day.

On 12 June 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, for a third consecutive day, a group of residents held a demonstration in the Nazon neighbourhood to decry the killing of three police officers by gang members on 9 June (coded separately). Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires. Gunshots were heard. The mobilization was held on the occasion of the anniversary of the National Police of Haiti.

On 12 June 2024, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, scores of residents took to the streets calling for the return of the head of the police in the Sud-Est department. He had resigned the day prior after police officers called on his departure due to working conditions (coded separately). Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires on Baranquilla Avenue.

On 14 June 2024, in Delmas - Chancerelles, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members during an anti-gang operation launched in response to the killing of three police officers on 9 June (coded separately). Gunshots were heard in Bas Delmas (Chancerelles neighbourhood). Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 15 January 2024, in Cite Soleil - Waaf Jeremie, Ouest, members of three rival gangs engaged in armed clashes in Waaf Jeremie neighbourhood and in nearby La Saline neighbourhood, in the Port-au-Prince commune (coded separately) as part of a fight for territory. At least five people were killed in the crossfire. According to one of the sources, the gang members involved in the clashes were from the Grand-Ravine Gang, Base Project La Saline Gang, and the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang), against the Micanord Gang (a.k.a. Whart Jeremie Gang). At least 5 fatalities split across two events.

Non-violent activity: On 25 June 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, members of the 400 Mawozo Gang, tried without success to dig the foundations to create a wall along the National Road 8 (at the height of the National High School) in the aim of cutting communication between Croix-des-Bouquets and Tabarre communes. On 4 September, the gang members managed to erect the wall in the mentioned area, commonly known as 'Gran Rigol' area. Police forces demolished it during an intervention on 6 September (coded separately).

Property destruction: On 27 June 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, in the early morning, the 400 Mawozo Gang set fire to the city hall building. Some vehicles and equipment were burned inside the institution's premises. The facilities were empty as they had been abandoned long before the attack. Smoke was seen coming from the nearby General Tax Directorate (DGI), the empty Croix-des-Bouquets Civil Prison, and the commune's police station. The last two had been assaulted in May (coded separately).

On 23 June 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, overnight, police forces clashed with 400 Mawozo gang members during several hours as part of an operation in their base. Gunshots were also heard. Casualties unknown.

Around 27 June 2024 (as reported), in Delmas - Musseau, Ouest, members of several organizations representing disabled people held a sit-in protest in front the premises of the Villa d'Accueil facilities (in Musseau neighbourhood) demanding authorities to appoint a man they claimed to support as head of the State Secretariat for the Integration of Disabled People.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Haiti Standard; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 1 July 2024, in Gressier - Cite Gressier, Ouest, in the morning, the Viv Ansanm Gang, the 103 Zombies Gang, and the Grand-Ravine Gang demolished a part of the Gressier sub-police station, which had been under attack since the night prior (coded separately). The gangsters, armed with sled hammers, managed to bring down the building's fences. Police forces intervened and clashed with the gangsters, killing several of them. The police managed to gained the control of the sub-police station after clashes. During the offensive, houses were set on fire and at least five civilians were killed, including a minibus driver man by gunshots along the National Road 1. His body was burned. The gangsters kidnapped a Catholic priest from inside a church and asked for a ransom for his liberation. He was released the day after under unclarified circumstances. At least 5 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 30 June 2024, in Gressier - Cite Gressier, Ouest, overnight, more than 200 members of the Viv Ansanm Gang, the 103 Zombies Gang, and the Grand-Ravine Gang, attacked and partially burned the Gressier sub-police station. Some officers were taken as hostages while others were forced to leave. Following this, the gangsters attacked residents at their homes, shooting, raping, and extorting them. A number of houses were set on fire with residents inside, killing at least 20 civilians. Among the fatal victims, there was a cousin of the Gressier's mayor. He was killed in front of his family and burned. Transport vehicles were hijacked on the National Road 2. Some public transport drivers were killed while several passengers were robbed and aggressed. Police forces responded and clashed with the gangsters for several hours. An unspecified number of criminals were killed. Two police armored vehicles were attacked. Hundreds of gangsters were seen parading along the commune's beaches. Three roadblocks were erected by the mentioned gangs in separate areas in the commune. A priest who was also kidnapped from the Gressier parish during the incident was released on 2 July. At least 20 fatalities.

Looting: On 2 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, unidentified individuals looted a water pumping station belonging to the National Directorate of Drinking Water and Sanitation (DINEPA). The perpetrators cut some electric cables, damaged several equipment, and stole batteries. Motivation unknown.

On 4 July 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 48, Ouest, intern students from the ENS School held a sit-in protest in front of the Ministry of National Education and Vocational Training (MENFP), in Delmas 48 neighbourhood, to demand the payment of their internships.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 11 July 2024, near Pont Sonde, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang kidnapped at least 20 civilians from their homes in Moreau Paye. The gang members asked for the payment of ransoms as a condition for their liberation. The victims were taken to Savien, although their whereabouts are unknown.

On 7 July 2024, in Petion Ville - Thomassin, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals kidnapped a notary man together with two of his family members when they were hiking in Laboule 12 (Thomassin neighbourhood). There is no information on the perpetrators, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

Around 6 July 2024 (between 5 - 7 July), in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals kidnapped an unspecified number of people in Plaine du Cul-de-Sac area. There is no information on the perpetrators and circumstances of the abduction, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

Around 6 July 2024 (as reported), in Delmas - Delmas 19/Mackandal, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals kidnapped a doctor man in Delmas 19 (Delmas 19/Mackandal neighbourhood). There is no information on the perpetrators and circumstances of the abduction, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victim was released under unclarified circumstances.

Around 6 July 2024 (between 5 - 7 July), in Port-au-Prince - Turgeau, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals kidnapped an unspecified number of people in the Turgeau neighbourhood. There is no information on the perpetrators, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

On 7 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Avenue Christophe, Ouest, in the morning, armed gang members kidnapped a businessman at the height of the Avenue Christophe neighbourhood. The wife of the victim, who was inside their private vehicle, was about to be kidnapped too, although security forces intervened and prevented it (nature of the interaction with the perpetrators unreported). The abductors managed to escape with the businessman. His whereabouts are unknown.

Property destruction: Around 4 July 2024 (between 30 June - 8 July), in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, gang members set fire to the premises of the Gressier Civil Protection Office. There is no further information on the circumstances of the attack.

On 12 July 2024, in Pont Sonde, Artibonite, in the morning, residents from Moreau Paye and Carrefour Paye held a protest on the National Road 1 against insecurity and gang violence. Protesters blocked the road with pieces of vehicles and tree trunks. They asked the police to address the issue.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Alterpresse; Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 15 July 2024, in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, in the morning, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang set fire to several vehicles, including one belonging to the 'Yaya' water treatment company, on the National Road 1. The criminals aggressed public transport drivers and traders (nature of the aggressions unspecified). It happened as the gang members clashed with police forces in nearby Pont Sonde (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 12 July 2024, in Pont Sonde, Artibonite, overnight, police forces and members of the Chandelle self-defence group clashed with members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang as they tried to take control of the Pat-Chwal sub-police station. Security forces managed to prevent the criminals from success, although they had to leave due to a shortage of ammunition. Clashes continued for at least four consecutive days (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 13 July 2024, in Pont Sonde, Artibonite, for a second consecutive day, police officers and members of the Chandelle self-defence group clashed with scores of Baz Gran Grif de Savien gang members as they tried to attack and demolish the Pat-Chwal sub-police station, on the National Road 1. There were several injured by gunshots among civilians. Between 13 and 15 July, at least eight gang members were killed amidst clashes. An unspecified number of others were injured. 8 fatalities split across three events.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 14 July 2024, in Pont Sonde, Artibonite, for a third consecutive day, overnight, around 20 police officers and members of the Chandelle self-defence group clashed with scores of Baz Gran Grif de Savien gang members as they tried to attack and demolish the Pat-Chwal sub-police station, on the National Road 1. During clashes, at least two gang members were killed and a third one was injured. At least four self-defence group members were killed and 11 others were wounded while they supported the police. There were several injured by gunshots among civilians. Armed clashes continued on 15 July (coded separately). Between 13 and 15 July, at least eight gang members were killed amidst clashes. An unspecified number of others were injured. 8 fatalities split across three events, including the at least six people killed in this clash.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 15 July 2024, in Pont Sonde, Artibonite, for a fourth consecutive day, police officers and members of the Chandelle self-defence group clashed with scores of Baz Gran Grif de Savien gang members as they tried to attack and demolish the Pat-Chwal sub-police station, on the National Road 1. There were several injured by gunshots among civilians. Between 13 and 15 July, at least eight gang members were killed amidst clashes. An unspecified number of others were injured. Some unidentified corpses were found in nearby Moreau Paye in the morning of 16 July (assumed as likely victims of armed clashes). 8 fatalities split across three events.

source: Haiti Progres; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 16 July 2024, off the Coast of Cap-Haitien, Nord, overnight, Haitian coast guards intercepted a boat with more than 80 Haitian nationals trying to migrate towards the Turks and Caicos. The interception took place as the boat got burned by accident during a voodoo ritual. 37 people were rescued and arrested. Seven were severely injured. Around 40 died or went missing. Nine bodies were found several days later. It is still unconfirmed whether they belonged to the victims.

Non-violent activity: Around 24 July 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) started to build a pier at the waterfront in Cite de Dieu neighbourhood to transport weapons and drugs easily.

On 21 July 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, hundreds members of the 400 Mawozo Gang attacked security forces in the commune. At least four civilians were killed. Several others were injured. At least 4 fatalities, several injured.
On 18 July 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, police forces clashed with members of the 400 Mawozo Gang as the criminals attacked residents' areas in the commune. Casualties unknown.

actor1: Police Forces of Haiti (2024-) Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP)
notes: Around 21 July 2024 (weekend of), in Ferrier, Nord-Est, BSAP agents shot and killed a man during an altercation. No further details were mentioned. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Trip Foumi
notes: On 21 July 2024, in Gressier - Sous Fort, Ouest, for a fourth consecutive day, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members in the commune. At least two gang members were shot and killed as they transported a high sum of money. The gangsters hijacked an unspecified number of vehicles from drivers and set fire to at least one truck. Between 20 and 21 July, police forces killed around 10 gang members as they carried out anti-gang operations in La Conille area (Sous Fort neighbourhood). In total more than 40 gangsters were killed in Gressier since a state of emergency was declared on 17 July (coded separately). Police forces also removed part of a roadblock that had been erected by the criminals (coded separately). At least 10 fatalities split across two events.
On 18 July 2024, in Pilate, Nord, armed gang members kidnapped at least six people, including an education inspector. Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: AFP; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: Agreement: On 24 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, the leader of the G-9 Gang and the leader of the G-Pep La Gang reached a peace agreement to end armed conflict between them in the commune. These rival gangs have not clashed since both organizations joined the Viv Ansanm Gang in early 2024, although roadblocks and VAR positions separating the areas under their control still remained in Cite Soleil. The agreement involved the removal of these roadblocks.
Non-violent activity: Around 20 July 2024 (as reported), in Leogane, Ouest, gang members set up barricades at the Route 9 bridge and stole some drivers from their belongings.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Looting: Around 21 July 2024 (weekend of), in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, a bus driver and his passengers were forced to leave the public transport vehicle without their belongings. On the same day, gang members used containers and heavy machinery to set up a roadblock in the section leading to nearby Leogane.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Non-violent activity: Around 24 July 2024 (between 17 - 30 July), near Pont Sonde, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang set up a roadblock on the National Road 1.

On 1 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, employees of the Ministry of the Interior and Local Authorities (SMICT), supported by trade union members, held a sit-in protest at the Directorate of Immigration and Emigration (DIE) building (in Champs de Mars) demanding the payment of due salaries.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Other: On 28 July 2024, in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang fired shots and installed a music stand on the National Road 1. Gunshots and speaker vibrations were heard in the area and in nearby villages.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 28 July 2024, in Tabarre - Croix des Missions, Ouest, police forces shot and killed 27 members of the Chien Mechant Gang as they carried out an anti-gang operation in Croix-des-Missions neighbourhood. 27 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 30 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, gang members killed the driver of a cargo of rice near the National Port Authority (APN) facility, in La Saline neighbourhood. After the attack, the criminals tried to hijack the cargo, although police forces intervened and prevented it (coded separately). 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 29 July 2024, in Pont Sonde, Artibonite, hundreds of citizens, called by the 'Artibonite Stands Up to Fight Against Insecurity' organization, held a protest on the National Road 1 against gang violence in the department. Protesters held tree branches and called on the authorities to take responsibly for the insecurity situation.

Around 6 August 2024 (between 5 - 8 August), in Cap-Haitien, Nord, a group of chicken meat importers and traders coming from different Nord-Est department villages held a protest to decry the new customs tariffs applied by authorities at the Cap-Haitien port for their deliveries.

On 8 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Deprez, Ouest, employees of the Electricity of Haiti (EDH) company held a sit-in protest near the Anti-corruption Unit building (ULCC), in Deprez neighbourhood, to decry corruption within the company and to demand the departure of the EDH head.

Around 7 August 2024 (as reported), in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, hundreds of citizens, called by several local organizations, held a protest demanding the completion of rehabilitation works on the Notre-Dame square.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; KominoTek; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp); Telesur TV
notes: On 8 August 2024, in Carrefour - Bas Thorland, Ouest, the Ti Bwa Gang clashed with rival members of the Marc Arthur Gang in Thor 12 (Bas Thorland neighbourhood). Clashes erupted as the affiliates of Marc Arthur were intercepted by the Ti Bwa Gang trying to hijack a good truck vehicle in the area. Clashes were also mentioned in Brochette, Waney, and Bertin neighborhoods (coded separately). During clashes, the Ti Bwa Gang killed the leader of the rival gang and around 10 of his accomplices. The gang leader's body was set on fire on Saint Charles street while gunshots were heard in Lamentin 12 (Nan Coucou/St-Charles/Lamentin). Dead bodies were found on the streets of Brochette. Gunshots were also heard in Fontamara 43. At least 11 fatalities split across four events. 3 fatalities coded for this event.

Looting: On 2 August 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, overnight, more than 40 gang members assaulted and occupied the Montfort Institute, a school for deaf-mute and deaf-blind children, located in Duval 30. The attack took place as more than 50 children with special needs were at the facility. The criminals disarmed the security guards, looted the building, stole vehicles and other items, and caused material damages. There were no civilian casualties. The children were evacuated and the occupation persisted at least until 5 August. There were no casualties.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 11 August 2024, in Gressier - Petit Boucan, Ouest, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members in the Echalot village (near Petit Boucan). Seven gangsters were killed. A rifle was seized. 7 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 15 August 2024, in Tabarre - Clercine, Ouest, police forces carried out a security operation near Carrefour Rita in Clercine neighbourhood and killed five suspected gang members (several described as allies of the 400 Mawozo Gang), including a man who have escaped from prison and was an active member of the Viv Ansanm gang alliance. Amid the operation, an officer was injured and 13 other people were arrested. Also, nearby the area, two journalists carrying out a gun were arrested. A rifle, several ammunitions, and three phones were seized by the police. 5 fatalities.

source: Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Trip Foumi
notes: On 14 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Canape-Vert, Ouest, several dozen residents from Carrefour-Feuilles, Solino, and Canape-Vert neighborhoods, and political militants held a protest with banners and tree branches to decry rising insecurity and to demand that authorities take responsibility for the situation. The protest started in Canape-Vert and was called by the 'New Blood For Change' organization (a.k.a. 'Du Sang9 Pour Le Changement'), integrated by residents from the mentioned areas.

On 6 August 2024, in the Gressier commune (coded to Port-au-Prince - Gressier), Ouest, armed members of the 103 Zombies Gang shot and injured a taxi driver man in the 'Monvil' village. The attack took place as the victim refused to hand over his moto-taxi vehicle to the criminals, who were looting and stealing vehicles in the area. He died due to the wounds. 1 fatality.

Around 20 July 2024 (as reported), in Gressier - Sous Fort, Ouest, 23 women were kidnapped by gang members when they were in their vehicles on their way to the Grand Sud. Fifteen of the abducted women were raped by at least four men each. The victims were released following a police operation carried out between 20 and 21 July in Monvil. The police operation took place within the framework of a series of clashes between police and gang members (coded separately).

On 28 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, overnight, armed gang members attacked (methods unknown) a residential property occupied by a 75-year-old woman and her daughter, near the Gressier Peace Court. The younger woman, who left the house to escape from the gangsters, was killed and her body was later found nearby. 1 fatality.
Around 18 August 2024 (weekend of), in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, a mob of residents lynched three gang members and set fire to their bodies. 3 fatalities.

On 18 August 2024, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, overnight, unidentified armed group members engaged in an armed clash on the 'des Bons enfants' street, injuring several people. No further details were mentioned. Several injured.

On 21 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Saint Antoine/Lalue, Ouest, contract workers from the Ministry of the Interior and Local Authorities (MICT) held a demonstration in front of the Directorate of Immigration and Emigration headquarters, on John Avenue (Lalue neighbourhood), demanding the payment of due salaries. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires and threw stones against the ministry's building. Police forces used tear gas to disperse the rioters.

On 23 August 2024, in Carnifice, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang clashed with rival gang members. Between 23 and 25 August, at least six people were killed and several houses and plantations were set on fire amidst the armed clashes. One source stated that the Kokorat San Ras Gang offensive was a reprisal for wrong accusations against the gang over the kidnapping of a 5-year-old girl (coded separately). At least 6 fatalities split across three events.

On 24 August 2024, in Carnifice, Artibonite, for a second consecutive day, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang clashed with rival gang members. Between 23 and 25 August, at least six people were killed and several houses and plantations were set on fire amidst the armed clashes. One source stated that the Kokorat San Ras Gang offensive was a reprisal for wrong accusations against the gang over the kidnapping of a 5-year-old girl (coded separately). At least 6 fatalities split across three events. 2 fatalities coded for this event.

On 25 August 2024, in Carnifice, Artibonite, for a third consecutive day, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang clashed with rival gang members. Between 23 and 25 August, at least six people were killed and several houses and plantations were set on fire amidst the armed clashes. One source stated that the Kokorat San Ras Gang offensive was a reprisal for wrong accusations against the gang over the kidnapping of a 5-year-old girl (coded separately). At least 6 fatalities split across three events. 2 fatalities coded for this event.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; KominoTek; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp); Telesur TV
notes: On 8 August 2024, in Carrefour - Bertin, Ouest, the Ti Bwa Gang clashed with rival members of the Marc Arthur Gang in Bertin. Clashes were also mentioned in Bas Thorland, Brochette, and Waney neighborhoods (coded separately). During clashes, the Ti Bwa Gang killed the leader of the rival gang and around 10 of his accomplices. The gang leader's body was set on fire on Saint Charles street while gunshots were heard in Lamentin 12 (Nan Coucou/St-Charles/Lamentin). Dead bodies were found on the streets of Brochette. Gunshots were also heard in Fontamara 43. At least 11 fatalities split across four events. 2 fatalities coded for this event.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; KominoTek; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp); Telesur TV
notes: On 8 August 2024, in Carrefour - Brochette, Ouest, the Ti Bwa Gang clashed with rival members of the Marc Arthur Gang in Brochette. The gang leader's body was set on fire on Saint Charles street while gunshots were heard in Lamentin 12 (Nan Coucou/St-Charles/Lamentin). Dead bodies were found on the streets of Brochette. Gunshots were also heard in Fontamara 43. At least 11 fatalities split across four events. 3 fatalities coded for this event.

On 5 February 2024, in Carrefour - La Grenade, Ouest, armed gang members attacked residents in La Grenade and in other nearby neighborhoods including Ti Sous (near Clocher) and Sapotille (coded separately). According to witnesses, at least two civilians were killed (a resident and a moto taxi driver). Several others were injured. The gangsters were said to be based in Mariani. At least 2 fatalities split across three events. 1 fatality coded for this event.

On 5 February 2024, in Carrefour - Sapotille, Ouest, armed gang members attacked residents in Sapotille and in other nearby neighborhoods including Ti Sous (near Clocher) and La Grenade (coded separately). According to witnesses, at least two civilians were killed (a resident and a moto taxi driver). Several others were injured. The gangsters were said to be based in Mariani. At least 2 fatalities split across three events. 0 fatalities coded for this event.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; KominoTek; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp); Telesur TV
notes: On 8 August 2024, in Carrefour - Waney Bijou, Ouest, the Ti Bwa Gang clashed with rival members of the Marc Arthur Gang in Waney. Clashes were also mentioned in Bas Thorland, Brochette, and Bertin neighborhoods (coded separately). During clashes, the Ti Bwa Gang killed the leader of the rival gang and around 10 of his accomplices. The gang leader's body was set on fire on Saint Charles street while gunshots were heard in Lamentin 12 (Nan Coucou/St-Charles/Lamentin). Dead bodies were found on the streets of Brochette. Gunshots were also heard in Fontamara 43. At least 11 fatalities split across four events. 3 fatalities coded for this event.

On 29 August 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 5, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang shot and killed a former football player man from the Racing Haitian Club (RCH) at his residence in Delmas 3 (Delmas 5 neighborhood). The gang members stole some items. 1 fatality.

source: Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 24 August 2024, near Gressier - La Source, Ouest, in the morning, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members as they carried out a security operation in the Jasmin village (near La Source) and in the Echalot village (coded separately). At least four gang members were killed. Two firearms were seized. At least 4 fatalities split across two events. 2 fatalities coded for this event.

source: Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 24 August 2024, near Gressier - Petit Boucan, Ouest, in the morning, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members as they carried out a security operation in the Echalot village (near Petit Boucan) and in the Jasmin village (coded separately). At least four gang members were killed. Two firearms were seized. At least 4 fatalities split across two events. 2 fatalities coded for this event.

source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 27 August 2024, in Gros-Morne, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang on motorcycles attacked residents in the village, killing at least one person. He was identified as a farmer man. Three residents were kidnapped. Their whereabouts are unknown. At least 1 fatality.

Around 25 August 2024 (weekend of), in Limonade, Nord, UEH university students from the Henry Campus held a protest to decry precarious conditions affecting their daily university life. Protesters blocked the march to the Prime Minister's team as the caravan of official vehicles tried to cross the area.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, masked individuals set up roadblocks and barricades of burning tires, tree trunks, and pieces of vehicles in Canape-Vert, Lalue, Solino, Nazon, and other areas. Although several sources state that the people behind these actions were not identified, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes

On 25 March 2024, in Tabarre - Cazeau/Tabarre 14, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members. Clashes between the police and gang members were also registered in Croix des Missions (coded separately). Gunshots were heard in Butte Boyer and Carrefour Clercine zones. Casualties unknown.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 16 January 2024, in Delmas - Cite Numero Un, Ouest, for the third consecutive day, the Belair Gang, supported by the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) attacked the Solino neighborhood (coded separately) and close areas, such as Carrefour Pean, Delmas 18 (Cite Numero Un neighborhood), and Delmas 24 (Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28 neighborhood) as they clashed with rival gang members. The gangsters, who aimed at taking control of the public markets, chased residents and set fire to several houses. At least a person was killed and several were injured. Police forces intervened and expelled the criminals (coded separately). An unknown number of residents fled their homes. The National Human Rights Defense Network's director claimed that at least 20 people were killed between 14 and 18 January as a result of gang clashes in Port-au-Prince. The Organization of Hearts for Change for Deprived Children (OCCED'H) stated that at least 7 children were shot and injured in the same period. At least 7 injured split across ten events. At least 20 fatalities split across ten events, 2 fatalities coded here.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes

The gangsters, who aimed at taking control of the public markets, chased residents and set fire to several houses. At least a person was killed and several were injured. The Organization of Hearts for Change for Deprived Children (OCCED'H) stated that at least 7 children were shot and injured in the same period. At least 7 injured split across ten events. At least 20 fatalities split across ten events, 2 fatalities coded here.

On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, masked individuals, some of them armed with machetes, set up roadblocks and barricades in Delmas 31, 33 (coded separately), and 40B, among other areas. On the Airport Road (Barbancourt neighborhood), stones and bottles were thrown (coded separately). This is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, masked individuals, some of them armed with machetes, set up roadblocks and barricades in Delmas 31, 33, and 40B, among other areas. On the Airport Road (Delmas - Barbancourt), stones and bottles were thrown. This is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 15 February 2024, in Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13, Ouest, demonstrations were registered in Carrefour Aeroport and Delmas 65 (coded separately), where demonstrators threw stones at vehicles. In addition to that, citizens, called by the Platfom Pitit Desalin party, held a demonstration on the Delmas Road demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry, and were dispersed by the police (coded separately).

On 15 February 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 65, Ouest, demonstrations were registered in Carrefour Aeroport (coded separately) and Delmas 65, where demonstrators threw stones at vehicles. In addition to that, citizens, called by the Platfom Pitit Desalin party, held a protest on the Delmas Road demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Police forces intervened using tear gas to disperse the crowd (coded separately).

source: AFP; Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 23 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, two cameramen from Tele Amen (Christian media outlet) were kidnapped in an unspecified location of the city. Armed gang members kidnapped also kidnapped a Catholic priest in Port-au-Prince - Portail Saint Joseph (coded separately) and Six Brothers of the Sacred Heart Congregation and a teacher in Morne a Tuf neighbourhood (coded separately).

On 24 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Portail Leogane/Cite Louverture, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in the sector and in the vicinity of the Salomon Market in Bas Peu de Choses neighbourhood (coded separately). An unspecified number of victims were reported (not clarified if wounded or killed). Casualties unknown.

source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 1 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members near the National Port Authority (APN) facilities (La Saline). Clashes also took place in the Civil Prison (Centre Ville), in Champs de Mars, and on Saint-Honore street (Morne a Tuf neighbourhood) (all coded separately). At least one fatality was counted (affiliation unknown). Gunshots were heard in different areas, such as Bicentenaire, Enterrement Street, Reunion Street, Grand Rue, Mgr Guilloux Street, and Bas Delmas. This was the second consecutive day of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). At least 1 fatality, split across 4 events, 1 fatality coded.

source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 1 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in Champs de Mars. Clashes also took place near the National Port Authority (APN) facilities (La Saline), in the Civil Prison (Centre Ville), and on Saint-Honore street (Morne a Tuf neighbourhood) (all coded separately). At least one fatality was counted (affiliation unknown). Gunshots were heard in different areas, such as Bicentenaire, Enterrement Street, Reunion Street, Grand Rue, Mgr Guilloux Street, and Bas Delmas. This was the second consecutive day of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). At least 1 fatality, split across 4 events, 0 fatalities coded.

source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 1 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members Saint-Honore street (Morne a Tuf neighbourhood). Clashes also took place near the National Port Authority (APN) facilities (La Saline), in the Civil Prison (Centre Ville), and in Champs de Mars (all coded separately). At least one fatality was counted (affiliation unknown). Gunshots were heard in different areas, such as Bicentenaire, Enterrement Street, Reunion Street, Grand Rue, Mgr Guilloux Street, and Bas Delmas. This was the second consecutive day of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). At least 1 fatality, split across 4 events, 0 fatalities coded.

On 1 March 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 48, Ouest, several dozens of citizens held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Another report indicates that barricades of burning tires in Delmas 40B (coded separately), 48, and 75 (coded separately), which might possibly related to the demonstration.

On 1 March 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 75, Ouest, several dozens of citizens held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Another report indicates that barricades of burning tires in Delmas 40B (coded separately), 48 (coded separately), and 75, which might possibly related to the demonstration.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 15 March 2024, in Delmas - Saint-Martin, Ouest, overnight, police forces shot and killed several members of the G-9 Gang during clashes in Delmas 6 (Cite Numero Un neighbourhood, coded separately) and Delmas 8 (2eme Cite Saint Martin neighbourhood). Clashes took place amidst a security operation aiming at removing a roadblock erected by the G-9 Gang in Delmas 6 around 11 March (coded separately). Clashes continued until the early morning of the following day. Several firearms were seized. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3, split across 2 events, coded as 2.

On 14 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Bellevue la Montagne, Ouest, overnight, gang members attacked the Vivy Mitchell (coded separately), Belvil (coded separately), and Bellevue neighborhoods. A number of families took to the streets to take refuge elsewhere. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 18 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Thomassin, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they attacked residents, private properties, and companies' facilities in Laboule (coded separately), Thomassin, Boutilliers (coded separately), and Pelerin neighborhoods (coded separately). Around a dozen people were killed and several were injured. One fatal victim was a woman described as the head of Women's Classical School. A bank branch, a gas station, and several houses were attacked and looted, including that of a judge at the Superior Court of Auditors and Administrative Litigation, who had been evacuated before the attack (in Laboule 18). In Laboule 12, gunshots were heard as the gangsters stole some vehicles. The criminals had arrived in three vehicles. Other versions stated that they used four trucks and 27 motorcycles. Several injured, at least 12 fatalities, split across 4 events, 3 fatalities coded.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 18 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Boutilliers, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they attacked residents, private properties, and companies' facilities in Laboule (coded separately), Thomassin (coded separately), Boutilliers, and Pelerin neighborhoods (coded separately). Around a dozen people were killed and several were injured. One fatal victim was a woman described as the head of Women's Classical School. A bank branch, a gas station, and several houses were attacked and looted, including that of a judge at the Superior Court of Auditors and Administrative Litigation, who had been evacuated before the attack (in Laboule 18). In Laboule 12, gunshots were heard as the gangsters stole some vehicles. The criminals had arrived in three vehicles. Other versions stated that they used four trucks and 27 motorcycles. Several injured, at least 12 fatalities, split across 4 events, 3 fatalities coded.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 18 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Pelerin, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they attacked residents, private properties, and companies' facilities in Laboule (coded separately), Thomassin (coded separately), Boutilliers (coded separately), and Pelerin neighborhoods. Around a dozen people were killed and several were injured. One fatal victim was a woman described as the head of Women's Classical School. A bank branch, a gas station, and several houses were attacked and looted, including that of a judge at the Superior Court of Auditors and Administrative Litigation, who had been evacuated before the attack (in Laboule 18). In Laboule 12, gunshots were heard as the gangsters stole some vehicles. The criminals had arrived in three vehicles. Other versions stated that they used four trucks and 27 motorcycles. Several injured, at least 12 fatalities, split across 4 events, 3 fatalities coded.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 19 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Metivier, Ouest, (Kraze Barye Gang) Vitelhomme Gang (supported by the Grand-Ravine Gang) attacked Laboule (coded separately), Metivier, and Peguy-Ville neighborhoods (coded separately), among others, besides clashing with the police in the Thomassin neighbourhood (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 19 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Laboule, Ouest, (Kraze Barye Gang) Vitelhomme Gang (supported by the Grand-Ravine Gang) attacked Laboule, Metivier (coded separately), and Peguy-Ville neighborhoods (coded separately), among others, besides clashing with the police in the Thomassin neighbourhood (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 23 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, several corpses were found scattered in Jeremie square, on Martin Luther King and Poupelard streets (Nazon, coded separately), in Bois Verna (coded separately), and Champs de Mars (coded separately), after clashes between gang members and the police in the Fort National neighbourhood (coded separately), while gunshots were heard in Christ-Roi and Canape-Vert. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3, split across 4 events, coded as 0.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 23 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, several corpses were found scattered on Martin Luther King and Poupelard streets (Nazon), in Bois Verna (coded separately), Champs de Mars (coded separately), and Jeremie square (Bas Peu de Choses, coded separately), after clashes between gang members and the police in the Fort National neighbourhood (coded separately), while gunshots were heard in Christ-Roi and Canape-Vert. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3, split across 4 events, coded as 1.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 23 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bois Verna, Ouest, several corpses were found scattered in in Bois Verna, on Martin Luther King and Poupelard streets (Nazon, coded separately), Champs de Mars (coded separately), and Jeremie square (Bas Peu de Choses, coded separately), after clashes between gang members and the police in the Fort National neighbourhood (coded separately), while gunshots were heard in Christ-Roi and Canape-Vert. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3, split across 4 events, coded as 1.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
