notes: On 23 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, several corpses were found scattered in Champs de Mars, on Martin Luther King and Poupelard streets (Nazon, coded separately), in Bois Verna (coded separately), and Jeremie square (Bas Peu de Choses, coded separately), after clashes between gang members and the police in the Fort National neighbourhood (coded separately), while gunshots were heard in Christ-Roi and Canape-Vert. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3, split across 4 events, coded as 1.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Trinidad and Tobago Guardian
notes: On 2 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bois Verna, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members and a man was shot and killed by a stray bullet in front of the Blaise Pascal School. The victim was a moto taxi driver. Gunshots were also heard in Christ-Roi. The gang members were described as affiliates of the Living Together gang-led coalition (Viv Ansanm gang). Clashes also took place in Champs de Mars neighborhood (coded separately). 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole
notes: On 18 April 2024, in Carrefour - Waney Bijou, Ouest, more than 200 Ti Bwa gang members attacked the Mon Repos (coded separately) and Waney Bijou neighborhoods as they carried out an offensive aiming at and taking control of the commune. Seven civilians and a police officer were killed as the gangsters opened fire in the Waney 93 area. There were several injured by gunshots. The criminals assaulted the Omega police station (in Bas Thorland neighbourhood, coded separately) and released the prisoners. Weapons and materials belonging to the police were stolen. Two officers who were present were forced to leave. Another version stated that they were kidnapped and released moments later in Bizoton. Clashes between the gangsters and the police were mentioned. The gangsters forced drivers to stop their march in the Brochette and Lamentin neighborhoods, among others. One source stated that the offensive aimed at establishing a new gang leader in the Cote Plage neighbourhood. At least 19 fatalities, several injured.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole
notes: On 18 April 2024, in Carrefour - Bas Thorland, Ouest, more than 200 Ti Bwa gang members attacked the Mon Repos (coded separately) and Waney Bijou neighborhoods (coded separately) as they carried out an offensive aiming at and taking control of the commune. Seven civilians and a police officer were killed as the gangsters opened fire in the Waney 93 area. There were several injured by gunshots. The criminals assaulted the Omega police station (in Bas Thorland neighbourhood) and released the prisoners. Weapons and materials belonging to the police were stolen. Two officers who were present were forced to leave. Another version stated that they were kidnapped and released moments later in Bizoton. Clashes between the gangsters and the police were mentioned. The gangsters forced drivers to stop their march in the Brochette and Lamentin neighborhoods, among others. One source stated that the offensive aimed at establishing a new gang leader in the Cote Plage neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 21 April 2024, between Port-au-Prince - Bois Verna and Port-au-Prince - Lalue, Ouest, police and military forces clashed with gang members in the vicinity of the National Palace (Champs de Mars neighbourhood, coded separately) and in nearby Lalue and Bois Verna neighborhoods. During clashes, several people were shot and injured by the stray bullets near the Ministry of Culture and Communications (Pacot neighbourhood). The gang offensive was described as an attempt to prevent the installation of a Presidential Transitional Council. One source suggested that the criminals were affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative (Viv Ansanm gang). Gunshots were also heard in La Saline neighborhood and in Waaf Jeremie neighborhood (Cite Soleil). Several injured.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 21 April 2024, in Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13, Ouest, gang members clashed with police forces as they looted and set fire to houses and in the Carrefour Aeroport and in Bas Delmas (Delmas 19) neighborhoods (coded separately). One source suggested that the criminals were affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative (Viv Ansanm gang). Gunshots were also heard in Delmas 32. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; GardaWorld; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Vi Free Press
notes: On 1 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, overnight, members of the Living-Together gang-led initiative (coded separately), led by the G-9 Gang, attacked the Nazon and Solino neighborhoods (coded separately) and burned residents' houses. Police forces were deployed and clashed with the criminals. There were several injured by the gunshots (affiliation unknown). Gunshots were heard throughout the day and overnight. Some residents fled their homes. According to one source, the criminals were members of the Bel Air Gang, although this was not confirmed by other sources. Several injured.

source: Alterpresse; GardaWorld; Haiti Press Network; Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Vi Free Press
notes: On 1 May 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, members of the Living-Together gang-led initiative (coded separately), led by the G-9 Gang, attacked Delmas 24 (in Delmas 28 neighbourhood) and Bas Delmas, Delmas 18 (in Cite Numero Un neighbourhood, coded separately). Some residents' houses were burned. Police forces were deployed and clashed with the criminals. There were several injured by the gunshots (affiliation unknown). Gunshots were heard throughout the day and overnight. According to one source, the criminals were members of the Bel Air Gang, although this was not confirmed by other sources. Casualties unknown.

On 14 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, the Belair Gang attacked residents in the Fort National (coded separately) and Solino neighborhoods and clashed with police forces, who intervened and expelled the criminals from these areas. Several civilians and several gang members were killed. Houses were set on fire. The gang members were described as affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3, split across 2 events, coded as 2.

On 16 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, affiliates of the Living-Together gang-led alliance (a.k.a. Viv Ansanm Gang) targeted state facilities in the Champs de Mars neighbourhood (the Ministry of the Interior and the Finances Palace) and also attacked residents in the Fort National neighbourhood (coded separately). In the Centre Ville neighbourhood, they assaulted the Superior Court of Account and Administrative Disputes and stole some materials. They fled moments before the police arrived. Several nearby buildings, including the Palace of Ministries (on the Reunion street) and an Adventist Protestant Church (in Morne a Tuf neighbourhood) were looted and vandalized. Gunshots were heard in Fort National, Poste Marchand, and Poupelard (Port-au-Prince - Saint Antoine/Lalue neighborhood). Casualties unknown.

source: Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); The St. Kitts Nevis Observer
notes: On 10 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Martissant, Ouest, armed members of the Living Together gang-led alliance, and members of the population held a protest in Bel Air (coded separately) and Martissant neighborhoods against the deployment of a Multilateral Support Security Mission (MMSS) in Haiti.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: On 9 June 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, members of the Living Together gang-led initiative (a.k.a. Viv Ansanm Gang) clashed with police officers arrived in Delmas 18, in nearby Delmas 24 (Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28 neighbourhood). Addition clashed took place in Solino neighbourhood (coded separately) and in the Cite Numero Un neighbourhood (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 10 June 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, several dozen residents held a demonstration in the Solino (coded separately) and Nazon neighborhoods to decry the killing of three police officers near Delmas 19 the day prior (coded separately). Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires.

On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, unidentified individuals, armed with heavy weapons, set up barricades in Clercine and Croix-des-Missions areas. These individuals threw tear gas and intimidated traders on the 15 October Boulevard (Carrefour Fleuriot neighborhood)), forcing them to leave the area. This is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 31 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, hundreds of citizens of several socio-political organizations held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires. Police forces intervened using tear gas and dispersed the crowd at the height of Delmas 73 (Delmas 75 neighborhood) and Delmas 60. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: AFP; Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 16 January 2024, in Delmas - Carrefour Pean, Ouest, for the third consecutive day, the Belair Gang, supported by the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) attacked the Solino neighborhood (coded separately) and close areas, such as Carrefour Pean, Delmas 18 (Cite Numero Un neighborhood), and Delmas 24 (Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28 neighborhood) as they clashed with rival gang members. The gangsters, who aimed at taking control of the public markets, chased residents and set fire to several houses. At least a person was killed and several were injured. Police forces intervened and expelled the criminals (coded separately). An unknown number of residents fled their homes. The National Human Rights Defense Network's director claimed that at least 20 people were killed between 14 and 18 January as a result of gang clashes in Port-au-Prince. The Organization of Hearts for Change for Deprived Children (OCCED'H) stated that at least 7 children were shot and injured in the same period. At least 7 injured split across ten events. At least 20 fatalities split across ten events, 2 fatalities coded here.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 21 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gressier, Ouest, three gang members beat and raped a woman in an area known as 'Doriam'. The victim had returned to the area to recover her belongings and look for her father who had been killed in a gang attack the night before (coded separately).

source: Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 1 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, police forces shot and killed three young men whose bodies were found on the Martin Luther King Avenue in the morning of 2 September. There is no information on the circumstances of the shooting. 3 fatalities.

On 1 September 2024, in Saint Jean du Sud, Sud, police forces shot and killed two gang members and arrested five others during a security operation in the commune. The criminals were described as affiliates of the Lame Timanchet Gang. 2 fatalities.

source: AFP; GardaWorld; Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 2 September 2024, in Peligre, Centre, a group of around 10 citizens held a demonstration at the Electricity of Haiti's (EDH) hydroelectric power station against black-outs. Rioters vandalized the EDH facilities and violently forced the cessation of the power station activity. The nature of vandalism was not clarified, although the mobilization was described as violent. Rioters entered the compound and looked for the company's leaders. The mobilization was joined by the President of the Mirebalais municipal commission.

On 2 September 2024, in Limonade, Nord, medical graduates and students from the UEH University held a sit-in protest at the Justinien University Hospital to demand the departure of the head of the health institution, among other claims. Police forces attended the mobilization and dispersed the protesters (methods unknown).

On 2 September 2024, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, in the morning, a group of relatives and citizens held a protest to decry the death of a gynaecologist man due to unavailability of oxygen at hospital. The man died on 30 August due to trouble breathing. Protesters also demanded the departure of the head of the Fort-Liberte public hospital.

On 3 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour Feuilles, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they carried out an anti-gang operation along the Magloire Ambroise Avenue (Carrefour Feuilles). Several gang members were killed. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 5 September 2024, in Belladere, Centre, Polifront agents arrested the second leader of the Marc Arthur Gang in the border area with the Dominican Republic. Members of the Mirebalais population of the Bwa Kale Movement later lynched the man, shooting him and burning his body. 1 fatality.

On 5 September 2024, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, scores of residents held a protest with banners to demand the departure of the head of the public hospital after the death of a gynaecologist man due to unavailability of oxygen at hospital.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 5 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour Feuilles, Ouest, in the morning, police forces clashed with members of the Viv Ansanm Gang as they carried out anti-gang operations in Carrefour Feuilles and Bas Peu de Choses (coded separately) neighbourhoods. During clashes along the Magloire Ambroise Avenue (which crosses both neighbourhoods), an officer who was inside a police vehicle was shot and killed. Gunshots were heard on Monseigneur Guilloux Avenue and Alerte Street (Bas Peu de Choses). 1 fatality.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 6 September 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, in the morning, police forces clashed with the 400 Mawozo Gang in the Duval area as they carried out anti-gang operations in Marassa, Santo, the Tabarre commune, and Duval area (Croix-des-Bouquets) (coded separately). The gang members attacked the officers with Molotov cocktails and gunfire. Police forces were able to remove the roadblock on National Road 8 that had been set-up by the gang in early July (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 6 September 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, in the morning, police forces clashed with the 400 Mawozo Gang as they carried out anti-gang operations in Marassa, Santo, the Tabarre commune, and Duval area (Croix-des-Bouquets) (coded separately). The gang members attacked the officers with Molotov cocktails. Casualties unknown.

On 6 September 2024, in Santo, Ouest, in the morning, police forces clashed with the 400 Mawozo Gang as they carried out anti-gang operations in Marassa, Santo, the Tabarre commune, and Duval area (Croix-des-Bouquets) (coded separately). The gang members attacked the officers with Molotov cocktails. Casualties unknown.

On 6 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, in the morning, police forces clashed with the 400 Mawozo Gang as they carried out anti-gang operations in Marassa, Santo, the Tabarre commune, and Duval area (Croix-des-Bouquets) (coded separately). The gang members attacked the officers with Molotov cocktails. Casualties unknown.

On 7 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Avenue Christophe, Ouest, a man was killed in an area where armed violence has increased. His body was found 24 hours later on 8 September. Two individuals were arrested in connection to the attack. 1 fatality.
On 8 September 2024, in Gressier - Nan Reserve, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members during an operation, killing three of them in La Colline area. 3 fatalities.

On 9 September 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, graduates and students from the Medical School of the Henri Christophe campus demonstrated at the Justinian University Hospital to demand more specialized positions. Students of the Higher Institute of Medical Technology (ISTMECH) also demanded their integration in the Haiti State University (UEH) after the ISTMECH was reopened by the director which indicated opposition to the integration. The students barricaded doors, held four employees hostage, and kicked out all patients from the hospital until the police intervened (unknown methods) to regain control of the situation.

On 9 September 2024, in Leogane, Ouest, members of the population of the Palmiste-a-Vin area lynched and burned a man who was accused of having killed his ex-girlfriend. They managed to take the man from police custody despite the officers taking shots and using tear gas to disperse the group. 1 fatality.

source: Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Trip Foumi
notes: On 10 September 2024, off the Coast of Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members on a speedboat kidnapped two Filipino merchants as they were getting ready to dock. One source stated that the abductors were members of the 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang). The victims were released on 3 October after the payment of a ransom.

source: Alterpresse; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 11 September 2024, between Delmas - Pele Simon and Delmas - Village Solidarite, Ouest, Nan Boston and Simon-Pele gang members clashed as a result of a football match where one of the two teams refused to admit they lost. According to the International Organization for Migration (IOM) 2,061 residents fled their homes in Boston, Cite Soleil as a result of the clashes. During the clash, a second rank Simon Pele gang leader was killed while the leader of the Belekou gang was injured. It is unknown if the Belekou gang was involved in the clash. At least 20 people, the majority suspected to be members of the Simon Pele gang were killed during clashes recorded from 11 to 13 September. At least 20 fatalities -including the killing of the gang leader- split into five clashes recorded by ACLED between 11 and 13 September in Simon Pele and Village Solidarite neighborhoods, 4 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Standard; Jamaica Gleaner; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; Trinidad and Tobago Guardian; Trip Foumi
notes: Movement of forces: On 12 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, 24 Jamaican soldiers and police officers, as well as two Belizean soldiers, were deployed as part of the multinational security support mission backed by the United Nations to fight against gang violence in the country.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Vant Bef Info
notes: On 16 September 2024, in Manquette, Ouanaminthe, gang members shot a lawyer near his house. The victim was taken to the hospital where he died. Although, there is no information on the motives of the attack, a few days before the attack, the victim publicly shared in an audio that he had been receiving threats. According to another lawyer, a business owner who was involved in a land dispute might have been one of the people responsible for the killing as the victim defended the opposing party in the dispute. 1 fatality.
On 10 September 2024, in Delmas - Saint-Martin, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members causing 266 residents to flee their homes. Casualties unknown.
On 17 September 2024, in Coteaux, Sud, the police killed a member of the Grand-Ravine gang. 1 fatality.

On 23 September 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 19/Mackandal, Ouest, armed men driving a minibus shot and killed two police officers who were patrolling on a motorcycle in Delmas 19 (drive-by) near the Seradot market. One of the officers was killed, while the other was injured. 1 fatality. Another police patrol pursued the shooters, but they managed to escape. According to one of the sources, it is suspected that the perpetrators were trying to flee after committing a kidnapping. 1 fatality. 1 injured.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Around 25 September 2024 (between 24 - 25 September), in Cadeau, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang entered people's homes near Carrefour Trois Ponts on the Route Nationale #1 and killed at least three people, including a vendor. Some sources say between five and eight people were killed. They also kidnapped one person. It is possible the attack aimed to defy the police forces who have been clashing with the gangsters to try to keep them out of the Pont-Sonde police station. At least 3 fatalities.

source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 27 September 2024, in Limbe, Nord, overnight, police forces shot and killed two gang members during a clash in an area known as 'Soleil Leve'. Five other gangsters were arrested. The criminals were identified as members of La Police Gang. One deceased was described as the gang's second leader. Two firearms and several cell phones were seized. 2 fatalities.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: Looting: Around 27 September 2024 (week of), in Limbe, Nord, members of La Police Gang robbed more than 8,000 USD and more than 1 million gourdes to a businessman.

source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 27 September 2024, in Saint Jean du Sud, Sud, police forces shot and killed two members of the Lame Timanchet Gang and arrested its leader, among other accomplices, during a security operation. 2 fatalities.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Around 29 September 2024 (weekend of), in Cadeau, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang killed at least four civilians and looted several houses during an offensive against residents from Cadeau and nearby Savary (Carrefour Paye) village (coded separately). The attack was in reprisal for the use of agricultural roads by the population to avoid toll booths installed by the gang members. At least 4 fatalities split across two events.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Around 29 September 2024 (weekend of), in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang killed at least four civilians and looted several houses during an offensive against residents from Savary (Carrefour Paye) and Cadeau villages (coded separately). The attack was in reprisal for the use of agricultural roads by the population to avoid toll booths installed by the gang members. At least 4 fatalities split across two events.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 3 October 2024, in Pont Sonde, Artibonite, police forces clashed with members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang as they intervened in the area after the gang members had attacked residents in Pont Sonde earlier that day (coded separately). At least two gang members were shot and injured during clashes. At least 2 injured.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 8 October 2024, in Grasse, Artibonite, overnight, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang attacked residents in the town. Witnesses claimed that several people were killed and that their corpses are still missing. Five people were kidnapped in front of their families. Their whereabouts are unknown. Unknown number of fatalities coded as 3.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Non-violent activity: Around 3 August 2024 (between 1 - 5 August), in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang installed a toll booth on the National Road 1. The gang members demanded the payment of 250 gourdes to moto-taxi drivers, 2,500 gourdes to truck drivers, and 5,000 gourdes to mini-bus drivers.

On 22 July 2024, in Gressier, Ouest, armed gang members kidnapped a man at his home and asked for the payment of a ransom to his family as a condition for his release. The victim, who was a public worker at the National Equipment Centre (CNE) and a math's teacher, was not liberated despite the payment of the ransom. The victim's family claimed to have been attacked by the gang members as they contacted the police for help (coded separately). The victim's whereabouts are unknown.

Around 7 August 2024 (between 22 July - 22 August), in the commune of Gressier, Ouest, armed gang members set fire to a house and several vehicles in the commune. The burned properties belonged to the relatives of a kidnapped man (coded separately) in reprisal for having contacted the police to help finding the victim. Casualties unknown.

On 14 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, employees at the General Directorate of Taxation (DGI) held a protest against the presence of the general director at the institution's headquarters, located on Christophe Avenue, 62. Protesters threw eggs against the general director's vehicle. Security guards prevented the employees from puncturing the vehicles' tires. No interaction between the security agents and the protesters was mentioned.

On 16 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, gang members (likely the Belair Gang) attacked residents in the Solino neighbourhood. Houses were set on fire. An unknown number of civilians were killed or injured. According to residents and media, the Viv Ansanm Gang leader was the mastermind of the offensive against Solino. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 18 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Vivy Mitchell, Ouest, armed gang members kidnapped a journalist and former spokesperson of ancient President Martelly at his residence, in the Vivy Mitchell neighbourhood. The abductors broke into the house through the back of the property. They contacted the victim's family. He was released on 21 March under unknown circumstances. The Viv Ansanm Gang leader claimed to have orchestrated the abduction.

Other: On 15 October 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard on the Airport Road at the height of the Village Solidarite and Pele Simon neighborhoods. The circumstances and authorship of the gunshots are unknown.

On 17 October 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, the Belair Gang, supported by the Viv Ansanm Gang, attacked residents in Delmas 24, Solino, and Fort National neighborhoods (coded separately). Overnight, police forces intervened and clashed with the criminals. Casualties unknown.

On 17 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, the Belair Gang, supported by the Viv Ansanm Gang, attacked residents in Fort National, Delmas 24, and Solino neighborhoods (coded separately). Overnight, police forces intervened and clashed with the criminals. There were several killed and injured, although it was not clarified if they were gang members of civilians. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.
On 7 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, armed men kidnapped an entrepreneur from his house and later killed him. There is no information on the motives of the attack. 1 fatality.

Around 18 February 2024 (as reported), in Carries, Ouest, rival armed men engaged in armed clashes as part of a fight for territory. Dozen of vehicles got struck as a consequence of armed clashes. Casualties unknown.
Looting: On 2 September 2024, in Carries, Ouest, armed individuals hijacked four buses and seized all the passengers' possessions.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 14 October 2024, in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, the police clashed with members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. Casualties unknown.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Property destruction: On 22 October 2024, in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, police forces destroyed a property used as shelter by the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. A gang member was arrested.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Non-violent activity: Around 23 October 2024 (as reported), in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang set up roadblocks and installed a toll booth.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: Weapons seizure: On 22 October 2024, in Pont Sonde, Artibonite, police forces seized several weapons used by gang members during an operation at the Pat-Chwal locality. The seizure included an assault riffle, a fake weapon, and other items like four mobile phones and two bulletproof vests.

Other: On 16 October 2024, in Carrefour Zaboca, Grande-Anse, a truck was used to set up a roadblock on the Route Nationale #7. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

Around 24 October 2024 (as reported), in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, police forces clashed with the 400 Mawozo Gang in the Cite Doudoune area. Several gang members were injured and killed. At least one was identified. At least 1 fatality.
On 14 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bois Verna, Ouest, people protested. There is no information on the circumstances or motives for the protest.
On 14 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Turgeau, Ouest, people protested. There is no information on the circumstances or motives for the protest.

On 17 October 2024, in Carrefour - Fontamara, Ouest, people protested. There is no information on the circumstances or motives for the protest. The presence of armed individuals was registered, but it in unclear if they were connected to the protest.
Other: On 17 October 2024, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Drouillard. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 17 October 2024, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Vivy Mitchell. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 17 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Les Ruelles Riviere, Ouest, people protested at the intersection of John Brown Street and Martin Luther King Avenue. There is no information on the circumstances or motives for the protest. The police intervened to dispersed the crowd (methods unknown).

source: PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; The Nassau Guardian; Trinidad and Tobago Guardian
notes: Movement of forces: On 18 October 2024, in Tabarre, Ouest, 6 Bahamian soldiers were deployed as part of the multinational security support mission backed by the United Nations to fight against gang violence in the country.

On 18 October 2024, in Tabarre - Tabarre 27, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang as the criminals attacked residents in Tabarre 27 (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 20 October 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in Sylvio Cator, St-Michel, Bel Air, and Solino neighborhoods (coded separately). Security forces claimed to have regained control of these areas, although this was later denied by some residents. Casualties unknown.

On 20 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - St-Michel, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in St-Michel, Bel Air, Solino, and Sylvio Cator neighborhoods (coded separately). Security forces claimed to have regained control of these areas, although this was later denied by some residents. Casualties unknown.
Other: On 21 October 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard along the Airport Road. This was said to be the authorship of the Viv Ansanm Gang.
Other: On 21 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, unidentified individuals set up barricades burning tires on several roads in Christ Roi, Lalue, and Bourdon neighborhoods. Motivation unknown.

On 21 October 2024, between Port-au-Prince - Solino and Port-au-Prince - Bois Verna, Ouest, residents held a demonstration along the Martin Luther King and Lamartiniere avenues against the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS). The demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires.

On 23 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, in the morning, gunshots were heard in Solino as part of the continuation of armed attacks by gang members (likely the Viv Ansanm Gang). Casualties unknown.

source: Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); The St. Kitts Nevis Observer; Vi Free Press
notes: On 24 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Grand Ravine, Ouest, gang members shot at an UN helicopter operated by a World Food Program (WFP) (UN agency) when the helicopter flew over the Grand Ravine neighbourhood. Another version stated that it happened while flying over Village de Dieu neighbourhood (controlled by the 5 Secondes Gang). There were 18 people on board (three crew members and 15 passengers), although one was injured. The helicopter was damaged by the bullets. There were no casualties.

On 25 October 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 60, Ouest, members of human rights organizations held a sit-in protest in front of the Villa d'Accueil building to demand respect for the representative man that they elected to represent them at the Provisional Electoral Council.

source: Amerique Info 7; Juno 7; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 19 October 2024, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, police forces shot and injured a gang member before arresting him, in the Bremen neighbourhood. He was affiliated to the Dan F Bless Gang. 1 injured.

source: Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 17 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, Haiti and Kenya police forces clashed with gang members as they carried out a joint patrol with armored vehicles near the National Palace (Champs de Mars neighbourhood), and near Grand-Rue street (Centre-Ville neighbourhood, coded separately). Clashes also took place at the National Port Authority (APN) facilities, in La Saline (coded separately). Some sources stated that security forces managed to regain control of the APN, which had been under the control of gangs for several months. Other versions denied this and claimed that the facility did not stay under the control of gangs. Casualties unknown.

actor1: MSS: Multinational Security Support Mission in Haiti (2023-2025)
notes: Movement of forces: On 16 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, 200 police officers from Kenya arrived at the airport as part of the mission to help Haiti deal with gang violence.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Standard; Juno 7; KominoTek; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Tele Ginen; Tripotay Lakay; Vi Free Press
notes: On 29 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, armed members of the Viv Ansanm Gang opened fire on the State University of Haiti Hospital building (HUEH) (a.k.a. General Hospital), in Champs de Mars neighbourhood, as Prime Minister Garry Conille and his team were leaving the hospital's premises after being interviewed by CNN on site. Haitian and Kenyan police forces intervened and fired shots to repel the attack. Police officers, who were deployed in the area in Rue Saint-Honore got trapped. No one was injured. There were no casualties.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 30 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, Haitian and Kenyan police forces on patrol clashed with gang members as they intercepted the criminals trying to hijack a cargo of rice after having killed its driver (coded separately) near the National Port Authority (APN) facility, in La Saline neighbourhood. During clashes, a Kenyan police officer was shot and injured, while several gang members were injured and killed. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3, 1 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Haiti Standard; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Vi Free Press
notes: On 3 August 2024, in Malpasse, Ouest, overnight, Haiti and Kenya police forces clashed with members of the 400 Mawozo Gang as the criminals tried to attack a customs office located next to the Malpasse border with the Dominican Republic. The officers occupied the facility and clashed with the gang members from inside the institution. Clashes lasted until the morning of 4 August, when the gangsters managed to burn the customs office and broken down a police vehicle which was parked on the National Road 8. A police officer was injured. 1 injured.

On 28 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, overnight, gunshots were heard in Nazon. This was likely part of armed clashes between the Haitian police and military officers and Kenyan police forces with the Belair Gang. Armed clashes took place in several neighborhoods of the capital since an anti-gang operation was launched on 27 August (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 27 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, Haitian police and military officers, supported by the Kenyan police forces, clashed with the Belair Gang during anti-gang operations in the Solino, Bel Air, and Delmas 2 neighborhoods (coded separately). During clashes in Solino, several gang members were killed. At least two civilians were injured in Solino and Bel Air. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3. At least 2 injured split across two events.

On 28 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Solino throughout the day. This was likely part of armed clashes between the Haitian police and military officers and Kenyan police forces with the Belair Gang, as clashes erupted in the mentioned neighbourhood the day prior (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 17 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, Haiti and Kenya police forces clashed with gang members at the National Port Authority (APN) facilities, in La Saline. The forces were also carrying out a joint patrol with armored vehicles near the National Palace (Champs de Mars neighbourhood, coded separately), and near Grand-Rue street (Centre-Ville neighbourhood, coded separately) . Some sources stated that security forces managed to regain control of the APN, which had been under the control of gangs for several months. Other versions denied this and claimed that the facility did not stay under the control of gangs. Casualties unknown.

On 29 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Solino. This was likely part of armed clashes between the Haitian police and military officers and Kenyan police forces with the Belair Gang. Armed clashes took place in several neighborhoods of the capital since an anti-gang operation was launched on 27 August (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

Around 1 September 2024 (weekend of), in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, police forces shot and killed several gang members during an anti-gang operation in the Solino and Bel Air (coded separately) neighbourhoods. This was likely part of interventions by the Haitian and Kenyan police forces as part of the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) against gangs. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

Around 3 September 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, Haitian police and military officers, supported by the Kenyan police forces, clashed with gang members as they carried out anti-gang operations in Bas Delmas, Solino, and Fort National (coded separately). During clashes, several gang members were killed and some firearms were seized. An unspecified number of officers were injured. As part of this intervention, in Bel Air neighborhood officer carried out operations, though no clashes were reported. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3 split into three clash events recorded in three different neighborhoods.

On 3 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, Haitian police and military officers, supported by the Kenyan police forces, clashed with gang members as they carried out anti-gang operations in Bas Delmas, Solino, and Fort National (coded separately). During clashes, several gang members were killed and some firearms were seized. An unspecified number of officers were injured. As part of this intervention, in Bel Air neighborhood officer carried out operations, though no clashes were reported. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3 split into three clash events recorded in three different neighborhoods.

On 3 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, Haitian police and military officers, supported by the Kenyan police forces, clashed with gang members as they carried out anti-gang operations in Bas Delmas, Solino, and Fort National (coded separately). During clashes, several gang members were killed and some firearms were seized. An unspecified number of officers were injured. As part of this intervention, in Bel Air neighborhood officer carried out operations, though no clashes were reported. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3 split into three clash events recorded in three different neighborhoods.

source: Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vant Bef Info
notes: On 26 September 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, Haitian police and military forces, supported by the Kenyan police, clashed with Viv Ansamn gang members in the Grand Headquarters of Haiti Armed Forces neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.

On 14 October 2024, near Petion Ville - Academie, Ouest, police forces (likely supported by Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) as they clashed against the same gang during anti-gang operations in Torcelle) engaged in armed clashes with the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) during anti-gang operations near the National Police Academy. Gunshots were heard on the Freres Road. A broken down police vehicle was set on fire. Casualties unknown.

On 14 October 2024, in Petion Ville - Fort Jacques, Ouest, police forces (likely supported by Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) as they clashed against the same gang during anti-gang operations in Torcelle) engaged in armed clashes with the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) during anti-gang operations in Fort Jacques. Casualties unknown.

On 14 October 2024, in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, police forces (likely supported by Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) as they clashed against the same gang during anti-gang operations in Torcelle) engaged in armed clashes with the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) during anti-gang operations in Pernier. Gunshots were heard in the area. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; The St. Kitts Nevis Observer
notes: On 14 October 2024, in Tabarre - Torcelle, Ouest, Haitian police forces supported by Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) engaged in armed clashes with the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) during anti-gang operations in Torcelle. Twenty gang members were killed and several others were injured during clashes on 12 and 14 October. 15 firearms, 11 assault riffles, ammunition, and other materials were seized by security forces. 20 fatalities split across two events, 10 fatalities coded here. Several injured.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Haiti Progres; Juno 7; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 17 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, several gangs (likely members of the Belair Gang and the Viv Ansanm Gang) carried out a coordinated attack against several houses near the National Palace and the Law Faculty, in Champs de Mars neighbourhood. Gunshots were heard at the MUPANAH Museum as national authorities laid a wreath on the occasion of the 218th anniversary of Jean-Jacques Dessalines' assassination. The ceremony was evacuated. The Belair Gang attacked several Port-au-Prince's neighbourhoods on that day (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 17 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, the Belair Gang attacked residents in Solino, St-Michel, Delmas 24, and Fort National neighbourhoods (coded separately). Several houses were burned. Haitian police and military forces, supported by Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS), intervened and clashed with the criminals overnight, preventing them from advancing to nearby areas. During clashes, two Haitian military officers were injured. There were killed and injured, including a young woman who was hit by a stray bullet at her home, and a pregnant woman. According to residents and media, the leader of the Viv Ansanm Gang was the mastermind of the offensive in Solino. Between 17 and 20 October, at least 10 gang members were killed by security forces and there were at least 2 fatalities among civilians in the Solino neighbourhood. More than 5,000 civilians in Solino were displaced between 16 and 21 October. At least 12 fatalities split across four events, 3 fatalities coded here. 2 injured.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 21 October 2024, in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, police forces and Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) clashed with the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang during an anti-gang operation that aimed at arresting the leader of the gang. Several gang members were shot and injured. Some of them, including their leader, managed to flee. Several dozens were arrested. Several injured.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 23 October 2024, in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, police forces and Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) clashed with the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang during an anti-gang operation in an area where the criminals had installed a toll booth (coded separately). During clashes, an unspecified number of gang members were killed. Ammunition was seized by the police. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 19 October 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, overnight, Haitian police forces and Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS), supported by armed members of the population (self-defence group), shot and killed around 12 gang members during anti-gang operations in the Cite Doudoune area. Several firearms, including a riffle, were seized. At least 12 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 19 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, for the third consecutive day, Haitian police forces and Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) clashed with the Belair Gang and the Viv Ansanm Gang as they continued attacking residents in Solino and Tabarre 27 (coded separately). Several people were killed and others were injured. Some houses were burned. Between 17 and 20 October, at least 10 gang members were killed by security forces and there were at least 2 fatalities among civilians in the Solino neighbourhood. More than 5,000 civilians in Solino were displaced between 16 and 21 October. At least 12 fatalities split across four events, 3 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 20 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, for the fourth consecutive day, Haitian police forces and Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) clashed with the Belair Gang and the Viv Ansanm Gang as they continued attacking residents in Solino and Tabarre 27 (coded separately). On Anglade street (Solino), several houses were burned. Several people were killed and others were injured. Between 17 and 20 October, at least 10 gang members were killed by security forces and there were at least 2 fatalities among civilians in the Solino neighbourhood. More than 5,000 civilians in Solino were displaced between 16 and 21 October. At least 12 fatalities split across four events, 3 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 21 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, for a fifth consecutive day, Haitian police forces and Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang as the criminals continued attacking residents and burning their houses in the Solino neighbourhood. During clashes, several gang members were killed and police forces claimed to have regained the control of certain areas, although this was later denied by residents. More than 5,000 civilians in Solino were displaced between 16 and 21 October. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 24 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in Solino. During the crossfire on the Anglade Street, a police officer was shot and killed. Two other civilians were killed and several were injured by the bullets. 3 fatalities, several injured.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 7 January 2024, in the Artibonite department (coded to Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite), Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang kidnapped a public transport vehicle with around 10 female and male passengers on board. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.
Other: On 11 January 2024, in Arcahaie, Ouest, a truck was used to block the Route Nationale #1. There is no further information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.
Around 15 January 2024 (month of), in Carrefour - Mariani, Ouest, members of the Bout Ba Gang abducted dozens civilians on the National Road 2. The whereabouts of the victims remain unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Filet Info; SG Alert (Whatsapp); UN (unspecified)
notes: On 13 January 2024, in Arcahaie, Ouest, gang members from the Williamson locality killed over 10 people in the area. The report indicates that the gangsters believed that the victims had provided support to a rival armed group. At least 10 fatalities.

Non-violent activity: Around 16 February 2024 (as reported), in Carrefour, Ouest, members of the Bout Ba Gang set up a gang roadblock at the height of the Bo dlo area, in the Mariani neighbourhood, preventing drivers and cargo vehicles from circulating. The gangsters installed a toll booth that persisted for an unknown period of time.

On 1 February 2024, in Trianon, Centre, an anti-government demonstration took place on the Route Nationale #3 which was blocked. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 18 February 2024, near Thomazeau, Ouest, members of the 400 Mawozo Gang opened fire on a public transport minibus near the Morne a Cabrits peak. The driver and nine passengers were killed. Eight others were injured. The vehicle was doing the Mirebalais/Port-au-Prince route when the shooting took place. The attack was carried out near a police station as policemen were trying to expel the criminals from the National Road 3, although no interaction between the officers and the gangsters was mentioned. 10 fatalities, 8 injured.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 24 February 2024, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang beat up a woman and shot and killed her son. According to residents, the gang members interrogated the woman, asking for the whereabouts of a man and as she claimed to ignore it, the gangsters beat her up. When her son arrived and verbally confronted the gangsters for the beating, the criminals took him to the vicinity of a river and shot and killed him. His corpse was moved to the morgue although the gangsters stole it and threw it into the river. 1 fatality.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi; Undisclosed Source
notes: On 26 February 2024, in Terre Rouge, Centre, police forces shot and killed two gang members and several accomplices during a security operation in Terre Rouge and nearby Fonds Cheval area (Grand Boucan). An unknown number of gangsters and at least one police officer were injured. The deceased were described as the leader of the Ti Avion Gang (a branch of the Canaan Gang) and his brother. Two women were arrested. One was the gang leader's wife. Firearms and vehicles were seized. At least 2 fatalities, several injured.

Other: On 17 February 2024, in Thomazeau, Ouest, buses were used to set roadblocks on the Route Nationale #3 near Dlo Gaye. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.

actor2: Police Forces of Haiti (2017-2024) Prison Guards
notes: On 13 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang attacked the National Penitenciary, wounding at least four people in Du Centre Street (Centre Ville neighborhood). The police reacted and managed to arrest one gang member. At least 4 injured.

source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 1 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they intervened to expel the criminals from the Civil Prison (a.k.a. National Penitentiary). Clashes were also reported near the National Port Authority (APN) facilities (La Saline), in Champs de Mars, and on Saint-Honore street (Morne a Tuf neighbourhood) (all coded separately). At least one fatality was counted (affiliation unknown). Gunshots were heard in different areas, such as Bicentenaire, Enterrement Street, Reunion Street, Grand Rue, Mgr Guilloux Street, and Bas Delmas. This was the second consecutive day of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). At least 1 fatality, split across 4 events, 0 fatalities coded.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 5 March 2024, near Thomazeau, Ouest, armed gang members kidnapped three nuns at the residence of the Congregation of Sisters of St. Joseph of Cluny, in the Morne a Cabrits peaks. The victims were released on 6 March under unspecified circumstances.

source: Amerique Info 7; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Property destruction: On 4 March 2024, near Bois d'Orme, Ouest, overnight, gang members set fire and destroyed a police antenna in the Morne a Cabrit peak.

On 22 March 2024, in Carrefour - Mariani, Ouest, a renowned gang member of the Bout Ba gang was killed. A report indicates that he was killed by people close to him, while another indicates that another leader of the Bout Ba gang ordered the killing following an argument between the two. 1 fatality.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: Around 3 April 2024 (between 3 - 4 April), in Verrettes, Artibonite, heavily armed individuals kidnapped four people in the Savari locality (Verrettes). Two of the victims were two lawyer men who were killed by the abductors. The other two victims were released without ransom. The deceased bodies were found the next day in an area known as 'Savann papiyon' (Liancourt). Preliminary versions stated that the kidnappers were members of the Savien Gang, and another source identified them as members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang. Latest reports claimed that the attack was perpetrated by members of a self-defence group. The motivation is suspected to be a settlement of scores. 2 fatalities.

On 1 March 2024, between Petionville and Port-au-Prince - Portail Saint Joseph, Ouest, a group of women, described as Madan Sara street vendors, held a march to the Prime Minister's Office, in Saint Joseph neighbourhood, demanding that authorities restore order and security in the country. The march had initiated in Petionville.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 6 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Portail Saint Joseph, Ouest, gang members attacked the so called Cafeteria police station in the Portail Saint Joseph neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.

On 14 April 2024, in Arcahaie, Ouest, unidentified gang members hijacked a truck transporting rice towards la Gonave. The hijackers kidnapped the six members of the transportation crew. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

Around 24 April 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Bel Air, Ouest, armed individuals, led by the G-9 Gang leader, held an improvised protest in the Bel Air neighbourhood. During the mobilization, the G-9 Gang leader called on attacking police forces.

On 24 April 2024, in Arcahaie, Ouest, in the morning, armed gang members 'attacked' the Public Market and caused panic among civilians and traders, who fled the market. A video showed the gangsters taking away a quantity of sacks. According to witnesses, they left the area with a rowboat. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: Around 29 April 2024 (week of), in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, armed gang members attacked the Foyer Saint-Vincent facilities (a.k.a. Saint Vicent School for Disabled Children), located on the Paul VI street, in Centre Ville neighbourhood. An unknown number of disabled people (mostly children) were forced to flee the building. Casualties unknown.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 9 May 2024, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang killed two people and abducted three others. The whereabouts of the victims are unknown. Moments after the attack, one of the gangsters was lynched by a mob of residents (coded separately). 2 fatalities.
Around 5 May 2024 (weekend of), in Carrefour - Mariani, Ouest, police forces shot and killed the leader of a gang from Mariani during clashes in the area. 1 fatality.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 9 May 2024, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, a mob of residents lynched a member of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. The attack was a reprisal for the killing of two people and the abduction of three others moments before (coded separately). 1 fatality.

On 17 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, affiliates of the Living-Together gang alliance assaulted the Superior Court of Account and Administrative Disputes, located on the Reunion Street (in the Centre Ville neighbourhood). Police forces intervened and forced the criminals to leave the Court, although they managed to steal some materials. The gang members had tried to assault the building the day prior (coded separately).

source: Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); The St. Kitts Nevis Observer
notes: On 10 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bel Air, Ouest, armed members of the Living Together gang-led alliance, and members of the population held a protest in Bel Air and Martissant neighborhoods (coded separately) against the deployment of a Multilateral Support Security Mission (MMSS) in Haiti.

On 20 May 2024, in Thomazeau, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang attacked residents in the Dalman neighbourhood and destroyed everything they found on their way (no further details mentioned). According to sources, residents resisted and the gang members left the area in search of reinforcements. The gangsters came back a day later and killed four people (coded separately). There were no casualties.

On 21 May 2024, in Thomazeau, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, the 400 Mawozo Gang attacked the Dalman neighbourhood, killing four people and setting fire to more than 10 houses. Among the victims, there was a fisherman who was decapitated. The headquarters of the LiveBeyond Foundation were looted and vandalized. 4 fatalities.

Other: On 21 May 2024, in Thomazeau, Ouest, civilians set up roadblocks to prevent gang members from entering their communities. The barricades were erected after the 400 Mawozo Gang killed four people in the area earlier that day (coded separately).

On 10 July 2024, in Verrettes, Artibonite, a group of citizens, led by the so called Alternatiba-Haiti movement, held a march with banners to decry the use of styrofoam, a material that they described as poisoning for the environment and people. During the mobilization, protesters tried to rise aware of the risks related to using this material.

On 19 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm gang opened fire on a convoy of trucks transporting petrol to the international airport. Two of the five vehicles were damaged as they were going through the downtown area on Dekazen street. Casualties unknown.
Other: On 9 August 2024, in Arcahaie, Ouest, a roadblock was set up on the Route Nationale #1 in order to protect the area from attacks.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole
notes: On 27 August 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 2, Ouest, Haitian police and military officers, supported by the Kenyan police forces, clashed with the Belair Gang during anti-gang operations in Delmas 2, as well as in Solino and Bel Air neighborhoods (Port-au-Prince) (coded separately). Several gang members were injured and killed. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 27 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bel Air, Ouest, Haitian police and military officers, supported by the Kenyan police forces, clashed with the Belair Gang during anti-gang operations in the Bel Air, Solino, and Delmas 2 neighbourhoods (coded separately). During clashes in Bel Air, authorities stated that 18 gang members were killed, while at least three police officers were injured. The spokesperson for the Bel Air district claimed that the official figure of fatalities was fake and that it was part of the government's propaganda. He added that only two criminals were killed. At least two civilians were injured by stray bullets in Bel Air and Solino. At least 18 fatalities, at least 3 injured.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 23 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Portail Saint Joseph, Ouest, armed gang members kidnapped a Catholic priest near Notre Dame de Fatima Chapel. Six Brothers of the Sacred Heart Congregation and a teacher were also kidnapped in Morne a Tuf neighbourhood (coded separately). On the same day, up to 10 people were kidnapped in the capital, including two cameramen from Tele Amen (Christian media outlet) (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Haiti Standard; InSight Crime; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Trip Foumi
notes: On 2 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang fired shots against the National Palace (Champs de Mars, coded separately) and assaulted the Civil Prison (a.k.a. National Penitentiary), in Centre Ville neighbourhood. Police forces clashed with the gangsters in the vicinity and within the prison, resulting in at least 30 fatalities among police officers, penitentiary staff members, and prisoners. The corpses of the deceased were found around the prison and scattered in several nearby areas of the downtown. Some had gunshot wounds, some other were mutilated, burned, or tied up. An unknown number of prison workers and inmates were injured. Thousands of prisoners fled. Some imprisoned gangsters were released by their accomplices, while other inmates took the opportunity to escape. Around 90 prisoners decided to stay inside the prison when police forces left the building. They were described as the convicted in relation to the killing of President Jovenel Moise (coded separately). The gang members had spied on the facilities with a drone since 29 February. The prison's assault was part of coordinated attacks against the two major Haiti prisons led by the G-9 Gang with the support of gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). Still that day, the Ministry of Culture and Communications (Bois Verna neighbourhood) was occupied and looted. Gunshots were heard in Champs de Mars, Lalue, Bas Delmas and Poste Marchand. The building hosting Radio TV Caraibes was hit by stray bullets (Morne a Tuf). A young woman was shot in the mouth as she took refuge at the FASCH Faculty (Avenue Christophe neighbourhood). At least 30 fatalities, several injured.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News St. Lucia; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Trinidad and Tobago Guardian; Vi Free Press
notes: On 8 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, gang members attacked civilian facilities in the area and around, including the Bird School on the Enterrement street. Material damages were mentioned at the school. Police forces used megaphones to inform citizens to leave the area. Because of that, police forces clashed with gang members in the vicinity of the National Palace in the Champs de Mars neighbourhood (coded separately). Gunshots were heard throughout the day in Nazon and Lalue neighborhoods, as well as in other areas such as Alerte street, Sylvio Cator Stadium (Morne a Tuf neighborhood), Marche Salomon (Bas Peu de Choses neighborhood), Bolosse Avenue. Casualties unknown.

source: Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 17 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, Haiti and Kenya police forces clashed with gang members as they carried out a joint patrol with armored vehicles near the National Palace (Champs de Mars neighbourhood, coded separately), and near Grand-Rue street (Centre-Ville neighbourhood). Clashes also took place at the National Port Authority (APN) facilities, in La Saline (coded separately). Some sources stated that security forces managed to regain control of the APN, which had been under the control of gangs for several months. Other versions denied this and claimed that the facility did not stay under the control of gangs. Casualties unknown.
On 28 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bel Air, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in Corridor Bastia. Casualties unknown.

Around 1 September 2024 (weekend of), in Port-au-Prince - Bel Air, Ouest, police forces shot and killed several gang members during an anti-gang operation in the Bel Air and Solino (coded separately) neighbourhoods. This was likely part of interventions by the Haitian and Kenyan police forces as part of the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) against gangs. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Looting: On 10 September 2024, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, members of the Gran Grif gang robbed the Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite Savings and Credit Cooperative (COPECPRA). In addition to the money, the gangsters took everything, including the furniture.

On 15 September 2024, in Arcahaie, Ouest, a deputy acting executive officer, joined by armed individuals, crashed a socio-cultural event happening at a police officer's home that the city hall had previously prohibited. The armed individuals clashed with police officers that were present, resulting in the death of two people and a police officer being injured. The injured officer was taken to the hospital where his state remains delicate. 2 fatalities. 1 injured.

On 10 October 2024, in Arcahaie, Ouest, overnight, police forces engaged in armed clashes with members of the Taliban Gang (coming from Canaan area), who had launched an armed offensive against Arcahaie and several nearby villages (coded separately) earlier that day. Police forces were supported by members of the population, although it was not clarified whether the local residents engaged in the clashes. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Juno 7; Rezo Nodwes; Swissinfo; Trip Foumi
notes: On 10 October 2024, in Arcahaie, Ouest, gang members from Canaan and Source Matelas areas (likely affiliated with the Taliban Gang) attacked residents and set fire to houses, vehicles, and a health centre. In an area known as Ponzil, the gang members burned several churches. One source stated that the criminals were members of the Canaan Gang, although this was not confirmed by other sources. Other sources claim that criminals were Taliban Gang affiliates who also attacked nearby Vignier and Bercy villages that day (coded separately). More than 4,600 residents fled their homes in Arcahaie and Bercy (1er Boucassin communal section). At least two people were killed and several got injured. At least 2 fatalities split across three events, 0 fatalities coded in this event.

Other: On 3 October 2024, in Arcahaie, Ouest, residents set up a roadblock on the Route Nationale #1 to prevent gang members from attacking their communities. The residents' action sparked reprisals by the gang members, who attacked the Arcahaie population on 10 October (coded separately).

On 14 October 2024, between Carrefour Paye and Verrettes, Artibonite, thousands of citizens, including people from the agricultural sector, businessmen, religious group members, lawyers, political and sociocultural organizations, held a march to the Verrettes police station carrying tree branches and banners to decry insecurity and gang violence in the Artibonite department. Protesters accused the state authorities of complacency with gang members.
Other: On 14 October 2024, in Arcahaie, Ouest, a roadblock was set up on the Route Nationale #1. There is no information on the motives for the roadblock or who set it up.

On 23 October 2024, in Arcahaie, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, police and armed members of the population (self-defense group) clashed with the Canaan Gang and the Grand-Ravine Gang (part of the Viv Ansanm Gang). Several gang members were killed. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

Around 19 October 2024 (between 17 - 21 October), in Robert, Ouest, the Canaan Gang supported by the 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) attacked residents. The criminals also attacked the nearby Saint-Meddard village (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: AFP; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 15 July 2024 (month of), in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, members of a self-defence group shot and killed a 10-year-old boy and set fire to his body. He was accused of being a gang informant. 1 fatality.

On 17 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bel Air, Ouest, gang members (likely members of the Belair Gang) attacked residents in Corridor Bastia, as well as other neighborhoods, such as Delmas 24, Solino, and Fort National (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 20 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bel Air, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in Corridor Bastia (Bel Air), Sylvio Cator, St-Michel, and Solino neighborhoods (coded separately). Security forces claimed to have regained control of these areas, although this was later denied by some residents. Casualties unknown.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 30 October 2024, in the Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune, Artibonite, in the morning, armed members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang abducted around 10 farmers and civilians as they assaulted the Kleto community (in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite's second communal section) and the Motoga community (in Dessalines' fourth communal section) (coded separately). The exact number of farmers kidnapped in each location is unknown. The criminals stole scores of cattle heads. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

On 17 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Turgeau, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Turgeau. This is likely related to clashes between police and Belair Gang recorded in several Port-au-Prince's neighbourhoods on that day, following gang attacks in Solino (coded separately).

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Around 27 October 2024 (as reported), in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, police forces clashed with the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang and forced the criminals to release the National Road 1 (RN1) between Carrefour Paye and Pont Sonde. The criminals abandoned their shelters in Carrefour Paye. Casualties unknown.

On 22 October 2024, in Vignier, Ouest, police forces shot and killed around 15 gang members during clashes in Vignier, and in nearby Carrefour Poy (in Saint-Meddard) and Tamand (coded separately). At least 15 fatalities split across two events, 8 fatalities coded in this event.

On 26 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in the Solino neighbourhood. Clashes took place as the gang members continued attacking residents in Solino that day (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 28 October 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 33, Ouest, a police officer was shot and killed in Delmas 33. There is no information on the circumstances and the perpetrators. 1 fatality.
On 21 October 2024, in Tabarre - Tabarre 27, Ouest, armed confrontations were registered. There is no information on the circumstances or actors involved in the clashes. Casualties unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 15 August 2024 (month of), in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, rival gang members engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood. Between July and August, at least 81 civilians were killed during clashes and attacks in La Saline (50 men, 28 women, and three children) and 28 were injured (16 men, and 12 women). More than 20 houses were set on fire. At least 81 fatalities split across two events, 20 coded in this event.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 15 July 2024 (month of), in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, rival gang members engaged in armed clashes in La Saline neighbourhood. Between July and August, at least 81 civilians were killed during clashes and attacks in La Saline (50 men, 28 women, and three children) and 28 were injured (16 men, and 12 women). More than 20 houses were set on fire. At least 81 fatalities split across two events, 21 coded in this event.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 31 July 2024 (between 1 July - 31 August), off the Coast of Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members attacked and looted at least five freight ships. At least five people were shot and injured. At least 23 others among passengers and workers were kidnapped. Their whereabouts are unknown. At least 5 injured.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 17 July 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gang members shot and killed a man whom they accused of having raped a 16-year-old girl. 1 fatality.

source: Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Vi Free Press
notes: On 26 October 2024, in Delmas - La Paix, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang looted the Missionaries of Charity nun's compound (Catholic group congregation) and set fire to the compound's convent and hospital. There were no injuries among the nuns who were at the compound when the attack took place. The looted items were sold at a market. There were no casualties.

On 25 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, overnight, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents, set fire to houses, and looted business establishments in the Solino neighbourhood. The attack was part of a gang offensive in Solino that started on 17 October (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 26 October 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, in the morning, gang members (likely from the Viv Ansanm Gang) attacked residents in Delmas 24, Nazon, and Solino (coded separately) neighbourhoods. Casualties unknown.

On 26 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, in the morning, armed individuals (likely from the Viv Ansanm Gang) attacked residents in Nazon, Solino, and Delmas 24 (coded separately) neighbourhoods. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Vi Free Press
notes: On 26 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, in the morning, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents as they set fire to their houses in the Solino, Nazon, and Delmas 24 (coded separately) neighbourhoods. The attack was part of a gang offensive against residents in Solino that started on 17 October (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

Weapons seizure: On 30 October 2024, in Petionville, Ouest, police forces seized more than 2,500 cartridges, a 9 millimetres calibre pistol, and a charger, among other items like cell phones, as they intercepted and arrested a police officer affiliated to the Base Krache Dife Gang in the commune.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Looting: On 26 October 2024, Delogne, Artibonite, overnight, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang stole scores of cattle heads in an area known as Delogne. The criminals fired shots as they perpetrated the robbery, although no one was injured.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Property destruction: On 25 July 2024, in Gressier, Ouest, gang members used heavy machinery to demolish a Gressier police post.
Property destruction: On 23 October 2024, in Arcahaie, Ouest, gang members cut the internet cables of Digicel which caused the suspension of several services in the area.

On 5 September 2024, near Fond Gerard, Ouest, a mob of residents stabbed a 15-year-old boy with a machete and burned him alive after he was accused of having robbed a pig, in Les Palmes area. 1 fatality.
