Other: On 20 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, roadblocks were set up in Delmas 75. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.
Other: On 20 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, roadblocks were set up in Christ Roi, Turgeau, and Canape Vert. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.
Other: On 22 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, burning tires were erected in Nazon. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.
Other: On 23 October 2024, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, trucks were used to set up a roadblock in Drouillard. There is no information on the motives of the roadblock or who set it up.

Other: On 18 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard near the Sylvio Cator Stadium (Morne a Tuf neighborhood) and the Fort National neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 23 October 2024, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Duviviers. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 24 October 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Cite Militaire. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 25 October 2024, in Delmas, gunshots were heard near Pele Simon. Stray bullets were registered in Delmas 31. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 25 October 2024, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Thomassin 32. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 25 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Solino. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
On 19 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bourdon, Ouest, people protested. Tires were set up on John Brown and Martin Luther King avenues. There is no information on the motives for the protest.
On 30 October 2024, in Petit-Goave, Ouest, residents held a demonstration against the transfer of the Petit-Goave's government commissioner to another jurisdiction. The demonstrators threw stones.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 15 August 2024 (month of), in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, gangs members attacked civilians in La Saline neighbourhood. Between July and August, at least 81 civilians were killed during attacks and clashes in La Saline (50 men, 28 women, and three children) and 28 were injured (16 men, and 12 women). More than 20 houses were set on fire. At least 81 fatalities split across four events, 20 coded in this event.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 15 July 2024 (month of), in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, gangs members attacked civilians in La Saline neighbourhood. Between July and August, at least 81 civilians were killed during attacks and clashes in La Saline (50 men, 28 women, and three children) and 28 were injured (16 men, and 12 women). More than 20 houses were set on fire. At least 81 fatalities split across four events, 20 coded in this event.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 26 January 2024, in Cite Soleil - Brooklyn, Ouest, members of the Terre Noire Gang raped a 17-year-old girl several times and shot and killed her as she was on her way to school through a road outside the Brooklyn neighbourhood. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 6 August 2024, in Arcahaie, Ouest, members of the Canaan Gang and the Base 5 Secondes Gang shot and killed a civilian and injured another one as they attacked residents in the commune. Police forces, supported by the population, intervened and clashed with the criminals. 1 fatality, 1 injured.

Around 30 October 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, employees at the General Directorate of Taxation (DGI), located on Christophe Avenue, 62, held a protest to demand the departure of the head of the institution. During the protest, there was an altercation between the protesting employees and employees opposing the mobilization's demands (nature of altercation unspecified). This was part of a labor strike started in September.

On 1 January 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, hundreds of citizens held a march through the streets and toward the Arms Square demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Police forces were present, although no intervention on their side was mentioned. The mobilization (led by a former convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord) was held on the occasion of the 220th anniversary of the political independence of Haiti.

On 15 January 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Protesters claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

Around 21 January 2024 (weekend of), in Gonaives, Artibonite, residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 22 January 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires and blocked access to the communal market using merchants' tables, preventing them from developing their economic activity. Armed individuals were seen and gunshots were heard across the commune. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). Police forces were seen patrolling the area, although no intervention on their side was mentioned.

On 17 January 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, several tens of residents took to the streets to demand the resignation of Prime Minister Ariel Henry. Many barricades of flaming tires were set up in multiple parts of the city, bringing circulation to a halt. Detonations were heard in several areas of the city, forcing schools, government offices and businesses to close. Armed men were also spotted in Raboteau.
Other: On 15 January 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, gunshots were heard around the Square of Arms. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 29 January 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Alterpresse; Clin d'Oeil Info; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 5 February 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, thousands of citizens held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Protesters set up barricades on the streets (nature unspecified). This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). It was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by the Anti-Corruption Union Brigade (coded separately). The protesters also demanded the release of a former congressman who was arrested the previous month for embezzlement (not coded).

On 8 February 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, for the fourth consecutive day, government opponents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: On 6 February 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, for the second consecutive day, thousands of citizens and supporters of the EDE party held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang and armed individuals from Raboto looted and vandalized the Peace Court and the Counter-Third Party Vehicle Insurance Office (OAVCT), among other public institutions. Some items were robbed. Police forces were present, although no intervention on their side was mentioned. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Ordre des Defenseurs des Droits Humains (ORDEDH); SG Alert (Whatsapp); Trip Foumi
notes: On 19 January 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, police forces shot and killed a member of the Les Revolutionnaires of Raboteau in the Jubile area. Gunshots were later heard in Raboteau as retaliation. Businesses and other institutions were forced to close their doors in a panic. 1 fatality.

On 8 February 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, people held a demonstration and roadblocks were set in the downtown area and in Gatereau area. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 26 February 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, in the morning, moto taxi drivers affiliated to the Drivers and Owners of Motorcycle Taxis of the Artibonite Trade Union held a demonstration on the National Road 1 demanding the release of their President, who was arrested the week prior for insults and defamation against a judge. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires near Carrefour Turene.

On 27 February 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, several dozens of teachers held a sit-in protest with banners in front of a police station demanding the return of school classes. Protesters called on police forces to take their responsibility regarding the insecurity situation.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: Around 8 May 2024 (as reported), in Gonaives, Artibonite, at least two men abducted a 19-year-old woman and raped her. The perpetrators asked for a ransom of 200,000 dollars as a condition for the release of the victim. It is known that the family already paid 50,000 dollars. The two abductors were arrested by the police on 8 May, although the victim's whereabouts are unknown.

Around 24 July 2024 (week of), in Gonaives, Artibonite, gang members kidnapped a 9-year-old boy and killed him despite the payment of a ransom of 100,000 gourdes by his family. The perpetrators had asked for a ransom of 1 million gourdes. 1 fatality.

On 1 August 2024, in Torbeck, Sud, an unknown number of armed individuals on a motorcycle shot and killed a trader man and injured a businessman as they opened fire on the Valere Market (drive-by). Motivation unknown. 1 fatality, 1 injured.

On 14 August 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, residents set up burning tires and held a demonstration in front of the Toussaint Louverture police station demanding that security forces take action against the Kokorat San Ras Gang violence in the commune.

On 28 August 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, residents and moto-taxi drivers held a protest in front of the Toussaint Louverture police station demanding that security forces take action against gang violence affecting the commune.

On 30 August 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, the leader of the Polda Gang operating in Descahos attacked a police officer at the entrance of the Vincent Park (nature of the aggression unspecified). Police forces arrested him. Casualties unknown.

On 28 September 2024, in Gonaives, Centre, in the early morning, police forces shot and killed a gang member at the communal market. The deceased was described as an ally of the Kokorat San Ras Gang. 1 fatality.
Around 4 October 2024 (as reported), in Gonaives, Artibonite, hundreds of residents held a protest in front of the Toussaint Louverture police station demanding police support against gang violence.

On 8 October 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, police forces shot and killed two men at the Gonaives police station (also known as Toussaint Louverture police station). The deceased men were described as members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang who had opened fire on the police facility moments before. 2 fatalities.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 24 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang and the Viv Ansanm Gang perpetrated an attack against residential areas around the National Palace (Champs de Mars neighbourhood). Two city blocks were destroyed. Casualties unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 15 January 2024, in Carrefour - Fontamara, a member of the Ti Bwa Gang (described as a 16-year-old boy) raped a 7-year-old girl in the Fontamara neighbourhood.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 15 January 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, two members of the Delmas 95 Gang raped a 17-year-old girl at a building. The victim was intercepted on the street as she was walking home. She got pregnant and then suffered an abortion. After the attack, she took refuge in the Dominican Republic.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 18 February 2024, in Carrefour - Fontamara, members of the Ti Bwa Gang raped a 15-year-old girl with mental disability in the Fontamara neighbourhood.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Weapons seizure: Around 15 April 2024 (month of), in Cap-Haitien, Nord, 26 firearms and 999 ammo were seized.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 15 May 2024 (month of), near Tabarre - Mais Gate/Clercine 2, Ouest, gang members raped a gay man at his home, located near the Toussaint Louverture Airport (Mais Gate/Clercine 2). The attack was perpetrated after the victim's boyfriend failed to pay an extortion demanded by the gang members. The couple took refuge abroad after the attack.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 15 May 2024 (month of), in the Ouest department (coded to Port-au-Prince), the Kraze Barye Gang engaged in armed clashes with members of a faction of the gang. The faction's leader was killed. The motivation for the clashes was an internal conflict over the leadership of the Kraze Barye Gang. 1 fatality.

On 1 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, police forces and armed residents clashed with gang members (likely from the Viv Ansanm Gang) as they intervened and expelled the criminals from the Solino neighbourhood. Solino had been under gang attack since 17 October (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

Around 2 November 2024 (between 1 - 2 November), near Port-au-Prince - Gabelliste/Grand Cimetiere, Ouest, gunshots were heard near the Grand Cemetery and the Monseigneur Guilloux street (in Gabelliste/Grand Cimetiere neighbourhood). The gunshots suspectedly are part of armed clashes between police forces and gang members, who have engaged in clashes in the vicinity of the cemetery since February 2024. Casualties unknown.

source: Juno 7; Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: Around 4 November 2024 (as reported), near Trois Ponts, Artibonite, police forces and agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MSS) clashed with the Kokorat San Ras Gang and took control of the National Road 1 (NR1) at the height of Savane Desolee. Several criminals were killed during clashes. Some others managed to flee. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 5 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in the Fort National neighbourhood as they intervened to expel the criminals from areas which had been under attack since 2 November (coded separately). Several gang members were killed during clashes. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 6 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in the Fort National neighbourhood as they intervened to expel the criminals from areas which had been under attack since 2 November (coded separately). Several gang members were killed during clashes. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 7 November 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 40b, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals kidnapped a woman and her daughter at their home, in Delmas 40 B. There is no information on the perpetrators and circumstances of the abduction, but the latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. Their whereabouts are unknown.

On 8 November 2024, in Delmas - Musseau, Ouest, in the morning, an unknown number of individuals perpetrated a kidnapping at the height of Musseau neighbourhood. The number of kidnapped victims and their whereabouts are unknown. There is no information on the perpetrators and circumstances of the abduction, but the latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related.

On 8 November 2024, in Delmas - Puits Blain, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals kidnapped two schoolchildren as they were on their way to the school centre. Their whereabouts are unknown. There is no information on the perpetrators and circumstances of the abduction, but the latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related.

Weapons seizure: On 8 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, police forces intercepted a police officer in possession of 2,400 cartridges, a Glock 17 firearm, an assault riffle, four chargers, and two cell phones.

On 2 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, overnight, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents on the ruelle Boisson street, in the Fort National neighbourhood. Several houses were set on fire, while an unknown number of civilians were shot and killed. Others were injured by the bullets. Some residents fled their homes. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 3 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, overnight, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents in the Fort National neighbourhood. Several houses were set on fire, while an unknown number of civilians were shot and killed. Others were injured by the bullets. Hundreds of residents fled their homes. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 4 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, for a third consecutive day, the Viv Ansanm Gang opened fire and tear gas on residents in the Fort National neighbourhood. Several houses were set on fire, while an unknown number of civilians were shot and killed. Others were injured by the bullets. Some residents fled their homes. Gunshots were heard throughout the day and overnight. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 6 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents and set fire to their houses in Fort National and Solino (coded separately). During the attack in Fort National, several civilians were killed. Some of the victims' bodies were taken away by the gang members or burned. Residents fled their homes. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 6 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents and set fire to their houses in Solino and Fort National (coded separately). During the attack in Solino, at least three civilians were killed, including a man known for being a football coach. He was shot in the head. Some of the victims' bodies were taken away by the gang members or burned. Residents fled their homes. At least 3 fatalities.

On 7 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents and set fire to their houses in the Fort National neighbourhood. The attack was in reprisal for the police killing of several gang members during clashes between 5 and 6 November (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

Property destruction: On 14 August 2024, around Baie d'Orange, Sud-Est, police forces seized and destroyed a marihuana field in Bois Codene. According to the police a suspect was identified as the manager of the field who lives in Petionville.

source: Haiti Press Network; Vant Bef Info
notes: On 18 May 2024, in Fond d'Icaque, Grande-Anse, a group of 30 individuals dressed in black clothes and led by a Catholic Christian priest attacked a female voodoo leader and her daughter as they participated in a march on the occasion of the Flag Festival commemoration. The rioters threatened to stone the victims and set them on fire. No further details were mentioned. The attack seemed to be a hate crime.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 11 May 2024, in Gressier - Grand Saline, Ouest, in the morning, members of the Grand-Ravine Gang engaged in armed clashes with police forces in the Bateau area. During clashes, two civilians were killed by the stray bullets. They were a woman who was hit in the back, and a man hit to the head. 2 fatalities.

On 13 April 2024, off the Coast of Lafiteau, Ouest, armed gang members hijacked a rice cargo ship at the height of the Flour Mill (Lafiteau) which destination was La Gonave island. Six on-board occupants were kidnapped while 1,500 rice sacks were stolen. The whereabouts of the victims are unknown.
On 14 March 2024, in Cite Soleil - Drouillard, Ouest, police forces on a patrol shot and killed two men in the Drouillard neighbourhood. Motivation unknown. 2 fatalities.

On 23 February 2024, near Toutier, Centre, armed members of the population shot and killed a local leader of the Canaan Gang who used to operate on the National Road 9. The killing took place while he was at a voodoo ceremony, in the Crete Brulee communal section. The perpetrators were supporting police forces in the fight of gangsters in the Mirebalais commune. 1 fatality.

source: Haiti Progres; International Crisis Group; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Le Placentin; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 31 January 2024, off the Coast of Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, members of the Bout Ba Gang abducted 70 passengers (including children and a baby) from a vessel that was carrying merchandise off the shore of the Mariani neighborhood. The victims were released on 6 February 2024.

On 30 January 2024, in Cite Soleil - Drouillard, Ouest, members of the G-9 Gang engaged in armed clashes with rival gangsters affiliated to the G-Pep La Gang in Drouillard area. Dozens people were killed. Several dozen families fled their homes to take refuge elsewhere. At least 12 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 6 January 2024, off the Coast of Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, unidentified gang members attacked a public transport canoe at the height of the Alpha Village, shooting and killing at least seven men and women, including several merchants. The canoe's destination was the coast of Gressier. The gangsters threw some corpses into the sea. An unknown number of passengers were injured. Several were kidnapped, including three women. Some of them were released. The whereabouts of the rest are unknown. At least 7 fatalities.

Around 10 November 2024 (weekend of), in Cite Soleil - Drouillard, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members (likely from the Viv Ansanm Gang) as the criminals attacked residents in the Drouillard neighbourhood (coded separately). This happened as the Viv Ansanm Gang threatened with armed offensives after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Looting: On 4 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, members of the Grand-Ravine Gang and the Base 5 Secondes Gang fired shots near the Civil Prison (a.k.a. National Penitentiary) -located in the Centre Ville neighbourhood-, and looted the Saint-Francois de Sales Hospital (Catholic Christian institution), in the Morne a Tuf neighbourhood. The looting, which was recorded on video, took place when the building was empty. The staff members and patients had been evacuated on 29 February. The French Asylum private hospital, on the Centre street, and the Faculty of Midwines (in Bas Peu de Choses neighbourhood), were looted that same day. Four buses and a private vehicle were stolen.

On 5 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, a military officer was shot and killed by a stray bullet while he was at a police office near the National Palace. Authorship unknown. 1 fatality.

On 1 March 2024, in Cite Soleil - Drouillard, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Cite Soleil - Drouillard. A report indicates that some passersby were wounded in the area. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots. Casualties unknown.

source: Juno 7; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: Weapons seizure: On 14 November 2024, in the Centre department (coded to Mirebalais), Centre, police forces seized two riffles, one pistol, a revolver, 21 cartridges, two white weapons, a quantity of marijuana, and several vehicles during an operation at a house in a locality known as 'Mamon'. The operation aimed at dismantling a criminal organization. A man was arrested in connection with the seizure.

On 11 November 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked the commune after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). Simultaneous attacks were launched in neighborhoods of Port-au-Prince, Petionville, Tabarre, and Croix-des-Bouquets communes (coded separately). Hours before, the leader of the 400 Mawozo Gang had warned residents of Croix-des-Bouquets not to take to the streets as the Viv Ansanm Gang was planning to do so. Casualties unknown.

On 11 November 2024, in Fonds-Parisien, Ouest, members of the 400 Mawozo Gang invaded the Fonds-Parisin commune. No further details on the invasion were mentioned. This was likely in support of the Viv Ansanm Gang, whose members had launched simultaneous attacks in several communes in the Ouest department (coded separately) after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

Other: On 10 November 2024, in Carrefour, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Fontamara neighbourhood. This was likely the authorship of the Viv Ansanm Gang, who had threatened with armed offensives after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). Gunshots were also heard in Port-au-Prince, Cite Soleil, Delmas, and Tabarre communes (coded separately).

Other: On 10 November 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, overnight, gunshots were heard along the Airport Road. This was likely the authorship of the Viv Ansanm Gang, who had threatened with armed offensives after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). Gunshots were also heard in Port-au-Prince, Tabarre, Cite Soleil, Carrefour, and Petionville communes (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; The St. Kitts Nevis Observer; Trip Foumi
notes: On 11 November 2024, between Cite Soleil - Drouillard and Delmas - Kernizan, Ouest, police forces and members of a self-defense group shot and killed two injured patients outside the La Paix University Hospital (in Kernizan neighbourhood, Delmas). The executions took place as the officers intercepted a Doctors Without Borders (MSF) ambulance transporting three wounded men to a MSF hospital in the Drouillard neighbourhood (Cite Soleil), and forced the driver to change the way towards another hospital in Delmas. Once in Delmas, the officers punctured the ambulance's tires to force the wounded men and the MSF workers out of the vehicle. The now deceased were moved to a nearby area before being killed. One source identified them as gang members, while the majority of reports did not clarify this. They were likely shot during clashes with police forces in Drouillard over the weekend (coded separately). The MSF workers were fired with tear gas, held against their will for four hours, and threatened. The ambulance was damaged. A second vehicle was used to transport them. 2 fatalities.

source: Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Trip Foumi
notes: On 11 November 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked the Delmas 28 neighbourhood. Several people were injured by the bullets during gang attacks in the Delmas commune that day. This was part of a Viv Ansanm Gang offensive after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). Between 11 and 14 November, at least 29 people were shot and injured as part of armed violence in Delmas. At least 29 injured split across six events. 5 injured coded here.

Other: On 10 November 2024, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Vivy Mitchell and Freres neighborhoods. This was likely the authorship of the Viv Ansanm Gang, who had threatened with armed offensives after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). Gunshots were also heard in Port-au-Prince, Cite Soleil, Carrefour, Delmas, and Tabarre communes (coded separately).

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Looting: On 16 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, unidentified individuals looted the Caribbean Port Services' containers (in Wharf de la Saline)

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 17 March 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the Belair Gang set fire to houses in the commune. Casualties unknown.

Other: On 10 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, overnight, gunshots were heard in the Martin Luther King Avenue, at the height of the Nazon neighbourhood. This was likely the authorship of the Viv Ansanm Gang, who attacked the nearby Solino neighbourhood on that day (coded separately), and who had also threatened with armed offensives after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). Gunshots were also heard in Tabarre, Cite Soleil, Carrefour, Delmas, and Petionville communes (coded separately).

Other: On 11 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a roadblock of burning tires was set up in front of the Immigration Office, located in the Lalue neighbourhood. There is no information on the circumstances and the authorship of the roadblock.

Non-violent activity: Around 13 November 2024 (between 11 - 15 November), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, members of a self-defense group installed road checkpoints and carried out searches to road users and drivers in Canape-Vert.

source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 12 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang shot and killed a woman doctor and injured a man doctor on Cameau Street (Bas Peu de Choses neighbourhood). The attack took place as the victims were travelling in a vehicle after leaving the clinic where both used to work. The victims were daughter and father. 1 fatality, 1 injured.

On 10 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents in the Solino neighbourhood. At least a young woman was shot and killed, while several other civilians were injured. The attack took place after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). At least 1 fatality, several injured.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Trip Foumi
notes: On 11 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents and burned their houses in the Solino neighbourhood. Some residents threw stones and bottles as they tried to resist the gang offensive. A young musician man was shot and killed. There were several injured, including a elderly woman. The Viv Ansanm Gang launched simultaneous attacks in neighborhoods of Port-au-Prince, Petionville, Tabarre, and Croix-des-Bouquets communes (coded separately) after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). 1 fatality, at least 1 injured.

On 12 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, for a third consecutive day, the Viv Ansanm Gang attack residents in the Solino neighborhood. At least one of the victims was a man whose body was found on the street. At least 13 people were killed during gang attacks in Solino and Ti Cherie neighborhoods (coded separately) on that day. At least 13 fatalities split across two events. 6 fatalities coded here.

source: Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 14 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, for a fifth consecutive day, members of the Belair Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang) raped women, attacked residents, and set fire to their houses in the Solino neighborhood. An unknown number of people were killed. Others fled their homes. The criminals had taken control of Solino the day prior after clashes with police forces (coded separately). Armed clashes were also reported in the area on 14 November (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 12 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Ti Cherie, the Viv Ansanm Gang killed at least two people as they set fire to the Ti Cherie neighbourhood (up to four fatalities according to another source). The victims were described as young people who were resisting the gang members assault, although it was not clarified if they were members of self-defense groups. At least 13 people were killed during gang attacks in Ti Cherie and Solino neighborhoods (coded separately) on that day. At least 13 fatalities split across two events. 7 fatalities coded here.

Other: On 10 November 2024, in Tabarre, Ouest, overnight, gunshots were heard in Tabarre 27, Chateau Blond, and Torcelle neighborhoods. This was likely the authorship of the Viv Ansanm Gang, who had threatened with armed offensives after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). Gunshots were also heard in Port-au-Prince, Cite Soleil, Carrefour, Delmas, and Petionville communes (coded separately).

source: Amerique Info 7; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 11 November 2024, in Tabarre, Ouest, armed individuals (likely from the Viv Ansanm Gang) perpetrated a kidnapping in the commune. The number of victims and their whereabouts are unknown. Sporadic gunshots were heard in Cazeau, Torcelle, Chateau Blond, and Caradeux neighborhoods. The Viv Ansanm Gang launched simultaneous attacks in neighborhoods of Port-au-Prince, Petionville, Tabarre, and Croix-des-Bouquets communes (coded separately) after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately).
Around 11 November 2024 (as reported), in Tabarre, Ouest, armed clashes were registered in the commune. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; El Nacional (Dominican Republic); Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 11 November 2024, in Tabarre - Aeroport Toussaint Louverture, Ouest, armed members of the Viv Ansanm Gang shot at a Spirit Airlines aircraft when it was about to land at the Toussaint Louverture Airport. There were no casualties among the passengers, although a stewardess was injured by a bullet as the plane was hit by at least four shots. The flight came from the US and diverted to the Dominican Republic, where the pilot landed. On the same day, a JetBlue aircraft that had taken off towards New York (US) was shot at by the gang members. No injuries were reported. The Viv Ansanm Gang launched simultaneous attacks in neighborhoods of Port-au-Prince, Petionville, Tabarre, and Croix-des-Bouquets communes (coded separately) after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). 1 injured.

On 12 November 2024, in Tabarre, Ouest, gang members (likely from the Viv Ansanm Gang) engaged in armed clashes with police forces in the commune. Gunshots were heard in Croix-des-Missions. Armed individuals were seen in the area, but there is no information on the circumstances of the gunshots. According to the UN spokesman, there were more than 20 armed clashes on 12 November in the Port-au-Prince metropolitan area. The UN reported at least 150 fatalities in violent events that happened during the 11 November week, around 83 fatalities were reported during clashes between police and gangs. 83 fatalities split into 11 armed clash events between police forces and gangs coded between 11 and 15 November in Port-au-Prince. 7 fatalities coded in this event.

source: Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: Other: On 11 November 2024, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, roadblocks of burning tires were set up in Carrefour Vincent (Sarthe neighbourhood), and in the Drouillard and Duvivier neighborhoods. This was likely the authorship of civilians trying to resist gang members attacking Sarthe area on that day (coded separately) and Drouillard over the weekend (coded separately).

On 12 November 2024, in Cite Soleil - Drouillard, Ouest, gang members (likely from the Canaan Gang) attacked the Drouillard and Sarthe neighborhoods (coded separately) as they tried to invade the area. This was likely in support of the Viv Ansanm Gang offensive launched after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). The UN reported several fatalities in attacks perpetrated by gangs that happened between 11 and 15 November in Port-au-Prince and at least 150 fatalities in all violent events that happened during said week. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: GardaWorld; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: Around 11 November 2024 (as reported), in Delmas, Ouest, armed clashes (likely between police forces and gang members) were registered in the commune. Between 11 and 14 November, at least 29 people were shot and injured as part of armed violence in Delmas. At least 29 injured split across six events (4 injured coded here). The UN reported at least 150 fatalities in violent events that happened during the 11 November week, around 83 fatalities were reported during clashes between police and gangs. 83 fatalities split into 11 armed clash events between police forces and gangs coded between 11 and 15 November in Port-au-Prince. 8 fatalities coded in this event.

notes: On 11 November 2024, in Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13, Ouest, police forces clashed with armed gang members (likely from the Viv Ansanm Gang) in the Carrefour Aeroport neighbourhood. Civilians who were around were seen hiding to avoid being hit by the bullets. Several people were shot and wounded. Gunshots were heard on Airport Road, as well as in Pele Simon and Delmas 19. The Viv Ansanm Gang launched simultaneous attacks in neighborhoods of Port-au-Prince, Petionville, Tabarre, and Croix-des-Bouquets communes (coded separately) after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). notes: Other: On 8 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, eight out of the nine Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) members signed a resolution stating the replacement of Garry Conille by Alix Didier Fils-Aime as the head of the Transitional Government. On 11 November, the decision (taken by consensus) was published in Le Moniteur, the official journal of the Republic of Haiti. Alix Didier Fils-Aime sworn as Prime Minister (PM) on the same day, and was installed at the PM's residence in Musseau neighbourhood. Garry Conille contested the PTC decision considering it illegal and unconstitutional. A new government integrated by 18 ministers took office on 16 November.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Vi Free Press

notes: Weapons seizure: On 19 November 2024, in Petionville, Ouest, in the early morning, police forces intercepted members of the Viv Ansanm Gang in a truck and seized hundreds of ammunition, two drones, several firearms, and telecommunication materials, in the Panamericaine Avenue (Panamericaine neighbourhood). Five gang members were arrested and some others managed to flee and take refuge elsewhere. The seizure took place moments before clashes with the Viv Ansanm Gang (coded separately).

The seizures took place moments before armed clashes with the Viv Ansanm Gang (coded separately).

notes: Around 17 November 2024 (between 16 - 18 November), in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm attacked the Solino neighbourhood. Gunshots were heard. notes: On 8 March 2024, in Ganthier, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang killed at least 11 civilians as they attacked residential areas in the commune. At least 11 fatalities.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Haiti Progres
notes: On 9 March 2024, in Ganthier, Ouest, gang members (likely from the 400 Mawozo Gang) attacked a police station and took control of the area. Members of the mentioned gang attacked residents in Ganthier the day prior (coded separately). On that day, the 400 Mawozo leader was seen at the Croix-des-bouquets police station mocking Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Casualties unknown.

source: Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 21 July 2024, in Ganthier, Ouest, in the morning, members of the 400 Mawozo Gang set fire to a police station and attacked a customs office as they attacked residents in the commune. At least four civilians were killed, including a woman. Two of the fatal victims were identified as the former mayor of Ganthier and his nephew. The former politician was tortured before being killed. Several other civilians went missing. The gang offensive was described as a reprisal for the police intervention against gangs in nearby Croix-des-Bouquets (coded separately). In early August, one source counted up to 15 fatalities among civilians as part of gang attacks in Ganthier in late July. Another source counted more than 20, although this was not confirmed by authorities. Between 21 July and 4 August, members of this gang killed at least 12 civilians and injured three others during attacks against Ganthier. At least 12 fatalities split across two events. 6 coded here.
Property destruction: On 25 July 2024, in Ganthier, Ouest, members of the 400 Mawozo Gang destroyed the commune's police station facility after it was set on fire on 21 July (coded separately).

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Metropole; Vi Free Press
notes: On 29 July 2024, in Ganthier, Ouest, Haitian and Kenyan police forces clashed with armed gang members as they intervened to expel the criminals from the commune after a new gang offensive was launched. The criminals were likely affiliates of the 400 Mawozo Gang, whose members killed several civilians during attacks in Ganthier between 21 July and 4 August (coded separately). The number of casualties during clashes was not clarified. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Vi Free Press
notes: On 24 July 2024, in Ganthier, Ouest, Haitian and Kenyan police forces shot and killed several gang members as they carried out anti-gang operations in the commune. The criminals were likely affiliates of the 400 Mawozo Gang, whose members killed several civilians during attacks in Ganthier between 21 July and 4 August (coded separately). Between 24 and 25 July, three gangsters were killed by the police. 3 fatalities split across two events, 2 coded in this event.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Vi Free Press
notes: On 25 July 2024, in Ganthier, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, Haitian and Kenyan police forces shot and killed several gang members as they carried out anti-gang operations in the commune. The criminals were likely affiliates of the 400 Mawozo Gang, whose members killed several civilians during attacks in Ganthier between 21 July and 4 August (coded separately). Between 24 and 25 July, three gangsters were killed by the police. 3 fatalities split across two events, 1 coded in this event.

Property destruction: On 28 July 2024, in Ganthier, Ouest, the leader of the 400 Mawozo Gang destroyed the Bonnet bridge linking Ganthier to Fonds-Parisien. Also, gang members looted houses and business establishments.

Non-violent activity: On 3 August 2024, in Bonnet, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang members welded iron bars at the Bonnette bridge and barricaded the infrastructure, blocking traffic towards Ganthier, Fonds Parisien, and Malpasse.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Loop News Haiti
notes: On 1 August 2024, in Ganthier commune, Ouest, gang members attacked residents at the Mare Roseaux communal section. The criminals were likely affiliates of the 400 Mawozo Gang. Between 21 July and 4 August, members of this gang killed at least 12 civilians and injured three others during attacks against Ganthier. At least 12 fatalities split across two events. 6 coded here.

Around 12 August 2024 (as reported), in Ganthier, Ouest, Haiti and Kenya police forces clashed with gang members in the commune. It is known that the national police escorted the Kenyan forces to flee safely as the criminals opened fire on them. Casualties unknown.

On 28 August 2024, in Ganthier, Ouest, residents from Ganthier and Fonds-Parisien took to the street of the commune against insecurity and demanding that authorities take responsibility for the situation.

On 10 May 2024, in Gressier - Cite Gressier, Ouest, the 103 Zombies Gang killed a woman and raped her 14-year-old and 15-year-old granddaughters at her house, in an area known as 'Bo Lanme', near the Cite Gressier police station. 1 fatality.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Property destruction: On 25 November 2024, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif Gang set fire to the already damaged police station of Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite (coded separately) and blocked the road leading to Liancourt. The station's destruction took place hours after authorities announced the reopening of the Liancourt police station.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 24 November 2024, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang killed a person and kidnapped at least five members of a local self-defence group as they attacked the Colin village (located at the Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite 3rd communal section). The criminals stole several motorcycles. The victims' whereabouts are unknown. 1 fatality.
Other: On 16 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a roadblock was set up in Canape Vert. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock and who set it up.
Other: On 20 November 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, burning tires were set up in Delmas 48. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

Other: On 20 November 2024, in Petionville, Ouest, a roadblock was set up in Thomassin 48, Morne Lazare, Peguy Ville, and Juvenat road. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

Other: On 20 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, roadblock were set up in different areas, such as Faustin, Riviere, Lamartiniere, Bois Patate, and Dalencourt roads, as well as in Debrosse. There is no information on the circumstances about the roadblocks or who set them up.

Around 15 May 2024 (month of), in Cite Soleil - Brooklyn, Ouest, four members of the G-9 Gang raped a 25-year-old woman in the Brooklyn neighbourhood. She was attacked as she was walking on the street.

On 23 November 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, four police officers on patrol arrested and attacked a lawyer man and human rights defender at the Bienac 23 area. The attack was described as an assassination attempt. No further details were mentioned. There were no fatalities.

On 23 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bois Verna, Ouest, police forces dressed in black clothes who arrived in a vehicle with no plates shot and killed a man on Ruelle Robin Street in Bois Verna neighbourhood. The officers fled from the scene leaving the corpse on the street. The killing was an extrajudicial execution. Motivation unknown. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 23 November 2024, near Kenscoff - Belo, Ouest, police forces supported by members of the population killed four out of five gang members who were intercepted in a vehicle and who refused to obey the police instructions. As clashes erupted between police forces and the gang members, a gangster who used to work for a gang leader known as 'Didi' was shot. Armed residents took part in the clashes and lynched four criminals. The fifth one managed to escape. The police seized a vehicle and two firearms. Clashes took place in Viard at the entrance of Le Montcel. According to police, the now deceased planned to attack the Kenscoff commune. 4 fatalities.

On 7 October 2024, in Gressier, Ouest, police forces clashed with armed gang members as the criminals attacked the officers' position. During clashes, several gang members were killed, while a police officer who was shot in the leg died because of the wounds. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 21 November 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 65, Ouest, six gang members were killed (likely amidst clashes with police forces and armed members of the population) between Delmas 57, Delmas 59 (Delmas 65 neighbourhood) and Christ-Roi neighbourhood in Port-au-Prince (coded separately). 6 fatalities split across two events. 3 fatalities coded here.

On 21 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Christ-Roi, Ouest, six gang members were killed (likely amidst clashes with police forces and armed members of the population) between the Christ-Roi neighbourhood, and Delmas 57 and Delmas 59 areas in Delmas (coded separately). 6 fatalities split across two events. 3 fatalities coded here.

On 23 November 2024, in Delmas - Rimbole, Ouest, an unknown number of armed individuals (likely gang members, due to ongoing control of almost all of the commune by gangs) shot and killed three men at a house on Didine Street (which crosses the Rimbole and Puits Blain neighbourhoods). The motivation for the attack is unknown. 3 fatalities.
On 17 October 2024, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, thousands of residents called by former convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord, Guy Philippe, held a protest against the national government.

On 21 November 2024, near Gros-Morne, Artibonite, the Ti Bwa Gang kidnapped a health worker man along the Grepen Road as he was transporting medicines to the Alma Mater hospital, located in Gros-Morne. His whereabouts are unknown.

Around 16 November 2024 (as reported), in Delmas - Delmas 60, Ouest, armed men likely killed a person and the burnt body was found in Delmas 60. The circumstances around the incident are unclear, though similar attacks were recorded in Port-au-Prince commune on the same day (coded separately). 1 fatality.
Other: On 16 November 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard on the Airport Road near Pele Simon. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 16 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Bas Peu de Choses, Turgeau, and Canape Vert. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship on the gunshots.
Other: On 17 November 2024, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Pelerin 5. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 17 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the downtown area, in Bel Air, and Portail Leogane. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 17 November 2024, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard around the OAVCT and US embassy area (Chateau Blond neighborhood). There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 18 November 2024, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Sarthe and Douillard. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Non-violent activity: On 27 November 2024, in Petionville, Ouest, in the early morning, gang members set up roadblocks in Pernier 12 A, Pernier 12, Pernier 10, and Deye Lise to prevent police forces from entering the Pernier neighbourhood. The criminals used broken-down vehicles to cut the roads.

On 24 November 2024, in Delmas - Cite Numero Un, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents and looted and destroyed houses in Delmas 6 (Cite Numero Un neighbourhood) and Delmas 4 (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 24 November 2024, in Delmas - Saint-Martin, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents and looted and destroyed houses in Delmas 4 (Saint-Martin neighbourhood) and Delmas 6 (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: PNH: National Police of Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 18 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they carried out anti-gang interventions in Solino and Bel Air (Port-au-Prince), Bas Delmas and Carrefour Aeroport (Delmas), and Tabarre (Tabarre) (coded separately). Gunshots were also heard in the neighboring areas of Fort National and Nazon. During clashes, several gang members were shot and injured. Several injured.

Around 17 November 2024 (between 16 - 18 November), in Delmas - Delmas 32, Ouest, gang members attacked the Delmas 32 neighbourhood. Two internal displaced residents sheltering at nearby Terrain Accra area were shot and injured by stray bullets. 2 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Standard; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 13 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, Haitian police forces and Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang as they attacked residents in the Solino neighbourhood (coded separately). During clashes at the Pean Market area, a police officer and three civilians were killed. Residents fled their homes. The UN reported at least 150 fatalities in violent events that happened during the 11 November week, around 83 fatalities were reported during clashes between police and gangs. 83 fatalities split into 11 armed clash events between police forces and gangs coded between 11 and 15 November in Port-au-Prince. 7 fatalities coded in this event.

On 26 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, police forces and agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) clashed with gang members in Champs de Mars as the criminals tried to invade the area. Casualties unknown.
On 2 December 2024, in Cite Soleil - Drouillard, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in Drouillard. Gunshots were heard. Casualties unknown.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole
notes: On 18 January 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, armed individuals set up roadblocks and barricades in Lizon neighbourhood, among others. This is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). Police forces intervened to remove the roadblocks, although no interaction with the armed individuals was mentioned.

On 16 January 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, a protest was registered near Radio Tele Zenith. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the incidents, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).
Other: On 18 January 2024, in Cayes-Jacmel, Sud-Est, a barricade was set up in Raymond Crossroad. There is no information on the circumstances and motivations for the roadblock.

Other: On 19 January 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, roadblocks were reported, as well as in the Lilavois and Lizon neighborhoods. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.
Other: On 8 February 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, a roadblock was set up on the Route Nationale #1. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

On 29 February 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, gangs members attacked civilians in La Plaine du Cul-de-Sac areas. At least two civilians were killed and two others were injured. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. At least 2 fatalities.

On 7 February 2024, in Cayes-Jacmel, Sud-Est, people protested and set up barricades throughout the city. This is part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Meyer, Sud-Est, people held a demonstration and roadblocks were set on the Meyer Route. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

Looting: Around 3 March 2024 (weekend of), in Bon Repos, Ouest, the Canaan Gang and the Chien Mechant Gang looted the facilities of several private companies, including transfer houses and food depots. They also looted the facilities of the National Old Age Insurance Office (ONA).
Other: On 1 March 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, roadblocks were set up. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.
Other: On 2 March 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, blockades were registered in Lizon. There is no information on the circumstances of the blockades or who set them up.
Other: On 4 March 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, roadblocks were set up in Lizon. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.
Other: On 5 March 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, roadblocks were set up in Lizon. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.
Other: On 6 March 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, roadblocks were set up in Lizon. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.

Looting: On 15 March 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, warehouses were looted. This action is likely related to other lootings by armed men recorded in the metropolitan area of Port-au-Prince. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship behind the incidents.

source: Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News St. Lucia; Rezo Nodwes
notes: Property destruction: On 7 April 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, overnight, members of the Canaan Gang used an excavator and demolished an empty police station. The police facility had been under the control of the gangsters since they attacked the building on 29 February (coded separately).

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 23 March 2024, in Vivier, Ouest, an unknown number of armed individuals kidnapped a man at his home, in Lilavois 23. The man was a musician at a Baptist Church. There is no information on the perpetrators although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victim's whereabouts are unknown.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Looting: On 8 March 2024, near Bon Repos, Ouest, armed gang members looted UNIBANK and SOGEBANK offices in Lathan area. The scenes of looting persisted in the bank branch until 9 March.

On 6 July 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, an unknown number of individuals kidnapped a doctor in the Lizon neighbourhood. The abductors asked for a ransom as a condition for his release. The victim's whereabouts are unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Looting: On 23 May 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, members of the Base Krache Dife Gang (a.k.a. Pierre VI Gang) looted and vandalized the Bon Espoir orphanage (Evangelical Christian) in the Lizon neighbourhood, in La Plaine du Cul-de-Sac area. The gang members stole some items.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 17 March 2024, in Delmas - 1er Cite Saint Martin, Ouest, the Delmas 6 Gang fired shots in Delmas 8 (Cite Saint Martin neighbourhood) in unknown circumstances. A 15-year-old girl was shot and killed by the stray bullets. 1 fatality.

On 30 November 2024, around Gressier - Petit Boucan, Ouest, the 103 Zombies Gang shot and injured two people as they attacked residents in the Echalot village. Following the attack, police forces intervened and clashed with the criminals (coded separately). 2 injured.

Other: On 28 November 2024, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, a roadblock was set up on Rue Hubert in the Drouillard neighborhood and another on Rue Aral in the Sarthe neighborhood. There is no information on the motives for the roadblock or who set it up.

On 2 December 2024, near Petion Ville - Academie, Ouest, the Kraze Barye Gang attacked civilians in the 'Kajwo' locality (less than 1 km away from the Police Academy). At least five people were killed and several were injured. Houses were robbed and looted. Police forces later intervened and clashed with the criminals (coded separately). At least 5 fatalities.

On 28 November 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, rival members of the Canaan Gang and the Chien Mechant Gang engaged in armed clashes in the Lilavois neighbourhood, and in nearby Rosembert area in Chapini village (coded separately). Clashes erupted over the control of a toll booth. Casualties unknown.

On 28 November 2024, in Chapini, Ouest, rival members of the Canaan Gang and the Chien Mechant Gang engaged in armed clashes in the Rosembert area, and in nearby Lilavois neighbourhood in Bon Repos (coded separately). Clashes erupted over the control of a toll booth. Casualties unknown.
On 25 November 2024, in Petion Ville - Jacquet Toto, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members on the Freres road. Casualties unknown.
Other: On 25 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a barricade was set up at the entrance of Christ-Roi. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.
Other: On 28 November 2024, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Carrefour Vincent in the Sarthe neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
On 26 November 2024, in Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members on the airport road. Casualties unknown.
Other: On 4 December 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, in the morning, residents set up roadblocks in the Delmas 32 neighborhood to prevent gang members from entering their communities.
Other: On 4 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, in the morning, residents set up roadblocks in the Christ-Roi neighborhood to prevent gang members from entering their communities.
Other: On 22 November 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 75 and 83. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 27 November 2024, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in areas like Diegue, Meyotte, Corlette, Kargo, and Doko. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 30 November 2024, in Delmas - Chancerelles, Ouest, police forces and agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) clashed with affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang in the Chancerelles neighbourhood. Gunshots were heard. Casualties unknown.

Security measures: On 29 November 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, Haitian police forces and Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) installed an operations centre at the former facilities of the General Inspectorate of the Haitian National Police (IGPNH), in the Delmas 2 neighbourhood, after taking control of the abandoned building. The operations centre is expected to serve centre of strategic support in the fight of gangs.

On 30 November 2024, around Gressier - Petit Boucan, Ouest, police forces engaged in armed clashes with the 103 Zombies Gang in the Echalot village. Clashes erupted after the criminals had attacked residents in the village (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 1 December 2024, in Tabarre - Cazeau/Tabarre 14, Ouest, police forces and agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) engaged in armed clashes with gang members in the Cazeau neighborhood. During clashes, several criminals were shot and injured, while a hijacked truck was recovered by the police. Several injured.
Other: On 28 November 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 30. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 2 December 2024, in Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13, Ouest, police forces and agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) clashed with gang members in Carrefour Aeroport. Gunshots were heard near the airport. Casualties unknown.

Security measures: Around 1 December 2024 (as reported), in Petionville, Ouest, local authorities banned public gatherings for security reasons. The ban is expected to remain in force until police forces put an end to anti-gang operations in the commune.

On 2 December 2024, in Delmas - Puits Blain, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) along the Freres Road, at the height of the Puits Blain neighbourhood, as the criminals attacked the area (coded separately). Clashes were also registered in the so called Nan Tunnel area, 'Gwo Jan' area (Pernier), and 'Kagwo' locality (near Academie) (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
Other: On 28 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Nazon. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 2 December 2024, near Petion Ville - Academie, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defence group) clashed with the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) as the criminals attacked the 'Kajwo' locality (less than 1 km away from the Police Academy) (coded separately). An unspecified number of gang members were killed. Clashes were also registered in Puits Blain, Nan Tunnel area, and 'Gwo Jan' area (Pernier) (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 2 December 2024, in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, overnight, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defence group) clashed with the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) as the criminals attacked the 'Gwo Jan' area, in Pernier neighbourhood (coded separately). More than four gang members were killed. At least three corpses were seen on the streets. Clashes were also registered in Puits Blain, Nan Tunnel area, and 'Kajwo' locality (near Academie) (coded separately). At least 4 fatalities.

On 2 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, police forces and agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) clashed with gang members in the Nazon neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.
On 2 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Saint Antoine/Lalue, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in the Lalue neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.
On 2 December 2024, in Tabarre - Tabarre 27, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in Tabarre 27. Casualties unknown.

On 3 December 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, overnight, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defence group) clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in Delmas 30 and Delmas 32 (coded separately) neighbourhoods. Casualties unknown.

On 3 December 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 32, Ouest, overnight, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defence group) clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in Delmas 32 and Delmas 30 (coded separately) neighbourhoods. Casualties unknown.

On 3 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Christ-Roi, Ouest, overnight, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defence group) clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in the Christ-Roi neighbourhood. The criminals were expelled after several hours of clashes. Gunshots were heard in nearby Nazon and Bourdon neighborhoods (Port-au-Prince). Casualties unknown.

On 3 December 2024, in Pont Sonde, Artibonite, more than 1,000 residents from Pont Sonde held a sit-in protest at the Pat-Chwal sub-police station demanding the dismantling of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. The mobilization was led by the Commission for Dialogue, Reconciliation and Awareness to Save the Artibonite, and the Federation of Peasant Organizations and Agricultural Entrepreneurs of the Artibonite Valley.

source: Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 3 December 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 75, Ouest, residents and members of the police held a spontaneous demonstration to decry the lack of action by political authorities to fight gang violence. The mobilization was held in the vicinity of the Our Lady of the Perpetual Help Church (Delmas 75) moments after the funeral of a police officer who was killed during clashes with gang members on 13 November (coded separately). Demonstrators also called for justice. Police agents fired shots into the air, though several civilians, including a boy, were injured by the stray bullets. Several injured.
Other: On 29 November 2024, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Vivy Mitchell. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 6 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Christ-Roi, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in Christ-Roi, Nazon, Carrefour Aeroport, and Delmas 30 neighbourhoods (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

Other: On 2 December 2024, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the vicinity of the Isaie Jeanty - Leon Audain maternity hospital, in the Pont Rouge neighbourhood. There is no information on the authorship of the gunshots. They were heard as authorities reopened the mentioned health facility.

On 4 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Canape-Vert, Ouest, in the morning, residents held a demonstration in the Canape-Vert neighbourhood against the installation of a former deputy for the 3rd constituency of Port-au-Prince as the head of the Ouest department government delegation. Residents claimed that the man has ties with armed individuals. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires.
Non-violent activity: Around 3 December 2024 (as reported), Petionville, Ouest, gang members set up roadblocks in the Pernier neighbourhood to prevent police forces from accessing the area.

On 30 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, a young woman travelling in a public transport bus was shot and killed suspectedly by gang members controlling the area as the public transport vehicle crossed Cameau Street (Bas Peu de Choses neighbourhood). The killing took place moments after the bus passed through an informal toll booth on Alerte Street. 1 fatality

Around 2 December 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked, killed, and injured several residents in the Nazon neighbourhood. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 5 December 2024, in Tabarre - Clercine II/Carrefour Clercine, Ouest, gang members attacked the Motorized Intervention Brigade (BIM) facilities (police forces), located in the Clercine II neighbourhood. Police forces responded and clashed with the criminals whom they managed to expel. Casualties unknown.

Around 3 December 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents in Solino, killing and injuring an unspecified number of them. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 6 December 2024, in Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in Carrefour Aeroport, Christ-Roi, Nazon, and Delmas 30 neighborhoods (coded separately). An unspecified number of people were killed and injured by stray bullets in the Delmas commune. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 6 December 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in Delmas 30, Carrefour Aeroport, Christ-Roi, and Nazon neighborhoods (coded separately). An unspecified number of people were killed and injured by stray bullets in the Delmas commune. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 6 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defense group) clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang near Carrefour Samida, in the Nazon neighborhood. During clashes, a self-defense group member and former military officer, and a police officer were shot and killed. Several civilians were injured. 2 fatalities, several injured.

On 6 January 2024, off the Coast of Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, gang members attacked a rowboat, killing five men and kidnapping three women who were on board. The attack took place at the height of the Mariani neighborhood. Their whereabouts are unknown. 5 fatalities.

On 2 January 2024, in Carrefour - Mariani, Ouest, police forces clashed with unidentified gang members as they intervened to prevent the criminals from extorting drivers along the National Road 2. Casualties unknown.

On 3 January 2024, in Carrefour - Mariani, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, police forces clashed with unidentified gang members as they intervened to prevent the criminals from extorting drivers along the National Road 2. Casualties unknown.

On 2 January 2024, in Carrefour - Mariani, Ouest, armed gang members perpetrated an attack and set fire to a public transport vehicle which had been parked on the road and set up a roadblock. At least two people were killed and their bodies were found on the ground. At least 2 fatalities.
Non-violent activity: Around 8 January 2024 (week of), in Carrefour, Ouest, gang members set a roadblock on the National Road 2 as they installed a large trailer in the middle of the road.
On 14 January 2024, in Montrouis, Artibonite, a mob of residents decapitated a gangster. The attack was described as vigilante violence. 1 fatality.

On 12 January 2024, in Montrouis, Artibonite, a group of residents held a protest and set up barricades on the national road (nature unspecified) against the designation of a new municipal commission. They threatened to boycott.

On 22 January 2024, in Carrefour - Mariani, Ouest, the leader of the Bout Ba Gang operating in this location killed around 20 people who were trying to reach higher regions of the commune by sea. The report indicates that the boats' captains were decapitated. Around 20 fatalities.

Looting: On 3 February 2024, in Cite Soleil - Drouillard, Ouest, unidentified armed individuals attacked a warehouse (methods unspecified). Gunshots were also heard in the area which caused residents to flee their homes.

source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp); Trinidad and Tobago Guardian
notes: Property destruction: On 6 March 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, in the early morning, gang members set fire to the Delmas Peace Court, in Delmas 28.

source: Alterpresse; GardaWorld; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Property destruction: On 1 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, dozens of armed gang members looted and set fire to the Province Market supermarket.
Property destruction: On 3 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, overnight, gang members set fire to the public Sylvio Cator National Stadium.

Looting: Around 7 March 2024 (between 4 - 10 March), in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) looted and vandalized the ARAKA Library, located on the Enterrement Street. The library had been closed several years before.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Juno 7; Sakapfet.com; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: Looting: On 7 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, a group of around 250 individuals among gangsters and members of the population looted the Caribbean Port Services' containers and the National Port Authority (ANP) facilities (in Wharf de la Saline) after taking over the premises, which prevented ships from arriving to the country.
