notes: Around 29 December 2024 (between 28 - 29 December), in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, police forces supported by the Multinational Security Support Mission killed several gang members (likely from the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang) in the Quatorzieme area. Between 28 and 29 December, at least 10 gang members were killed during anti-gang operations in five locations in the Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune (coded in three events). At least 10 fatalities split across three events, 2 fatalities coded here.

On 30 December 2024, in Pont Sonde, Artibonite, police forces supported by the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) clashed with gang members as they carried out anti-gang operations near the Pat-Chwal sub-police station. Five firearms were seized by the police. Several gang members were arrested. Casualties unknown.

source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; The St. Kitts Nevis Observer; Trip Foumi
notes: On 30 December 2024, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, a mob of residents stoned, lynched, and set fire to the second leader of the Pon Bouk Gang (also member of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang) after dragging him from the Ouanaminthe's customs office, where he was in custody. Police forces used tear gas to prevent the mobsters from killing the gang member, although they did not success. The victim had been arrested in the Dominican Republic after escaping Haiti with the help of BSAP agents. The Dominican forces handed him over to the Haitian police. 1 fatality.

Looting: Around 30 December 2024 (between 29 - 30 December), in Delmas - Cite Caraibes, Ouest, gang members looted a warehouse of the Bernard Mevs Hospital (private property) and the facilities of the Haytrac company, on Village Solidarite Avenue (near the Airport Road, at the height of Cite Caraibes neighborhood). The criminals stole solar panels and light materials. The hospital had been attacked on several occasions by the Viv Ansanm Gang between 15 and 16 December 2024 (coded separately).

Property destruction: Around 30 December 2024 (between 29 - 30 December), in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, gang members looted the Safari Motor car dealership facilities, located in the Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28 neighborhood (close to the Airport Road), and set fire to a part of the building. The criminals were seen stealing materials.

Property destruction: On 30 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Gabelliste/Grand Cimetiere, Ouest, police forces destroyed a wall of the cemetery of Port-au-Prince that had been serving as a hiding place for gang members.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Looting: On 31 December 2024, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Ouest, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang looted and stole in at least five houses.

Around 31 December 2024 (between 31 December - 1 January), in the Artibonite department (coded to Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite), Artibonite, police forces clashed with gang members as they carried out anti-gang operations in several areas in the department. During clashes, an unknown number of gang members were injured. Some of them died from their wounds. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

Non-violent activity: On 31 December 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, members of the 400 Mawozo Gang occupied the Croix-des-Bouquets' public square, where they organized socio-cultural activities on the occasion of New Year's Eve.

Around 31 December 2024 (between 31 December - 1 January), in Delmas, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they carried out anti-gang operations in Bas Delmas, Solino, and Nazon (coded separately). During clashes, an unknown number of gang members were injured. Some of them died from their wounds. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

Looting: Around 31 December 2024 (as reported), in Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13, Ouest, gang members perpetrated lootings on the Airport Road (in Carrefour Aeroport neighborhood) and in the Nazon neighborhood (coded separately). No further details were mentioned.

On 31 December 2024, in Petion Ville - Laboule, Ouest, gang members attacked the Laboule neighborhood. Gunshots were heard. Police forces intervened and clashed with them (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 31 December 2024, in Petion Ville - Laboule, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they intervened to expel them from Laboule neighborhood, which was under gang attack (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 31 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, gunshots were heard as gang members attacked the Nazon neighborhood. Casualties unknown.

Around 31 December 2024 (between 31 December - 1 January), in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they carried out anti-gang operations in Nazon, Solino, and Bas Delmas (coded separately). During clashes, an unknown number of gang members were injured. Some of them died from their wounds. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

Looting: Around 31 December 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, gang members perpetrated lootings in the Nazon and Carrefour Aeroport neighborhoods (coded separately). No further details were mentioned.

Around 31 December 2024 (between 31 December - 1 January), in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they carried out anti-gang operations in Solino, Nazon, and Bas Delmas (coded separately). During clashes, an unknown number of gang members were injured. Some of them died from their wounds. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Amerique Info 7; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 1 January 2025, in Petion Ville - Boutilliers, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang and the Kraze Barye Gang attacked the Taraz and Makako zones (in Laboule 12), where they took control of a property. Police forces intervened and clashed with the criminals (coded separately). This was part of a gang offensive aiming at installing the leader of the Didi Gang in the area. Casualties unknown.

source: Amerique Info 7; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 1 January 2025, near Petion Ville - Laboule, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang and the Kraze Barye Gang attacked the Taraz zone and nearby Makako zone, where they took control of a property. Police forces intervened and clashed with the criminals (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 1 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, gunshots were heard as gang members attacked the Nazon neighborhood. Casualties unknown.

On 2 January 2025, in Petion Ville - Boutilliers, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in Makako zone (in Laboule 12). Clashes took place after the criminals attacked the area on 1 January (coded separately) as part of an offensive aiming at installing the leader of the Didi Gang. Security forces tried to expel the criminals towards Diquini (Carrefour commune). Casualties unknown.

On 2 January 2025, near Petion Ville - Laboule, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in Makako zone (a strategic zone near Laboule which connects Savanne Pistaches with Grand Ravine). Clashes took place after the criminals attacked the area on 1 January (coded separately). Security forces tried to expel the criminals towards Diquini (Carrefour commune). Casualties unknown.
On 2 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, for a third consecutive day, gunshots were heard as gang members attacked the Nazon neighborhood. Casualties unknown.

On 3 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Poste Marchand, Ouest, police forces shot and killed a Muslim man and set fire to his corpse in the Poste Marchand neighborhood. The officers tried to hide the corpse among the street garbage, although the victim was identified by witnesses. The man was killed when he attended an office to make a money transfer. He was executed after a brief exchange, during which the officers were not convinced by the explanations provided on the reasons for the movement of money. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: Movement of forces: On 3 January 2025, in Tabarre - Aeroport Toussaint Louverture, Ouest, 75 Guatemalan soldiers, as well as eight Salvadorian soldiers, arrived to the Toussaint Louverture Airport and were deployed as part of the multinational security support mission backed by the United Nations to fight against gang violence in the country.

Around 4 January 2025 (between 1 - 8 January), in Saint-Michel-de-l'Atalaye, Artibonite, residents lynched at least 11 individuals whom they accused of being gang members. Some of them were identified as gangsters from Savien. At least 11 fatalities.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Non-violent activity: Around 5 January 2025 (between 30 December - 8 January), in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune, Artibonite, gang members (likely from the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang that operate in the area) installed traps and regained control of certain areas in the Palmiste locality and Savien (coded separately). This happened after the criminals were expelled from the mentioned areas by police forces on 29 December (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Standard; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 5 January 2025, in Delmas - Fragneauville - 75, Ouest, in the morning, three armed individuals dressed in black suits shot and killed a businessman and Catholic parishioner when he exited his personal vehicle (described as armored) to attend a religious service at the Our Lady of the Perpetual Help Church (Fragneauville - 75 neighborhood). One version stated that the perpetrators shot from moving motorcycles (drive-by). A different version described the shooting as execution-style. The attackers were said to be waiting for the victim. They fled the scene. The national police believe that the attack was not linked to gang activity, although they confirmed that it was planned. 1 fatality.

On 5 January 2025, in Petion Ville - Boutilliers, Ouest, police forces and agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission clashed with gang members (likely from the Viv Ansanm Gang that had carried out previous attacks in the area) in the Makako zone (Laboule 12). Clashes erupted as the gang members launched an offensive aiming at installing the leader of the Didi Gang in the area (coded separately). Between 5 and 7 January, several residents were shot and injured as security forces clashed with gang members in the Makako area. Several injured.

On 6 January 2025, in Gonaives, Artibonite, a group of teachers held a sit-in protest in front of the office of the Departmental Directorate of Education demanding better working conditions. The mobilization was part of a labor strike.

On 6 January 2025, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, several scores of teachers held a protest with banners demanding better working conditions, including the payment of due salaries and benefits, among other claims. Protesters closed the doors of the North-East Departmental Directorate of the Ministry of National Education and Vocational Training (DDNE-MENFP). The mobilization was part of a labor strike.

On 6 January 2025, in Petion Ville - Boutilliers, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, police forces and agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission clashed with gang members (likely from the Viv Ansanm Gang that had carried out previous attacks in the area) in the Makako zone (Laboule 12). Clashes erupted as the gang members launched an offensive aiming at installing the leader of the Didi Gang in the area (coded separately). Between 5 and 7 January, several residents were shot and injured as security forces clashed with gang members in the Makako area. Several injured.

On 6 January 2025, in Ducis, Sud, overnight, police forces shot and killed three gang members during a security operation coordinated by the Miragoane police commissioner, Ernst Muscadin. The victims were identified as the leader and two members of the Bakop Bosal Gang. 3 fatalities.

On 7 January 2025, in Petion Ville - Boutilliers, Ouest, for a third consecutive day, police forces and the Multinational Security Support Mission clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in Makako and Taraz areas (Laboule 12, Boutilliers neighborhood) and in the Saint-Roc area(coded separately). During clashes, several criminals were shot and killed. An unspecified number of others were injured. A vehicle belonging to the criminals was seized. Between 5 and 7 January, several residents were shot and injured as security forces clashed with gang members in the Makako area. Clashes erupted as the gang members carried out an offensive aiming at installing the leader of the Didi Gang in the area (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3, several injured.

Around 8 January 2025 (as reported), in Gressier, Ouest, police forces and self-defense group members ambushed and killed a gang leader as he attended a voodoo ceremony in the commune. The now deceased was described as a gangster from Gressier who used to control territories in the commune up to La Coline (at the border with the Leogane commune). 1 fatality.

source: PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: Property destruction: On 8 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, police forces destroyed several structures on Poupelard Street (Fort National neighborhood) used by gang members as hiding places to perpetrate attacks.

Other: On 10 January 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard near the National Police Academy (Academie neighborhood) when hundreds of police officers took part in a graduation ceremony. The authorship of the gunshots was not clarified.

On 10 January 2025, Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, in the morning, police forces shot and killed several gang members during clashes on Oswald Durand Street, at the height of the Bas Peu de Choses neighborhood. Clashes were also registered in Morne a Tuf neighborhood (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 10 January 2025, Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, in the morning, police forces shot and killed several gang members during clashes on L'Enterrement Street (Morne a Tuf neighborhood). Clashes were also registered in the Bas Peu de Choses neighborhood (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 9 January 2024, in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang kidnapped more than 10 passengers from a bus and a tap-tap as they ambushed both vehicles on the National Road 1. BINUH reported at least 25 people (15 men and 10 women) abducted on that day in the Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune. Their whereabouts are unknown.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: Around 24 June 2024 (between 23 - 25 June), near Carrefour Paye, Aritbonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang kidnapped at least eight people and hijacked several trucks on the National Road 1, at the height of Moreau Paye. The abductors asked for a ransom of several million dollars as a condition for the release of the victims. According to BINUH, up to 15 people (nine men and six women) were kidnapped by the mentioned gang on 23 June in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune. Their whereabouts are unknown.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 4 July 2024, in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, in the morning, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang injured several people and kidnapped up to 18 (10 men and eight women) as they perpetrated an attack in the area. Several vehicles were stolen. The victims' whereabouts are unknown. Several injured.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Loop News St. Lucia
notes: Looting: On 16 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Portail Saint Joseph, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang together with a group of civilian rioters looted a UNICEF's container at the Port-au-Prince International Port. The shipment carried medical equipment for mothers and children.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; GardaWorld; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: Non-violent activity: On 22 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) took control of 10 trucks after they left the Varreux Terminal premises (in Village Democratie neighborhood) and used them to block roads leading to it and to the Caribbean Port Services facilities (in nearby Wharf de La Saline neighborhood). The roadblocks were erected in the 'Gonaives Station' parking lot (in Village Democratie), and at the entrance of the SHODECOSA Industrial Park (in nearby Chancelleres neighborhood, Delmas commune). Although the gangsters did not enter the terminal and the park's premises, employees were evacuated. Police forces managed to remove the roadblocks 10 days later. No interaction with the gang members was mentioned.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 5 January 2024, in La Coupe, Nord-Ouest, police forces shot and killed a member of the 305 Gang during an intervention near the Port-de-Paix River. One source described the deceased as the leader of the gang. Another individual was arrested. A firearm was seized. 1 fatality.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 18 January 2024, in the Port-de-Paix commune, Nord-Ouest, police forces shot and killed a member of the Ti Bwa Gang during a clash on Ti Fond village road. 1 fatality.

On 31 January 2024, in Port-de-Paix, Nord-Ouest, citizens and political militants (unknown affiliation) held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 24 January 2024, in Petion Ville - Sainte Therese, Ouest, people protested near the courthouse, in Sainte Therese, and Juvenat (coded separately). A group of people was also seen gathering around Boyer Square (coded separately). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the protest, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). The report indicates that the police was present, but no specific activity was reported.

On 5 February 2024, in Port-de-Paix, Nord-Ouest, government opponents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Schools and publics institutions remained their doors closed. The protest, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 6 February 2024, in Port-de-Paix, Nord-Ouest, for the second consecutive day, government opponents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Schools and publics institutions remained their doors closed. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Port-de-Paix, Nord-Ouest, for the third consecutive day, government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 3 March 2024, in Cabaret, Ouest, the Canaan Gang clashed with police forces as they attacked and set fire to the Cabaret police station. Several people were shot and injured (affiliation unspecified). Several injured.

actor2: Police Forces of Haiti (2017-2024) Prison Guards
source: AFP; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 3 May 2024, in Port-de-Paix, Nord-Ouest, overnight, the 37 prisoners of a cell rioted at the Civil Prison in an escape attempt. According to the officers, as an inmate who pretended to feel unwell refused to go back to his cell, other inmates took advantage of the situation and attacked a prison guard, forced the gate, and escaped. Other prison guards intervened and shot and killed at least four rioters (up to nine according to BINUH). There were 15 injured among prisoners and security guards. Eight inmates managed to escape (up to 30 according to other sources). Two officers were arrested on suspicion of having facilitated the riot. At least 4 fatalities, 15 injured.

Security measures: On 4 May 2024, in Port-de-Paix, Nord-Ouest, authorities declared a state of emergency in the commune. The measure was taken a day after 37 inmates rioted at the Civil Prison and at least eight of them escaped (coded separately).
On 10 January 2024, in Port-de-Paix municipality, Nord-Ouest, police forces shot and killed a member of the Guepe Noire Gang during a clash in La Saline area. 1 fatality.

Looting: Around 10 July 2024 (as reported), in the Cabaret commune, Ouest, unidentified individuals looted the facilities of the G.O.C. University, located on the National Road 1, in the Source-Matelas neighbourhood.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 6 August 2024, in Cabaret, Ouest, members of the Canaan Gang and the Base 5 Secondes Gang shot and killed nine people and set fire to five houses as they attacked residents in the commune. 9 fatalities.
Around 8 August 2024 (as reported), in Bercy, Ouest, the Canaan Gang killed at least four civilians as they attacked residents in the area. At least 4 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: Property destruction: On 13 August 2024, in Cabaret, Ouest, armed members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang, affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang, and members of the Canaan Gang, demolished the commune's police station. The criminals used hammers to destroy the walls of the fence and the rooms. The facility had been under their control since 3 March, when the criminals set fire to the building (coded separately).
Property destruction: Around 23 October 2024 (as reported), in Cabaret, Ouest, gang members destroyed the Bethel bridge to prevent police forces from entering the commune.

Property destruction: Around 29 October 2024 (between 28 - 29 October), in Cabaret, Ouest, members of the Canaan Gang, the Base 5 Secondes Gang, and the Viv Ansanm Gang demolished the commune's police station. The criminals used heavy machinery to destroy the already ruined building. The facility had been under the criminals' control since 3 March, when they set fire to the building (coded separately). It was partially demolished in another attack in August (coded separately).

Non-violent activity: On 30 October 2024, in Cabaret, Ouest, in the morning, gang members set up a roadblock along the National Road. They used dozens of truckloads of garbage to block the roadway at the height of the Cabaret bridge.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 26 April 2024, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang kidnapped 10 people from a pickup truck (six men and four women). Their whereabouts are unknown.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 1 May 2024, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang kidnapped 15 passengers from two minibuses (five men and 10 women). Their whereabouts are unknown.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 4 June 2024, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang kidnapped 32 passengers from a bus (22 men and 10 women). Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 27 June 2024, in the Gros-Morne commune, Artibonite, the Kokorat San Ras Gang kidnapped the 12 passengers of a minibus (seven men and five women) in the Tibwadom area and asked for the payment of around 9,470 USD ransom per hostage as a condition for their release. The whereabouts of the victims are unknown.

On 1 January 2025, in Petion Ville - Laboule, Ouest, armed individuals abducted an unknown number of civilians who were passing through the area on their way to the capital. According to witnesses, the victims were not harmed and some were able to contact family members. Although there is no information about the perpetrators, according to latest reports, most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 27 May 2024, in Cite Soleil - Hasco/Village Democratie, Ouest, gang members kidnapped 10 employees as they travelled in a Varreux Terminal's vehicle. Their whereabouts are unknown.

On 20 December 2024, in Beaumont, Grande-Anse, the police, led by Jean Ernest Muscadin police commissioner, killed a member of the Kraze Barye Gang who was visiting his family in the Mon Ranp area. 1 fatality.
On 5 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, the police forces clashed with armed individuals. There is no information on the circumstances of the confrontations. Casualties unknown.

On 13 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Gabelliste/Grand Cimetiere, Ouest, in the morning, police forces clashed with gang members on Alerte street, at the height of the Port-au-Prince's cemetery (Gabelliste/Grand Cimetiere neighborhood). Casualties unknown.

On 27 December 2024, in Cite Soleil - Sarthe, Ouest, there were exchanges of gunfire suspectedly related to an armed clash. Gunshots were also registered in Carrefour Vincent. There is no information on the circumstances of the clash. Casualties unknown.

On 7 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, armed clashes were registered, including in connecting areas in Christ-Roi. There is no information on the circumstances or actors involved in the clashes. Casualties unknown.

On 14 December 2024, in Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Carrefour Aeroport. There is no information on the circumstances, however, these are likely related to clashes between police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang. The gang alliance and police forces engaged in several clashes in nearby neighborhoods (coded separately).

On 3 January 2025, in Deluge, Artibonite, a man was killed (methods unknown) and his body was found in the yard of his home later that day. The corpse was burned and decapitated. His feet were missing. The attack was attributed to gang members. 1 fatality.

Property destruction: On 11 January 2025, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, police forces set fire to an armed group members' base in the Ti Bwadom neighborhood and arrested scores of criminals during a security operation.
Looting: On 27 December 2024, in Carrefour - Bas Thorland, Ouest, gang members attacked a petrol terminal and hijacked several petrol trucks.
Looting: On 4 January 2025, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, gang members hijacked seven trucks from a water company.

Looting: On 4 January 2025, in Delmas - Village Solidarite, Ouest, gang members looted a business, stealing containers of oil, generators, as well as other things they found. Gunshots were heard, although the circumstances of the gunshots was not reported.
Other: On 1 January 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, a roadblock was set up on the Kenscoff road in Thomassin. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the roadblock.
Other: On 2 January 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, neighborhood brigades set up roadblocks in Thomassin 35 and 48 using rocks and debris to prevent possible attacks from gang members in the area.

Other: On 15 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Rue Alerte in Bas Peu de Choses and on Avenue Christophe. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 16 December 2024, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Belvil and Vivy Mitchell. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 17 December 2024, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Drouillard. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 18 December 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Carrefour Aeroport. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 19 December 2024, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Torcelle. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Non-violent activity: On 21 December 2024, in Tabarre, Ouest, a roadblock was set up on the Route Nationale #1 near Croix-des-Missions. Although armed individuals were seen in the area, there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

Other: On 23 December 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Carrefour Aeroport (and Nazon), coming from Delmas 32 and 30. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 25 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Nazon and Carrefour Aeroport. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 26 December 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were fired in Carrefour Aeroport. They were heard in different areas, including Musseau, Delmas 65, 75, Christ Roi, and Puits Blain. There is no information on the circumstances of the gunshots.

Other: On 26 December 2024, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Trois Mains area (Mais Gate neighborhood). Although armed men were seen on Roumain street near the Boulevard 15 Octobre, there is no information on the circumstances or the gunshots.
Other: On 28 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Nazon. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 29 December 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Pele Simon at the entrance of Village Solidarite. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 29 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard on Mgr Guilloux street downtown and in Nazon. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 30 December 2024, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Carrefour Clercine near the Motorized Intervention Brigade (BIM) premises. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 1 January 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Butte Boyer and Damien. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Non-violent activity: Around 15 September 2024 (month of), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members set up a toll booth on Alerte street at the height of the Port-au-Prince's cemetery (Gabelliste/Grand Cimetiere neighborhood). Public drivers trying to cross the area are forced to pay extortions.

On 15 January 2025, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, in the morning, hundreds of students, mostly from public schools, took to the streets demanding the return of teachers to classrooms after they went on a strike. The mobilization was held as teachers held a protest over labor-related demands in the commune (coded separately).

On 15 January 2025, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, hundreds of students from the Jacob Martin Henriquez, Pinchinat, and Celie Lamour high schools took to the streets demanding the return of teachers to classrooms after they went on a labor strike.

On 13 January 2025, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, teachers from public schools and several teachers' organizations took to the streets demanding better working conditions. The mobilization was part of a teachers' labor strike.

On 15 January 2025, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, in the morning, teachers held a protest and marched to the Bordes administrative complex demanding better working conditions. The mobilization was part of a teachers' labor strike. It was held as students held a protest calling for the teachers' return to classrooms (coded separately).

Around 15 January 2025 (between 14 - 15 January), in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, teachers from public schools and several teachers' organizations took to the streets demanding better working conditions. The mobilization was part of a teachers' labor strike. It was the second time that they protested in Fort-Liberte since 13 January (coded separately).

On 16 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Musseau-Delmas 48, Ouest, a group of teachers held a sit-in protest in front of the Ministry of National Education and Vocational Training (MENFP), in Musseau-Delmas 48 neighborhood, demanding better working conditions. The mobilization was part of a teachers' labor strike.

On 11 January 2025, in Hinche, Centre, employees at the National Old Age Insurance Office (ONA) held a demonstration against a decision involving the removal of their general director, among other claims. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires.

On 16 January 2025, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, teachers from public schools and several teachers' organizations took to the streets demanding better working conditions. During the mobilization demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires. This was part of a teachers' labor strike. It was the third time that they demonstrated in Fort-Liberte since 13 January (coded separately).

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2021-2025)
source: Jamaica Observer; Trinidad and Tobago Guardian
notes: On 22 January 2024, off the Coast of Cap-Haitien, Nord, US coast guards intercepted a sinking boat and arrested 33 Haitian migrants who were on board. They were transferred to Haitian authorities on 23 January.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2021-2025)
notes: Security measures: Around 7 March 2024 (week of), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, US agents of the Fleet Anti-terrorism Security Team (Fast) were deployed in Haiti. The decision was taken after a surge in gang violence against public and police facilities in the Ouest department.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2021-2025)
source: Haiti Progres; Loop News St. Lucia
notes: Security measures: On 10 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, overnight, US agents were deployed in the vicinity of the US Embassy and evacuated their non-essential diplomatic staff. The decision was taken after a surge in gang violence against public and police facilities in the Ouest department since 29 February.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2021-2025)
notes: On 5 June 2024, off the Coast of Cap-Haitien, Nord, US coast guards intercepted a vessel with a group of around 98 Haitian migrants on board. Between 5 and 6 June, a total of 196 migrants were arrested in two vessels in waters at the Nord of Haiti. 196 split across two events.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2021-2025)
source: Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 6 June 2024, off the Coast of La Tortue, Nord-Ouest, US coast guards intercepted a vessel with a group of around 98 Haitian migrants on board. Between 5 and 6 June, a total of 196 migrants were arrested in two vessels in waters at the Nord of Haiti. 196 split across two events.

source: Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 21 October 2024, in Tabarre - Chateau Blond, Ouest, members of the Chien Mechant Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang opened fire on several vehicles belonging to the US Embassy on the Roumain Street. Two armored cars were damaged. There were no casualties among the Embassy's employees, who were evacuated. There were no casualties.

source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Trip Foumi
notes: Non-violent activity: On 9 January 2025, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, the leader of the Micanord Gang forced the closure of the Caribbean Port Services (CPS) facilities, in Waaf Jeremie neighborhood, and demanded a high ransom to allow the containers to pass through. The resumption of activities at the CPS took place on 11 January.

Around 13 January 2025 (as reported), in Petion Ville - Pelerin, Ouest, overnight, unidentified individuals broke into a home in Pelerin 3, looted it, and abducted one of the residents. Although there is no information on the perpetrators, latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victim's whereabouts are unknown.

On 18 January 2025, in Gros-Morne, Artibonite, police forces clashed with the Kokorat San Ras Gang as they intervened to expel the criminals from the commune, which was under gang attack (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 26 October 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 5, Ouest, the police clashed with armed individuals in Delmas 3. There is no information on the circumstances of the clash. Casualties unknown.

On 15 January 2025, in Cite Soleil - Terre Noire/ Blanchard, Ouest, the police clashed with armed individuals in Terre Noire. There is no information on the circumstances of the circumstances of the clash. Casualties unknown.
On 10 December 2024, in Marassa, Ouest, the police clashed with armed individuals. There is no information on the circumstances of the clash. Casualties unknown.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 20 January 2025, in Petit-Goave, Ouest, police forces clashed with a gang member (and former police officer man) as they intervened to arrest him after the killing of a young man in the commune the day prior (coded separately). During clashes, several people were injured. The wanted man was eventually arrested in an area known as Sinistre. Later that day, a mob of residents managed to lynch him while he was in custody (coded separately). Several injured.

source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 21 January 2025, in Cite Soleil - Sarthe, Ouest, police forces clashed with members of the Viv Ansanm Gang at the height of Carrefour Vincent, where gunshots had been heard since the morning. Police forces destroyed the walls of several houses used by the criminals in Carrefour Vincent and Drouillard. Burning barricades that had been erected by the gang members were also removed (coded separately). According to residents, there were several killed and injured among the local population. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.
On 19 January 2025, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, Polifront police agents arrested the second leader of the Pont-Blanc Gang. The criminal was also as the second leader of the Cadush Gang.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 3 December 2024, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang kidnapped a journalist man on Paul Eugene Magloire street over accusations of being an informant to the government. The journalist was taken to the gang's stronghold in Savien, where he was tortured and beaten up during captivity, specially on 31 December and 12 January (coded separately). He was severely injured. Several ransoms were paid before he was released on 18 January 2025. The release happened thanks to the Palmiste Gang leader, who used to hear his radio broadcasts and visited the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang stronghold when he was about to be executed. The leader of the Palmiste Gang asked the Baz Gran Grif Gang to release him. 1 injured.

On 24 December 2024, in the Artibonite department (coded to Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite), Artibonite, heavily armed men killed two women and three men from the same family at a property and took a fourth man to an unknown location. He was found dead, without eyes and heart several days later. The attack was motivated by accusations of ties with the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang after one of the women had a baby with a gang member. The event is described as a popular movement launched to defend the population from gang violence similar to the Bwa Kale. 6 fatalities.

On 19 January 2025, in Petit-Goave, Ouest, a gang member and former police officer man shot and killed a young man in the commune. The perpetrator, who was identified as the killer of a journalist man in December 2022 (coded separately), was arrested by the police and lynched to death by a mob of residents the day after (coded separately). 1 fatality.

On 12 January 2025, in Montrouis, Artibonite, suspected gang members operating in the Piatre locality killed three people, including a sixteen-year-old teenager. Their bodies were found in said locality. This attack resulted in the residents burning down houses and injuring people to denounce the violence in the area (coded separately). 3 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; InSight Crime; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Trip Foumi
notes: On 20 January 2025, in Tabarre - Chateau Blond, Ouest, in the morning, gang members opened fire on an armored vehicle belonging to the US diplomatic mission. The vehicle was attacked when a group of employees were travelling inside on their way to workplace at the US Embassy (Chateau Blond neighborhood). A gardener employee at the embassy was shot and injured. 1 injured.

Security measures: On 24 January 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, local authorities imposed a night curfew between 10 p.m. and 5 a.m. as of 25 January. The decision was taken to ensure security in the face of threats of armed attacks against the commune. Authorities also imposed a ban on cultural activities' celebrations and the riding of motorcycles overnight. Shops are forced to close at 9 p.m. and everybody has to carry an identity card at anytime.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: Movement of forces: On 18 January 2025, in Tabarre - Aeroport Toussaint Louverture, Ouest, at least 218 Kenyan police officers (213 men and five women) arrived to the Toussaint Louverture Airport and were deployed as part of the multinational security support mission backed by the United Nations to fight against gang violence in the country.

On 23 January 2025, in Arcahaie, Ouest, a group of citizens held a protest against the nomination of a vice-delegate for the Arcahaie. As the crowd was in front of the police station, unidentified armed individuals opened fire, killing at least three people and injuring several others. At least 3 fatalities, several injured.

source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 20 January 2025, in Petit-Goave, Ouest, a mob of residents lynched a man who was in custody after having killed a young man in the commune the day prior (coded separately). The victim's corpse was dragged and set on fire by the mobsters. The now deceased was described as a former police officer and as a gang member. He had killed a journalist man in December 2022 (coded separately). 1 fatality.

On 12 January 2025, in Montrouis, Artibonite, residents burned down houses and injured several people to denounce the ongoing gang violence in the Piatre locality. This happened after three people were killed in the area on the same day (coded separately). Several injured.
Other: On 26 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, barricades were erected with burning tires in Christ-Roi. There is no information on the motives of the barricades or who set them up.

Property destruction: On 11 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazone, Ouest, several houses were set on fire. Also, gunshots were heard in the neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots or fire.

Non-violent activity: On 21 January 2025, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, gang members forced the closure of the Varreux Terminal facilities and set up blockades at the height of Station Gonaives, in the Hasco/Village Democratie neighborhood. The blockage was linked to civilian upheavals around Cite Soleil. No further information was mentioned.
Non-violent activity: Around 21 January 2025 (as reported), in Tabarre, Ouest, gang members erected barricades in the Butte Boyer neighborhood to prevent police forces from accessing the area.

Non-violent activity: On 12 January 2025, in Carrefour, Ouest, armed gang members (likely from the Viv Ansanm Gang, who control the commune) took part at gang-organized pre-carnival festivities between Centre Sportif and Diquini neighborhoods. A vehicle followed by several people led a parade. This was part of the gangs' efforts aimed at bringing them closer to local population. Similar carnival-related activities were organized on 19 January (coded separately).

Non-violent activity: On 19 January 2025, in Carrefour, Ouest, at least 30 armed gang members took part at a Viv Ansanm Gang-organized pre-carnival parade along the National Road 2. Scores of people joined them. Chants in favor of the gang coalition were heard. This was part of the gangs' efforts aimed at bringing them closer to local population. Similar carnival-related activities were organized in the commune on 12 January (coded separately).

Non-violent activity: Around 20 January 2025 (as reported), in Carrefour, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang installed a toll booth in front of the commune's city hall, located in the Campus Diquini neighborhood.
Around 14 January 2025 (between 13 - 15 January), in Cap-Haitien, Nord, students took to the streets demanding the return of teachers to classrooms after they went on a labor strike.
Around 14 January 2025 (between 13 - 15 January), in Gonaives, Artibonite, students took to the streets demanding the return of teachers to classrooms after they went on a labor strike.

Around 18 January 2025 (weekend of), in Port-de-Paix, Nord-Ouest, the FOSNOU political movement held a protest against the mayor of Port-de-Paix. Protesters decried the political management of his administration during the eight years that he has been in power.

On 24 January 2025, in Port-de-Paix, Nord-Ouest, a group of citizens, called by the FOSNOU political movement, held a protest with banners next to the cathedral to decry the management of the municipal administration.

On 10 December 2024, between Grande Riviere du Nord and Dondon, Nord, residents protested by setting up a roadblock on the Route Nationale #3 in Morne Grand Gilles to demand the reparation of the roads that have been damaged by the rain.

On 20 January 2025, in Port-de-Paix, Nord-Ouest, students from the Tertullien Guilbaud High School held a demonstration to decry the absence of teachers at classrooms after they went on a labor strike. The students marched to the premises of several schools and threw stones against classrooms. Several students were injured. Police forces intervened (methods unclarified) and took control of the situation. Several injured.

Around 21 January 2025 (as reported), in Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in Carrefour Aeroport neighborhood. The criminals were likely members of the Viv Ansanm Gang, who managed to occupied the Toussaint Louverture Boulevard around 29 January. Casualties unknown.

notes: On 9 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Turgeau, Ouest, armed men shot and killed the coordinator of the Social Assistance Fund (CAS) near his office when he had just left his workplace. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Looting: On 4 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, gang members looted the Saint-Francois de Sales Hospital (Catholic Christian institution). The looting, which was recorded on video, took place when the building was empty. The staff members and patients had been evacuated on 29 February.

source: Alterpresse; GardaWorld; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Looting: On 1 March 2024, overnight, in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, the gangsters also looted and vandalized the National Port facilities. Looting scenes at the Port persisted until 8 March. On 7 March, the Caribbean Port Services (Cps) S.A. company announced the suspension of activities and the closure of the port due to repeated attacks.
Looting: On 14 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, overnight, gang members looted and vandalized a car dealership in the Bas Delmas area.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Looting: On 4 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, gang members looted the French Asylum private hospital, on the Centre street, and the Faculty of Midwines on that same day. Four buses and a private vehicle were stolen.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: Property destruction: On 21 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Portail Leogane/Cite Louverture, Ouest, armed members from the Viv Ansanm Gang-led initiative attacked a police station. The building was also empty after the criminals set it on fire on 29 February (coded separately).
Other: On 29 January 2024, in Bonbon, Grande-Anse, a roadblock was registered. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

Non-violent activity: Around 21 January 2025 (as reported), in Cite Soleil, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang erected barricades of burning tires in the Sarthe neighborhood to prevent police forces from entering the area. They also used trucks to cut the road towards Terre Noire.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 20 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, in the morning, gunshots were heard as police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang near the Alerte Street, where the criminals had erected toll booths several months ago. Casualties unknown.

On 30 January 2025, near Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, gang members kidnapped two people in the Clovil locality in the 1re Section Bas Coursin I. There is no information on the circumstances of the abduction. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

On 18 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, the police clashed with armed individuals. There is no information on the circumstances of the clash. Gunshots were heard on Magloire Ambroise Avenue. Casualties unknown.

On 19 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, the police clashed with armed individuals in the neighborhood the Salomon market and surrounding areas including Mgr Guilloux and Alerte streets, Sylvio Cator stadium (coded separately). There is no information on the circumstances of the clash. Casualties unknown.

On 19 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, the police clashed with armed individuals in the neighborhood, including Mgr Guilloux street, Alerte street and the Sylvio Cator stadium as well as surrounding areas like the Salomon market (coded separately). There is no information on the circumstances of the clash. Casualties unknown.
On 27 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in Champs de Mars. Casualties unknown.
On 27 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Portail Leogane/Cite Louverture, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in Portail Leogane neighborhood. Casualties unknown.
On 27 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in the vicinity of the Sylvio Cator Stadium (located in Morne a Tuf). Casualties unknown.

source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 27 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, police forces engaged in armed clashes with the Viv Ansanm Gang on Mangloire Ambroisse street. A police officer was shot and killed near the Solomon Market (Bas Peu de Choses). Clashes took place as security forces were deployed to expel the criminals who were attacking the area (coded separately). 1 fatality.

On 30 January 2025, near Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, gang members killed a farmer in the Clovil locality in the 1re Section: Bas Coursin I. There is no information on the circumstances or motives of the incident. 1 fatality.

On 27 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents on the Mangloire Ambroisse street. Police forces were deployed and clashed with the criminals to prevent them from keep attacking the area (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

Property destruction: On 29 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bourdon, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang set fire to the Grande Loge d'Ayiti de 1961 masonic temple building, located on Ruelle Mayard street, in Bourdon neighborhood.

Non-violent activity: Around 28 January 2025 (between 27 - 29 January), in Kenscoff, Ouest, gang members set up roadblocks with tree branches to prevent security forces from circulating through the commune. Roadblocks were erected as part of an offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang in Kenscoff launched on 27 January (coded separately).

Looting: On 23 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang dug holes and set up barricades in the Salomon market (Bas Peu de Choses neighborhood) to seize a couple of police armored vehicles.
Other: On 21 January 2025, in Arcahaie, Ouest, a roadblock was set up on the Route Nationale #1. There is no information on the motives for the roadblock or who set it up.

Other: On 24 January 2025, in Santo, Ouest, roadblocks were set up throughout, including in Santo 17. There is no information on the motives for the roadblocks or who set them up.

Other: On 18 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Bois Verna near the French Institute. Gunshots were also heard on Route des Dalles. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 19 January 2025, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard on Rue Hubert. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 21 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard on Route des Dalles in Carrefour Feuilles. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 23 January 2025, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Terre Noire. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Non-violent activity: On 23 January 2025, in Santo, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang set up roadblocks from Santo 9 to Santo 15 as part of a mobilization in the areas occupied by the gang against the government. Other areas where roadblocks have been announced include Bas Delmas and Cite Soleil.

On 22 January 2025, near Zanglais, Sud, students from the national school protested by setting up a roadblock on the Route Nationale #2 at the Saint-Georges area to demand that the teachers come back to school.
On 27 January 2025, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, teachers from several public schools held a sit-in protest to demand better working conditions.

On 22 January 2025, in Moron, Grande-Anse, members of the population protested by setting up a roadblock on the Route Departementale #72 to demand that the government supports the victims of bad weather conditions last December.

On 28 January 2025, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, students from the Pinchinat high school took to the streets demanding the return of teachers to classrooms after they went on a labor strike. During the mobilization, demonstrating students threw stones and bottles against the Celie Lamour and the Nossirhel Lherisson schools to press students joining the demonstration.

On 28 January 2025, in Kenscoff - Bonga, Ouest, police forces supported by armed members of the population clashed with gang members in the Bonga neighborhood as they tried to expel the criminals from the commune, which was under gang attack since 27 January (coded separately). The criminals were part of an armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). Recent reports clarified that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. Casualties unknown.

On 28 January 2025, in Kenscoff - Furcy, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, police forces supported by armed members of the population clashed with gang members in the Furcy neighborhood as they tried to expel the criminals from the commune, which was under gang attack since 27 January (coded separately). The criminals were part of an armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). Recent reports clarified that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. Casualties unknown.

source: Amerique Info 7; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Resumen Latinoamericano
notes: On 1 January 2025, in Petion Ville - Boutilliers, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang and the Kraze Barye Gang in the Makako zone (in Laboule 12). Clashes took place as the criminals attacked the area (coded separately) as part of an offensive aiming at installing the leader of the Didi Gang. Security forces managed to expel the gang members. Casualties unknown.

source: Amerique Info 7; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Resumen Latinoamericano
notes: On 1 January 2025, near Petion Ville - Laboule, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang and the Kraze Barye Gang in the Makako zone (a strategic zone near Laboule which connects Savanne Pistaches with Grand Ravine). Clashes took place after the criminals attacked the area (coded separately). Security forces managed to expel the gang members. Casualties unknown.

On 14 September 2024, in Tabarre - Tabarre 27, Ouest, members of the police forces and citizens held a demonstration and set up barricades of burning tires across the road not far from Carrefour Fleuriot against the arrest of the head of the city's police station. Demonstrators claimed that the arrest was arbitrary and defended the officer's work against gang violence. Gunshots were heard during the mobilization.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 31 January 2025, in Kenscoff - La Rate, Ouest, the police killed several gang members during an operation to halt increasing gang violence in the area reported during the week. They also seized two weapons and a bag of ammunition in Bonga and La Rate. Several reports indicate that the attacks carried out in the area over the week (coded separately) were announced by the gangs and should have been prevented by the authorities. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Property destruction: On 6 February 2025, in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, in the morning, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang set fire to a gas and service station on the National Road 1. The station had been out of service for several years. The arson attack took place near an already removed roadblock which had been set up by the criminals.

On 3 February 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 33, Ouest, in the morning, moto-taxi drivers held a demonstration in front of the Delmas 33 police station against members of the police who demanded the relocation of the moto-taxi drivers station to another location. Demonstrating drivers set up barricades of burning tires. They accused the officers of beating and extorting them.

On 4 February 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 60, Ouest, employees at the National Equipment Centre (CNE) held a sit-in protest in front of the Villa d'Accueil building demanding the payment of due salaries.

Around 3 February 2025 (as reported), in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, public school students held a demonstration in front of the Jean Wesley college building demanding the return of teachers to classrooms. During the mobilization, students threw stones and bottles against the Jean Wesley college and the Saint-Louis de Jeremie college, while police forces fired tear gas to disperse them. Some students were taken to hospital due to tear gas inhalation.

On 31 January 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, gang members attacked residents in the commune. This was part of an armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). Recent reports clarified that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. Casualties unknown.

On 3 February 2025, in Kenscoff - Belo, Ouest, gang members set fire to houses and vehicles as they attacked the Belo neighborhood (Bongars communal section), among others in the commune. Between 27 January and 3 February, more than 100 civilians fled their homes to take refuge at the Kenscoff city hall after the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) launched a coordinated armed offensive against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). Recent reports clarified that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. Casualties unknown.

On 3 February 2025, in Kenscoff - Belo, Ouest, military forces clashed with gang members in Belot and Godet neighborhoods (coded separately). Clashes took place as security forces intervened to expel the criminals from the commune, which was under the attack amid a coordinated offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) since 27 January (coded separately). Recent reports clarified that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. Casualties unknown.

source: Amerique Info 7; Haiti Standard; Trip Foumi
notes: On 3 February 2025, in Kenscoff - Bois d'Avril, Ouest, in the morning, armed gang members attacked the Boid d'Avril neighborhood (Bongars communal section). According to residents, the criminals opened fire as they noticed that security forces had left the area. Clashes with police forces were reported after the attack (coded separately). Between 27 January and 3 February, more than 100 civilians fled their homes to take refuge at the Kenscoff city hall after the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) launched a coordinated armed offensive against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). Recent reports clarified that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. Casualties unknown.

On 3 February 2025, in Kenscoff - Bois d'Avril, Ouest, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members in Bois d'Avril (Bongars communal section) after the criminals attacked the neigborhood moments before (coded separately). Between 27 January and 3 February, more than 100 civilians fled their homes to take refuge at the Kenscoff city hall after the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) launched a coordinated armed offensive against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). Recent reports clarified that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. Casualties unknown.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 31 January 2025, in Kenscoff - Bonga, Ouest, the police killed several gang members during an operation to halt increasing gang violence in the area reported during the week. They also seized two weapons and a bag of ammunition in Bonga and La Rate. Several reports indicate that the attacks carried out in the area over the week (coded separately) were announced by the gangs and should have been prevented by the authorities. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 3 February 2025, in Kenscoff - Godet, Ouest, military forces clashed with gang members in the Godet and Belo neighborhood (coded separately). Clashes happened as security forces intervened to expel the criminals from the commune, which was under the attack of the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) since 27 January (coded separately). Recent reports clarified that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. Casualties unknown.

On 2 December 2024, in Pentionville, Ouest, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defense group) clashed with members from the Didi Gang and the Viv Ansanm Gang alliance as they were trying to take control of the Petionville commune. Security forces managed to thwart the gangs' purposes. Casualties unknown.

Around 11 September 2024 (as reported), in the Artibonite department (coded to Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite), Artibonite, employees at the Development Organization of the Artibonite Valley (ODVA) held a protest demanding the departure of their general manager due to irregularities.
Other: On 30 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Solino and Nazon. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 28 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, armed gang members attacked residents in Bas Peu de Choses and Morne a Tuf neighborhoods (coded separately). Armed clashes (likely with police forces) were registered (coded separately). Hundreds of civilians fled their homes between 28 and 29 January. Casualties unknown.

On 28 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, gang members engaged in armed clashes likely with police forces, following similar clashes reported in the same area in previous days (coded separately). The clash was reported as gangs attacked residents in Bas Peu de Choses and Morne a Tuf neighborhoods (coded separately). Hundreds of civilians fled their homes between 28 and 29 January. Casualties unknown.

On 29 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, armed gang members attacked residents in Bas Peu de Choses and Morne a Tuf neighborhoods (coded separately). Armed clashes (likely with police forces) were registered (coded separately). Hundreds of civilians fled their homes between 28 and 29 January. Casualties unknown.

On 29 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, gang members engaged in armed clashes likely with police forces, following similar clashes reported in the same are in previous days (coded separately). The clash was reported as they attacked residents in Bas Peu de Choses and Morne a Tuf neighborhoods (coded separately). Hundreds of civilians fled their homes between 28 and 29 January. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: Around 2 February 2025 (weekend of), in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in the Salomon Market zone, Avenue Christophe, Capois Street, and Magloire Ambroise Street (Bas Peu de Choses neighborhood). Clashes were also registered in Champs de Mars (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: Around 2 February 2025 (weekend of), in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in Champs de Mars and Bas Peu de Choses neighborhoods (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 28 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, armed gang members attacked residents in Morne a Tuf neighborhoods and Bas Peu de Choses neighborhoods (coded separately). Armed clashes (likely with police forces) were registered (coded separately). Hundreds of civilians fled their homes between 28 and 29 January. Casualties unknown.

On 28 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, gang members engaged in armed clashes likely with police forces, following similar clashes reported in the same are in previous days (coded separately). The clash was reported as they attacked residents in Morne a Tuf neighborhoods and Bas Peu de Choses neighborhoods (coded separately). Hundreds of civilians fled their homes between 28 and 29 January. Casualties unknown.

On 29 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, armed gang members attacked residents in Morne a Tuf and Bas Peu de Choses neighborhoods (coded separately). Armed clashes (likely with police forces) were registered (coded separately). Hundreds of civilians fled their homes between 28 and 29 January. Casualties unknown.

On 29 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, gang members engaged in armed clashes likely with police forces, following similar clashes reported in the same are in previous days (coded separately). The clash was reported as they attacked residents in Morne a Tuf and Bas Peu de Choses neighborhoods (coded separately). Hundreds of civilians fled their homes between 28 and 29 January. Casualties unknown.

On 7 February 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Saint Antoine/Lalue, Ouest, employees at the Social Assistance Fund (CAS) held a sit-in protest in front of the headquarters of the First Instance Court, in Lalue, demanding the release of their director general, who was arrested on 30 January.

On 16 September 2024, in Tabarre, Ouest, people took to the streets against the arrest of the head of the city's police station and calling for his release. Protesters claimed that the arrest was arbitrary and defended the officer's work against gang violence.

Movement of forces: On 4 February 2025, in Tabarre - Aeroport Toussaint Louverture, Ouest, at least 60 Salvadorian police officers and soldiers (up to 70 according to other sources) arrived to the Toussaint Louverture Airport and were deployed as part of the multinational security support mission backed by the United Nations to fight against gang violence in the country.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: Movement of forces: On 6 February 2025, in Tabarre - Aeroport Toussaint Louverture, Ouest, at least 140 Kenyan police officers (up to 200 according to other sources) arrived to the Toussaint Louverture Airport and were deployed as part of the multinational security support mission backed by the United Nations to fight against gang violence in the country.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 5 April 2024, in Drouet, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang shot and killed nine people, injured eight others, and abducted 10 as they perpetrated an attack on the main road leading to Liancourt. There were farmers among the victims. The whereabouts of the abducted are unknown. The official version had stated that the fatal victims were four, the injured were six, and the kidnapped five, although several photos shared on social media by local sources confirmed the other balance. 9 fatalities, 8 injured.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 17 May 2024, in Tabarre - Carrefour Fleuriot, Ouest, police forces shot and killed a member of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) during a clash in the Colosso area, in Tabarre 42. A firearm was seized. 1 fatality.

On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Tabarre, Ouest, unidentified individuals, armed with heavy weapons, set up barricades in Clercine and Croix-des-Missions areas. These individuals threw tear gas and intimidated traders on the 15 October Boulevard (Carrefour Fleuriot neighborhood)), forcing them to leave the area. This is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Around 10 November 2024 (week of), in Drouet, Artibonite, police forces clashed with the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang for the control of the Liancourt Road. During clashes, a police officer and a driver were shot and injured. 2 injured.

Non-violent activity: Around 10 November 2024 (as reported), in Drouet, Artibonite, police officers from the Verrettes police division installed toll booth and demanded the payment of 50,000 gourdes to drivers wanting to cross the Liancourt Road safely. The money was demanded in exchange of police protection from the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang.

source: Gazette Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vant Bef Info
notes: On 15 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Turgeau, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Bas Turgeau. A woman who was at her residence was shot and killed by a stray bullet. This was likely the authorship of the Viv Ansanm Gang, whose members attacked multiple neighborhoods of Port-au-Prince on that day, and clashed with police forces (coded separately). 1 fatality.
On 22 January 2025, in Maissade, Centre, members of the population killed a member of the Kokorat San Ras Gang. There is no information on the circumstances of the killing. 1 fatality.

On 7 February 2025, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, police forces arrested six farmers, including a 15-year-old one, and killed them while in custody. The police killings were witnessed by residents who were at 'Sou Kanal', a public space where the extrajudicial executions took place. The victims' corpses were thrown to the Artibonite river. Residents claimed that police kill unharmed peasants who they make appear as gangsters or allies of the gangsters. 6 fatalities.

On 7 February 2025, near Kenscoff - Corail, Ouest, in the morning, several scores of citizens held a protest in front of the Kenscoff police station (near Corail neighborhood) in support of the commune's police commissioner and against his potential transfer to another jurisdiction. Authorities claimed that the transfer was a rumor.

source: Juno 7; Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 8 February 2025, in Marassa, Ouest, police forces killed several members of the 400 Mawozo Gang a during a security operation that also involved the destruction of stands set up by the gang to celebrate carnival festivities. Several trucks and a generator belonging to the gang were also seized. Barricades were removed. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 8 February 2025, in the Petionville commune, Ouest, overnight, the Kraze Barye Gang attacked the Gros Jean and Doko zones, among others in the commune (coded separately), as they tried to invade Petionville. Gunshots were heard. Casualties unknown.

On 8 February 2025, in Petion Ville - Diegue, Ouest, overnight, the Kraze Barye Gang attacked the Diegue neighborhood, among others in the commune (coded separately), as they tried to invade Petionville. Gunshots were heard. Casualties unknown.

On 8 February 2025, in Petion Ville - Boulay, Ouest, overnight, the Kraze Barye Gang attacked the Marlique area (in Boulay neighborhood), among others in the commune (coded separately), as they tried to invade Petionville. Gunshots were heard. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Juno 7; Trip Foumi
notes: Looting: On 9 February 2025, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, the leader of the 400 Mawozo Gang and its members looted and occupied the Centre FIFA Goal, at the Ranch Croix des Bouquets community center (likely to use it as operations base).

On 9 February 2025, in the Petionville commune, Ouest, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defense group) clashed with the Kraze Barye Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang) in the Doko, Nan Zago, and Nan Tunnel areas, killing several. Clashes were also registered in Gracien and 'Kajwo' (coded separately). Gunfight erupted after the Kraze Barye Gang tried to invade the Petionville commune the night prior (coded separately) and police forces launched an operation to expel them. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

Weapons seizure: On 9 February 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, the police and the Multinational Security Support Mission seized 15 firearms and 12 communication radios at the Kraze Barye Gang's base. Several members of the gang were also arrested.
Non-violent activity: Around 9 February 2025 (as reported), in Tabarre, Ouest, the Kraze Barye Gang set up a roadblock in the Torcelle neighborhood.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: On 9 February 2025, in Petion Ville - Freres, Ouest, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defense group) clashed with the Kraze Barye Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang) in the Impasse Gracien area (Freres neighborhood), killing several. Clashes were also registered in 'Kajwo', Doko, Nan Zago, and Nan Tunnel areas (coded separately). Gunfight erupted after the Kraze Barye Gang tried to invade the Petionville commune the night prior (coded separately) and police forces launched an operation to expel them. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 9 February 2025, near Petion Ville - Academie, Ouest, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defense group) clashed with the Kraze Barye Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang) in the 'Kajwo' area (less than 1 km away from the Police Academy), killing several. Clashes were also registered in the Impasse Gracien, Doko, Nan Zago, and Nan Tunnel areas (coded separately). Gunfight erupted after the Kraze Barye Gang tried to invade the Petionville commune the night prior (coded separately) and police forces launched an operation to expel them. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 10 February 2025, in Maissade, Centre, police forces clashed with more than 50 members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang when they tried to invade the commune. The criminals were forced to leave. Casualties unknown.
On 10 February 2025, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, several hundreds of students from public schools took to the streets demanding the return of teachers to classrooms after they went on a strike.
