On 9 March 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 65, Ouest, a police officer opened fire on a woman while trying to move a truck. Although the report indicates that the killing might have been accidental, an investigation has been open to clarify the circumstances of the incident. 1 fatality.

On 11 March 2025, in Delmas - Barbancourt, Ouest, gunshots were heard near the Airport road. A dead person was seen in a car near Haiti Plastics (on L. Jeudy Street) while two other people were kidnapped. There is no information on the perpetrators of the abductions, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown. 1 fatality.

On 12 March 2025, around Carrefour, Ouest, armed individuals opened fire on a bus transporting around 20 passengers towards the capital. Several people were killed. Several were injured. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.
On 17 March 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 19/Mackandal, Ouest, gang members attacked Delmas 19. They also attacked the Christ-Roi and Delmas 30 neighborhoods (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 17 March 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, gang members attacked the Delmas 30 neighborhood. They also attacked the Christ-Roi and Delmas 19 neighborhoods (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 12 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bois Verna, Ouest, 27 injured people (including women and children) were treated at a Doctors Without Borders (MSF) center known as 'Physicians Sans Frontieres-Centre D'urgence Turgeau', located along the Ch. Summer Avenue (Bois Verna). The victims were wounded amidst gang attacks in nearby areas of the hospital. 27 injured.
On 19 March 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition attacked Delmas 30. Casualties unknown.
On 19 March 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 32, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition attacked the Delmas 32 neighborhood. Casualties unknown.
On 19 March 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 19/Mackandal, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition attacked the Delmas 19 neighborhood. Casualties unknown.
On 19 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition attacked the neighborhood. Casualties unknown.
On 19 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Christ-Roi, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition attacked the neighborhood. Casualties unknown.
On 19 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour Feuilles, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition attacked the neighborhood. Casualties unknown.
On 19 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Avenue Christophe, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition attacked the neighborhood. Casualties unknown.
On 19 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Pacot, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition carried out an attack on Pacot street. Casualties unknown.
On 19 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition carried out an attack on Cameau and Capois streets. Casualties unknown.

Around 12 March 2025 (as reported), in Delmas - Delmas 19/Joseph Janvier, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents in Delmas 19. Following the attack, police forces intervened and clashed with the criminals (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

Property destruction: On 27 February 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Ravine Pintade, Ouest, overnight, gang members set fire to the facilities of the Order of Human Rights Defenders (ORDEDH), located on N. Alexis Road.
Property destruction: Around 15 March 2025 (as reported), overnight, in Delmas - Delmas 19/Mackandal, Ouest, gang members looted and set fire to several businesses.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Trip Foumi
notes: Property destruction: On 15 March 2025, in Delmas - Village W. Lamothe, Ouest, overnight, the Viv Ansanm Gang looted and set fire to the Tele Pluriel headquarters, located at the intersection of the Aine street and the Delmas 19 Road. Another business establishments located in the same area, including the 'R & C Plaza' mall, were also looted and burned. Gunshots were heard along the Delmas 19 Road and surrounding areas.

On 17 March 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 32, Ouest, several gang members trying to invade the neighborhood were killed and their corpses were burned. The perpetrators were not clarified, although this was likely the authorship of mobs of residents taking justice by their hands. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.
Other: On 17 March 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, barricades were erected in Juvenat using tires, a car, and a metal fence. There is no information on the motives of the barricades or who set them up.
Other: On 17 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, barricades were erected in Debrosse. There is no information on the motives of the barricades or who set them up.

Other: On 18 March 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, barricades were erected in Juvenat using tires and metal. There is no information on the motives of the barricades or who set them up.

Other: On 18 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, barricades were erected in the Debrosse neighborhoods, as well as on Bois Patate, Cheriez, Fernand, and Dalencourt streets. There is no information on the motives of the barricades or who set them up.

Other: On 14 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, residents set up barricades and installed barriers and checkpoints in the Bois Patate, Avenue N (Pacot), Turgeau, Bois Verna, and Canape-Vert neighborhoods to prevent gang members from access to their communities.
Other: Around 9 March 2025 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Christ-Roi and Nazon. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 10 March 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Cazeau and Croix des Missions. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 12 March 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 32. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 12 March 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Torcelle. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 13 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince , Ouest, gunshots were heard and fires set in Terre-Blanche, Campeche, and Morne Marie. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots and fires.
Other: On 18 March 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 30. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 18 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Christ-Roi. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 18 March 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Cazeau. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 20 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Avenue Christophe. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 17 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Carrefour-Feuilles, Solino, and Nazon neighborhoods. There is no information on the circumstances and the authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 15 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, self-defense brigades of the Debrosse area closed the neighborhood's gates to search people going through.
Other: On 16 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, self-defense brigades set up barricades and imposed curfews in Turgeau, Pacot, and Canape Vert in the face of potential attacks.

On 14 March 2025, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, in the morning, health workers and other staff members held a sit-in protest with banners at the courtyard of the Saint-Michel de Jacmel hospital in support of the head of the institution and against rumors stating his possible transfer to another hospital.

On 19 March 2025, in the Kenscoff commune, Ouest, residents holding signs marched through the road leading to Tet K-Jak area to denounce how the gangs have occupied this road connecting with Seguin, which affects transport and their commercial activities. The march had initiated in Seguin.

On 15 March 2025, in the Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune, Artibonite, residents held a protest to decry the killing of six people by the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang earlier that day (coded separately). Protesters displayed the victims' corpses and placed them outside a police station while demanding the police to take action in the face of insecurity. The protest was held somewhere in Bas Coursin II (Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite's 2nd communal section).

source: AFP; Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 14 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents on Marcellin, Cameau, and Capois streets. They looted several buildings, including the Infopac School. Other buildings were set on fire. The criminals fired shots and raped a 16-year-old girl. People fled the area. The French Embassy, on Capois street, closed its doors due to gang-related violence in the area. They also targeted nearby areas of the Avenue Christophe neighborhood (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 19 March 2025, in Petion Ville - Juvenat, Ouest, people demonstrated by erecting burning barricades on the Juvenat Road to denounce the rising insecurity due to gang violence, as well as to prevent gang attacks.

source: Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Vi Free Press; Xinhua
notes: On 21 October 2024, in Arcahaie, Ouest, members of the Canaan Gang and the Grand-Ravine Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang) attacked residents in the Williamson neighborhood as they tried to take control of the Arcahaie, Carries, and Bercy villages (coded separately). The criminals set fire to homes and vehicles. Several residents were killed. A total of 23 people were killed during gang attacks in Arcahaie on 21 October. 23 fatalities split across three events. 8 fatalities coded here.

source: Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: On 12 November 2024, in Cite Soleil - Sarthe, Ouest, members of the Canaan Gang, the Chien Mechant Gang, and Terre Noire Gang (all dressed in red clothes) set fire to a dozen houses as they attacked the Sarthe and Drouillard neighborhoods (coded separately). Only in the Sarthe neighborhood, 21 people were killed and nine were injured (including seven children) as the criminals chased off-duty police officers and their families on Germain and Arald streets, and near La Couronne Company. This was likely in support of the Viv Ansanm Gang offensive launched after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). The UN reported several fatalities in attacks perpetrated by gangs that happened between 11 and 15 November in Port-au-Prince and at least 150 fatalities in all violent events that happened during said week. 21 fatalities, 9 injured.

source: Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Haiti Info Project (HIP); Haiti Libre; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 30 November 2024, in the Leogane commune, Ouest, the 103 Zombies Gang and the Ti Bwa Gang attacked the relatives of members of a self-defense group from the Petro locality, which belongs to the Paques section (in Leogane 7th communal section), killing around 20 farmers and residents (up to 50 according to BINUH). Several other people were shot and injured. Some houses were burned. Among the victims, which include women, and children, there is a local 'hougan' (voodoo priest) whose activity motivated the attack. The gang members accused the voodoo priest of disclosing to the community a ritual which would have weakened their spiritual protections, and that would have fostered losses among their affiliates during clashes with police forces and self-defense groups. At least 20 fatalities.

source: Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Metropole; Trip Foumi
notes: On 13 December 2024, off the Coast of Anse a Galets, Ouest, armed gang members hijacked a ship called 'Nono' with 52 passengers and six crew members on-board. The victims were kidnapped and taken to the Mariani neighborhood in Carrefour commune. It is suspected they were captives of the Bout Ba Gang, which controls Mariani. Other sources identified the abductors as gang members from Village de Dieu and Canaan. The criminals stole the victims from their money and belongings before being released.

source: Gazette Haiti; InSight Crime; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 21 January 2025, near Cite Soleil - Sarthe, Ouest, armed gang members opened fire on three vehicles belonging to the Indian General Consulate circulating along the Airport Road towards the Sarthe neighborhood. The consul's assistant was shot and killed, while two drivers and two daughters of the Indian consul were injured. One source stated that the Honorary Consul was injured (not confirmed by other sources). The criminals set fire to one of the vehicles. The attack was described as a reprisal against anti-gang operations by the police and the Multinational Security Support Mission. The police arrested a man in connection with the attack on 17 March. 1 fatality, 4 injured.

Looting: On 22 March 2025, in Cite Soleil - Drouillard, Ouest, unidentified armed individuals fired shots as they tried to hijack two containers in Drouillard and Carrefour Vincent (Sarthe neighborhood) (coded separately). No further details were mentioned and it is unknown if the criminals managed to hijack the containers.

On 8 January 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, tens of health workers from the Saint-Nicolas hospital held a protest with banners at the entrance of the health centre to decry an administrative measure which force them to go to Gonaives to obtain their wages. The mobilization was part of a labor strike.

On 15 January 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, citizens held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires. Demonstrators claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 16 January 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, an anti-government demonstration took place in Route National #1 which was blocked around Frecyneau. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 17 January 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, a group of people set barricades of burning tires and rocks to block Fleurenceau Road and other areas. The report also indicates that people threw bottles and rocks at passers-by. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the incidents, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).
Other: On 22 January 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, the Route Nationale #1 was blocked in Portail Guepe. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.
Other: On 24 January 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, the Route National #1 was blocked. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

source: Alterpresse; Le Filet Info; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 7 February 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, thousands of residents and members of socio-political organizations held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. During the mobilization, some vehicles were burned and police forces intervened to disperse the rioters. A 18-year-old woman was shot and killed by the police as the crowd marched towards Frecyneau police station. Several other demonstrators were injured. This part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 1 fatality, several injured.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole
notes: On 17 February 2024, in Liancourt, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang attacked drivers and trucks drivers on the roadway. At least two passengers of a vehicle were killed. Three merchants' trucks were set on fire, although the occupants escaped unharmed. Several other people were burned alive. One source described the deceased as smugglers who used to facilitate access to dangerous areas, although this was not confirmed by other reports and their affiliation was not clarified. A fourth vehicle crashed on the road while the driver was trying to flee from the attackers. At least 2 fatalities.

On 5 February 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, people protested and set up barricades (unspecified). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the protest, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 17 February 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, members of the political opposition held a protest against the government of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry, after having attended the funeral of a young woman who was killed during an anti-government mobilization on 7 February (coded separately). Protesters set up barricades (nature unknown) and shouted anti-government slogans as they approached a police station.

On 8 February 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, people held a demonstration and roadblocks were set. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 6 February 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. This part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 14 April 2024, in Liancourt, Artibonite, members of the Savien Gang attacked the Savane Pistache locality. According to the report, more than five people were wounded during the attack, while three residents were abducted. The victims' whereabouts are unknown. At least 5 injured.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 14 June 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, Ouest, overnight, at least two members of the Timonette Gang assaulted and disarmed two security guards working at the Ti Malice company's facilities, in the Timonette communal section. The criminals set fire to several nearby houses before fleeing with the stolen arms. As the company's private security team boarded a truck and chased the criminals, members of the same gang managed to hijack the vehicle at the height of Pont-Sonde. They fled with the stolen items. Two gang members, including the leader of the gang, were arrested on 16 June (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 16 June 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, police forces arrested a local gang leader in the Timonette communal section. The arrested was the leader of a gang known as Timonette Gang.

Security measures: On 16 August 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, local authorities imposed a curfew in the commune that will go from 16 August to 19 August 2024 (8 PM to 6 AM) after a group of inmates rioted and escaped from the Saint-Marc civil prison on 15 August (coded separately). The measure was taken as security forces searched for fugitives to arrest them. The curfew was reviewed for one month starting on 19 August 2024.

On 31 August 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, police forces arrested a human rights advocate man and head of the Action Network for the Defence of Human Rights (RADDH) organization. The motivation for the arrest was accusations of corruption against him.

Looting: On 15 October 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, in the early morning, armed group members occupied the Philippe Guerrier square and looted everything the found on their way. The square was occupied by residents from Pont Sonde who were sheltering there after the gang massacre of 3 October (coded separately).

On 23 October 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, a group of students held a protest at the UPBAS University compound over unspecified claims. During the protest, armed individuals threatened and aggressed the students. A journalist man who was covering the mobilization was aggressed by a faculty dean and former deputy of the Saint-Marc commune. The aggressor lunged at him with a punch. The journalist's equipment (cell phone screen) was damaged.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: On 21 October 2024, in Carries, Ouest, members of the Canaan Gang and the Grand-Ravine Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang) attacked residents as they tried to take control of the Carries, Arcahaie, and Bercy villages (coded separately). A total of 23 people were killed during gang attacks in Arcahaie on 21 October. 23 fatalities split across three events. 8 fatalities coded here.

source: Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 21 October 2024, in Bercy, Ouest, members of the Canaan Gang and the Grand-Ravine Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang) attacked residents and caused damages (nature unspecified) as they tried to take control of the Bercy, Carries, and Arcahaie villages (coded separately). A total of 23 people were killed during gang attacks in Arcahaie on 21 October. 23 fatalities split across three events. 7 fatalities coded here.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Vi Free Press
notes: On 5 September 2024, in Tabarre - Dumornay, Ouest, four armed individuals exited a vehicle and shot and killed a man riding a motorcycle in Tabarre 41 (specifically in the area of the Petits Freres et Soeurs Hospital, in Dumornay neighborhood, which is near the US Embassy, located in nearby Chateau Blond neighborhood). A woman was shot and injured by the stray bullets. According to police, the man was killed because he was involved in illegal trafficking and had ties with the Kraze Barye Gang, although the shooting was later identified as a case of extrajudicial execution by police forces. Two police officers were arrested. 1 fatality, 1 injured.

On 14 October 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, students of the Antoinette Dessalines National School held a march demanding the authorities to address the situation of the displaced people from Pont Sonde who were sheltering at their school after gang attacks of 3 October (coded separately). Protesters blocked the National Road 1 (RN1).

On 6 November 2024, in Savien, Artibonite, the Savien Gang kidnapped a truck driver and set fire to his vehicle. Another truck was hijacked. Both belonged to the Syntransbel company. A ransom was asked for the driver's safe release. His whereabouts are unknown.

On 7 November 2024, between Pont Sonde and Saint-Marc (coded to Saint-Marc), Artibonite, more than 1,000 residents called by the '3 October Collective' movement held a march along the National Road 1 (RN1) demanding the dismantling of two main armed groups operating in the Artibonite department. The march had initiated in Pont Sonde and finished in front of the Saint-Marc city hall, where protesters shouted slogans against the commune's authorities and held banners and tree branches.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 27 November 2024, near Poste Pierrot, Artibonite, scores of Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang members supported by the Palmiste Gang invaded and attacked the Coutang area in Savane Brulee section. Three people were killed and six were shot and injured. 10 houses and three vehicles were burned. At least 50 cattle heads were stolen. The criminals' motivation was to recover a gang member firearm which had been taken by residents. 3 fatalities, 6 injured.

On 22 November 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, 1,000 residents from Pont Sonde led by the 3 October Collective movement held a march to Saint-Marc with banners and tree branches demanding justice for the victims of the 3 of October gang massacre in Pont Sonde (coded separately). Demonstrators called on authorities to take measures for the dismantling of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. During the march, they placed stones, pieces of vehicles, and other debris on the roadway to block traffic. Scenes of looting and violence were registered.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
actor2: MSS: Multinational Security Support Mission in Haiti (2023-2025)
source: Alterpresse; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: Property destruction: On 28 December 2024, in Savien, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang set fire to a broken down and abandoned armored vehicle belonging to the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS). One source stated that the Dinosaur Gang took part in the destruction of the vehicle in support of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Alterpresse; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 29 December 2024, in Savien, Artibonite, police forces supported by the Multinational Security Support Mission shot and killed several members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. Security forces also destroyed several properties belonging to gang members, including a house that was set on fire. Stolen animals were recovered. A number of gang members managed to flee. Between 28 and 29 December, at least 10 gang members were killed during anti-gang operations in five locations in the Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune (coded in three events). At least 10 fatalities split across three events, 2 fatalities coded here.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 4 January 2025, in Liancourt, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang shot and killed a man riding a motorcycle when he tried to cross the Liancourt Road. 1 fatality.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Non-violent activity: Around 5 January 2025 (between 30 December - 8 January), in Savien, Artibonite, gang members (likely from the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang) installed traps and regained control of certain areas in Savien and the Palmiste locality (coded separately). This happened after the criminals were expelled from the mentioned areas by police forces on 29 December (coded separately).

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 12 January 2025, in Savien, Artibonite, several members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang tortured a journalist man who was captive as he was kidnapped on 3 December 2024 (coded separately). The victim got feet, hands, and back burnt. He was severely beaten on the head and other parts of the body. He was released on 18 January 2025. 1 injured.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 31 December 2024, in Savien, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang beat up a journalist man and two women who were captives as they had been kidnapped days before (coded separately). The women were beaten up until they fainted. The journalist was hit with telephone and electrical cables. The beatings were punishment after people who were supposed to submit the payment of ransoms for the victims' release did not do so. 3 injured.
Around 14 January 2025 (between 13 - 15 January), in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, students took to the streets demanding the return of teachers to classrooms after they went on a labor strike.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 23 February 2025, in Liancourt, Artibonite, self-defense group members clashed with the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. Casualties unknown.

Around 5 March 2025 (between 5 - 6 March), in Cap-Haitien, Nord, Platfom Pitit Desalin party militants and supporters smashed plates and chairs, and beat other members of the party with sticks during a demonstration at the Philippe Guerrier national high school to decry decision making within the party by a small group of foreign agents who, according to demonstrators, are absent from the street movements, but reap all the benefits. The mobilization was held during the holding of a party internal meeting, which was interrupted by demonstrators.

On 20 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, gang members threw a Molotov cocktail and set fire to a police armored vehicle parked in front of the Kotemal business, at the intersection of Magloire Ambroise Avenue and Marche Salomon (Bas Peu de Choses). Police forces, supported by Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission, intervened and clashed with the criminals. Casualties unknown.

On 21 March 2025, in Jeanton I, Artibonite, overnight, police forces clashed with gang members as they conducted a security operation in the Jeanton II neighborhood. A gang member was shot and killed, another one was arrested, and a peace judge who accompanied the officers was injured. Several firearms and ammunition were seized. 1 fatality, 1 injured.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 10 December 2024 (between 9 - 10 December), near Descordes, Artibonite, members of the Chandelle Communal Militia (self-defense group) killed an unclarified number of people in nearby Bois Laville area over accusations of being accomplices or collaborators of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. Among the victims, there were women and girls who were suspected of being partners of gang members. The victims' gang affiliation was not confirmed. Some victims were stabbed with machetes and others killed with gunshots. Between 9 and 10 December, 39 people were killed by this communal militia in Bois Laville and Passe Barque (coded separately). Between 9 and 12 December, 67 civilians were killed by self-defense groups in Bois Laville, Passe Barque (coded separately), and Ti Rouge (coded separately). 19 fatalities coded here.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 10 December 2024 (between 9 - 10 December), in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune, Artibonite, members of the Chandelle Communal Militia (self-defense group) killed an unclarified number of people in the Passe Barque area over accusations of being accomplices or collaborators of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. Among the victims, there were women and girls who were suspected of being partners of gang members. The victims' gang affiliation was not confirmed. Some victims were stabbed with machetes and others killed with gunshots. Between 9 and 10 December, 39 people were killed by this communal militia in Passe Barque and Bois Laville (coded separately). Between 9 and 12 December, 67 civilians were killed by self-defense groups in Bois Laville (coded separately), Passe Barque, and Ti Rouge (coded separately). 39 fatalities split across two events. 20 fatalities coded here.

Looting: On 22 March 2025, in Cite Soleil - Sarthe, Ouest, unidentified armed individuals fired shots as they tried to hijack two containers between Carrefour Vincent (Sarthe neighborhood) and Drouillard (coded separately). No further details were mentioned and it is unknown if the criminals managed to hijack the vehicles.

On 25 March 2025, in the Petionville commune, Ouest, unidentified individuals carried out attacks in the Gramot area. Gunshots were also heard in Thomassin 48. There is no further information on the circumstances and the actors involved in these attacks. Casualties unknown.

On 24 March 2025, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, several thousands of people, called by several organizations from the Artibonite department, held a protest on the National Road 1 against the violence of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. They demanded support from the police and other authorities.

On 24 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Pacot, Ouest, overnight, armed individuals traveling in a vehicle shot and killed a man in front of the building of the Ministry of Culture and Communication (MCC), what is now being used as a shelter (drive-by). There is no information on the motives of the attack. 1 fatality.
On 25 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Baillergeau, Ouest, gang members invaded and attacked the neighborhood, causing residents to flee the area. Gunshots were heard. Casualties unknown.

On 26 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Baillergeau, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, gang members attacked the neighborhood, causing residents to flee the area. Gunshots were heard. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Vi Free Press
notes: On 24 March 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 19/Mackandal, Ouest, in the morning, the Viv Ansanm Gang opened indiscriminate fire along the Delmas 19 Road, hitting a public transport vehicle and killing the driver and injuring two passengers (a man and a woman). The shooting took place on the Delmas 19 Road at the height of Delmas 31 Road to the East, and the Mosaiques Gardere S.A. Company to the West. Several people were kidnapped and taken to Bas Delmas. Their whereabouts are unknown. Some public institutions and private companies were looted and vandalized. At least 20 people were injured as part of attacks launched against several Delmas neighborhoods that morning. This was part of a gang offensive aimed at taking control of the Delmas commune. 1 fatality.

source: Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 24 March 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, in the morning, the Viv Ansanm Gang opened indiscriminate fire on citizens in Delmas 30. Several civilians who were at the top of a building were shot at and taken as hostages. An unknown number of dead bodies were also found on the streets of the neighborhood. Some public institutions and private companies were looted and vandalized. At least 20 people were injured as part of attacks launched against several Delmas neighborhoods that morning. This was part of a gang offensive aimed at taking control of the Delmas commune. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 24 March 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 32, Ouest, in the morning, the Viv Ansanm Gang shot a young man to the head, killing him, as they opened indiscriminate fire in Delmas 32. This was part of a gang offensive aimed at taking control of the Delmas commune. Some public institutions and private companies were looted and vandalized. At least 20 people were injured as part of attacks launched against several Delmas neighborhoods that morning. 1 fatality.

On 24 March 2025, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked Delmas 24. At least 20 people were injured as part of attacks launched against several Delmas neighborhoods that morning. This was part of a gang offensive aimed at taking control of the Delmas commune. Some public institutions and private companies were looted and vandalized.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 24 March 2025, in Delmas - Village W. Lamothe, Ouest, in the morning, the Viv Ansanm Gang opened indiscriminate fire on pedestrians in Delmas 25 and Delmas 27 streets. The targeted victims on the mentioned streets managed to escape unharmed, although others were injured as gang members hiding in occupied buildings along the Delmas 29 and Delmas 31 streets also fired at civilians. At least 20 people were injured as part of attacks launched against several Delmas neighborhoods that morning. This was part of a gang offensive aimed at taking control of the Delmas commune. Some public institutions and private companies were looted and vandalized.

On 24 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Avenue Christophe, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang fired shots as they attacked residents in Avenue Christophe and Pacot neighborhoods (coded separately). In Avenue Christophe, the criminals looted and set fire to the Haitian Artisanal Committee building, located on Rue 3 street. The scene was recorded on video. Casualties unknown.

On 24 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Campeche, Ouest, overnight, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang carried out an attack and set fire to residents' homes, forcing them to flee the area. Casualties unknown.

On 24 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Pacot, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang fired shots and participated in lootings as they attacked residents in the Pacot and Avenue Christophe neighborhoods (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Haiti Press Network; Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Trip Foumi
notes: Security measures: On 25 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) announced, via a bulletin, the closing of the Haitian borders by land and air with the Dominican Republic. This decision aims to control the flux of import from the neighboring country to avoid contraband. The measure will take effect on 7 April and goods coming from and through the Dominican Republic will only be received via maritime routes. It is expected that this decision will have a big impact on both commercial and diplomatic relations between the two countries.
Other: On 21 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Christ-Roi. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 22 March 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 19 and Delmas 30. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 24 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Baillergeau neighborhood, causing residents to flee the area. This was likely the authorship of gang members who attacked the close Campeche neighborhood on that day (coded separately), and the Baillergeau neighborhood on the next two consecutive days (coded separately). Gunshots were also heard in Christ-Roi and Nazon.
Other: On 25 March 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 30. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 25 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Nazon and Christ-Roi. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 25 March 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Tabarre 27. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 24 March 2025, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, hundreds of teachers and students, called by the Northern Teachers' Coalition, held a protest at the gates of the Paul Eugene Magloire and La Renaissance schools to demand better working conditions. Protesting teachers blocked access to the school centres. This was part of a teachers' labor strike.

Other: On 26 March 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, a roadblock of tires was set up on the road near the Union School (Juvenat neighborhood), where the presence of the police was registered. Another roadblock was also registered in Thomassin 32. There is no information on the circumstances or motives of the roadblocks.
Other: On 26 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Campeche. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 26 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a roadblock was set up in Debrosse. There is no information on the motives of the roadblock or who set it up.
Other: On 26 March 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard on Rue Roumain, near the Boulevard du 15 Octobre. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 27 March 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, overnight, gunshots were heard in the higher areas of Delmas, in Petionville. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 27 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Bourdon. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Around 15 December 2024 (month of), in Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13, Ouest, unidentified armed individuals shot a 14-year-old girl and raped her in Delmas 9. 1 injured.

On 26 March 2025, between Delmas 40b and Delmas 75 (coded to Delmas - Delmas 75), Ouest, a few dozen citizens, called by the Committed to Development Party (EDE) and several civil society organizations, held a demonstration through the streets of Delmas against rising insecurity and to demand the stepping down the Transitional Presidential Council, among other claims. Burning tires were set up on the path of the demonstrators across Delmas 40b, Delmas 48, and Delmas 71. The police used tear gas and gunshots to disperse the demonstrators in Delmas 40B and Delmas 75.
Around 20 March 2025 (between 17 - 23 March), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, more than 10 gang members raped a 70-year-old woman on the Magloire Ambroise Avenue. She was taken to hospital for treatment.

On 24 March 2025, in Terre Rouge, Centre, residents protested by blocking the Route Nationale #3 to demand that the authorities send armored vehicles to the area for protection after the police station was burned (coded separately).

On 28 March 2025, in Carrefour - Fontamara, Ouest, public transport drivers demonstrated against a fifth toll station established by gang members in 4e Bolosse Avenue. They set up barricades of burning tires, blocking the circulation between Carrefour and the rest of Port-au-Prince. The demonstrators expressed that those tolls have affected their work and denounced the passivity of the authorities in relation to the issue.

On 25 March 2025, near Kenscoff - Corail, Ouest, at least 50 people demonstrated in front of the Kenscoff police station (located between the 108 Departmental Road and the Kenscoff 78 Road, near Corail neighborhood) by setting objects on fire in the area. There is no information on the motives of the demonstration.

On 1 April 2025, off the Coast of Mariani, Ouest, overnight, gang members assaulted a rice cargo ship anchored off the Mariani bay and kidnapped two crew members. The ship managed to reach the bay of Port-au-Prince hours later, although the victims' whereabouts are unknown.

Around 31 December 2024 (as reported), in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune, Ouest, armed individuals killed two civilians and stole their organs. The killings took place in an uninhabited area near a canal, not far from the Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite police station. These killings are said to be perpetrated as the criminals make fake accusations of complicity of the victims with rival gang members. 2 fatalities.

On 27 March 2025, between Port-au-Prince - Canape-Vert and Port-au-Prince - Bourdon (coded to Port-au-Prince - Bourdon), Ouest, several hundreds of people, called by a self-defense group from Canape-Vert, held a demonstration from that neighborhood towards Villa d'Accueil (in Delmas 60) against rising insecurity and to demand the stepping down the Transitional Presidential Council, among other claims. The demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires along the Bourdon road, around Musseau, and on Dalencourt Street. As the crowd arrived to Bourdon, the police fired tear gas and dispersed the demonstration.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2025-)
source: Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi; Vi Free Press
notes: On 1 April 2025, off the Coast of Cap-Haitien, Nord, US coast guards intercepted and arrested 99 Haitian migrants in a boat about 35 miles north of Cap-Hatien that was heading north toward the Turks and Caicos. They were deported.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: Other: On 24 July 2024, in Dufort, Ouest, civilians set up barricades and roadblocks on the Route Nationale#2 near the police station to prevent members of the 103 Zombies Gang from entering their communities.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 20 March 2025, around Preval, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang kidnapped four civilians, including two women who were raped during captivity. Three of the victims were released after a ransom was paid, while the fourth one was killed due to lack of payment. 1 fatality.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 19 March 2024, in the commune of Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a woman identified as member the Base Nan Tokyo Gang and wife of the gang's leader stabbed to death a woman. The victim as a known person on the Tik Tok social media. The perpetrator was arrested in Delmas 62 in April 2025. 1 fatality.

Non-violent activity: Around 15 March 2025 (as reported), in Mirebalais, Centre, armed members of the population (self-defense group) set up roadblocks along the National Road 3, near the Mirebalais police station, and the Mirebalais University Hospital (HUM). This was part of efforts by the local population to prevent gang members from entering their communities.

source: Lune Actus; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vant Bef Info
notes: Non-violent activity: On 28 March 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, members of the Pele-Simon Gang set up a toll station on the Airport Road in Pele Simon, forcing drivers to pay a fee to circulate through the area. When drivers do not comply, the gangsters either assault them or seize their car. A source indicates that the gangsters were members of the Viv Ansanm Gang.

On 29 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Christ Roi - Lalue, Ouest, several groups of citizens held a march to reject proposals to reform the Haitian Constitution. As the crowd arrived to the Christ Roi - Lalue neighborhood, police forces fired tear gas and dispersed the mobilization, which was supposed to reach the Primature building. The protest was held on the occasion of the 38th anniversary of the Haitian Constitution.

On 6 January 2025, in the Leogane commune, Ouest, a gang member accompanied by 25 other gangsters shot and killed his father at his home before his accomplices beheaded the victim and set fire to the corpse and the property, located in the Paques section (Leogane 7th communal section). The deceased man was a former CASEC member (communal authority). The criminals were part of a gang affiliated to the Ti Bwa Gang. The victim's son was arrested in March 2025. 1 fatality.
Other: Around 30 March 2025 (as reported), in Trianon, Centre, residents set up roadblocks to prevent gang members from entering their communities.

Non-violent activity: Around 30 March 2025 (weekend of), in Delmas, Ouest, the Base Krache Dife Gang installed a toll booth in the Simon Pele neighborhood along the Boulevard Toussaint Louverture (a.k.a. Airport Road).

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 2 April 2025, between Port-au-Prince - Canape-Vert and Port-au-Prince - Bourdon, Ouest, thousands of residents led by the leader of the Canape-Vert self-defense group, and called by the 'Unblock Haiti' citizens' movement, held a march holding three branches and machetes from Canape-Vert towards Villa D'Accueil (in Delmas 60) to decry rising insecurity and to demand the stepping down the Transitional Presidential Council, among other claims. The demonstrators, who set up burning barricades in Lalue, Turgeau, and Bourdon, were dispersed by police forces with tear gas and real bullets as the crowd crossed Bourdon. At least one demonstrator was injured during police reprisals. Another group of residents who marched over the same claims from Petionville were dispersed in Villa D'Accueil (coded separately). At least 1 injured.

On 2 April 2025, in Tabarre - Tabarre 27, Ouest, police forces engaged in armed clashes with the Viv Ansanm Gang as the criminals attacked the area. Clashes were also registered in nearby Clercine II, Butte Boyer, and Croix des Missions neighborhoods (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 27 March 2025, around Mont-organise, Nord-Est, overnight, armed group members shot and injured three people near a river located along the road connecting Mont-organize to Ouanaminthe to the North and Carice to the South. The victims identified the aggressors as members of an armed group. Armed group members have recently expressed willingness to establish a base in the Ouanaminthe region. 3 injured.

source: Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 3 April 2025, in Tabarre - Clercine II/Carrefour Clercine, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, police forces supported by the Multinational Security Support Mission (MSS) clashed with members of the Canaan Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang as they tried to take control of the Motorized Intervention Brigade (BIM) facilities (police forces), located in the Clercine II neighborhood. During clashes, at least 20 gang members were killed. Their bodies were found scattered on the streets. At least 20 fatalities.

On 2 April 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, gunshots were heard as more than 100 armed group members invaded and attacked the Delmas 30 neighborhood. Armed individuals were also seen in Delmas 32 and Christ-Roi neighborhoods. Casualties unknown.

On 3 April 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, for a fourth consecutive day, police forces clashed with gang members on Geffrard and Grand-rue streets, killing several. The criminals were affiliates of the Canaan Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang who attacked the commune since 31 March (coded separately). Residents claimed that this was part of reprisals orchestrated by the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition for the resistance of the Trianon self-defense group to gang presence in the area (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities as 3.
On 2 April 2025, in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, the Savien Gang hijacked a bus and kidnapped several passengers on board. Their whereabouts are unknown.

On 1 April 2025, in Kenscoff - Fermathe, Ouest, armed group members engaged in armed clashes in Thomassin 32, Grenier, and Pyron areas, prompting scores of residents to flee their homes to take refuge in Petionville. Witnesses claimed that material damages were registered during the clashes. It was not clarified if human casualties were counted. Casualties unknown.
On 5 February 2024, in Carrefour - Bas Thorland, Ouest, gang members attacked (methods unknown) the Omega police station. Casualties unknown.

source: Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 2 April 2025, in Saut-d'Eau, Centre, armed gang members opened fire on a civil protection helicopter, injuring a police officer on board. The aircraft integrated a government convoy that was on its way to Mirebalais to fight gang members attacking the commune since 31 March (coded separately). The helicopter was hit by six gunshots. 1 injured.

On 31 March 2025, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, scores of public school teachers supported by parents held a protest through the streets of Fort-Liberte to demand better working conditions for the educators, including higher wages, among other claims.

On 3 April 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out a drone airstrike against the Viv Ansanm Gang, killing several criminals who were gathering at the Cassandra Market. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 24 March 2025, around Bois d'Orme, Ouest, armed gang members killed seven passengers of a bus as they attacked the transport vehicle along the National Road 3 at the height of Morne-a-Cabrits area. Several other passengers went missing. Their whereabouts are unknown. The bus destination was Jean-Rabel (Nord-Ouest). Relatives claimed to recover the victims' bodies. At least 7 fatalities.

source: Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 2 April 2025, in Tabarre - Clercine II/Carrefour Clercine, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang coming from La Plaine du cul-de-sac attacked the vicinity of the Motorized Intervention Brigade (BIM) facilities (police forces), located in the Clercine II neighborhood. Police forces responded and clashed with the criminals in Carrefour Rita. Clashes were also registered in nearby Tabarre 27 and Butte Boyer (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 2 April 2025, in Tabarre - Croix des Missions, Ouest, Viv Ansanm Gang members coming from La Plaine du Cul-de-Sac clashed with police forces in the neighborhood. Clashes were also registered in nearby Butte Boyer and Tabarre 27 neighborhoods (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 2 April 2025, between Petionville and Delmas - Delmas 60, Ouest, thousands of residents, called by the 'Unblock Haiti' citizens' movement, held a march with banners and machetes towards Villa D'Accueil (in Delmas 60) to decry rising insecurity and to demand the stepping down the Transitional Presidential Council, among other claims. Armed demonstrators set up burning barricades in Delmas 91 and 95 and were seen firing shots to force residents into their houses along the Freres Road (Delmas 95) and the Juvenat Road (Juvenat). Police forces fired real bullets and tear gas to disperse the crowd in Villa D'Accueil (Delmas 60). The demonstrators responded throwing stones and attacking business establishments. Another group of residents who marched over the same claims from Canape-Vert (Port-au-Prince) were dispersed in Bourdon (Port-au-Prince) (coded separately).
On 28 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Canape-Vert, Ouest, people protested with accompanying rara music. There is no information on the motives for the protest.

On 3 April 2025, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, residents held a protest with banners to demand the release of the mayor. She had been arrested over accusations of involvement in the killing of President Jovenel Moise (coded separately). Protesters claimed to believe in her innocence.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: Around 21 December 2024 (between 7 December - 4 January), in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune, Artibonite, according to the Commission for Dialogue, Reconciliation and Awareness to Save the Artibonite organization, self-defense group members supported by mobs of residents killed more than 150 suspected members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang and threw their bodies to the Artibonite river. Among the victims, there were family members of the gangsters, including eight girls. At least 30 of the victims were killed between 8 and 10 December (coded separately). 120 fatalities coded here.

source: Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 2 April 2025, in Tabarre - Butte Boyer, Ouest, police forces engaged in armed clashes with the Viv Ansanm Gang in Clercine 24 and 22, where the gang members also looted homes (coded separately). Clashes were also registered in nearby Tabarre 27 and Croix des Missions neighborhoods (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 3 April 2025, between Delmas - Delmas 40b and Delmas - Delmas 60, Ouest, thousands of militants and supporters of the Committed to Development Party (EDE) held a march from Delmas 40b to the Primature building (in Delmas 60) demanding the stepping down of the Presidential Transitional Council (CPT), among other claims. Barricades of burning tires were erected in Delmas 52 and Delmas 81 on the Delmas road. Demonstrators were also seen in Delmas 83. As the crowd arrived to the intersection of Musseau and Delmas 60, police forces fired tear gas and dispersed the mobilization. The demonstration was held on the occasion of the anniversary of the so-called 3rd of April Agreement (designed by the CPT for a political transition).

source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 1 March 2025, in the Saut-d'Eau commune, Centre, armed members of the Viv Ansanm Gang invaded and attacked the Coupe Mardi Gras and Montagne Terrible communal sections (3rd and 4th communal sections of Saut-d'Eau, respectively). Several houses and stores were looted and burned, including a house and a store belonging to the President of the Communal Section Administrative Council (CASEC) (communal authority). A collaborator of the CASEC President was burned alive at the store. At least 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 27 January 2025, in Kenscoff - Belo, Ouest, around 75 gang members killed several residents and injured others as they shot and set fire to houses in the Belo neighborhood (Bongars communal section). At least six killed residents were identified. Gunshots were heard in Seguin and Obleon neighborhoods. This was part of a coordinated armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). A BINUH report clarifies that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. On 27 January, a total of 31 civilians (15 men and 15 women) were killed and 27 were injured (23 men and four women) as a result of gang attacks in Belo, Bois Majo, Bonga, Carrefour bete, and Furcy. 31 fatalities split across five events (6 coded here). Between 26 and 30 January, at least 127 civilians had been killed by gangs in Kenscoff and Petionville during the attacks of the Viv Ansanm Gang (up to 150 according to some sources though most of these fatalities remain unconfirmed). At least 127 fatalities split across 26 events. 6 fatalities coded here.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 27 January 2025, in Kenscoff - Bonga, Ouest, around 100 gang members attacked residents and set fire to houses in the Bonga neighborhood. A woman and her daughter were killed and burned at their home. Gunshots were heard in nearby Chauffard area. This was part of a coordinated armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). A BINUH report clarifies that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. On 27 January, a total of 31 civilians (15 men and 15 women) were killed and 27 were injured (23 men and four women) as a result of gang attacks in Belo, Bois Majo, Bonga, Carrefour bete, and Furcy. 31 fatalities split across five events (2 coded here). Between 26 and 30 January, at least 127 civilians had been killed by gangs in Kenscoff and Petionville during the attacks of the Viv Ansanm Gang (up to 150 according to some sources though most of these fatalities remain unconfirmed). At least 127 fatalities split across 26 events. 2 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi; Vi Free Press
notes: On 27 January 2025, in Kenscoff - Carrefour bete, Ouest, around 100 gang members burned alive a woman and her six children as they set fire to residents' properties to install themselves in the Carrefour bete neighborhood (Bongars communal section). At least 11 other residents (burned at their homes or killed while trying to flee) were identified. Farmers and their cattle heads were targeted by the criminals. At least 11 people were kidnapped and others went missing. Their whereabouts are unknown. Gunshots were heard in Seguin and Obleon neighborhoods. This was part of a coordinated armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). A BINUH report clarifies that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. On 27 January, a total of 31 civilians (15 men and 15 women) were killed and 27 were injured (23 men and four women) as a result of gang attacks in Belo, Bois Majo, Bonga, Carrefour bete, and Furcy 31 fatalities split across five events (18 coded here). Between 26 and 30 January, at least 127 civilians had been killed by gangs in Kenscoff and Petionville during the attacks of the Viv Ansanm Gang (up to 150 according to some sources though most of these fatalities remain unconfirmed). At least 127 fatalities split across 26 events. 18 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 27 January 2025, in Kenscoff - Furcy, Ouest, in the morning, around 100 gang members shot and killed several residents and injured others as they opened fire and set fire to houses in the Furcy neighborhood. Gunshots were heard in Seguin and Obleon neighborhoods. This was part of a coordinated armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). A BINUH report clarifies that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. On 27 January, a total of 31 civilians (15 men and 15 women) were killed and 27 were injured (23 men and four women) as a result of gang attacks in Belo, Bois Majo, Bonga, Carrefour bete, and Furcy. 31 fatalities split across five events (3 coded here). Between 26 and 30 January, at least 127 civilians had been killed by gangs in Kenscoff and Petionville during the attacks of the Viv Ansanm Gang (up to 150 according to some sources though most of these fatalities remain unconfirmed). At least 127 fatalities split across 26 events. 3 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Haiti Standard; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 3 February 2025, in Kenscoff - Godet, Ouest, members of the Grand-Ravine Gang raped a 16-year-old girl and killed her disabled mother as they set fire to houses and vehicles in Godet and other neighborhoods of the commune (coded separately). Security forces intervened and clashed with the criminals (coded separately). Between 27 January and 3 February, more than 100 civilians fled their homes to take refuge at the Kenscoff city hall after the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) launched a coordinated armed offensive against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). A BINUH report clarified that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the nearby Petionville commune. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 27 January 2025, in Kenscoff - Furcy, Ouest, police and military forces supported by Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission shot and killed several gang members in the Furcy neighborhood during clashes to expel the criminals from the commune, which was under gang attack since the morning (coded separately). This was part of an armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). A BINUH report clarifies that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. On 27 January, at least 23 gang members were killed and seven injured during clashes with security forces in Belo, Carrefour Bete, Furcy, and Godet (coded separately). Two firearms, tear gas grenades, and more than 200 cartridges were seized. More than 14 people were treated at the Fermathe hospital due to gunshots and white weapons wounds due to incidents in Kenscoff on 27 January. At least 23 gang fatalities were split across four events. 6 coded here.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Le Reflet; Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Trip Foumi
notes: On 27 January 2025, in Kenscoff - Godet, Ouest, police and military forces supported by Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission and a self-defense group from Fort-Jacques (Petionville) shot and killed several gang members in the Godet neighborhood during clashes to expel the criminals from the commune, which was under gang attack since the morning (coded separately). This was part of an armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). A BINUH report clarifies that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. On 27 January, at least 23 gang members were killed and seven injured during clashes with security forces in Belo, Carrefour bete, Furcy, and Godet (coded separately). Two firearms, tear gas grenades, and more than 200 cartridges were seized. During clashes, a Fort-Jacques self-defense group member was killed and a police officer was injured. More than 14 people were treated at the Fermathe hospital due to gunshots and white weapons wounds due to incidents in Kenscoff on 27 January. At least 23 gang fatalities split across four events. 7 coded here (6 gang fatalities and 1 self-defense group fatality).

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti

On 16 February 2025, in the Kenscoff commune, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents in the Sourcailles communal section (Kenscoff 3rd communal section), injuring several by gunshots. Some civilians fled their homes. On 16 February, at least 10 people were killed during gang attacks in the Kenscoff commune. 10 fatalities split across four events. 0 coded here. Several injured.

On 16 February 2025, in Kenscoff - Belo, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents in the Belo neighborhood, injuring several by gunshots. Some civilians fled their homes. On 16 February, at least 10 people were killed during gang attacks in the Kenscoff commune. 10 fatalities split across four events. 0 coded here. Several injured.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 16 February 2025, in Kenscoff - Godet, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang, the Ti Bwa Gang, and the Base 5 Secondes Gang killed a woman and her child at a house and set the bodies on fire. Three farmers were also killed as the criminals crossed Godet while retreating after police forces expelled them from nearby Obleon neighborhood (coded separately). On 16 February, at least 10 people were killed during gang attacks in the Kenscoff commune. 10 fatalities split across four events. 5 fatalities coded here.

actor2: Police Forces of Haiti (2024-) Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP)
source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 16 February 2025, in Kenscoff - Obleon, Ouest, in the early morning, the 400 Mawozo Gang, the Ti Bwa Gang, and the Base 5 Secondes Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang) attacked security forces' strategic positions at the former Teleco company headquarters (a.k.a. Teleco base, where Teleco antenna is located, in Morne Tranchant area), killing two BSAP police agents and a military officer, and injuring two other military soldiers. Security forces had been deployed there on 29 January (coded separately). At least a woman and the son of a blind man were killed as the gang members set fire to houses. Other civilians were injured. In response, the Multinational Security Support Mission together with security forces engaged in armed clashes with the criminals and managed to expel them from the area, although they took control of the nearby Wynne Farm Ecological Reserve. On 16 February, there were at least 18 gang fatalities during clashes in Obleon and Furcy (coded separately), while at least 10 people were killed during gang attacks in the Kenscoff commune. 18 gang fatalities split across two events (9 coded here), and 10 fatalities split across four events (5 coded here). 14 fatalities coded here, at least 1 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 11 November 2024, in Petion Ville - Vivy Mitchell, Ouest, the Kraze Barye Gang attacked residents, looted their houses, and set fire to the properties in the Vivy Mitchell neighborhood. At least one civilian was shot and injured. He was identified as the brother of a known journalist. Police forces intervened and expelled the criminals (coded separately). This was likely in support of the Viv Ansanm Gang, who had threatened with armed offensives after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). In November 2024, attacks by the Kraze Barye Gang caused 21 civilian victims among fatalities and wounded in Vivy Mitchell, Cargo, and Pernier neighborhoods (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 12 November 2024, in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, the Kraze Barye Gang (in support of the Viv Ansanm Gang) attacked the Pernier neighborhood. Gunshots were heard in Pernier and Belvil neighborhoods. This Viv Ansanm Gang had launched armed offensives after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). The UN reported several fatalities in attacks perpetrated by gangs that happened between 11 and 15 November in Port-au-Prince and at least 150 fatalities in all violent events that happened during said week. In November 2024, attacks by the Kraze Barye Gang caused 21 civilian victims among fatalities and wounded in Vivy Mitchell, Cargo, and Pernier neighborhoods (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; L'Oeil Mondial Info; Metropole; SG Alert (Whatsapp)

The UN reported several fatalities in attacks perpetrated by gangs that happened between 11 and 15 November in Port-au-Prince and at least 150 fatalities in all violent events that happened during said week. notes: Around 16 November 2024 (between 15 - 17 November), in Petion Ville - Vivy Mitchell, Ouest, the Kraze Barye Gang (in support of the Viv Ansanm Gang) attacked residents on the Freres Road, at the height of Vivy Mitchell. notes: On 13 February 2025, in Kenscoff - Bonga, Ouest, gang members set fire to residents' properties as they attacked the neighborhood. The victims were 10 men, three women, and a baby. At least 14 fatalities split across six locations. 2 coded here.

notes: On 13 February 2025, in Kenscoff - Carrefour bete, Ouest, gang members attacked the Carrefour bete neighborhood and kidnapped five people. There were at least two women among the abducted. Between 5 and 15 February, at least 14 civilians were killed during gang attacks against the Carrefour bete, Bonga, Belo, Godet, Furcy, and Viard neighborhoods (coded separately). The victims were 10 men, three women, and a baby. At least 14 fatalities split across six locations. 2 coded here.

notes: On 9 February 2025, in Petion Ville - Metivier, Ouest, police forces and self-defense group affiliates killed several members of the Kraze Barye Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang) near Petion Ville - Metivier. notes: Around 2 March 2025 (weekend of), near Kenscoff - Fond Ferier, Ouest, gang members based in Carrefour Badio (close to Fond Ferier) shot and killed around 60 residents and farmers. An unknown number of others were kidnapped. Their whereabouts are unknown. The attack was related to an armed offensive orchestrated by the Viv Ansanm Gang and carried out by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Ti Bwa Gang, and the Grand-Ravine Gang. It started by the end of January and aimed at seizing control of areas in Kenscoff commune (coded separately). At least 60 fatalities.

A report clarified that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune.
