At least 127 fatalities split across 26 events (at least 9 fatalities in Kenscoff on 29 January split across four events). 2 fatalities coded here.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 29 January 2025, in Kenscoff - Carrefour bete, Ouest, for a third consecutive day, gang members attacked residents in the Carrefour bete neighborhood. An elderly woman and a man were killed. The man's body was eaten by dogs. At least nine people were killed in the Kenscoff commune on that day. This was part of a coordinated armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). A report clarified that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. Between 26 and 30 January, at least 127 civilians had been killed by gangs in Kenscoff and Petionville during the attacks of the Viv Ansanm Gang (up to 150 according to some sources though most of these fatalities remain unconfirmed). At least 127 fatalities split across 26 events (at least 9 fatalities in Kenscoff on 29 January split across four events). 2 fatalities coded here.

source: Haiti Progres; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 30 January 2025, in Kenscoff commune, Ouest, gang members attacked residents in the commune. This was part of an armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). A report clarified that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. Between 26 and 30 January, at least 127 civilians had been killed by gangs in Kenscoff and Petionville during the attacks of the Viv Ansanm Gang (up to 150 according to some sources though most of these fatalities remain unconfirmed). At least 127 fatalities split across 26 events. 0 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 19 November 2024 (as reported), in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, the Kraze Barye Gang (in support of the Viv Ansanm Gang) attacked residents in Pernier 12 A, Pernier 10, Deye Lise, Do Rigol, Impasse Laurette, and Impasse Hauteur. Houses were destroyed, looted, and set on fire. Residents fled their homes. In November 2024, attacks by the Kraze Barye Gang caused 21 civilian victims among fatalities and wounded in Vivy Mitchell, Cargo, and Pernier neighborhoods (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 7 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Saint-Roc, Ouest, police forces and the Multinational Security Support Mission clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang. Clashes erupted as the gang members carried out an offensive aiming at installing the leader of the Didi Gang in the Makako area (Petionville) (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 8 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Saint-Roc, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Saint-Roc area. This was likely part of armed clashes between police forces and the Multinational Security Support Mission against the Viv Ansanm Gang. Armed clashes between the mentioned actors were registered in the area since 7 January (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 21 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Saint-Roc, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members in the area. According to witnessing residents, gunshots were also heard as police forces in an armored vehicle crossed the area towards the Carrefour commune. Casualties unknown.
On 24 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Saint-Roc, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members as they tried to move from Carrefour to the above-mentioned neighborhood. Casualties unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 27 January 2025, near Kenscoff - Godet, Ouest, gang members set fire to a dozen civilian properties in the Kikwa area (a.k.a. Qui-Croit), including houses belonging to the Bongard's CASEC (Council of Administration of the Communal Section) and his relatives. This was part of a coordinated armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). A BINUH report clarifies that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. Between 26 and 30 January, at least 127 civilians had been killed by gangs in Kenscoff and Petionville during the attacks of the Viv Ansanm Gang (up to 150 according to some sources though most of these fatalities remain unconfirmed). At least 127 fatalities split across 26 events. 0 fatalities coded for this event.

source: Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Haiti Standard; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: Property destruction: On 16 March 2025, near Kenscoff - Ti Boucan, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang threw Molotov cocktails and set fire to a police armored vehicle stuck at the Depanse area (close to Ti Boucan). The police vehicle was stuck in a hole suspectedly dug up in the floor by the criminals to prevent security forces from accessing the area where they had installed. The officers who drove the vehicle to that location had the time to flee the scene before the criminals targeted it.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Trip Foumi; Vi Free Press
notes: On 24 March 2025, in Kenscoff - Ti Boucan, Ouest, in the early morning, the Base 5 Secondes Gang, Ti Bwa Gang, and Grand-Ravine Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) opened fire on residents and set fire to their homes in Ti Boucan and nearby Depanse locality, killing several civilians. A 12-year-old child was abducted. His whereabouts are unknown. Between 24 and 27 March, attacks by the mentioned gangs resulted in at least 28 civilians killed across the Kenscoff commune. 28 fatalities split across three events. 10 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Trip Foumi
notes: On 9 April 2025, around Delmas - Delmas 17, Ouest, in the morning, members of the Base Nan Tokyo Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang) shot and injured two police inspectors as they opened fire on their car on the Airport Road (Boulevard Toussaint Louverture) at the height of DHL headquarters. They died in hospital later that day. The shooting took place as the officers intervened to thwart a kidnapping attempt against a person who managed to escape by driving away in a car. The police officers' car was stolen. 2 fatalities.

On 8 April 2025, in Fort-Liberte, Nord-Est, 115 former workers at the Industrial Development Company (CODEVI) accompanied by their lawyer held a protest in front of the prosecutor's office to decry their firing and abusive practices by the company. They described the firings as arbitrary and possibly based on the request for a salary increase. They also demanded compensation.

Property destruction: On 6 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Turgeau, Ouest, overnight, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang looted and set fire to the Fonkoze Cooperative premises (Turgeau). Due to its proximity to the Sacre-Coeur presbytery, the police evacuated the priests of the parish, although the premises did not suffer any damage. The criminals also set fire to houses along the Avenue Christophe, Avenue N, and Rue 0 (Turgeau).
Property destruction: On 7 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Deprez, Ouest, gang members set fire to civilian infrastructure in the neighborhood. No further details were mentioned.

On 7 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Pacot, Ouest, members of a self-defense group engaged in armed clashes with gang members and managed to expel them from the Kanno area (Haut Pacot) where the criminals were trying to establish a base. Fires were also set in the neighborhood. Casualties unknown.

Property destruction: On 8 April 2025, in Saut-d'Eau, Centre, overnight, gang members looted and set fire to the house of a former senator and the public prosecutor's office at the First Instance Court building. The stolen materials were taken to the Canaan Gang base. The criminals were likely members of that gang.

source: Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Metropole; Trip Foumi
notes: Property destruction: On 6 April 2025, in Kenscoff - Belo, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, the Viv Ansanm Gang set fire to several houses and to the 'Le Montchel Ranch' hotel as they attacked the neighborhood. The hotel facilities were destroyed.

On 11 April 2025, between Tabarre - Carrefour Fleuriot and Tabarre - Clercine II/Carrefour Clercine, Ouest, hundreds of people held a march with banners from Carrefour Fleuriot neighborhood to the Tabarre police station (in Clercine II/Carrefour Clercine neighborhood) to decry ongoing insecurity and gang violence. Protesters demanded the restoration of safety in the commune.

On 9 April 2025, in Leogane, Ouest, the police killed several gang members and seized five weapons as well as ammunition during a security operation in the commune. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 7 April 2025, in the Saint-Louis du Sud commune, Sud, scores of residents from the Morne Zoranje locality held a protest along the National Road 2 to decry the dumping of gang members' dead corpses on the streets of the locality by police forces. Protesters set up a barricade with tree trunks, branches, and stones, blocking road traffic. They claimed that at least 14 bodies were found on the streets of the locality in recent weeks.
On 6 April 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, police forces clashed with members of four gangs during anti-gang operations in the commune. The criminals were expelled. Casualties unknown.
Other: On 30 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Debrosse. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 31 March 2025, in Petion Ville - Thomassin, Ouest, armed members of the population fired shots as they tried to catch a gang member in Vallee Heureuse (Laboule 12). The health state of the chased gangster was not clarified.

Other: On 31 March 2025, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, tires were burned on the National Road 1 near Carrefour Vincent (Sarthe neighborhood). There is no information on the circumstances, the motives, and those involved in the burning of tires.

On 31 March 2025, in Kenscoff - Fermathe, Ouest, overnight, gang members fired shots as they attacked the Fermathe 52 area. Self-defense groups deployed in the zone, although no direct interaction with the criminals was mentioned. Casualties unknown.

Non-violent activity: On 30 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members set up barricades on Rue de la Montagne street (Pacot neighborhood) that had previously been removed by a self-defense brigade.

Other: On 2 April 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, a roadblock was set up on the Kenscoff road at the height of Platon Cafe (Drouette neighborhood). There is no information on the motives for the roadblock or who set it up.

Other: On 2 April 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard by residents in the Diegue and Meyotte neighborhoods. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 3 April 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard on the Airport Road at the height of the Pele Simon neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 3 April 2025, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, a roadblock was set up on the National Road 1 in Sarthe. There is no information on the motives of the roadblock or who set it up.

On 3 April 2025, in Tabarre - Croix des Missions, Ouest, the police engaged in armed clashes with armed individuals. Clashes were also registered in nearby Shada and Lathan areas in Croix des Bouquets (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 3 April 2025, in Marin, Ouest, the police engaged in armed clashes with armed individuals in the Shada and Lathan areas. Clashes were also registered in nearby Croix des Missions neighborhood in Tabarre (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
Other: On 3 April 2025, in Bon Repos, Ouest, barricades were set up on several road axes. There is no information on the motives of the barricades or who set them up.

Property destruction: On 3 April 2025, in Tabarre - Clercine, Ouest, armed individuals set fire to houses in the Kanal area. Gunshots were also heard near the U.S. Embassy (Chateau Blond neighborhood).
Other: On 3 April 2025, in Santo, Ouest, barricades were set up in Santo 3 and Santo 25. There is no information on the motives of the barricades or who set them up.

Other: On 4 April 2025, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, roadblocks were set up in Carrefour Vincent (Sarthe neighborhood) and in Damiens neighborhoods. This was likely part of calls for a strike on that day, although there is no information on the motives for the barricades and who set them up.

Other: On 4 April 2025, in Santo, Ouest, barricades were set up between Santo 3 and Santo 23. This was likely part of calls for a strike on that day, although there is no information on the motives for the barricades and who set them up.
Other: On 4 April 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Clercine and Carrefour Fleuriot neighborhoods. This was likely the authorship of armed individuals seen in nearby Clercine 24.

On 4 April 2025, in Leogane, Ouest, thousands of people held a march with banners to decry rising gang violence. Protesters claimed to be ready to fight gangs. The mobilization was guarded by the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) police.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 18 January 2025, in Kenscoff - Bonga, Ouest, gang members raped a woman in Bonga. The sexual assault took place as the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) prepared a coordinated armed offensive against the Kenscoff commune. It was launched on 27 January (coded separately).

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 25 January 2025, in Kenscoff - Bonga, Ouest, gang members raped a 14-year-old girl when she was leaving the neighborhood due to gang presence in the area. The sexual assault took place as the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) prepared a coordinated armed offensive against the Kenscoff commune. It was launched on 27 January (coded separately).

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 27 January 2025, near Kenscoff - Furcy, Ouest, in the morning, around 100 gang members shot and killed several residents and injured others as they opened fire and set fire to houses in the Bois Majo area (close to Furcy). This was part of a coordinated armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). A BINUH report clarifies that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. On 27 January, a total of 31 civilians (15 men and 15 women) were killed and 27 were injured (23 men and four women) as a result of gang attacks in Belo, Bois Majo, Bonga, Carrefour bete, and Furcy. 31 fatalities split across five events (2 coded here). Between 26 and 30 January, at least 127 civilians had been killed by gangs in Kenscoff and Petionville during the attacks of the Viv Ansanm Gang (up to 150 according to some sources though most of these fatalities remain unconfirmed). At least 127 fatalities split across 26 events. 2 fatalities coded here.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti

Security forces managed to expel the criminals. This was part of a coordinated armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). A BINUH report clarified that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. Casualties unknown.

This was part of a coordinated armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). A BINUH report clarifies that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. The sexual assault took place amidst a coordinated armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately).

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Non-violent activity: On 25 January 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, members of five self-defense groups from Kenscoff started patrolling specific areas of the commune after threats of imminent gang attacks were confirmed by local authorities, who established a night curfew (coded separately).

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 27 January 2025, in Kenscoff - Belo, Ouest, police and military forces supported by Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission shot and killed several gang members in the Belo neighborhood during clashes to expel the criminals from the commune, which was under gang attack since the morning (coded separately). This was part of an armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). A BINUH report clarifies that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. On 27 January, at least 23 gang members were killed and seven injured during clashes with security forces in Belot, Carrefour bete, Furcy, and Godet (coded separately). Two firearms, tear gas grenades, and more than 200 cartridges were seized. More than 14 people were treated at the Fermathe hospital due to gunshots and white weapons wounds due to incidents in Kenscoff on 27 January. At least 23 gang fatalities split across four events. 6 coded here.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 2 February 2025, near Carrefour - Chaufa, Ouest, members of the Ti Bwa Gang killed three residents in the Kay Bab neighborhood of nearby Procy locality (Carrefour commune). The criminals set fire to the bodies. 3 fatalities.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 16 February 2025, in Petion Ville - Thomassin, Ouest, police and military forces supported by the Multinational Security Support Mission and self-defense group members clashed with gang members in Thomassin, killing at least eighteen gangs. The criminals were members of the 400 Mawozo Gang, the Ti Bwa Gang, and the Base 5 Secondes Gang who were fleeing the Kenscoff commune after attacking security forces positions in Obleon (coded separately). At least 18 fatalities.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 17 February 2025, near Kenscoff - Godet, Ouest, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members (likely from the Base 5 Secondes Gang, with whom they also clashed in other neighborhoods on that day) in Viard. Clashes were also registered in Godet, Belo, Furcy, and Bois d'Avril (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 17 February 2025, in Kenscoff - Belo, Ouest, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members (likely from the Base 5 Secondes Gang, with whom they also clashed in other neighborhoods on that day). notes: On 17 February 2025, in Kenscoff - Furcy, Ouest, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members (likely from the Base 5 Secondes Gang, with whom they also clashed in other neighborhoods on that day). Clashes were also registered in Godet, Viard, Belo, and Bois d'Avril (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Property destruction: On 26 February 2025, in Kenscoff - Godet, Ouest, gang members looted and set fire to 30 houses as they invaded Godet, Bois d'Avril, Belo, and Ti Boucan (coded separately).

At least 30 fatalities, 13 injured.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 10 February 2025 (between 7 - 13 February), in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, police forces and self-defense group members killed at least 54 members of the Kraze Barye Gang during clashes in Pernier, Meyotte and Metivier (coded separately). At least 54 fatalities split across three events. 18 coded here.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti

Their whereabouts are unknown.

Other: On 2 January 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the leader of the Viv Ansanm Gang announced that the gang-led coalition became a political party. He described the party as a political movement representing the interests of marginalized communities in Haiti.

source: Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Standard; Jamaica Gleaner; Jamaica Observer; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 31 March 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, in the early morning, several dozen gang members attacked Mirebalais and Trianon (coded separately). Only in Mirebalais, at least 13 killed civilians were identified, including two nuns from the Little Sisters of Saint Therese congregation (Catholic group). They were taking refuge at the Mirebalais National School when the gang members killed them, among others, and injured a girl who was with them. The criminals opened fire on houses, schools, and churches, and set fire to vehicles along the National Road 3. They burned a gas station, the communal market, a part of the Mirebalais police station, and assaulted the Civil Prison. Security forces had abandoned the facilities moments before. The gang members released more than 500 inmates (including the wife of the Pierre VI Gang leader) and killed a prisoner. The facilities were later recovered by security forces after clashes with the gang members (coded separately). Residents claimed that the offensive was a reprisal orchestrated by the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition for the resistance of the Trianon self-defense group to gang presence in the area. The gangsters were identified as affiliates of the Taliban Gang (from Canaan) and the 400 Mawozo Gang. They wore t-shirts with the names of these groups. Between 31 March and 3 April, at least 30 people were killed and more than 6,000 were displaced as a result of gang attacks in Mirebalais and Saut-d'Eau communes (30 fatalities split across seven events). Between 31 March and 8 April, 19 civilians were killed in Mirebalais village (19 fatalities split across four events). 14 coded here.

source: Gazette Haiti; Jamaica Gleaner; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 31 March 2025, in Trianon, Centre, in the early morning, several dozen gang members attacked residents in Trianon and Mirebalais (coded separately), killing and injuring several people. The gang members opened fire on residents' houses, schools, and churches (Catholic churches), and set fire to vehicles along the National Road 3. Security forces intervened and expelled the criminals (coded separately). Residents claimed that the attack was a reprisal orchestrated by the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition for the resistance of a Trianon self-defense group to gang presence in the area. The gang members were identified as affiliates of the Canaan Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang. They wore t-shirts with the names of these groups. Between 31 March and 3 April, at least 30 people were killed and more than 6,000 were displaced as a result of gang attacks in Mirebalais and Saut-d'Eau communes. At least 30 fatalities split across seven events, 3 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Gleaner; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 31 March 2025, in the Saut-d'Eau commune, Centre, in the early morning, gang members attacked residents in the La Selle communal section (Saut-d'Eau 2nd communal section) as part of an offensive orchestrated by the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition aimed at taking control of the National Road 3 in Mirebalais commune. The criminals were identified as affiliates of the Canaan Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang. Similar attacks were registered hours later in nearby Mirebalais and Trianon (coded separately). Between 31 March and 3 April, at least 30 people were killed and more than 6,000 were displaced as a result of gang attacks in Mirebalais and Saut-d'Eau communes. At least 30 fatalities split across seven events, 3 fatalities coded here.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 2 April 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, for a third consecutive day, police forces clashed with gang members who attacked the commune since 31 March (coded separately). The criminals were identified as affiliates of the Canaan Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang. Residents claimed that this was part of reprisals orchestrated by the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition for the resistance of the Trianon self-defense group to gang presence in the area (coded separately). Between 31 March and 2 April, at least 60 gang members were killed in the downtown of Mirebalais. 60 fatalities split across three events. 20 coded here.

source: Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 2 April 2025, in Saut-d'Eau, Centre, gang members attacked residents and set fire to stores and houses in the commune, including the private residence of a Saut-d'Eau former deputy. The Transparence FM radio station was also burned. This was part of an offensive launched by the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition to take control of Mirebalais. Between 31 March and 3 April, at least 30 people were killed and more than 6,000 were displaced as a result of gang attacks in Mirebalais and Saut-d'Eau communes. At least 30 fatalities split across seven events, 3 fatalities coded here.

source: Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 3 April 2025, in Saut-d'Eau, Centre, for a second consecutive day, more than 500 gang members attacked residents and took control of the commune. Several vehicles and around 20 houses were set on fire, including a private property belonging to a former senator. At least one person was killed. The gang members were described as affiliates of the Canaan Gang supporting an offensive launched by the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition to take control of Mirebalais. Between 31 March and 3 April, at least 30 people were killed and more than 6,000 were displaced as a result of gang attacks in Mirebalais and Saut-d'Eau communes. At least 30 fatalities split across seven events, 3 fatalities coded here.

source: Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 6 April 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, gang members set fire to houses, chased residents, and occupied several hotels as they attacked the downtown of Mirebalais. The criminals were identified as members of the Canaan Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang. According to the mayor, there are people who have been killed and injured. This was part of an offensive orchestrated by the Viv Ansanm Gang aimed at taking control of Mirebalais. Between 31 March and 8 April, 19 civilians were killed in Mirebalais village. 19 fatalities split across four events. 2 coded here.

source: Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 7 April 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, for a second consecutive day, gang members fired shots and set fires in the downtown of Mirebalais. The criminals were identified as members of the Canaan Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang. According to the mayor, there are people who have been killed and injured. This was part of an offensive orchestrated by the Viv Ansanm Gang aimed at taking control of Mirebalais. Between 31 March and 8 April, 19 civilians were killed in Mirebalais village. 19 fatalities split across four events. 1 coded here.

Other: On 10 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, residents set up a roadblock in the Canape-Vert neighborhood, cutting off circulation with Petionville. Another roadblock was set up in Bois Patate. There is no information on the motives for the roadblocks.

On 13 April 2025, in Petion Ville - Caille Boucan, Ouest, overnight, gang members fired shots and burned residents' houses as they attacked the Caille Boucan neighborhood, among others in the Petionville and Kenscoff communes (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 14 April 2025, in Petion Ville - Caille Boucan, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, gang members fired shots and burned residents' houses as they attacked the Caille Boucan neighborhood, among others in the Petionville and Kenscoff communes (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 15 January 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, hundreds of residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Public and private institutions kept their doors closed during the mobilization. Protesters claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). They were described as supporters of the Citizens' Movement Committed To Another Haiti.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Vi Free Press
notes: On 16 January 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, for the second consecutive day, hundreds of residents, politicians, and activists who claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti) held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Protesters were described as supporters of the Citizens' Movement Committed To Another Haiti.

On 17 January 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, for the third consecutive day, residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Protesters claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). They were described as supporters of the Citizens' Movement Committed To Another Haiti.
Other: On 12 January 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, a truck was used to block a road in Cance and in front of the airport. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

Around 21 January 2024 (weekend of), in Les Cayes, Sud, residents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 22 January 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, several hundreds of residents, mostly young people, held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They set up roadblocks of burning tires, tree trunks, and branches in Torbeck, Coteaux, and Camp Perrin neighbourhoods. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 23 January 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, for the second consecutive day, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They set up roadblocks of burning tires and pieces of vehicles. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 29 January 2024, in Les Cayes, Nippes, supporters of the Platfom Pitit Desalin party held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. They blocked some roads. The protest was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by organizations from the political opposition (coded separately).

source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 29 January 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, residents held a demonstration on the National Road 7 demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry, and against the Sunrie Airways S.A. company. Police forces intervened using tear gas and firing automatic weapons to disperse the crowd near the Antoine Simon des Cayes Airport, although no casualties among demonstrators were mentioned. Also, burning tires were erected in Quatre Chemis crossroad to block the road. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by organizations from the political opposition (coded separately).

On 18 January 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, burning tires were erected in 4 Chemins crossroad, Deux Mapoux crossroad, and General Marion road. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the barricades or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).
Other: On 24 January 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, the Route National #7 was blocked in Vernet. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.
Other: On 30 January 2024, in Vaudreuil, Nord, the Route Nationale #1 was blocked. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

On 6 February 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, for the third consecutive day, government opponents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. At the height of Croix des Martyrs area, police forces fired tear gas and real bullets to disperse them. At least two protesters were shot and injured. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). At least 2 injured.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vant Bef Info
notes: On 8 February 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, for the fifth consecutive day, government opponents held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Protesters, who were described as 'unarmed', set up a huge barricade on National Road 7 (nature unspecified). Police forces, supported by a group of pro-government armed individuals, intervened to remove the roadblock. During the intervention, a man who was at a house (not taking part in the mobilization) was shot and killed. Other roadblocks were recorded in Vernet, Charpentier, and Bergeaud neighborhoods. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 1 fatality.

On 22 January 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, people protested in Quatre Chemins. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the protest, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, for the fourth consecutive day, residents, members of the Committed to Development Party (EDE), and partisans of the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party (PPD) held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. The crowd was integrated by masked individuals armed with machetes and riding motorcycles. Rioters tried to loot a warehouse, although police forces intervened with tear gas and prevented it. One demonstrator was stabbed and injured (perpetrator unknown). Also, roadblocks were set roadblocks were set on the Route Nationale #2 in Bergeau, Charpentier, and on the Route Nationale #7 up to the Saint Simon Airport near Vernet. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 1 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole
notes: On 5 February 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, for the second consecutive day, thousands of government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. On the National Road 7, rioters set up barricades of burning tires and threw stones against police forces, who responded firing real bullets and tear gas. A demonstrator was shot and killed, while at least three others were injured. Demonstrators marched through the streets with the corpse of the deceased demonstrator. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by the Committed to Development Party (EDE), the Platfom Pitit Desalin party (PPD) party, and Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). 1 fatality, at least 3 injured.

On 4 February 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. They set up barricades of burning tires on several roads. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 1 February 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, people protested on the Route Nationale #7. Although there is no information on the motives for the protest, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 18 February 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, citizens held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. The protest was called by the Mobilization Table, a political structure integrated by the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party (PPD) and the Committed to Development Party (EDE), among other political parties.

On 7 February 2024, in Fogas, Sud, people held a demonstration and roadblocks were set on the Route Nationale #2. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti)

On 8 February 2024, in Fogas, Sud, people held a demonstration and roadblocks were set on the Route Nationale #2. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti)

On 29 February 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, residents held a demonstration against Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires on Marion street. The mobilization occurred after it was known that the PM plans to stay in power until 2026.

On 4 March 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, citizens held an anti-government demonstration, asking for the resignation of Prime Minister Ariel Henry, and set up roadblocks on the Route Nationale #7 near the Antoine Simon Airport. Demonstrators occupied the airport runway and set fire to a plane.

On 7 March 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, citizens held an anti-government protest, demanding the resignation of Prime Minister Ariel Henry, and set up roadblocks on the Route Nationale #7 near the Antoine Simon Airport.

On 11 March 2024, in Barriere Bouteille, Nord, people demonstrated in the area. The demonstrators threw stones and bottles, although no target was specified. There is no information on the motives of the demonstration.

On 1 July 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, in the morning, political militants and supporters of a journalist man who was killed in 2022 (coded separately) held a sit-in protest in front of Les Cayes Court building demanding the arrest of a suspended government commissioner whom they accused of being linked to the journalist's killing. Protesters blocked access to the government commissioner's office.

On 11 August 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, overnight, a group of police officers beat up and tortured to death a man at his home. The victim was a former police officer assigned to the intelligence service of former government commissioner Ronald Richemond. According to the victim's wife, who witnessed the attack and was also beaten, the current government commissioner at Les Cayes Court of First Instance (TPI) was present and did nothing to stop the beating. While torturing the victim, the police asked him to tell them where the weapons he supposedly had hidden were. The police entered the house with the authorization of the Justice of the Peace of Cayes. 1 fatality, 1 injured.

source: PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 24 September 2024, in Barriere Bouteille, Nord, the police clashed with gang members. Another clash also happened in Milot (coded separately). Four gang members were killed during both clashes, including one gang leader in Barriere Bouteille. 4 fatalities split across two events, 2 fatalities coded here.

source: PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 24 September 2024, in Milot, Nord, the police clashed with gang members. Another clash also happened in Barriere Bouteille (coded separately). Four gang members were killed during both clashes, including one gang leader in Barriere Bouteille. 4 fatalities split across two events, 2 fatalities coded here.

source: Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 23 October 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, police forces clashed with two gang members, killing one and injuring the other, who managed to flee the scene. The criminals were about to ransom a citizen when the police intercepted them and the gangsters opened fire on them, leading to an armed clash. One officer was shot and wounded. A firearm was seized. 1 fatality, 2 injured.

On 22 November 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, unidentified individuals attacked a family near the La Cretonne hotel, killing the wife. The wounded husband was taken to the hospital. There is no information on the circumstances of the attack. 1 fatality. 1 injured.

On 6 January 2025, in Les Cayes, Sud, several scores of teachers held a protest at the Philippe Guerrier high school demanding higher wages, among other claims. The mobilization was part of a teachers' strike.

On 15 January 2025, in Les Cayes, Sud, students from public high schools held a march towards the South departmental office of the Ministry of National Education and Vocational Training (MENFP), on Bergeaud neighborhood, demanding the return of teachers to classrooms after they went on a strike. Police forces intervened and fired tear gas against the demonstrating students to disperse them. Some of them responded by throwing stones against the officers.
Other: On 21 January 2025, in Les Cayes, Sud, barricades of burning tires were erected throughout the city. There is no information on the motives for the barricades or who set them up.

On 26 March 2025, in Les Cayes, Sud, several dozens of students demonstrated to demand that professors return to classrooms as they have not since a national strike was launched in January. Demonstrating students threw stones against a school to disrupt their activities and forced the closing of other public schools on their path.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 27 January 2025, in the commune of Carrefour, Ouest, several gang members raped a woman in Pannye (near the border with the Kenscoff commune).

On 11 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Avenue Christophe, Ouest, armed individuals attacked residents in Avenue Christophe, Bois Verna, and Morne a Tuf neighborhoods (coded separately). This was likely the authorship of gang members as part of a gang offensive that targeted multiple areas in Port-au-Prince on that day (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 11 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bois Verna, Ouest, armed individuals attacked residents in Bois Verna, Morne a Tuf, and Avenue Christophe neighborhoods (coded separately). This was likely the authorship of gang members as part of a gang offensive that targeted multiple areas in Port-au-Prince on that day (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 11 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, armed individuals attacked residents in Morne a Tuf, Avenue Christophe, and Bois Verna neighborhoods (coded separately). This was likely the authorship of gang members as part of a gang offensive that targeted multiple areas in Port-au-Prince on that day (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 30 March 2025, in Trianon, Centre, overnight, gang members killed four people in the Bastille zone of Trianon. The criminals were identified as affiliates of the Canaan Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang. The attack was part of reprisals orchestrated by the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition for the resistance of a Trianon self-defense group to gang presence in the area. 4 fatalities.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Non-violent activity: Around 4 April 2025 (between 31 March - 8 April), in Mirebalais, Centre, the Viv Ansanm Gang set up barricades and roadblocks across the village after having taken control of the Mirebalais commune (coded separately).

On 5 April 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, police forces clashed with gang members, killing several of them. The gangsters still managed to set up barricades to stop the police from getting in with armored cars, used residents' homes to hide for surprise attacks against the police, and also looted and set fire to houses. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.
Other: On 6 April 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Cazeau and Croix des Missions neighborhoods. There is no information on the circumstances and the authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 7 April 2025, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Carrefour Vincent (Sarthe neighborhood). There is no information on the circumstances and the authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 7 April 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 32. There is no information on the circumstances and the authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 7 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Christ-Roi neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.
Looting: On 8 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Pacot, Ouest, Viv Ansanm gang members looted the Saint Francois D'Assise College (Catholic group), located on Rue 6 (Pacot neighborhood).

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Property destruction: On 9 April 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, gang members set fire to the La Fourchette d'Or restaurant, located on the Europe Avenue, along the 9th Road. This was part of an offensive launched by the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition on 31 March (coded separately) to take control of Mirebalais.

Other: On 9 April 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Carrefour Fleuriot and near the Motorized Intervention Brigade (BMI) (Clercine II neighborhood). There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 10 April 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard on Roumain Street, near the 15 Octobre Boulevard. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Property destruction: On 11 April 2025, in Saut-d'Eau, Centre, members of the 400 Mawozo Gang and the Taliban Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition) used sledgehammers to destroy and demolish the communal police station. Residents were forced to take part in the destruction.

On 11 April 2025, in Marassa, Ouest, armed clashes were registered in Carrefour Marassa and the bridge to Tabarre. There is no information on the circumstances of the clashes and the actors involved. Casualties unknown.
Other: On 11 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a roadblock was set up in the Canape-Vert neighborhood. There is no information on the motives for the roadblock or who set it up.

On 13 April 2025, in Kenscoff - Fermathe, Ouest, overnight, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents in Fermathe. Several houses and vehicles were set on fire. Civilians fled their homes. Casualties unknown.

On 13 April 2025, in Kenscoff - Godet, Ouest, overnight, gang members fired shots and burned residents' houses as they attacked the Godet neighborhood, among others in the Kenscoff and Petionville communes (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 13 April 2025, in Petion Ville - Thomassin, Ouest, overnight, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents in Thomassin 48 and 52. Several houses and vehicles, including one belonging to the Petionville police station, were set on fire. Civilians fled their homes. Casualties unknown.

Around 14 April 2025 (as reported), in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, armed group members looted and set fire to thousands of residents' houses and business establishments as they attacked and took control of the neighborhood. The scene was recorded on video. Similar incidents were registered in the Nazon and Solino neighborhoods (coded separately). Residents were forced to flee the area. Casualties unknown.

On 14 April 2025, in Kenscoff - Godet, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, gang members fired shots and burned residents' houses as they attacked the Godet neighborhood, among others in the Kenscoff and Petionville communes (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 14 April 2025, in Petion Ville - Nan Madeleine, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, gang members fired shots and burned residents' houses as they attacked the Nan Madeleine neighborhood, among others in the Petionville and Kenscoff communes (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

Other: On 14 April 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, in the morning, gunshots were heard in the Thomassin neighborhood. This was likely the authorship of the Viv Ansanm Gang who attacked residents in the neighborhood the night prior (coded separately).

On 14 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, in the morning, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out drone airstrikes against gangs' positions on Capois Street and the N Avenue. Residents claimed to have heard gunshots of unclarified authorship after the explosions. Drone airstrikes were also launched near the Grand Ravine and Cite de Dieu neighborhoods (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 14 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Cite de Dieu, Ouest, in the morning, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out drone airstrikes against gangs' positions near Village de Dieu (Cite de Dieu neighborhood). Residents claimed to have heard gunshots of unclarified authorship after the explosions. Drone airstrikes were also launched near the Grand Ravine neighborhood, on Capois Street, N Avenue, and near the Sylvio Cator Stadium (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 14 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Grand Ravine, Ouest, in the morning, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out drone airstrikes against gangs' positions near the Grand Ravine neighborhood. Residents claimed to have heard gunshots of unclarified authorship after the explosions. Drone airstrikes were also launched near the Cite de Dieu neighborhood, on Capois Street, N Avenue, and near the Sylvio Cator Stadium (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 14 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, in the morning, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out drone airstrikes against gangs' positions near the Sylvio Cator Stadium (in Morne a Tuf neighborhood). Residents claimed to have heard gunshots of unclarified authorship after the explosions. Drone airstrikes were also launched near the Grand Ravine and Cite de Dieu neighborhoods, on Capois Street, and the N Avenue (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

Around 14 April 2025 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, armed group members looted and set fire to thousands of residents' houses and business establishments as they attacked and took control of the neighborhood. The scene was recorded on video. Similar incidents were registered in the Delmas 30 and Solino neighborhoods (coded separately). Residents were forced to flee the area. Casualties unknown.

Around 14 April 2025 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, armed group members looted and set fire to thousands of residents' houses and business establishments as they attacked and took control of the neighborhood. The scene was recorded on video. Similar incidents were registered in the Delmas 30 and Nazon neighborhoods (coded separately). Residents were forced to flee the area. Casualties unknown.

On 16 April 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 32, Ouest, citizens held a demonstration to demand that the authorities take measures to stop the widespread gang violence. Demonstrators set up burning barricades and they threw stones at cars that tried to pass through. Mobilizations on the same claims were held in other neighborhoods across the capital (coded separately).

On 16 April 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 75, Ouest, citizens held a demonstration to demand that the authorities take measures to stop the widespread gang violence. Demonstrators set up burning barricades. Mobilizations on the same claims were held in other neighborhoods across the capital (coded separately).

On 16 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Turgeau, Ouest, citizens demonstrated to demand that the authorities take measures to stop the widespread gang violence. Demonstrators set up burning barricades. Mobilizations on the same claims were held in other neighborhoods across the capital (coded separately).

On 17 April 2025, in Kenscoff - Corail, Ouest, overnight, police forces clashed with members of the Viv Ansanm Gang in areas around the Kenscoff police station (Corail neighborhood), including nearby Carrefour Maroca area. The police managed to expel the criminals after they attempted to attack the mentioned zones. This caused residents to flee the area. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 4 April 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, the 400 Mawozo Gang kidnapped a journalist man (owner of radio RC FM) and his brother after intercepting them on the streets of Mirebalais, which was under gang attacked since 31 March (coded separately). The gangsters accused them of belonging to the Protected Areas Surveillance Brigade Police (BSAP). The abductors shared a video of the victims threatening to kill them. A USD 500.000 ransom was requested in exchange for their release. This was part of an offensive orchestrated by the Viv Ansanm Gang to take control of Mirebalais. The former owner of the Voice of America (VOA) and Radio Kiskeya went missing, although he was not confirmed to be kidnapped. The journalist and his brother were released on 17 April after the leader of the Viv Ansanm Gang ordered the 400 Mawozo Gang to release the hostages.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 10 February 2024 (between 8 - 12 February), in Cite Soleil - Drouillard, Ouest, members of the Belekou, Nan Boston, Simon-Pele, and Terre Noire gangs (aligned to the G-9 Gang) clashed with rival members of the Brooklyn Gang (a.k.a. Ti Gabriel Gang) (aligned to the G-Pep La Gang) and splinter groups of the G-9 Gang in the Belecou, Boston, Brooklyn, and Drouillard neighborhoods (coded separately). The clashes took place in an attempt to gain territorial control. An unknown number of civilians were killed in the crossfire. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi; Undisclosed Source
notes: On 25 February 2024, in Carrefour - Mariani, Ouest, the leader of the Bout Ba Gang killed a police officer on the National Road 2 and burned his body. The attacker tore off the victim's head and ate part of his body. Both the perpetrator and the victim had a mutual past and that the motivation for the attack could be personal animosity between them. Overnight, police forces under the orders of the Miragoane police commissioner, Ernst Muscadin, shot and killed a member of the Bout Ba Gang in Kalbassier. The killing was an extrajudicial execution. 2 fatalities.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 8 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, unidentified gangs engaged in armed clashes. Between 8 and 12 February, clashes between the Chien Mechant and Canaan Gang (from G-Pep La Gang coalition) against their rivals from the Pierre VI and Terre Noir Gangs (from G-9 Gang coalition) resulted in at least 127 civilians killed in Cite Soleil, Tabarre, and Croix-des-Bouquets communes (coded separately). Also, a roadblock was set up on the National Road 1 in Damiens while gunshots were heard in Sarthe and Terre Noire. At least 127 fatalities split across four events, 32 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: Around 10 February 2024 (between 8 - 12 February), in Cite Soleil - Terre Noire/ Blanchard, Ouest, rival gang members engaged in armed clashes in Terre Noire and Blanchard neighborhoods. At least six casualties were counted among civilians in Blanchard (unspecified if they were injured or killed). The Rhum Barbancourt S.A. Company announced the closure of its facilities after the burning of eight hectares of cane fields near the company's premises as a result of the gang clashes. Clashes lasted for several days. Gunshots were heard in Waaf Jeremie area. Between 8 and 12 February, clashes between the Chien Mechant and Canaan Gang (from G-Pep La Gang coalition) against their rivals from the Pierre VI and Terre Noire Gangs (from G-9 Gang coalition) resulted in at least 127 civilians killed in Cite Soleil, Tabarre, and Croix-des-Bouquets communes (coded separately). At least 127 fatalities split across four events, 32 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: Property destruction: On 21 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Martissant, Ouest, armed members from the Living-Together gang-led initiative (a.k.a. Viv Ansanm Gang) vandalized and demolished the Martissant 1 police station. The facility has been under the control of the gangs since June 2021 (coded separately). The building was also empty after the criminals set it on fire on 29 February (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: Property destruction: On 17 May 2024, in Titanyen, Ouest, overnight, members of the Canaan Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition) used an excavator to destroy the Cabaret women's civil prison building. The facility was empty since police forces abandoned it in January 2024.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Looting: On 30 January 2024, in Titanyen, Ouest, armed members of the Canaan Gang and a group of looters seized the Cabaret Women's Civil Prison and forced police officers to abandon the prison. The gang members stole solar panels and other materials and items. There were no inmates at the building, as around 600 female prisoners had been moved to another place in June 2023.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Property destruction: On 6 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, members of the Grand-Ravine Gang looted and set fire to a police station in Marche Salomon area. Police agents who were inside managed to escape before the attack. Several vehicles were burned.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; The St. Kitts Nevis Observer
notes: On 15 August 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, overnight, a group of inmates rioted at the Saint-Marc civil prison and managed to escape the facility in the morning of 16 August. The facility was set on fire and smoke was seen from outside. As police forces intervened to capture the fugitives, two prisoners (described as members of the Haiti in Action party) were shot and killed, while an unspecified number of others were injured. Authorities stated that between 12 to 15 people were killed, although inmates who managed to escape the prison claimed that at least 33 prisoners were executed. Several officers were wounded. Several other fugitives were arrested and around 12 prisoners escaped the prison. Residents reported having seen armed men arriving in the village prior to the prison break. The tensions started the day prior when prisoners complained about the lack of food. Following the clash, gunshots were heard in Cite Nissage Saget and the city center as police officer chased the fugitives. Police also mentioned that one of the prisoners was later arrested in Arcahaie after having been held by residents (there is no information on the interaction between the prisoner and the residents). In September 2024, a human rights network denied to official version and described the event not as a prisoners' riot but as a peaceful mobilization by inmates over the lack of food. The network accused security forces of excessive force against the prisoners and summary executions. Some of the deceased were shot to the head. They were buried in a mass grave. At least 12 fatalities, several injured.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 4 March 2024, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, overnight, hundreds of prisoners rioted at the Civil Prison as part of an escape attempt. During the riot, male prisoners raped several women prisoners. Police guards intervened with tear gas and gunshots were heard. Three inmates were killed and at least four others were injured. A prison guard was also injured. 12 cells were looted and damaged. 3 fatalities, at least 5 injured.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 24 October 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, a mob of residents set fire to the corpse of a man on Quatre Chemins Boulevard. The man had been killed by police forces together with another individual moments before over accusations of having committed a robbery (coded separately). 0 fatalities coded here.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: Around 21 July 2024 (between 18 - 25 July), in Gressier - Petit Boucan, Ouest, an unspecified number of gang members were killed by mobs of residents as police forces carried out anti-gang operations in the commune (coded separately). On 24 July, residents lynched an unclarified number of criminals who were intercepted by the police for their involvement in the kidnapping and raping of 23 women (uncoded). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 10 February 2024 (between 8 - 12 February), in Cite Soleil - Belecou, Ouest, members of the Belekou, Nan Boston, Simon-Pele, and Terre Noire gangs (aligned to the G-9 Gang) clashed with rival members of the Brooklyn Gang (a.k.a. Ti Gabriel Gang) (aligned to the G-Pep La Gang) and splinter groups of the G-9 Gang in the Belecou, Boston, Brooklyn, and Drouillard neighborhoods (coded separately). The clashes took place in an attempt to gain territorial control. An unknown number of civilians were killed in the crossfire. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 10 February 2024 (between 8 - 12 February), in Cite Soleil - Boston, Ouest, members of the Belekou, Nan Boston, Simon-Pele, and Terre Noire gangs (aligned to the G-9 Gang) clashed with rival members of the Brooklyn Gang (a.k.a. Ti Gabriel Gang) (aligned to the G-Pep La Gang) and splinter groups of the G-9 Gang in the Belecou, Boston, Brooklyn, and Drouillard neighborhoods (coded separately). The clashes took place in an attempt to gain territorial control. An unknown number of civilians were killed in the crossfire. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 10 February 2024 (between 8 - 12 February), in Cite Soleil - Brooklyn, Ouest, members of the Belekou, Nan Boston, Simon-Pele, and Terre Noire gangs (aligned to the G-9 Gang) clashed with rival members of the Brooklyn Gang (a.k.a. Ti Gabriel Gang) (aligned to the G-Pep La Gang) and splinter groups of the G-9 Gang in the Belecou, Boston, Brooklyn, and Drouillard neighborhoods (coded separately). The clashes took place in an attempt to gain territorial control. An unknown number of civilians were killed in the crossfire. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 10 February 2024 (between 8 - 12 February), in Tabarre, Ouest, rival gang members engaged in armed clashes in areas of the commune belonging to La Plaine. Between 8 and 12 February, clashes between the Chien Mechant and Canaan Gang (from G-Pep La Gang coalition) against their rivals from the Pierre VI and Terre Noire Gangs (from G-9 Gang coalition) resulted in at least 127 civilians killed in Cite Soleil, Tabarre, and Croix-des-Bouquets communes (coded separately). At least 127 fatalities split across four events, 31 fatalities coded here.

On 25 April 2025, in the Gressier commune, Ouest, the police, supported by members of a self-defense group, killed around 10 Viv Ansanm gang members during an operation aiming at expelling them from the Morne Chandelle locality, where they tried to install a toll station. The police also seized several war-grade weapons. Around 10 fatalities.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 17 July 2024, in Berken, Nippes, police forces under the orders of the Miragoane police commissioner, Ernst Muscadin, killed a member of the 103 Zombies Gang. The killing was described as an extrajudicial execution. 1 fatality.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: Around 19 April 2025 (as reported), in Mirebalais, Centre, police forces shot and killed several gang members during an anti-gang operation in the commune. Six firearms were seized. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 24 October 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, police forces under the orders of the Miragoane police commissioner, Ernst Muscadin, killed two men on Quatre Chemins Boulevard. The victims had been involved in unspecified criminal activities in the village. Their killings were described as extrajudicial executions. A mob of residents set fire to one of the corpses moments later (coded separately). 2 fatalities.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Property destruction: Around 21 May 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang demolished La Saline sub-police station (methods unclarified).

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Looting: On 29 February 2024, in Tabarre - Duvivier/Galette Goureau, Ouest, unidentified individuals looted the Croix-des-Bouquets Peace Court building in Tabarre 23 (Duvivier/Galette Goureau neighborhood). This was likely the authorship of gang members who also looted other Peace Courts of the Port-au-Prince commune around 29 February (coded separately). The institution had been displaced from its original headquarters in Croix-des-Bouquets after a gang attack in July 2022 (coded separately).

Looting: On 2 April 2025, in Tabarre - Butte Boyer, Ouest, gang members looted homes in Clercine 22. Clashes were registered in the area, as well as in Clercine 24, and near the Tabarre 27 and Croix des Missions neighborhoods (coded separately).

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Around 15 February 2024 (between 1 January - 31 March), in Belladere, Centre, mobs of residents killed an unclarified number of G-Pep La Gang affiliates who tried to establish a gang base in the Centre department. Similar vigilante attacks were registered in Mirebalais, Saut-d'Eau, and Hinche (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Around 15 February 2024 (between 1 January - 31 March), in Hinche, Centre, mobs of residents killed an unclarified number of G-Pep La Gang affiliates who tried to establish a gang base in the Centre department. Similar vigilante attacks were registered in Belladere, Mirebalais, and Saut-d'Eau (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Around 15 February 2024 (between 1 January - 31 March), in Mirebalais, Centre, mobs of residents killed an unclarified number of G-Pep La Gang affiliates who tried to establish a gang base in the Centre department. Similar vigilante attacks were registered in Belladere, Saut-d'Eau, and Hinche (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Around 15 February 2024 (between 1 January - 31 March), in Saut-d'Eau, Centre, mobs of residents killed an unclarified number of G-Pep La Gang affiliates who tried to establish a gang base in the Centre department. Similar vigilante attacks were registered in Belladere, Mirebalais, and Hinche (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 6 April 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, citizens held a protest over unclarified claims and vandalized the Gonaives Peace Court (nature of the vandalic acts unclarified).

On 19 April 2025, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, several scores of citizens and local personalities held a protest with banners against rising insecurity and demanding the authorities to take concrete measures in the face of gang violence.

On 20 April 2025, in Ouanaminthe, Nord-Est, a group of BSAP police agents held a demonstration outside the commune's police station demanding the release of an arrested BSAP colleague. As their demands were denied, the demonstrating BSAP officers took their arms and assaulted the police station, leading to an exchange of fire with police forces at place. During the gunfight, a BSAP agent was shot and injured. 1 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 16 April 2025, in Petion Ville - Morne Hercule, Ouest, scores of citizens held a demonstration demanding that the authorities take measures to stop the widespread gang violence. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires and stones. The police dispersed them using tear gas near the Saint-Jean Bosco church. Mobilizations on the same claims were held in other neighborhoods across the capital as part of the Black Wednesday Initiative (Mercredi Noir) against insecurity (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 18 April 2025, in Kenscoff - Fermathe, Ouest, according to witnesses, gang members killed an unknown number of people as they attacked and set fire to residents' houses in the neighborhood. The criminals forced civilians out of their properties and used the houses as gang bases. Police and armed civilians (likely self-defense group members) were deployed, although no interaction with the gang members was mentioned. Between 18 and 20 April, more than 900 people were displaced due to gang-related violence in the commune. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 20 April 2025, in Kenscoff - Fermathe, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition based on the top of a building opened fire on a military vehicle circulating through the heights of Kenscoff (near Kenscoff - Fermathe). Among the nine military officers onboard, three were killed and six were injured. The ambush was described as a reprisal for the killing of around 40 gang members during security forces' drone airstrikes the day prior (coded separately). Between 18 and 20 April, more than 900 people were displaced due to gang violence in the commune. 3 fatalities, 6 injured.

source: Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vi Free Press
notes: On 11 April 2025, in Kenscoff - Godet, Ouest, overnight, the Viv Ansanm Gang ambushed police forces in the Godet neighborhood, injuring five police officers. Another one who went missing was reported as killed. At least two police vehicles were set on fire. The criminals targeted the officials at several houses where they had retired with women to spend the night. The women were described as accomplices of the gang members. The officers denied to have abandoned their posts and to be present at the said houses. The criminals managed to seize police firearms and materials. 1 fatality, 5 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 16 April 2025, in Petion Ville - Delmas 95, Ouest, hundreds of citizens demonstrated along the Freres Road and Saint Pierre Square to demand that the authorities take measures to stop the widespread gang violence. Demonstrators set up burning barricades and threw stones at cars that tried to pass through. The police intervened against armed individuals who tried to push them out of the area, causing clashes between the officers and demonstrators. Mobilizations on the same claims were held in other neighborhoods across the capital as part of the Black Wednesday Initiative (Mercredi Noir) against insecurity (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 16 April 2025, in Petion Ville - Juvenat, Ouest, citizens demonstrated to demand that the authorities take measures to stop the widespread gang violence. Demonstrators set up burning barricades in different areas. Gunshots were also heard in the area (authorship unclarified). Mobilizations on the same claims were held in other neighborhoods across the capital as part of the Mercredi Noir initiative against insecurity (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: Security measures: On 17 July 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, Prime Minister Garry Conille declared a state of emergency in 14 communes of the Ouest and the Artibonite departments, as of 19 July and until 19 August. The measure was then extended for 30 additional days (until 19 September) and several communes of the Nippes and Centre departments were added to the list. The communes affected are: Gressier, Carrefour, Port-au-Prince, Delmas, Cite Soleil, Tabarre, Petion-Ville, Kenscoff, Croix-des-Bouquets, Cabaret, Thomazeau, Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Liancourt, Verrettes and Route Nationale #1, l'Estere, Gros Morne until TiBois d'Homme. The Plaisance and Limbe communes (North department) were added to the list on 19 August. The measure was imposed due to insecurity in the territories under the control of the Viv Ansanm Gang. The decision was published in Le Moniteur, the official journal of the Republic of Haiti. On 4 September, Prime Minister extended the state of emergency to the whole national territory. The measure was declared to be in force until 3 November, although it was later renewed on several occasions, the last one on 1 May 2025, extending it for an additional three months.

Movement of forces: On 15 April 2025, in Tabarre - Aeroport Toussaint Louverture, Ouest, 63 Jamaican soldiers and police officers were deployed as part of the Multinational Security Support Mission in Haiti (MSS) backed by the United Nations to fight against gang violence in the country.

source: Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 15 January 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, thousands of citizens held a march demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Protesters claimed to support Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). Police forces were present, although no intervention on their side was mentioned.

On 16 January 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, for the second consecutive day, citizens held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Protesters, who claimed to support Guy Philippe (former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), called on merchants to close their businesses and join the mobilization.

On 17 January 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, for the third consecutive day, citizens held a march demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Protesters claimed to support Guy Philippe (former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 18 January 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, for the fourth consecutive day, citizens held a march demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry.
