As protesters marched next to the regional customs office, police forces used tear gas to disperse them. They claimed to support Guy Philippe (former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 22 January 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, residents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry. Demonstrators threw stones in Carrefour Zamour and set up barricades of burning tires. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 29 January 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, some dozen residents held a protest on the National Road 2 demanding the departure of Prime Minister, Ariel Henry, and against the departmental delegate. Police forces intervened with tear gas to disperse the crowd when they marched next to the National Port Authority (APN). The protest, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti), was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by organizations from the political opposition (coded separately).

Other: On 29 January 2024, near Dame-Marie, Grande-Anse, the road connecting that location to Anse d'Hainaut and Les Irois was blocked. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: On 5 February 2024, between Chalon, Du Parc, and Reynold (coded to Reynold), Nippes, government opponents held a march demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Protesters held banners and tree branches, and used trucks to block the National Road 2. The protest had initiated in Chalon and passed through Du Parc before ending in Reynold, where protesters closed the National Port Authority (APN) offices. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by the Committed to Development Party (EDE), the Platfom Pitit Desalin Party (PPD), Fanmi Lavalas, and Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). It was held on the first day of nationwide general strike called by the Anti-Corruption Union Brigade (coded separately).

On 7 February 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, for the second consecutive day, thousands of government opponents and members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade police (BSAP), called by the EDE Party, held a march demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades (nature unspecified), and threw stones against a police patrol and against the National Old Age Insurance regional office (ONA). ONA security guards fired shots against the crowd, although no casualties were mentioned. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 19 January 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 41, Ouest, an anti-government demonstration took place in Delmas 47 (Delmas 41 neighborhood), and 75 (coded separately). The demonstrators set up barricades with burning tires. Another report indicates that the police was present, but no specific activity was reported. Another report indicates that barricades were erected with burning tires in Delmas 60 (coded separately). Although there is no information on the circumstances of the demonstration, and the barricades or who set them up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 5 February 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, people protested. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the protest, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 7 February 2024, in Chalon, Nippes, people protested on the Route Nationale #2. The report also indicates that members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) were present, although no specific actions were registered. This is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 8 February 2024, in Chalon, Nippes, people held a demonstration and roadblocks were set on the Route Nationale #2 in Bekin. Although there is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up, this is likely to be part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

On 25 February 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, police forces shot and killed a member of the Bout Ba gang. This was part of a police operation led by the Miragoane police commissioner, Ernest Muscadin. 1 fatality.

On 15 March 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, police forces shot and killed a gang member in the Berquin neighbourhood. The deceased was identified as a member of the Base 5 Secondes Gang. The operation was carried out by the Nippes police commissioner, Ernst Muscadin. 1 fatality.

On 27 March 2024, in Anse-d'Hainault commune, Grande-Anse, in the morning, masked armed pirates kidnapped a fisher and stole a dozen rowboat engines during an attack against Les Irois and Anse-d'Hainault communes. The victim's whereabouts are unknown. There is no information on the perpetrators and circumstances of the abduction, but the latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related.

On 6 February 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, several hundreds of citizens held a protest demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).

source: Haiti News TV; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 20 June 2024, in Saint Michel du Sud, Nippes, police forces shot and killed a member of the Bout Ba Gang on the National Road 2 at the height of the Morne Bosse locality. The killing took place under the orders of the Miragoane police commissioner, Ernst Muscadin. 1 fatality.
On 5 June 2024, in Chalon, Nippes, police forces shot and killed a gang member who had escaped the prison in March. He was killed during an operation that aimed at seizing him. 1 fatality.

On 26 June 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, police forces shot and killed a member of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang). The officers were under the orders of the Miragoane police commissionaire. 1 fatality.

source: Haiti Progres; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 26 July 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, police forces shot and killed a gang member who used to kidnap and ransom public transport drivers and passengers in the Nippes department. The killing took place under the order of the Miragoane police commissioner, Ernst Muscadin. 1 fatality.

Around 8 August 2024 (between 5 - 11 August), in the Anse-d'Hainault commune, Grande-Anse, members of the Mostly Lindor Gang killed three young individuals in the Bourdon communal section. 3 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 10 August 2024, in the Anse-d'Hainault commune, Grande-Anse, overnight, members of the population affiliated to a self-defence group lynched around 10 members of the Mostly Lindor Gang (up to 15 according to another source), and burned their bodies, in the Bourdon communal section. This was in support of police forces, who were carrying out a security operation in the area. They also set fire to more than 10 houses used as shelters by the gangsters. The leader of the gang managed to escape. Firearms were seized and cattle heads which had been stolen were recovered. At least 10 fatalities.

On 12 August 2024, in Anse-d'Hainault, Grande-Anse, members of the population killed two gang members (methods unspecified). Two women accused of having ties with the gangsters were apprehended and handed over to the police. The perpetrators were likely to be affiliated to a local self-defence group. 2 fatalities.

On 13 August 2024, in the Anse-d'Hainault commune, Grande-Anse, overnight, members of the population affiliated to a local self-defence group, in support of police forces, lynched four gang members in the Bourdon communal section. The victim were affiliates of the Mostly Lindor Gang. 4 fatalities.

On 12 August 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, police forces shot and killed a member of the 103 Zombies Gang. The killing took place under the order of the Miragoane police commissioner, Ernst Muscadin. According to another source, the father of the gang member was also killed during the police operation. At least 1 fatality.

Around 19 August 2024 (between 19 - 20 August), in Anse-d'Hainault, Grande-Anse, police forces supported by members of the population affiliated to a local self-defence group killed at least seven gang members, including the leader of the Mostly Lindor Gang, during an anti-gang operation in the Anse-d'Hainault, Moron, and Chambellan communes. Several houses used as shelters by the gang members were set on fire. At least 7 fatalities split across three events.

Around 19 August 2024 (between 19 - 20 August), in Chambellan, Grande-Anse, police forces supported by members of the population affiliated to a local self-defence group killed at least seven gang members, including the leader of the Mostly Lindor Gang, during an anti-gang operation in the Chambellan, Moron, and Anse-d'Hainault communes. Several houses used as shelters by the gang members were set on fire. At least 7 fatalities split across three events.
Property destruction: On 18 August 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, police forces seized more than 4 tons of marijuana and 5 kg of cocaine. Four individuals were arrested in connection with the drugs.

On 28 August 2024, near Miragoane, Nippes, police forces shot and killed a member of the Belair Gang in the Berquin area. The now deceased was intercepted at a police checkpoint as he rode a motorcycle. The killing was ordered by the Miragoane police commissioner, Ernst Muscadin. The criminal had been injured during clashes with security forces in the Bel Air neighbourhood the day prior (coded separately). 1 fatality.

On 10 September 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, people marched downtown in support to the government court commissioner as human rights organizations are demanding he steps down. The march was organized after he was accused of physical assault by the wife of the chief public prosecutor. The protesters, accompanied by music trucks, praised the commissioner by highlighting how good he has been for the community, especially in the managing of gang violence in the area. They also denounced the executive director of the National Human Rights Defense Network (RNDDH) whom they accused of plotting with gangs to demand the commissioner's resignation.

On 5 January 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 41, Ouest, overnight, unidentified armed individuals shot and killed a police officer man in Delmas 39 (Delmas 41 neighborhood). The victim was assigned to the Central Directorate of the Judicial Police (DCPJ). There is no information on the circumstances of the killing. 1 fatality.

On 14 January 2025, in Saint Michel du Sud, Nippes, students from the Saint-Michel des Nippes high school took to the streets demanding the return of teachers to classrooms after they went on a strike. Protesters blocked roads in the area.

On 13 January 2025, in Miragoane, Nippes, students from the Jeunes Filles public high school held a demonstration against the absence of teachers and calling for their return to classrooms after they went on a strike. During the mobilization, demonstrators clashed with another group of students from the Lumiere private college as they refused to join the mobilization. Clashes involved the throwing of stones and bottles. At least three students from the private institution were injured. Several others fainted. Police forces intervened and fired shots into the air to disperse the rioters. 3 injured.

source: Ordre des Defenseurs des Droits Humains (ORDEDH); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Tripotay Lakay
notes: On 15 June 2024, in Miragoane, Nippes, police officers, along with the Miragoane police commissioner, Ernst Muscadin, killed a member of the Bout Ba Gang. The now deceased was in charge of a road checkpoint in Lambi 5 (Carrefour commune). The killing was an extrajudicial execution. 1 fatality.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Vi Free Press
notes: Around 24 April 2025 (as reported), in Kenscoff - Fermathe, Ouest, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang shot and killed four young civilians whom they had held hostage, in the heights of the commune (near Kenscoff - Fermathe). A social media video showed a gang leader executing the four civilians. 4 fatalities.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 22 April 2025, near Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang carried out an attack, killing at least two people and kidnapping an unspecified number of others in the Moreau Paye area. The victims' whereabouts are unknown. At least 2 fatalities.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 28 April 2025, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, in the morning, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang attacked residents and farmers on Capois street and the Quatorzieme neighborhood. The criminals set fire to houses and looted some business establishments. At least four civilians (including a 11-year-old boy) were killed and 15 others were injured by gunshots during gang attacks in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Haut Canal, and Haut Forneau (coded separately) on that day. Police and self-defense brigade forces intervened to expel the criminals (coded separately). At least 4 fatalities split across two events. 2 coded here.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 28 April 2025, in the Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune, Artibonite, in the morning, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang attacked residents and farmers in Haut Canal and Haut Forneau areas. The criminals set fire to houses and looted some business establishments. At least four civilians (including a 11-year-old boy) were killed, and 15 others were injured by gunshots during gang attacks in Haut Canal, Haut Forneau, and Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite (coded separately) on that day. Police and self-defense brigade forces intervened to expel the criminals (coded separately). At least 4 fatalities split across two events. 2 coded here.
Non-violent activity: On 20 April 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, members of the Canaan gang took control of the Taliban Radio Station which they have been using to broadcast gang-related propaganda.
On 14 April 2025, in Miragoane, Nippes, the Miragoane police commissioner killed a member of the Viv Ansanm Gang in the Berquin locality. 1 fatality.

Looting: On 13 April 2025, in Picmi, Ouest, armed gang members hijacked the 'Merci Dieu' boat at the Picmi dock and looted it from coal sacks and money, among other belongings from the passengers on board. The gangsters released the boat and the passengers safely after the looting.

Around 24 April 2025 (as reported), in Leogane, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members who tried to take control of the area. Several gang members were injured and others were arrested. Firearms were seized. Several injured.
On 25 April 2025, in the Leogane commune, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in an area known as 'Jasmen'. Several firearms were seized. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: Non-violent activity: On 28 April 2025, in Carrefour, Ouest, a three-day strike ending on 30 April was imposed by the Ti Bwa Gang leader in the commune to force local authorities to appoint a new interim executive agent at the head of the municipality. Ti Bwa Gang armed members were seen patrolling streets on motorcycles to prevent road traffic and the development of regular activities. Only hospitals were authorized to continue operating. On 29 April, the gang leader announced the suspension of the strike and called the population to meet on 30 April to clean the commune.

On 17 April 2025, in Cite Soleil - Hasco/Village Democratie, Ouest, gang members attacked and took over the Varreux Terminal, causing panic among workers and disrupting petrol distribution throughout the country. Gunshots were heard near the terminal. There were no casualties.

On 16 April 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 60, Ouest, burning tires were set up in Delmas 60. There is no information on the motives for the barricades or who set them up, although they were likely part of demonstrations against widespread gang violence. Also, gunshots were heard between Delmas 32 and Delmas 35 (Delmas 41 neighborhood). Mobilizations on the same claims were held on that day in Delmas 32 and Delmas 75 (coded separately).
Other: On 24 April 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Bas Delmas. The circumstances and authorship of the gunshots are unknown.

On 13 April 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, armed clashes were registered in Delmas 30. The circumstances and actors involved in the clashes were not clarified, although they might be related to ongoing attacks in the area. Casualties unknown.

Other: On 17 April 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Godet. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots, although they might be related to armed clashes between police forces and gang members, as it was the case in nearby Corail neighborhood on that day (coded separately).
Property destruction: Around 23 April 2025 (as reported), in Kenscoff, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang set fire to a police armored vehicle in the commune. The scene was recoded on video.

On 14 April 2025, in Kenscoff - Fermathe, Ouest, in the morning, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out drone airstrikes in the Fermathe 50 and Fermathe 53 neighborhoods. Drone airstrikes were also launched near the Grand Ravine, Cite de Dieu, Nazon, Morne a Tuf , Portail Leogane neighborhoods, as well as other areas of the capital (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
Other: On 15 April 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the mountains of Thomassin. There is no information of the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 16 April 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Peguy-Ville. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 14 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a roadblock was set up in Canape-Vert. Another was also set up on the Martin Luther King Avenue from the Natcom offices (in Bois Patate) to the Canado school (Debussy/Haut-Turgeau). The roadblocks were still present on 15 April. There is no information on the motives for the roadblocks or who set them up.
Other: On 16 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Solino. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 16 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Canape-Vert, Ouest, hundreds of citizens held a protest demanding that the authorities take measures to stop the widespread gang violence. Protesters set up roadblocks from Debrosse to the Canape-Vert square using vehicles and debris. Mobilizations on the same claims were held in other neighborhoods across the capital as part of the Black Wednesday Initiative (Mercredi Noir) against insecurity (coded separately).

Looting: On 26 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Pacot, Ouest, more than 15 armed gang members occupied and vandalized the Catholic Saint-Francois d'Assise High School, located on Rue 6 (Pacot). The criminals recorded a video dressed in students' clothes.

On 14 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Portail Leogane/Cite Louverture, Ouest, in the morning, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out drone airstrikes against gangs' positions in the Portail Leogane neighborhood. Drone airstrikes were also launched near the Grand Ravine, Cite de Dieu, Nazon, Morne a Tuf neighborhoods, as well as other areas of the capital (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

Property destruction: Around 27 April 2025 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Turgeau, Ouest, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang) set fire to the Social Assistance Fund (CAS) headquarters, located on N Avenue (Turgeau). The scene was recorded on video and shared on social media.

source: Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Vi Free Press
notes: Around 24 April 2025 (as reported), in Kenscoff - Fermathe, Ouest, gang members killed two soldiers in the heights of the commune (near Kenscoff - Fermathe). 2 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 19 March 2025, between Port-au-Prince - Canape Vert and Port-au-Prince - Musseau-Delmas 48 (coded to Port-au-Prince - Musseau-Delmas 48), Ouest, thousands of residents from several neighborhoods held a march holding signs, sticks, and machetes through the streets of Canape Vert, Bois Patate, Bourdon, and Lalue towards the Villa D'Accueil building (in Delmas 60) against gang violence and demanding that authorities take measures to fight insecurity. Demonstrators set up burning barricades across the capital. As the crowd arrived to the Primature headquarters (Musseau-Delmas 48), police fired tear gas and live shots to disperse them, injuring at least 10 people by gunshots, including a member of the Canape-Vert self-defense brigade, who later died in hospital. At least one other person was also killed. Demonstrators threw rocks and violently aggressed at least 10 journalists who were covering the event (their health state is unknown). At least 2 fatalities, at least 10 injured.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 7 April 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 17, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in Delmas 17, Delmas 30, and Delmas 19 (coded separately). Several gang members were killed. The police also seized seven weapons across all of the clashes. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 7 April 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 19/Mackandal, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in Delmas 19, Delmas 17, and Delmas 30 (coded separately). Several gang members were killed. The police also seized seven weapons across all of the clashes. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 7 April 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in Delmas 30, Delmas 17, and Delmas 19 (coded separately). Several gang members were killed. The police also seized seven weapons across all of the clashes. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 19 April 2025, in Kenscoff - Fermathe, Ouest, military forces and other security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces), supported by the Multinational Security Support Mission (MSS), carried out between 13 to 16 drone airstrikes against the Viv Ansanm Gang positions in the heights of the commune (near Kenscoff - Fermathe). Around 40 gang members were killed. At least 40 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi; Vi Free Press
notes: On 23 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Pacot, Ouest, the Canape-Vert self-defense brigade together with the police and military forces clashed with the Base 5 Secondes Gang and the Grand-Ravine Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang) in the neighborhood. During clashes, three self-defense brigade members -including the right hand of the leader-, a police officer, two military officers, and a journalist covering the event were killed. At least 20 gang members were killed amidst clashes (up to 30 according to other sources), while 15 others were killed by police drone airstrikes (coded separately). An unclarified number of people were injured. At least 27 fatalities. Several injured.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 27 April 2025, in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang killed around 10 civilians and injured several others as they set fire to residents' houses in Carrefour Paye (Bas Artibonite). At least 30 people were abducted, including drivers and passengers along the National Road 1. The attack was a reprisal for the lynching of a woman identified as concubine of the gang's leader (coded separately). The victims' whereabouts are unknown. At least 10 fatalities.

Around 27 April 2025 (weekend of), in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, a mob of residents lynched a woman identified as concubine of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang's leader. Another source stated that the perpetrators were members of a self-defense brigade. Her killing motivated a gang reprisal that resulted in around 10 civilians killed (coded separately). 1 fatality.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 2 May 2025, in Poste Pierrot, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang raped, killed, injured, kidnapped, and set fire to residents' houses in the Grand Hatte locality, which is part of the Poste Pierrot communal section (Dessalines' 4th communal section). There were at least three fatal victims. The abducted victims' whereabouts are unknown. The head of Radio-Tele Mike FM claimed that the attack was a reprisal against the La Coalition self-defense brigade, whose affiliates are originals from the area, although the identify of the victims was described as civilian. At least 3 fatalities.

Other: On 21 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a roadblock was set up on Canape-Vert square at the entrance of Bois Patate street. There is no information on the motives for the roadblock or who set it up.
Other: On 24 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, roadblocks were set up in the Canape-Vert and Debrosse neighborhoods. There is no information on the motives for the roadblocks or who set them up.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 6 May 2025, in Aquin, Sud, police forces shot and killed a member of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang during an armed clash. The police also seized a weapon. 1 fatality.

source: Haiti Press Network; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: Around 4 May 2025 (weekend of), in Tabarre - Clercine, Ouest, police forces engaged in armed clashes with the Chien Mechant Gang and the Base Nan Tokyo Gang in Clercine. Several gang members, including the second leader of the Chien Mechant Gang, were shot and killed. At least two other criminals, including the leader of the Base Nan Tokyo Gang, were injured. Clashes erupted as the police conducted a security operation to thwart gangs' efforts to install a gang leader in the neighborhood. At least 30 gang members were killed during three separate police operations in Tabarre, Mirebalais, and Kenscoff in early May (coded separately). 30 fatalities split over three locations. 5 coded here, at least 2 injured.

On 4 May 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Grand Ravine, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out five drone airstrikes against the stronghold of the Grand-Ravine Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang) in the neighborhood. At least 17 gang members were killed and around 40 were injured. At least 17 fatalities, at least 40 injured.

source: Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 3 May 2025, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, in the morning, police forces engaged in armed clashes with the Koulou Gang during a security operation in the Nan Zombie neighborhood. During clashes, five gang members, including the right hand of the gang's leader, were shot and killed. A police officer was injured. A woman gangster, concubine of the gang second leader, was arrested. Two firearms and ammunition were seized. 5 fatalities, 1 injured.

On 22 April 2025, in Kenscoff - Corail, Ouest, gang members threw Molotov cocktails and set fire to the Kenscoff public market (likely opened to the public), which is very close to the Kenscoff police station (in the Corail neighborhood). Casualties unknown.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 22 April 2025, in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, the police shot and killed a gang member as they conducted anti-gang operations to regain control of areas occupied by criminals. The officers seized a weapon and ammunition. 1 fatality.

On 2 May 2025, in Gressier - Bois Lassale/Nan Coline, Ouest, police forces supported by the Multinational Security Support Mission (MSS) engaged in armed clashes with gang members in the Nan Coline neighborhood. Security forces managed to recover control over the neighborhood, allowing residents to get back some of their belongings in their homes. Casualties unknown.

On 23 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Pacot, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out drone airstrikes against gang positions as they conducted anti-gang operations in the neighborhood. At least 15 members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang and the Grand-Ravine Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang) were killed. 20 others were killed during clashes with security forces and self-defense groups on that day (coded separately). At least 15 fatalities.
Around 4 May 2025 (weekend of), in Saut-d'Eau, Centre, police forces killed several gang members as they carried out anti-gang operations in the commune. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 4 May 2025, in Savien, Artibonite, police forces and agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MSS) shot and killed three gang members and arrested a fourth one during clashes in the village. The criminals were intercepted when trying to destroy a bridge to prevent security forces from accessing Savien. 3 fatalities.

source: Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: Around 2 May 2025 (as reported), in Kenscoff, Ouest, police forces killed around 20 members of the Viv Ansanm Gang and injured several others during an anti-gang operation in the centre of Kenscoff. Several among the deceased were identified as members of the Ti Bwa Gang. At least 30 gang members were killed during three separate police operations in Kenscoff, Tabarre, and Mirebalais in early May (coded separately). 30 fatalities split over three locations. 20 coded here, several injured.

source: Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Looting: On 21 April 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, members of the Taliban Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition) looted and took over the Radio Panique station, renamed it as 'Taliban FM', and used it to broadcast their leader's messages as well as their own music. The gang members also stole some equipment and took it to their stronghold in Canaan.

On 21 April 2025, in Delmas - Barbancourt, Ouest, in the morning, unidentified individuals kidnapped a person from a vehicle along the Gaou Guinou Street, close to the Automeca car dealership (Barbancourt). The abductors forced the other occupants out of the vehicle before taking the victim to an unknown location. There is no information on the perpetrators of the abduction, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victim's whereabouts are unknown.

On 23 April 2025, in Kenscoff - Corail, Ouest, armed clashes were registered in the Carrefour Maroca zone, which is close to the Kenscoff police station (Corail neighborhood). The circumstances and actors involved in the clashes were not clarified, although this was not ruled out to be part of armed clashes between gangs and police forces. They engaged in clashes and in property destruction in the commune between 23 and 24 April (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

Other: On 19 April 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, gunshots were heard near the police station (Corail neighborhood). Stray bullets were also mentioned in Fermathe 52 (Fermathe). There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots, although they were likely linked to police interventions against gangs in the area. Security forces carried out drone airstrikes in the area on that day (coded separately).

Other: On 22 April 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard on the airport road at the entrance of Village Solidarite and Pele Simon neighborhoods. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 23 April 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Delmas 95 and Jacquet Toto neighborhoods. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 9 May 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Fermathe. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots, although they were not ruled out to be linked to gang activity in the area.

Other: On 9 May 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Thomassin. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots, although they were not ruled out to be linked to gang activity in the area.
On 20 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Pacot, Ouest, gang members attacked the neighborhood at the intersection of Babiole and Casseus streets. Gunshots were heard. Casualties unknown.

source: Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 6 May 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 41, Ouest, in the morning, according to witnesses, armed gang members opened fire on a four-occupants vehicle at the intersection of Delmas 41 and Delmas 49 streets (Delmas 41 neighborhood), killing a married couple and injuring one of their children. The deceased were business people, although the motivation for the attack is unknown. 2 fatalities, 1 injured.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Property destruction: On 23 May 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, overnight, the Viv Ansanm Gang vandalized the headquarters of the Souffle Divin Radio station. No further details were mentioned.

source: Amerique Info 7; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi; Vant Bef Info
notes: Property destruction: On 14 April 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 19/Joseph Janvier, Ouest, overnight, the Viv Ansanm Gang set fire to the Storm TV facilities. The building had been used as shelter by the criminals. Several vehicles were also burned in front of the TV station.

On 23 April 2025, in Tabarre - Butte Boyer, Ouest, Viv Ansanm gang members fired shots and threw tear gas in Clercine 12, causing residents to flee the area. Gunshots were also heard in Clercine 22. Casualties unknown.

Non-violent activity: On 9 May 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, a dozen Viv Ansanm gang members set up a toll booth near the Haiti Post Office (OPH), in Bas Peu de Choses neighborhood, forcing drivers to pay fees to be let through. Gang members as well as a police armored vehicle were seen at the location, although no further interaction was mentioned between both actors.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; iciHaiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 8 May 2025, in Kenscoff - Furcy, Ouest, overnight, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked the Furcy sub-police station. The officers who were inside, outnumbered by the gang members, left the police station's premises, although they came back with reinforcements and clashed with the criminals. Security forces managed to regain control, expelling the criminals, and implementing a security apparatus for the protection of residents. During the attack, the gangsters managed to set fire to part of the sub-police station building and at least one police vehicle. They also set fire to a nearby hotel and looted the presbytery of Saint-Paul de Furcy parish. The mayor of Kenscoff claimed that there were several fatalities, including gang members. Two police officers were shot and injured. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3. 2 injured.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Vant Bef Info
notes: On 29 January 2025, near Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, gang members kidnapped 11 farmers (eight men and three women) in the Laverdure, Palmiste, and Grotimal localities on the 2e Section Bas Coursin in the span of 72 hours. Most of the victims were farmers who were kidnapped while working. There is no information on the circumstances of the abductions. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

source: Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 19 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Martissant, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched drone airstrikes over the territories of the Base 5 Secondes Gang. This action was also carried out in the downtown area, near Fort-Mercredi, in Eglise Baptiste Bolosse, Grand Ravine, as well as Delmas 30 (coded separately). In March, police drone airstrike and armed clashes were drones were used resulted in at least 115 gang members killed and 119 injured. At least 115 fatalities split across 22 events. 5 coded here.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; HCN: Haiti Channel Network; Mag Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 29 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Cite de Dieu, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out drone airstrikes against the house of the Base 5 Secondes Gang leader (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) in Village de Dieu (Cite de Dieu neighborhood), causing material damages. The criminals shot at the drones to knock them down. In March, police drone airstrike and armed clashes were drones were used resulted in at least 115 gang members killed and 119 injured. At least 115 fatalities split across 22 events. 5 coded here.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Juno 7
notes: On 12 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Grand Ravine, Ouest, police forces conducted an anti-gang operation at the Grand-Ravine's Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition) stronghold, killing several gang members and seizing their firearms. According to unconfirmed sources, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out two drone airstrikes. Between 1 and 17 March, drone strikes by the police and armed clashes were drones were used killed at least 50 gang members, according to the head of the RNDDH (50 fatalities split across nine events). In March, police drone airstrike and armed clashes were drones were used resulted in at least 115 gang members killed and 119 injured. At least 115 fatalities split across 22 events. 1 coded here.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 19 March 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched drone airstrikes over the territories of several gangs in Delmas 30. This action was also carried out in the Centre Ville, near Fort-Mercredi, Cite de Dieu, Eglise Baptiste de Bolosse, Martissant, as well as in Grand Ravine neighborhoods (coded separately). In March, police drone airstrike and armed clashes were drones were used resulted in at least 115 gang members killed and 119 injured. At least 115 fatalities split across 22 events. 5 coded here.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 19 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched drone airstrikes over the territories of several gangs the Centre Ville neighborhood. notes: On 12 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour Feuilles, Ouest, overnight, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out drone strikes against gang targets in the neighborhood, killing 22 gang members and injuring several others. Between 1 and 17 March, drone strikes by the police and armed clashes were drones were used killed at least 50 gang members, according to the head of the RNDDH (50 fatalities split across nine events). source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Metropole
notes: On 13 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour Feuilles, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out drone strikes against gang targets in the neighborhood, killing several gang members. notes: On 7 March 2025, in Delmas - Cite Numero Un, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out drone strikes against several gang-controlled areas in Bas Delmas, including the Viv Ansanm Gang's stronghold in Delmas 6 (in Cite Numero Un), Waaf Jeremie (Cite Soleil), and Bel Air (Port-au-Prince) neighborhoods (coded separately), causing considerable damage.
