source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: Around 30 March 2025 (weekend of), in Trianon, Centre, members of a local vigilance brigade (the so-called Bakop Feray brigade) clashed with the Canaan Gang as they resisted the criminals' attempts to take control of the Mirebalais commune. An unknown number of gang members were killed. In reprisal, the criminals attacked residents in Trianon and Mirebalais on 31 March (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 24 February 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, overnight, the Delmas 6 Gang and the Belair Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm coalition) attacked the positions of a self-defense group brigade in Delmas 30, prompting clashes with the police, who intervened and managed to expel them. During the offensive, 21 people were killed and eight were injured as the gang members threw Molotov cocktails and burned residents' houses. There were two military officers among the fatal victims. They were killed at their home after the gangsters located them with the help of informants who had infiltrated among self-defense groups. The soldiers were brothers. Many residents fled their homes. 21 fatalities, 8 injured.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 19 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Peguy-Ville, Ouest, the Kraze Barye Gang (supported by the Grand-Ravine Gang) attacked Peguy-Ville neighborhood, and Laboule (coded separately) and Metivier (coded separately), among others, besides also clashing with the police in the Thomassin neighborhood (coded separately). Overnight, gunshots were heard along the Corlette Road, Delmas 95, and Pernier. The morning after, at least five dead bodies were found between the Panamerican Avenue and Corlette Road. It is unknown if there were civilians among the deceased. Another two bodies of gang members were found after having been lynched and burned by Bwa Kale Movement (coded separately). One body had been crushed by a vehicle. By the end of March, there were at least 38 casualties (killed and injured victims) as a result of gang attacks and subsequent anti-gang police operations in Vivy Mitchell, Belvil, and Peguy-Ville neighborhoods (coded separately). At least 5 fatalities.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: On 13 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Vivy Mitchell, Ouest, overnight, the Kraze Barye Gang attacked residents and clashed with police forces in the Vivy Mitchell neighborhood and in the vicinity of the Police National Academy (Academie neighborhood, coded separately). Gunshots were heard. By the end of March, there were at least 38 casualties (killed and injured victims) as a result of gang attacks and subsequent anti-gang police operations in Vivy Mitchell, Belvil, and Peguy-Ville neighborhoods (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Jamaica Gleaner; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 31 March 2025, in Trianon, Centre, police forces and members of the population affiliated to the Trianon Bakop Feray self-defense group clashed with several dozen gang members to repeal an attack against residents in Trianon and Mirebalais earlier that day (coded separately). At least 30 gang members were killed and two self-defense group members were injured that day in the armed clashes in Trianon and Mirebalais (coded separately). Security forces managed to expel them and seized their firearms. The gang members were identified as affiliates of the Canaan Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang. They wore t-shirts with the names of these groups. Residents claimed this was part of reprisals orchestrated by the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition for the resistance of the Bakop Feray self-defense group to gang presence in the area. At least 30 fatalities split across two events, 10 coded here.

source: Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 1 April 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, for a second consecutive day, police forces supported by members of the population affiliated to the Trianon Bakop Feray self-defense group clashed with gang members who attacked the commune (coded separately). The criminals occupied the rooftops of several buildings and opened fire on security forces from there. They were identified as affiliates of the Canaan Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang. This was part of an offensive orchestrated by the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition in reprisal for the resistance of the Trianon self-defense group to gang presence in the area over the weekend (coded separately). Between 31 March and 2 April, at least 60 gang members were killed in the downtown of Mirebalais. 60 fatalities split across three events. 20 coded here.

source: Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Libre; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 2 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Cite de Dieu, Ouest, overnight, police forces shot and killed several members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) during an anti-gang operation at the criminal group's stronghold (in Village de Dieu, Cite de Dieu neighborhood). Some sources stated that the gang's leader was injured by the gunshots, while others claimed that he was wounded by a drone strike as he was preparing to go out to join the carnival. The second gang leader was also injured, although he managed to escape with five accomplices. Between 1 and 17 March, drone strikes by the police and armed clashes were drones were used killed at least 50 gang members, according to the head of the RNDDH (50 fatalities split across nine events). In March, police drone airstrike and armed clashes were drones were used resulted in at least 115 gang members killed and 119 injured. At least 115 fatalities split across 22 events. 1 fatality coded here. At least 2 injured.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 26 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour Feuilles, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched three drones charged with explosives against gang targets in Carrefour Feuilles and one against gang members in Centre Ville (coded separately), resulting in around 100 casualties among gang members (nature of the casualties unclarified). In reprisal, the gangsters shot at the officers and engaged in armed clashes, injuring two officers. In March, police drone airstrike and armed clashes were drones were used resulted in at least 115 gang members killed and 119 injured. At least 115 fatalities split across 22 events. 5 coded here, 2 injured.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 26 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched a drone charged with explosives against gang targets in Centre Ville and three others against gang members in Carrefour Feuilles (coded separately), resulting in around 100 casualties among gang members (nature of the casualties unclarified). In reprisal, the gangsters shot at the officers and engaged in armed clashes, injuring two officers. In March, police drone airstrike and armed clashes were drones were used resulted in at least 115 gang members killed and 119 injured. At least 115 fatalities split across 22 events. 5 coded here.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; El Nacional (Dominican Republic); Gazette Haiti; InSight Crime; Jamaica Observer; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 1 March 2025, in Delmas - Cite Numero Un, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out a drone strike against the Viv Ansanm Gang's stronghold, in Delmas 6 (located in Cite Numero Un neighborhood and the Bas Delmas area), and clashed with members of the gang, killing at least four. During clashes, three police officers were injured. This was part of a police anti-gang security operation. Several firearms and ammunition were seized. Later that day, the gang's leader appeared on a social media video claiming that he was not injured during the strike, and that the fatal victims were civilians, not members of his gang. He also threatened with reprisal attacks. Between 1 and 17 March, drone strikes by the police and armed clashes were drones were used killed at least 50 gang members, according to the head of the RNDDH (50 fatalities split across nine events). In March, police drone airstrike and armed clashes were drones were used resulted in at least 115 gang members killed and 119 injured. At least 115 fatalities split across 22 events. 4 fatalities coded here, at least 3 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 13 February 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, the Baz Pilate Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Base 5 Secondes Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition) looted and set fire to the State University of Haiti Hospital (HUEH) (a.k.a. General Hospital). The special procedures room, pharmacy, surgery, orthopedics, and the central archives office were burned. A police officer and two journalists died as a result. Medical equipment was stolen. The medical personnel and patients fled the building to avoid harm. The attack was launched after false rumors stating that the Multinational Security Support Mission had established a base at the hospital's building. Gunshots were heard on nearby Saint-Honore and Reunion streets (Champs de Mars). 3 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 18 January 2025, in the Gros-Morne commune, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang riding motorcycles, and coming from Tibwadom area, killed 13 civilians (11 men and two women) and injured four as they opened fire on residents in the commune (drive-by). Six houses were burned. Some of the victims were taking part at a voodoo ceremony when the shooting took place. Several fatalities were counted in the Campeche area, while at least six people were hit by the bullets near the Grepin cemetery. Gunshots were heard near the Gros-Morne communal market. The attack was described as a reprisal over a land conflict, and over residents' resistance against a gang toll booth installed near the mentioned cemetery. Police forces intervened and expelled the criminals (coded separately). 13 fatalities, 4 injured.

source: Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 13 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Belvil, Ouest, members of the Kraze Barye Gang killed a child. The circumstances surrounding the attack are unclear. By the end of March, there were at least 38 casualties (killed and injured victims) as a result of gang attacks and subsequent anti-gang police operations in Vivy Mitchell, Belvil, and Peguy-Ville neighborhoods (coded separately). At least 1 fatality.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 14 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Belvil, Ouest, overnight, gang members attacked the Vivy Mitchell (coded separately), Belvil, and Bellevue neighborhoods (coded separately). A number of families took to the streets to take refuge elsewhere. By the end of March, there were at least 38 casualties (killed and injured victims) as a result of gang attacks and subsequent anti-gang police operations in Vivy Mitchell, Belvil, and Peguy-Ville neighborhoods (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 14 March 2024, in Petion Ville - Vivy Mitchell, Ouest, overnight, gang members attacked the Vivy Mitchell, Belvil (coded separately), and Bellevue neighborhoods (coded separately). A number of families took to the streets to take refuge elsewhere. By the end of March, there were at least 38 casualties (killed and injured victims) as a result of gang attacks and subsequent anti-gang police operations in Vivy Mitchell, Belvil, and Peguy-Ville neighborhoods (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Jamaica Gleaner; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 31 March 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, in the morning, the National Police of Haiti, BSAP police agents, and affiliates of the Mirebalais Bakop Feray brigade (self-defense group) clashed with several dozen gang members who attacked residents in Mirebalais and Trianon (coded separately). After police reinforcement arrived, security forces managed to expel the criminals from the Mirebalais police station and the Civil Prison, assaulted earlier that day (coded separately), and seized firearms. At least 30 gang members were killed and two self-defense group members were injured that day in the armed clashes in Trianon and Mirebalais (coded separately). The gang members were identified as affiliates of the Canaan Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang. They wore t-shirts with the names of these groups. Residents claimed that this was part of reprisals orchestrated by the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition for the resistance of the Trianon self-defense group to gang presence in the area. Between 31 March and 2 April, at least 60 gang members were killed in the downtown of Mirebalais (60 gang fatalities split across three events). 60 fatalities split across three events. 20 coded here.

source: Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 6 April 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, police forces supported by armed members of the population (affiliated to the Bakop Feray Mirebalais self-defense group) engaged in armed clashes with gang members during a security operation aimed at pushing back the criminals, who continued attacking the village on that day (coded separately). A gang leader was killed. The criminals were identified as members of the Canaan Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang. This was part of an offensive orchestrated by the Viv Ansanm Gang aimed at taking control of Mirebalais. 1 fatality.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Looting: On 10 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Saint Gerard, Ouest, members of the Grand-Ravine Gang and the Base 5 Secondes Gang looted the Oloffson hotel, located on the Cadet Jeremie Street.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; AP; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 14 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, the Belair Gang attacked the Solino neighborhood as they clashed with rival gang members. Several residents were injured by the bullets. Police forces intervened (methods unspecified) and expelled the criminals from the area. The National Human Rights Defense Network's director claimed that at least 20 people were killed between 14 and 18 January as a result of gang clashes in Port-au-Prince. The Organization of Hearts for Change for Deprived Children (OCCED'H) stated that at least 7 children were shot and injured in the same period. At least 7 injured split across ten events. At least 20 fatalities split across ten events, 2 fatalities coded here.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; AP; GardaWorld; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, for the fifth consecutive day, the Belair Gang, supported by the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu) and the Grand-Ravine Gang engaged in armed clashes with rival gangsters in the Solino neighborhood, Poupelard Avenue (Lalue neighborhood), and the Airport Road. According to a witness, at least six people were killed as the gangsters set up roadblocks and burned some houses. An unknown number were injured. Later that day, police forces were deployed and clashed with the armed men (coded separately). The National Human Rights Defense Network's director claimed that at least 20 people were killed between 14 and 18 January as a result of gang clashes in Port-au-Prince. The Organization of Hearts for Change for Deprived Children (OCCED'H) stated that at least 7 children were shot and injured in the same period. At least 7 injured split across ten events. At least 20 fatalities split across ten events, 2 fatalities coded here.

source: AP; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, police forces deployed in Solino neighbourhood and clashed with members of the Belair Gang and its accomplices. Clashes between gangs and attacks on civilians happened in the area since the early morning. One source stated that the Belair gang leader was shot and injured. 1 injured.

Other: On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, residents of Canape-Vert and several other communities near the Solino neighbourhood set up barricades with rocks, trucks, tires and banana trees to prevent gang members from entering and attacking their homes.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 24 January 2024, near Dessalines, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang attacked a bus on the National Road 1, between Hatte Grammont and Marchand-Dessalines communes, killing at least four civilians and injuring at least eight others. The driver and four passengers were among the fatal victims. According to one source, the gang members were members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang, although this was not confirmed by other sources. At least 4 fatalities, at least 8 injured.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: Around 5 January 2024 (between 4 - 5 January), in Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras gang kidnapped over a dozen of passengers from a bus traveling on the Route Nationale #1. According to BINUH, up to 20 people (13 men and seven women) were kidnapped from two pickup trucks. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

source: AP; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 21 January 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, masked armed men shot and killed the vice-consul of Haiti in Dajabon (Dominican Republic) in the vicinity of the Cap-Haitien International Airport. The victim was a doctor and former senator candidate. The motivation and perpetrators of the attack are unknown. 1 fatality.

actor2: Police Forces of Haiti (2017-2024) Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP)
source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 7 February 2024, in Petion Ville - Laboule, Ouest, police forces shot and killed five members of the Protected Areas Security Brigade police (BSAP) and arrested three others in Laboule neighbourhood. The circumstances around the incident were not clarified. A first version stated that, as a group of armed BSAP agents moving in a vehicle ignored a police halt, an armed clash erupted. A second version supported that the police officers engaged in a conversation with the BSAP agents before opening fire on them. The head of the Synapoha police union claimed that the BSAP agents opened fire after police the asked them to drop their weapons, prompting officers to shoot. On the contrary, the Haitian Military Association claimed that the BSAP agents were ambushed and they did to resist. A closed person to Guy Philipe (former rebel who called on anti-government demonstrations) claimed that the shooting was an assassination attempt against Philipe, as the police believed that he was travelling inside the BSAP vehicle. The BSAP vehicle was seized and the five corpses were buried in a common grave in Petionville cemetery. An investigation was ordered. A Petionville interim executive police officer and his brother-in-law were said to be involved in the killings. Since 29 January, the BSAP police are banned from circulation with arms. 5 fatalities.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 29 February 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, the Canaan Gang, together with the Chien Mechant Gang, killed at least five police officers (three men and two women) and injured five others during an attack against a police station. One of the wounded was lynched to death by the gangsters. The bodies of the deceased were tortured and mutilated. One was taken by the criminals and another corpse belonging to a police inspector was found the day after. The police station and a patrol vehicle were set on fire. The gangsters took over the police station and, on March 11, published a video showing a police officer held hostage. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya in a government visit. At least 6 fatalities.

Other: On 29 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, residents set up roadblocks in the Turgeau and Canape-Vert neighborhoods to prevent gang members from entering their communities. Roadblocks were erected after several gangs led by the leader of the G-9 Gang carried out coordinated attacks in the capital (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 29 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, gang members (likely G-9 members due to ongoing coordinated attacks) clashed with police forces as they set fire to several houses in Saint-Honore Street (Morne a Tuf), and they burned the Portail Leogane police station (coded separately). The gangsters also occupied the Sylvio Castor National Stadium (Morne a Tuf) and kidnapped an employee. His whereabouts are unknown. Gunshots were heard in Bicentenaire, Carrefour-Feuilles, Bel Air, Bas Delmas, Post Marchand, Champs de Mars, and Morne a Tuf areas. An Education Centre on Allerte Street was vandalized while two trader women were killed on the Magloire Amboise Avenue (Bas Peu de Choses, coded separately). At least 25 people injured by the bullets were received in the Haiti State University Hospital (Morne a Tuf). Two of the wounded died. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. At least 23 injured, and least 2 fatalities, split across 2 events.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 28 February 2024, in Petion Ville - Academie, Ouest, the Vitelhomme gang attacked the National Police Academy (Academie neighbourhood) with heavy machinery and broke a section of the institution's wall. As police forces responded, two gangsters were killed. Gunshots were heard in Pernier and on the Frere Road. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. 2 fatalities.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; AP; GardaWorld; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 29 February 2024, in Tabarre - Mais Gate/Clercine 2, Ouest, gang members shot and injured a police officer as they attacked the Toussaint Louverture International Airport and the Guy Malary Terminal, in Mais Gate/Clercine 2 neighbourhood. At least one airport worker was injured by the bullets. Passengers were seen jumping to the ground to avoid being shot. Three aircrafts and several facilities were hit by the gunshots. Flights were suspended. Gunshots were heard in Clercine, on the 15 Octobre Boulevard, and near the US Embassy. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative. The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. At least 2 injured.

source: AP; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Vi Free Press
notes: On 21 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members on the Saint-Honore street as they tried to repel a gang attack against the National Palace (Champs de Mars neighbourhood). Several gang members were killed. A civilian got a leg shot and injured. He was assisted by security forces. Gunshots were heard near the general hospital, the National Palace, the National Penitentiary (Champs de Mars), and in Poste Marchand, where a young man was hit by a stray bullet while at home. He died later in hospital. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: AP; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 24 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Morne a Tuf, Ouest, overnight, gang members (likely from the Base 5 Secondes Gang and the Viv Ansanm Gang) perpetrated an attack on the Reunion and Enterrement streets (Morne a Tuf), and around the National Palace (coded separately), and set fire to vehicles inside an open-air garage, to houses, business establishments, and goods. A Peace Court was burned. Casualties unknown.

source: AP; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: On 27 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Canape-Vert, Ouest, an unspecified number of dead bodies were found on nearby streets after the gang members entered the Canape-Vert neighbourhood. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 31 March 2024, in L'Estere, Artibonite, overnight, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang as they set fire to a private vehicle, several houses, a mill, and a rice warehouse in the commune. During the attack there was an exchange of shots ( unknown with whom) and two gang members were shot and killed. 2 fatalities.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 2 February 2024, in Bassin Bleu, Nord-Ouest, armed group members from Tibwadom kidnapped the Bassin Bleu mayor and several other people. The armed individuals looted the mayor's house and then released him. The other victims remained captive. Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 8 January 2024, in Bassin Bleu, Nord-Ouest, overnight, gang members decapitated a man and a woman as they returned from a business establishment that they owned. 2 fatalities.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; AP; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: On 25 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, police and military forces clashed with gang members near the National Palace (in Champs de Mars neighbourhood), where a ceremony was being held for the installation of a National Transitional Council -TPC- (coded separately). During clashes, at least three people were killed and several others were injured (affiliation unspecified). At least two of the injured were military officers who got shot on the Saint-Honore street. The gang members were described as affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative (Viv Ansanm gang). They had claimed to oppose the installation of the TPC. The gang members occupied the Nazon Road and gunshots were heard in the nearby Bel Air neighbourhood. At least 3 fatalities, at least 2 injured.

On 18 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite Soleil, Ouest, police forces in an armoured vehicle shot and injured a civilian man while he was collecting wood in an area under the control of the gangs. 1 injured.

Other: On 23 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard near the National Palace (in Champs de Mars neighbourhood). The circumstances and the authorship of the gunshots were not clarified, although the shooters were likely to be gang members, who had clashed with police forces in the area the day prior (coded separately).

source: AP; GardaWorld; Metropole; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vi Free Press
notes: On 2 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, gang members assaulted the Solino and Nazon neighborhoods (coded separately) and burned some residents' houses. Police forces intervened and clashed with the gangsters, who seemed to be affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative (Viv Ansanm gang). Clashes between police forces and gang members were also mentioned near the National Palace (in Champs de Mars, coded separately). Gunshots were heard throughout the day and overnight in the area, as well as in Christ-Roi. Some residents fled their homes. Casualties unknown.

source: AP; GardaWorld; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vi Free Press
notes: On 2 May 2024, in Delmas - Cite Numero Un, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, gang members assaulted Delmas 18 and Delmas 22 (in Cite Numero Un neighborhood), and Delmas 24 (in Delmas 28 neighborhood, coded separately). Some residents' houses were burned. Police forces intervened and clashed with gangsters, who seemed to be affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative (Viv Ansanm gang). Gunshots were heard throughout the day and overnight in the area, as well as in Siloe, Delmas 33, and Catalpa. Some residents fled their homes. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Vi Free Press
notes: On 12 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members on the Anglade street, in the Solino neighbourhood, as they intervened to expel the criminals from the area. Two teenager boys were shot and killed, while several civilians were injured. The gang members were described as affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative (a.k.a. Viv Ansanm Gang). 2 fatalities, several injured.

On 13 May 2024, near Dessalines, Artibonite, the Kokorat San Ras Gang kidnapped a peace judge man in the Estere commune and a lawyer man when they were riding a motorcycle along the Mapou Road (in Marchand Dessalines) on their way home. Both men were killed. The judge's corpse was found a day later in a forested area in Lacroix-Perisse. 2 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; AP; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; L'Oeil Mondial Info; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vi Free Press
notes: On 23 May 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, overnight, members of the Living Together gang-led initiative (a.k.a. Viv Ansanm Gang) moving in three trucks ambushed three Evangelical missionaries (a US woman, a US man, and a Haitian man) who were travelling in a vehicle with their children. The attack happened moments after the victims had left a church in the Lizon neighbourhood, in La Plaine du Cul-de-Sac area. The gang members beat up the US man and forced him to drive them to his home, where the three missionaries were killed. The property was looted and the corpse of the US missionary was found tied up and partially burned. Another version stated that the Haitian man, who was the local head of the missionary group they belonged to, was directly killed after being recognized for his work. The three used to work at the Bon Espoir orphanage. The US citizens were the daughter and son-in-law of a local politician from Missouri (US). The bodies were retrieved through the mediation of the Kraze Barye Gang (Vitelhomme Gang), which was said not to be involved in the attack. A suspect was arrested in August 2024. More than 100 gang members were thought to have participated in the attack. A person was arrested as a suspect in this case on 22 August 2024. 3 fatalities.

source: AP; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti
notes: Property destruction: On 27 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Canape-Vert, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang set fire to the Superior Normal School (ENS) facilities. It is known that the building was unoccupied when the attack took place.

source: Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 23 July 2024, near Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, armed members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang kidnapped a Christian pastor and former departmental delegate of the Artibonite as he was travelling in a public transport vehicle along the National Road 1. The abductors forced the victim to exit the vehicle and took him to an unknown location. They asked for a ransom of 500,000 gourdes as a condition for his release. After being paid, the abductors asked for 2,5 million additional gourdes. His whereabouts are unknown.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Trinidad and Tobago Guardian
notes: On 19 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, in the morning, thousands of residents took to the streets in the Solino, Nazon (coded separately), and Lalue neighborhoods (coded separately) to decry insecurity and violence by the Viv Ansanm Gang. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires and blocked the Martin Luther King Avenue (a.k.a. Nazon Road), as well as the John Brown Avenue, among others. They also used parked vehicles to block roads in the Nazon neighbourhood. Police forces used tear gas to disperse them. A woman was affected by the tear gas. The demonstration was held after a set of gang attacks against the Solino neighbourhood in recent days (coded separately).

source: AFP; Alterpresse; AP; GardaWorld; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 18 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Saint Antoine/Lalue, Ouest, for the fifth consecutive day, the Belair Gang, supported by the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu) and the Grand-Ravine Gang engaged in armed clashes with rival gangsters in the Solino neighborhood, Poupelard Avenue (Lalue neighborhood), and the Airport Road. According to a witness, at least six people were killed as the gangsters set up roadblocks and burned some houses. An unknown number were injured. Later that day, police forces were deployed and clashed with the armed men (coded separately). The National Human Rights Defense Network's director claimed that at least 20 people were killed between 14 and 18 January as a result of gang clashes in Port-au-Prince. The Organization of Hearts for Change for Deprived Children (OCCED'H) stated that at least 7 children were shot and injured in the same period. At least 7 injured split across ten events. At least 20 fatalities split across ten events, 2 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 29 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Portail Leogane/Cite Louverture, Ouest, gang members (likely G-9 members due to ongoing coordinated attacks) burned the Portail Leogane police station. One source stated that the building was empty when the arson attack took place. A different version stated that some officers were inside, although they were not injured. Clashes with police forces also took place in Saint-Honore Street (Morne a Tuf, coded separately). Gunshots were heard in Bicentenaire, Carrefour-Feuilles, Bel Air, Bas Delmas, Post Marchand, Champs de Mars, and Morne a Tuf areas. An Education Centre on Allerte Street was vandalized while two trader women were killed on the Magloire Amboise Avenue (Bas Peu de Choses, coded separately). At least 25 people injured by the bullets were received in the Haiti State University Hospital (Morne a Tuf). Two of the wounded died. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. At least 23 injured, and least 2 fatalities, split across 2 events.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 29 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu De Choses, Ouest, an Education Centre on Allerte Street was vandalized while two trader women were killed on the Magloire Amboise Avenue (Bas Peu de Choses) by gang members (likely G-9 members due to ongoing coordinated attacks). Clashes between the gang and police forces also took place in Saint-Honore Street (Morne a Tuf, coded separately), and they burned the Portail Leogane police station (coded separately). Gunshots were heard in Bicentenaire, Carrefour-Feuilles, Bel Air, Bas Delmas, Post Marchand, Champs de Mars, and Morne a Tuf areas. At least 25 people injured by the bullets were received in the Haiti State University Hospital (Morne a Tuf). Two of the wounded died. This was part of a set of coordinated attacks led by the G-9 Gang leader, who claimed responsibility, and supported by gangs aligned to the Living Together Movement gang-led initiative (coded separately). The G-9 leader was seen in a video announcing his intentions of seizing the police chief and government ministers and preventing Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry, from returning to Haiti. The PM was in Kenya on a government visit. 2 fatalities.

source: AP; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 24 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Cite de Dieu, Ouest, overnight, in Village de Dieu, gang members opened fire on a helicopter flying over the South of the capital. Casualties unknown.

source: AP; GardaWorld; Metropole; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vi Free Press
notes: On 2 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, gang members assaulted the Solino (coded separately) and Nazon neighborhoods and burned some residents' houses. Police forces intervened and clashed with the gangsters, who seemed to be affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative (Viv Ansanm gang). Clashes between police forces and gang members were also mentioned near the National Palace (in Champs de Mars, coded separately). Gunshots were heard throughout the day and overnight in the area, as well as in Christ-Roi. Some residents fled their homes. Casualties unknown.

source: AP; GardaWorld; Metropole; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vi Free Press
notes: On 2 May 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, clashes between police forces and gang members, who seemed to be affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative (Viv Ansanm gang), took place near the National Palace. Clashes also took place in the Solino and Nazon neighborhoods (both coded separately). Gunshots were heard throughout the day and overnight in the area, as well as in Christ-Roi. Some residents fled their homes. Casualties unknown.

source: AP; GardaWorld; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vi Free Press
notes: On 2 May 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, gang members assaulted Delmas 24 (in Delmas 28 neighborhood), besides Delmas 18 and Delmas 22 (in Cite Numero Un neighborhood, coded separately). Some residents' houses were burned. Police forces intervened and clashed with gangsters, who seemed to be affiliates of the Living Together gang-led initiative (Viv Ansanm gang). Gunshots were heard throughout the day and overnight in the area, as well as in Siloe, Delmas 33, and Catalpa. Some residents fled their homes. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Trinidad and Tobago Guardian
notes: On 19 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, in the morning, thousands of residents took to the streets in the Solino (coded separately), Nazon, and Lalue neighborhoods (coded separately) to decry insecurity and violence by the Viv Ansanm Gang. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires and blocked the Martin Luther King Avenue (a.k.a. Nazon Road), as well as the John Brown Avenue, among others. They also used parked vehicles to block roads in the Nazon neighbourhood. Police forces used tear gas to disperse them. A woman was affected by the tear gas. The demonstration was held after a set of gang attacks against the Solino neighbourhood in recent days (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Trinidad and Tobago Guardian
notes: On 19 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Saint Antoine/Lalue, Ouest, in the morning, thousands of residents took to the streets in the Solino (coded separately), Nazon (coded separately), and Lalue neighborhoods to decry insecurity and violence by the Viv Ansanm Gang. Demonstrators set up barricades of burning tires and blocked the Martin Luther King Avenue (a.k.a. Nazon Road), as well as the John Brown Avenue, among others. They also used parked vehicles to block roads in the Nazon neighbourhood. Police forces used tear gas to disperse them. A woman was affected by the tear gas. The demonstration was held after a set of gang attacks against the Solino neighbourhood in recent days (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; AP; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Progres; L'Oeil Mondial Info; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vi Free Press
notes: On 23 May 2024, in Bon Repos, Ouest, overnight, suspected members of the Vivi Ansanm gang alliance who had been involved in the kidnapping and killing of three missionaries (coded separately) clashed with other gang members inside the house where the bodies of the missionaries were found. According to latest reports, the gang members who took the victims to the house (Viv Asanm) were different from the gangsters who killed them moments later. One source stated that as the members of a second gang arrived to the property (BINUH identified them as Canaan Gang members) and a gangster got shot and killed (assumed by the other gang members). Other versions suggest that the missionaries were killed during this clash after being caught in the cross-fire. 1 fatality.

source: AP; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 18 September 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, overnight, armed gang members traveling on a motorcycle shot and killed the regional director of the National Office of Migration (ONM) when he was on the street near his home, in the so called 'Pon Gran Bwa' area (drive-by). 1 fatality.

Around 11 October 2024 (as reported), in L'Estere , Artibonite, police forces supported by Kenyan police officers from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MSS) engaged in armed clashes with the Kokorat San Ras Gang. Several gang members were killed. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 8 October 2024, around Johanisse, Artibonite, police forces engaged in armed clashes with the Kokorat San Ras Gang during anti-gang operation in the communal section of Croix-Perisse. During clashes, at least two gang members were killed and two police officers were injured. Other gang members managed to flee. At least 2 fatalities, 2 injured.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Haiti Standard; La Jornada; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Ordre des Defenseurs des Droits Humains (ORDEDH); Vi Free Press
notes: On 10 October 2024, in Bercy, Ouest, in the early morning, members of the Taliban Gang coming from Canaan area opened fire on the population and set fire to houses as they launched an armed offensive in Bercy, Arcahaie, and Vignier villages (coded separately). At least two people were killed and several got injured. More than 4,600 residents fled their homes in Bercy and Arcahaie (1er Boucassin communal section). At least 2 fatalities split across three events, 1 coded in this event.

source: AP; Haiti Standard; La Jornada; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Ordre des Defenseurs des Droits Humains (ORDEDH); Vi Free Press
notes: On 10 October 2024, in Vignier, Ouest, in the early morning, members of the Taliban Gang coming from Canaan area opened fire on the population and set fire to houses as they launched an armed offensive in Vignier, Arcahaie, and Bercy villages (coded separately). At least two people were killed and several got injured. At least 2 fatalities split across three events, 1 coded in this event.
Non-violent activity: On 9 October 2024, in Johanisse, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang extorted civilians at a toll booth installed by the criminals on the National Road 1.
Non-violent activity: Around 15 September 2024 (month of), in Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang installed a toll booth on the National Road 1.

On 10 October 2024, in Johanisse, Artibonite, Canaan gang members killed four people and injured more than 70 (including 23 children, and 22 women) as they attacked residents in the village. Several houses and vehicles were set on fire. Some residents fled their homes. 4 fatalities, at least 70 injured.

On 10 October 2024, in Johanisse, Artibonite, police forces engaged in armed clashes with the Canaan Gang as they intervened to expel the criminals from the village. Several gang members were killed. The police intervention took place after the gang members attacked residents in Johanisse earlier that day (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 10 October 2024, in Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, the Kokorat San Ras Gang kidnapped two men on the National Road 1. The victims were the Saint-Marc School District Office's head inspector, and a messenger man. They were on their way to Gonaives when the abductors intercepted them on the road. Their whereabouts are unknown.

On 11 October 2024, in Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, the Kokorat San Ras Gang kidnapped several dozen people on the National Road 1. The gang's leader threatened to kill them if security forces from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) do not stop intervening in the area. Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 12 October 2024, in Tabarre - Torcelle, Ouest, Haitian police forces supported by Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) engaged in armed clashes with the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) during anti-gang operations in Torcelle. Twenty gang members were killed and several others were injured during clashes on 12 and 14 October. The gang's second leader was among the injured. 15 firearms, 11 assault riffles, ammunition, and other materials were seized by security forces. 20 fatalities split across two events, 10 fatalities coded here. Several injured.

On 17 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - St-Michel, Ouest, gang members (likely from the Belair Gang and in support of the Viv Ansanm Gang) attacked residents in St-Michel and in Solino (coded separately). An unknown number of civilians were killed or injured during these attacks. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; AP; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 17 October 2024, in Tabarre - Tabarre 27, Ouest, police forces clashed with dozens of Viv Ansanm gang members as the criminals attacked residents in Tabarre 27 (coded separately). A land belonging to the so-called 'Roc Solide' Church and some residents' houses were set on fire. The church was about to be burned, but police forces prevented it. Several acts of vandalism were registered in the municipality of Tabarre. It is still unknown if there were casualties among civilians. Casualties unknown.

On 18 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, police and military forces supported by Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) clashed with members of the Belair Gang as the criminals continued attacking residents in Solino. The criminals fired shots and set fire to homes in Solino, Tabarre 27, and St-Michel neighborhoods (coded separately). According to residents and media, the leader of the Viv Ansanm Gang was the mastermind of the offensive in Solino. Between 17 and 20 October, at least 10 gang members were killed by security forces and there were at least 2 fatalities among civilians in the Solino neighbourhood. More than 5,000 civilians in Solino were displaced between 16 and 21 October. At least 12 fatalities split across four events, 3 fatalities coded here.

On 18 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - St-Michel, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, gang members (likely from the Belair Gang) attacked residents as they fired shots and set fire to homes in St-Michel, Tabarre 27, and Solino neighborhoods (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 18 October 2024, in Tabarre - Tabarre 27, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, Viv Ansanm gang members attacked residents as they fired shots and set fire to homes in Tabarre 27, Solino, and St-Michel neighborhoods (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; AP; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 17 October 2024, in Tabarre - Tabarre 27, Ouest, dozens of Viv Ansanm gang members attacked residents in Tabarre 27. A land belonging to the so-called 'Roc Solide' Church and some residents' houses were set on fire. The gang members fired shots and looted a business establishment. Several acts of vandalism were registered in the municipality of Tabarre. It is still unknown if there were casualties among civilians. Casualties unknown.
Around 15 April 2024 (month of), in the commune of L'Estere, Artibonite, members of the 5 Etoiles Gang clashed with self-defense group members. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 21 October 2024, in L'Estere, Artibonite, members of the 5 Etoiles Gang (a subsidiary and allied gang of the Kokorat San Ras Gang) moving on a motorcycle opened indiscriminate fire against the Congregational Presbyterian School (drive-by) and killed at least a man (parent of a student). One of the sources stated that there could have been at least 10 fatalities among students and civilians who were leaving or near the school's compound, including a parent and the high school janitor. Several students and a 3-year-old boy were injured. At least 1 fatalities, several injured.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; AP; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: On 19 October 2024, in Tabarre - Tabarre 27, Ouest, for a third consecutive day, Viv Ansanm gang members attacked residents in Tabarre 27, Solino, and Bas Delmas neighborhoods (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; AP; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole
notes: On 20 October 2024, in Tabarre - Tabarre 27, Ouest, for a fourth consecutive day, Viv Ansanm gang members attacked residents in Tabarre 27 and Solino neighborhoods (coded separately). In Tabarre 27, some houses and vehicles were burned. Casualties unknown.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 30 October 2024, in the Dessalines commune, Artibonite, in the morning, armed members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang abducted around 10 farmers and civilians as they assaulted the Motoga community (in Dessalines' fourth communal section), and the Kleto community (in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite's second communal section) (coded separately). The exact number of farmers kidnapped in each location is unknown. The criminals stole scores of cattle heads. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

On 29 October 2024, in L'Estere, Artibonite, police forces clashed with the Kokorat San Ras Gang and the 5 Etoiles Gang after members of these gangs attacked civilians in the commune (coded separately). During clashes, several gang members were shot and injured. A woman was also shot and injured by a stray bullet. Police forces managed to expel de the criminals from the area. At least 2 injured.

source: AP; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Vi Free Press
notes: Around 15 August 2024 (as reported), in Gressier, Ouest, gang members abducted a police officer and forced him to eat mutilated parts of his body before burning him alive. 1 fatality.

source: Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 29 October 2024, in L'Estere, Artibonite, the Kokorat San Ras Gang and the 5 Etoiles Gang attacked civilians and killed at least 10 people. There was at least one injured. After the attack, police forces intervened and expelled the criminals from the area (coded separately). At least 10 fatalities, at least 1 injured.

On 30 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, gang members (likely from the Viv Ansanm Gang) attacked the Nazon neighbourhood. Gunshots were heard in the area. Hundreds of residents fled their homes and took refuge in a church. Casualties unknown.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Looting: Around 3 November 2024 (as reported), in the Dessalines commune, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang looted around 20 houses and stole livestock in the Grande-Hatte locality. The criminals used vehicles to extort and rob the farmers from their goods, and to transport what they had stolen.

source: AFP; Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 19 November 2024, in Petion Ville - Panamericaine, Ouest, in the early morning, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defence group) killed at least 18 members of the Viv Ansanm Gang on Panamericaine Avenue. Several sources stated that 10 gangsters were shot and killed by police forces as they were intercepted in a truck, while the rest were chased and killed by residents. Their bodies were set on fire in Bourdon (Port-au-Prince) (coded separately). Some of them were decapitated or had their feet cut off. In the early morning of 19 November, at least 76 gang members were killed during clashes in Petionville, Delmas, and Port-au-Prince (coded separately). At least 76 fatalities split across eight events. 18 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Libre; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 19 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Canape-Vert, Ouest, in the early morning, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defence group) shot and killed at least 25 members of the Viv Ansanm Gang during clashes in Canape-Vert. More than three gang members were lynched by members of the population. Some of them were decapitated or had their feet cut off, while their bodies were set on fire. On 19 November, at least 76 gang members were killed during clashes in Canape-Vert, Bourdon, Lalue, Christ-Roi, and Poste Marchand (Port-au-Prince), Petionville, and Delmas (coded separately). At least 76 fatalities split across eight events. 25 fatalities coded here.

On 19 November 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 60, Ouest, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defence group) chased and clashed with gang members in Delmas 60. On 19 November, at least 76 members of the Viv Ansanm Gang were killed during clashes in Delmas, Petionville, and Port-au-Prince (coded separately). Some of the gang members were decapitated or had their feet cut off, while their bodies were set on fire. At least 76 fatalities split across eight events. 8 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 19 November 2024, in Delmas - Musseau, Ouest, in the early morning, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defence group) chased and clashed with gang members. On 19 November, at least 76 members of the Viv Ansanm Gang were killed during clashes in Musseau (Delmas), and in neighbourhoods in Petionville and Port-au-Prince (coded separately). Some of the gang members were decapitated or had their feet cut off, while their bodies were set on fire. In Musseau, two corpses were found. At least 76 fatalities split across eight events. 2 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 19 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bourdon, Ouest, in the early morning, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defence group) chased and clashed with gang members. Some of the gang members were decapitated or had their feet cut off, while their bodies were set on fire. In Bourdon, an armed individual on a motorcycle and a minor boy (both considered gang members) were killed and burned. At least 76 fatalities split across eight events. 2 fatalities coded here.

On 19 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Christ-Roi, Ouest, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defence group) chased and clashed with gang members in Christ-Roi neighbourhood. On 19 November, at least 76 members of the Viv Ansanm Gang were killed during clashes in Port-au-Prince, Delmas, and Petionville on that day (coded separately). Some of the gang members were decapitated or had their feet cut off, while their bodies were set on fire. At least 76 fatalities split across eight events. 7 fatalities coded here.

Some of the gang members were decapitated or had their feet cut off, while their bodies were set on fire. In Poste Marchand, clashes erupted as the police intercepted gang members in a minibus. At least 76 fatalities split across eight events. 7 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 19 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Saint Antoine/Lalue, Ouest, in the early morning, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defence group) chased and clashed with gang members. In Saint Antoine, the gang members were intercepted in a minibus on Poupelard Avenue. They were all killed. Residents set fire to the bodies of three gangsters. Some of them were decapitated or had their feet cut off. At least 76 fatalities split across six events. 7 fatalities coded here.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: Around 21 November 2024 (between 18 - 24 November), in Dessalines, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang kidnapped and tortured 12 farmers in Marchand-Dessalines. The criminals asked for the payment of ransoms for their release. Their whereabouts are unknown.

Around 14 November 2024 (between 11 - 17 November), in Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, armed gang members (likely from the Kokorat San Ras Gang that controls the area) kidnapped a man along the National Road 1. The victim's whereabouts are unknown.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 11 December 2024, in the Dessalines commune, Artibonite, in the morning, armed members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang moving on motorcycles attacked the Haut Bou area. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Vi Free Press
notes: Non-violent activity: On 6 December 2024, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, the Micanord Gang imposed movement restrictions in the Waaf Jeremie neighborhood that prevented residents from leaving the area. The measure was imposed as the leader of the gang prepared an offensive against elderly residents and voodoo practitioners whom he accused of harming his son through witchcraft. The offensive was launched later that day and lasted until 8 December (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; AP; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; InSight Crime; Jamaica Observer; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Reuters; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 6 December 2024, in Cite Soleil - Waaf Jeremie, Ouest, around 300 members of the Micanord Gang killed at least 242 civilians (at least 134 men and 73 women) as they attacked residents in the Waaf Jeremie neighborhood, between 6 and 11 December. 127 victims were identified as elderly people (90 men and 37 women) and voodoo practitioners whose corpses were mutilated and set on fire on the streets. Other victims were decapitated or buried alive. Witnesses confirmed the killing of young individuals and moto-taxi drivers who tried to flee with elderly victims and well-known community leaders who were taken to the gang's stronghold for execution. The attack was ordered by the leader of the gang, Micanord Altes, and at least two versions were given on his motivations. The most extended one explained the attack as an act of revenge after seeking advice from a voodoo priest who had accused elderly people in the area of harming his son through witchcraft (he died from illness on 8 December). The gang leader blamed the victims for his child's passing. He ordered his gang members to burn their mothers' homes. Those who refused and fled were chased and their families were killed. Another version stated that the criminal collectively sacrificed the victims to strengthen his mystical power. The RNDDH stated that at least 60 elderly people were killed with bullets or machetes on 6 December. Between 6 and 11 December, ACLED recorded 242 fatalities. Other sources estimate that the attacks resulted in 222 fatalities. At least 242 fatalities split across six events. 60 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; AP; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; InSight Crime; Jamaica Observer; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Reuters; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 7 December 2024, in Cite Soleil - Waaf Jeremie, Ouest, the Micanord Gang killed at least 242 civilians (at least 134 men and 73 women) as they attacked residents in the Waaf Jeremie neighborhood, between 6 and 11 December. The RNDDH stated that at least 70 people were killed with machetes and knives on 7 December. The criminals also kidnapped 57 residents (33 men and 24 women) participating in a voodoo ceremony. The victims were taken to the gang base, where they were killed the day later (coded separately). 127 victims were identified as elderly people and voodoo practitioners whose corpses were mutilated and set on fire on the streets. Other victims were decapitated or buried alive. Witnesses confirmed the killing of young individuals and moto-taxi drivers who tried to flee with elderly victims and well-known community leaders who were taken to the gang's stronghold for execution. The attack was ordered by the leader of the gang, Micanord Altes, and at least two versions were given on his motivations. The most extended one explained the attack as an act of revenge after seeking advice from a voodoo priest who had accused elderly people in the area of harming his son through witchcraft (he died from illness on 8 December). The gang leader blamed the victims for his child's passing. He ordered his gang members to burn their mothers' homes. Those who refused and fled were chased and their families were killed. Another version stated that the criminal collectively sacrificed the victims to strengthen his mystical power. Between 6 and 11 December, ACLED recorded 242 fatalities. Other sources estimate that the attacks resulted in 222 fatalities. At least 242 fatalities split across six events. 70 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; AP; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Observer; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Reuters; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 8 December 2024, in Cite Soleil - Waaf Jeremie, Ouest, the Micanord Gang killed at least 242 civilians (at least 134 men and 73 women) as they attacked residents in the Waaf Jeremie neighborhood, between 6 and 11 December. On 8 December, 57 residents (33 men and 24 women) who had been kidnapped by the criminals the day prior (coded separately) were executed in an area known as 'Nan Mangue'. Their bodies were thrown to the sea. 60 other residents were kidnapped and taken to a gang base. They were released on 11 December (coded separately). Between 6 and 8 December, 127 victims were identified as elderly people and voodoo practitioners whose corpses were mutilated and set on fire on the streets. Other victims were decapitated or buried alive. Witnesses confirmed the killing of young individuals and moto-taxi drivers who tried to flee with elderly victims and well-known community leaders who were taken to the gang's stronghold for execution. The attack was ordered by the leader of the gang, Micanord Altes, and at least two versions were given on his motivations. The most extended one explained the attack as an act of revenge after seeking advice from a voodoo priest who had accused elderly people in the area of harming his son through witchcraft (he died from illness on 8 December). The gang leader blamed the victims for his child's passing. He ordered his gang members to burn their mothers' homes. Those who refused and fled were chased and their families were killed. Another version stated that the criminal collectively sacrificed the victims to strengthen his mystical power. Between 6 and 11 December, ACLED recorded 242 fatalities. Other sources estimate that the attacks resulted in 222 fatalities. At least 242 fatalities split across six events. 57 fatalities coded here.

source: AP; Midland Daily News; Trinidad and Tobago Guardian; Vi Free Press
notes: On 5 December 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, police forces and Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) clashed with gang members at the former offices of the National Police, in Delmas. Casualties unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 9 January 2024, in Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang abducted 10 people (four women and six men) from a minibus. Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 20 January 2024, in Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang abducted 10 people (four women and six men) from a pickup truck. Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 7 April 2024, near Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, the Kokorat San Ras Gang killed a self-defense group member in the Joanis village. 1 fatality.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 7 April 2024, in Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang abducted 10 people (three men and seven women) from a pickup truck. The criminals asked for a ransom of 1,000,000 gourdes (around 7,576 USD) per hostage for their safe release. Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 24 April 2024, in Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang abducted 20 people from two pickup trucks (12 women and eight men). Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 28 May 2024, in Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang abducted 19 people from two pickup trucks (11 women and eight men). Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 15 June 2024, in Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang abducted 15 people from two pickup trucks (eight men and seven women). Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 16 June 2024, in Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang abducted 16 people from two pickup trucks (11 men and five women). Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 17 June 2024, in Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang abducted 10 people from a pickup truck (seven men and three women). Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; The St. Kitts Nevis Observer; Trip Foumi
notes: On 28 January 2025, in Kenscoff - Carrefour bete, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, gang members killed at least 25 residents as they set fire to their houses and took control of Carrefour bete neighborhood (Bongars communal section). Among the victims, there are 12 members of a family killed at a house; an elderly couple who were shot and killed at their home; at least two men who were burned at their properties (one in the Bwa Majo area). Two blind women killed in a house in Lafontant area; a pastor and a deacon of the Conservatory Baptist Church (Protestant Christian), and a woman in Tet Mon area. Among dead bodies that were found on the roads, four people were identified, including two women. A 95-year-old man who went missing was later reported as kidnapped. He was released on 10 July after the payment of a ransom. This was part of a coordinated armed offensive by the Base 5 Secondes Gang, the Grand-Ravine Gang, and the Ti Bwa Gang (affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang) against the Kenscoff commune (coded separately). A report clarified that the offensive was linked to a plan led by the Didi Gang to take control of the close Petionville commune. Between 26 and 30 January, at least 127 civilians had been killed by gangs in Kenscoff and Petionville during the attacks of the Viv Ansanm Gang (up to 150 according to some sources though most of these fatalities remain unconfirmed). At least 127 fatalities split across 26 events. 25 fatalities coded here.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Vi Free Press
notes: On 23 February 2025, near La Ville, Artibonite, police forces and Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MSS), supported by self-defense group members from Jean-Denis, clashed with the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang as these ones attacked a MSS strategic base in Segur (Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite's 2nd communal section). During clashes, a Kenyan police officer was injured and at least one gang member was killed. The Kenyan officer died later that day. Other criminals were arrested. At least 2 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 24 February 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 60, Ouest, scores of police officers affiliated to the national police trade union (SPNH-17) and about two dozen civilian employees held a sit-in protest with banners in front of the Villa d'Accueil (building hosting the Transitional Presidential Council) to demand that authorities provide security forces with appropriate equipment and materials to fight the violence of gangs. Protesting officers also called for the payment of due salaries.

On 12 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Saint Gerard, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang near the Oloffson hotel. Many residents fled their homes to take refuge elsewhere. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 12 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour Feuilles, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, police forces clashed with members of the Viv Ansanm Gang as the criminals looted and set fire to residents' houses. During clashes, a group of priests got trapped inside a church in the neighborhood. According to witnesses, two people were shot and injured (affiliation unclarified). Later that day, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out drone strikes against gang targets in the neighborhood (coded separately). Several sources stated that they managed to stop the criminals. 2 injured.

source: AP; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 15 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bois Verna, Ouest, gang members opened fire on a Doctors Without Borders (MSF) four-vehicle convoy as staff members engaged in the evacuation of the MSF center known as 'Physicians Sans Frontieres-Centre D'urgence Turgeau'. During the attack, several staff members suffered minor injuries, although there were no fatalities. The mentioned MSF center is located along the Ch. Summer Avenue, in Bois Verna. Its evacuation was ordered due to armed clashes between the police and gang members nearby on 14 March overnight (coded separately). There were no fatalities.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: AFP; Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Standard; Jamaica Observer; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Trip Foumi; Xinhua
notes: On 25 March 2025, around Pont Sonde, Artibonite, police forces supported by Kenyan officers from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MSS) clashed with the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. During clashes, a police armored vehicle got stuck in a ditch dug by the gang members. As two other armored vehicles came to rescue, one of them fell into a hole, while the other broke down. The gangsters set fire to the three vehicles. Two gang members were killed. A Kenyan officer disappeared. His dead body was later shown on an online video with gang members kicking the corpse, which was later chopped and burned. The criminals refused to return the body despite the police's attempts for negotiation. 3 fatalities.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: Around 21 March 2025 (between 20 - 21 March), in the Dessalines commune, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang attacked residents and opened indiscriminate fire against them in the Grande-Hatte locality. A young woman was killed and her body was set on fire. At least 1 fatality.

source: Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Radio Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 8 April 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, police forces clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in Carrefour Peligre, near the Mirebalais communal market. During clashes, a police officer, a self-defense brigade member (likely a member of the Bakop Feray Mirebalais self-defense group which have engaged in similar clashes in previous days), and 11 other people were killed. Clashes took place amidst police anti-gang interventions in Mirebalais, which had been under gang attack since 31 March (coded separately). At least 13 fatalities.

Non-violent activity: Around 22 April 2025 (as reported), in Lacroix-Perisse, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang set up a toll booth on the National Road #1 between Gonaives and L'Estere. Residents claimed that armed individuals were present along the road to get money from drivers. They only allow public transport vehicles to go through.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 24 April 2025, in Poste Pierrot, Artibonite, gang members attacked residents in the Grand Hatte locality, which is part of the Poste Pierrot communal section (Dessalines' 4th communal section). Two people were shot and injured, while 13 houses were set on fire. The criminals were likely affiliates of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang, whose members attacked locations in the Bas Artibonite on several occasions between 26 and 28 April (coded separately). 2 injured.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: AP; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Vi Free Press
notes: On 30 April 2025, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, police forces and self-defense brigades clashed with the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang and the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition in the Crete-a-Pierrot fort, as part of efforts to expel the criminals from the commune, which was under gang attack since the early morning (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 3 May 2025, in the Dessalines commune, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang killed several members of the same family, among other civilians, in the Duvallon communal section (a.k.a. Fosse-Naboth) (Dessalines' 2nd communal section). The head of Radio-Tele Mike FM claimed that the attack was a reprisal against the La Coalition self-defense brigade, whose affiliates are originals from the area, although the identify of the victims was described as civilian. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 4 May 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, several scores of residents held a march through the hills of Port-au-Prince demanding the departure of the Presidential Transitional Council (CPT), as well as calling for measures against the violence of gangs.

source: Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 12 May 2025, in Anse-d'Hainault, Grande-Anse, residents set fire to the police station, forcing the officers to abandon the premises, and to a police vehicle, in retaliation for the police killing of two family members as they opened fire on a group armed with machetes who tried to forcibly free a murder suspect from custody. Police explained their response was in self-defence. A third man was seriously injured during the incident. 2 fatalities. 1 injured.

On 15 May 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 40b, Ouest, residents demonstrated against the poor job they believe the Transition Presidential Council (CPT) has been doing. They erected burning tires during the mobilization. Police officers intervened with tear gas as well as rubber bullets to disperse the crowd, injuring two people. 2 injured.
