On 10 May 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) carried out five drone airstrikes in areas that had been taken over by gang members, killing at least 18 of them and injuring several others. At least 18 fatalities. Several injured.

Other: On 11 May 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Fermathe. Although there is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots, they are likely related to ongoing gang activity in the area.

On 13 May 2025, in Kenscoff - Furcy, Ouest, hundreds of armed gang members attacked the neighborhood, firing gunshots, vandalizing, looting and setting fire to houses. Residents were forced to flee the area. Casualties unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 31 March 2025, in the Saut-d'Eau commune, Centre, police forces and members of a local self-defense brigade (likely from the Mirebalais Bakop Feray group) engaged in clashes with the Canaan Gang, whose members had attacked the La Selle communal section (Saut-d'Eau 2nd communal section) since the early morning (coded separately) as part of an offensive orchestrated by the Viv Ansanm Gang. During clashes, no casualties were registered among police forces, civilians, or gang members, although these ones were expelled and fled to their stronghold in Canaan (Croix-des-Bouquets). There were no casualties.

actor1: Police Forces of Haiti (2024-) Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP)
source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 13 March 2025, in Gressier - La Salle Pte Place, Ouest, BSAP agents supported by members of the population carrying machetes killed four gang members out of a group of 103 occupying the premises of the Peres Salesians de Don Bosco School, located in la Colline area. The BSAP agents shot and killed a security guard suspected of being collaborating with the criminals. 5 fatalities.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 18 March 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Christ-Roi, Ouest, members of a self-defense brigade killed 13 affiliates of the Delmas 6 Gang in a surprise attack at abandoned houses that the criminals had occupied. 13 fatalities.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 10 March 2025, in Gressier - La Salle Pte Place, Ouest, members of the 103 Zombies Gang killed with a machete a 16-year-old boy at a square in Laferronay area in front of his friends. The killing was in reprisal for the lynching of three gang members earlier that day in the Nan-Boy zone (coded separately). 1 fatality.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 16 February 2025 (between 11 - 22 February), around Bois d'Orme, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang attacked and killed residents in the Morne a Cabrit area. The victims were accused of being police snitches. Between 11 and 22 February, at least 42 people were killed and five were injured during 400 Mawozo attacks against Morne a Cabrit and several neighborhoods in Croix-des-Bouquets downtown (coded separately). 42 fatalities split across three events. 32 coded here.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 16 March 2025, in Cite Soleil - Belecou, Ouest, the leader of a gang controlling the neighborhood (likely the Belekou Gang) shot and killed 11 people at their houses on Ruelle La Paix Street. The victims were accused of being police collaborators. 11 fatalities.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 21 March 2025, in Trianon, Centre, the Canaan Gang attacked residents in Trianon after the leader of the gang threaten to do so in reprisal for the setting up of a barricade along the National Road 3 by the Trianon Bakop Feray self-defense group on 19 March (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 6 February 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 17, Ouest, the Delmas 6 Gang attacked residents in the neighborhoods. Casualties unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 25 March 2025 (as reported), in La Porte, Artibonite, the leader of a gang operating in La Porte and Hatte Chevaux killed two residents. The killing motivated a reprisal attack against the gang leader's family in Hatte Chevaux (coded separately). 2 fatalities.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 20 March 2025, in Gressier - Santo, Ouest, residents held a protest over unclarified claims in the neighborhood. Gang members who were at their base in Santo opened fire on the crowd as the protest crossed the area. A person was killed and four others were injured. 1 fatality, 4 injured.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Property destruction: On 18 December 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, unidentified individuals looted and set fire to a hospital in the capital, forcing its closure.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 10 March 2025, in Gressier - La Salle Pte Place, Ouest, a mob of residents lynched to death three members of the 103 Zombies Gang in the Nan-Boy zone. The lynching motivated a gang attack in reprisal that left a 16-year-old boy killed in Laferronay later that day (coded separately). 3 fatalities.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Non-violent activity: On 19 March 2025, in Trianon, Centre, members of the Bakop Feray self-defense group set up a barricade along the National Road 3 with cement blocks and abandoned vehicles to prevent deliveries of drugs coming from the Dominican Republic as well as to prevent access to gang members. The action sparked a reprisal attack by the Canaan Gang on 21 March (coded separately).

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 24 February 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bicentenaire, Ouest, police officers supported by a trade union representing their interests held a sit-in protest in front of the Primature building (Bicentenaire) to demand better working conditions.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 18 February 2025 (between 17 - 18 February), in Kenscoff, Ouest, members of the Grand-Ravine Gang kidnapped a young woman and raped her on several occasions during captivity. She was forced to guide the criminals through mountainous zones of the commune as they prepared themselves for a gang offensive against Kenscoff. The victim managed to escape on 18 February.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: Around 15 March 2025 (month of), in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, several members of the Grand-Ravine Gang raped at least three victims before killing them at their homes. At least 3 fatalities.

On 13 April 2025, in Petion Ville - Nan Madeleine, Ouest, overnight, the Viv Ansanm Gang fired shots and burned residents' houses as they attacked the Nan Madeleine neighborhood, among others in the Petionville and Kenscoff communes (coded separately). Police intervened and clashed with gang members. A police officer was injured, several vehicles were burned, and some civilians fled their homes. 1 injured.

On 5 February 2024, near Morpeau, Ouest, government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister (PM), Ariel Henry. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires in the Lizon neighbourhood. The demonstration, which was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti). It was supported by the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) police, although their presence was not mentioned.

On 12 February 2024, in Sibert, Ouest, gang members from the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang clashed with the rival gang led by Ti Gabriel. Another version states that the clash was between members of the Chien Mechant Gang and the Canaan Gang. This was part of a gang war for territory and for the control of economic activity in the targeted areas. Some residents fled their homes. More than 20 people were killed amidst gang clashes near Marin and in Sibert. At least 20 bodies were found burned in the Marie Madeleine zone. At least 20 fatalities split across two events. 10 fatalities coded for this event.
Other: On 6 February 2024, in Hatte Lathan, Ouest, roadblocks were set up on the Route Nationale #1. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblocks or who set them up.
Other: On 3 February 2024, close to Sibert, Ouest, gunshots were heard. They were also heard in the Fourgy crossroad area. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 6 February 2024, in Sibert, Ouest, gunshots were heard. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

On 21 May 2024, in Hatte Lathan, Ouest, armed gang members attacked and set fire to the Cesse-Lesse police station (a.k.a. Corail police station). The attack was attributed to the Living-Together gang-led initiative (a.k.a. Viv Ansanm Gang). Casualties unknown.
Looting: Around 3 October 2024 (as reported), in Morpeau, Ouest, armed gang members looted the Tamarinier laboratory of the Ministry of Agriculture, Natural Resources, and Rural Development (MARNDR).

source: Amerique Info 7; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 22 October 2024, in Williamson, Ouest, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defence group) shot and killed at least 22 members of the Canaan Gang and the Grand-Ravine Gang (part of the Viv Ansanm Gang) during an anti-gang operation (up to 30 according to other sources). The police intervention followed a gang offensive against the Arcahaie population on 21 October (coded separately). At least 22 fatalities.

Around 19 October 2024 (between 17 - 21 October), in Saint-Meddard, Ouest, the Canaan Gang supported by the 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang) attacked residents in the Carrefour Poy area. The criminals also attacked the nearby Robert locality (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
Other: On 16 October 2024, in Williamson, Ouest, a truck was used to set up a roadblock on the Route Nationale #1. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

On 22 October 2024, in Saint-Meddard, Ouest, police forces shot and killed around 15 gang members during clashes in Carrefour-Poy area (Saint-Meddard), Tamand (not found), and the nearby Vignier locality (coded separately). At least 15 fatalities split across two events, 7 fatalities coded in this event.

Around 10 October 2024 (as reported), in Williamson, Ouest, the Taliban Gang killed around 20 civilians as they attacked and set fire to their houses. Scores of residents were kidnapped. Their whereabouts are unknown. The Taliban Gang also attacked nearby Vignier and Bercy villages on 10 October (coded separately). At least 20 fatalities.

actor1: Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang
notes: Around 9 December 2024 (between 8 - 10 December), in the Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune, Artibonite, members of La Coalition self-defense group killed at least two members of the Palmiste Gang. Between 8 and 10 December, at least 150 individuals were lynched among gang members and civilians in the commune. 150 fatalities split across six events, 2 fatalities coded here.

actor1: Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang
notes: Around 9 December 2024 (between 8 - 10 December), in the Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune, Artibonite, members of La Coalition self-defense group killed at least a member of a gang from Drouillard (in Cite Soleil). Between 8 and 10 December, at least 150 individuals were lynched among gang members and civilians in the commune. 150 fatalities split across six events, 1 fatality coded here.

actor1: Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang
notes: Around 9 December 2024 (between 8 - 10 December), in the Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune, Artibonite, members of La Coalition self-defense group killed at least two members of the Savien Gang. Between 8 and 10 December, at least 150 individuals were lynched among gang members and civilians in the commune. 150 fatalities split across six events, 2 fatalities coded here.

actor1: Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang
source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; Vi Free Press
notes: On 8 December 2024, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, members of La Coalition self-defense group lynched at least 25 people whom they accused of being accomplices or collaborators of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang and the Palmiste Gang. Some of the victims were killed because of their appearance, although their gang affiliation was not confirmed. Among the identified victims, there was a homosexual man, a voodoo priest, a butcher man, a moto-taxi driver, a businessman, a spaghetti vendor, and a popular soccer player. This one was set on fire while being questioned by police. Two girls identified as girlfriends of the gang members were also killed. Some victims were stabbed with knives, others killed with machetes, or burned alive. Several bodies were thrown into the Artibonite river. Between 8 and 10 December, at least 150 individuals were lynched among gang members and civilians in the commune. 150 fatalities split across six events, 25 fatalities coded here.

actor1: Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang
notes: On 9 December 2024, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, members of La Coalition self-defense group lynched at least 50 people whom they accused of being accomplices or collaborators of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang and the Palmiste Gang. Some of the victims were killed because of their appearance, although their gang affiliation was not confirmed. Some victims were stabbed with knives, others killed with machetes, or burned alive. Several bodies were thrown into the Artibonite river. Between 8 and 10 December, at least 150 individuals were lynched among gang members and civilians in the commune. 150 fatalities split across six events, 50 fatalities coded here.

actor1: Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang
notes: On 10 December 2024, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, members of La Coalition self-defense group lynched scores of people whom they accused of being accomplices or collaborators of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang and the Palmiste Gang. Some of the victims were killed because of their appearance, although their gang affiliation was not confirmed. Some victims were stabbed with knives, others killed with machetes, or burned alive. Several bodies were thrown into the Artibonite river. Between 8 and 10 December, at least 150 individuals were lynched among gang members and civilians in the commune. 150 fatalities split across six events, 70 fatalities coded here.

actor1: Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang
source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Infos Pro; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Trip Foumi; Vi Free Press
notes: On 20 May 2025, in Preval, Artibonite, the Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang (a.k.a. Jean Denis Coalition) killed at least 55 civilians, mostly farmers, but also residents, a 86-year-old pastor, 14 members of the church, and a 90-year-old woman. Some victims were shot and killed, while the majority were lynched and beheaded with machetes. Houses were set on fire. The attack was a reprisal for the killing of a Jean Denis Coalition Gang member by the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang earlier that day (coded separately). According to a Jean Denis Coalition Gang leader, the victims were innocent citizens who were targeted due to an incorrect tip they received stating that the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang had a base in the area. The initial target were farmers accused of collusion with members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. It was confirmed that all the gang affiliates escaped during the attack. At least 55 fatalities. Several injured.

On 23 May 2025, in Gonaives, Artibonite, citizens protested to demand the replacement of the police commissioner. Protesters planned to arrive to the police station, although they did not as a police truck blocked their path.

On 17 May 2025, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, residents held a demonstration by erecting burning barricades and throwing stones in the A La Foset area to decry poverty and the government neglect. The demonstration was held on the eve of the Flag Day celebration.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 18 May 2025, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, citizens protested against the government by publicly accusing president of the Transitional Presidential Council (CPT) of being incompetent and a thief. During the protest, a police officer slapped a teacher who was taking part in the mobilization. The teacher slapped him in return. Protesters also expressed frustration over the decision of moving the celebration from Arcahaie, the historic birth place of the flag, to Cap-Haitien. The mobilization was held on the occasion of the Flag Day celebration.

On 19 May 2025, in Delmas - Musseau, Ouest, several dozens of people living with HIV/AIDS (PLHIV) held a sit-in protest in from of the Villa D'Accueil against the suspension of USAID funding. They claimed it threatens treatment access for about 150,000 people.
On 19 May 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, armed individuals (likely gang members controlling the area) shot and killed a police officer during clashes in the commune. 1 fatality.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
actor2: Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang
source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 28 September 2024, in Pont Sonde, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang engaged in armed clashes with members of the so-called La Coalition self-defense group (a.k.a. Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang or Jean Denis Coalition). Clashes erupted as affiliates of this group blocked the National Road 1 (coded separately) at the height of a toll booth run by the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang (coded separately) to prevent drivers from being ransomed by the criminals. Casualties unknown.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 29 April 2025, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, for a second consecutive day, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang, supported by the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition, attacked residents, killing several dozens in the span of a few hours, and burning down dozens of houses and vehicles. An unknown number of civilians were kidnapped. Their whereabouts are unknown. This was part of a series of attacks carried out by the gangsters in several areas of the commune since 24 April (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; AP; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi; Vi Free Press
notes: On 30 April 2025, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, for a third consecutive day, in the early morning, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang, supported by the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition, attacked residents in areas around the Crete-a-Pierrot Fort, killing at least 57 people (35 men, 15 women, and seven boys) in the span of a few hours, injuring others by gunshots, raping young women, and burning down dozens of houses and vehicles. 36 civilians were kidnapped. Their whereabouts are unknown. Several dozens of residents were forced to swim or wade across the river to escape. Some of them were shot and killed, while others drowned. Following the attack, security forces and self-defense brigades intervened and clashed with the criminals (coded separately). This was part of a series of attacks carried out by the gangsters in several areas of the commune since 24 April (coded separately). At least 57 fatalities.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; AP; Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi; Vi Free Press
notes: On 30 April 2025, in the Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune, Artibonite, in the early morning, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang, supported by the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition, attacked residents in rural areas of the commune, killing several dozens in the span of a few hours, injuring others by gunshots, and burning down dozens of houses and vehicles. An unknown number of civilians were kidnapped. Their whereabouts are unknown. This was part of a series of attacks carried out by the gangsters in several areas of the commune since 24 April (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; France Info - Outre-mer La Premiere; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 13 May 2025, in Peligre, Centre, several civil society organizations from Mirebalais and Saut-d'Eau held a protest against insecurity and demanding the intervention of national authorities to restore order in their communes, recently hit by gang violence (coded separately). During the mobilization, protesting citizens closed the Peligre hydroelectric central, causing widespread blackouts across the country and especially in the capital. Activities resumed at the central on 23 May. The prolonged shutdown of the hydroelectric plant caused severe flooding. Some farmers died, and crops were destroyed.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 7 May 2025, in Delmas - Barbancourt, Ouest, overnight, members of the Simon-Pele Gang looted and set fire to the premises of the Automeca car dealership, near the Airport Road. Dozens of vehicles were burned. As the gangsters were looting the business, five women and two men who were walking nearby were intercepted by the criminals. The five women were raped before being shot. It was not clarified whether they died or not. At least 5 injured.

source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: Around 12 May 2025 (between 12 - 13 May), between Petion Ville - Pernier and Tabarre - Torcelle, Ouest, a man and a woman were killed (methods unknown) and their bodies were found in body bags with their organs harvested at a house. Several pieces of evidence, including organs in jars, were found at the property, suggesting organ trafficking. A person was arrested at the location. Two individuals were later arrested in connection with the killings. The owner of the house, who denied any knowledge about the activities that had taken place at the property, is also under investigated. The case might be related to gangs' activity in organ trafficking in the country, although no gang authorship has been confirmed so far. 2 fatalities.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
actor2: Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang
notes: On 20 May 2025, in Jean Denis, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang killed a member of the Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang (a.k.a. Jean Denis Coalition) at a yard in the Blain area. The circumstances of the attack are unknown, although it triggered a reprisal attack by the Jean Denis Coalition that resulted in the killing of at least 55 civilians later that day (coded separately). 1 fatality.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
actor2: Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang
source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 26 May 2025, around Jean Denis, Artibonite, in the morning, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang clashed with the Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang (a.k.a. Jean Denis Coalition) as they attacked residents and farmers in the Dekod, Pont Benoit, and Bwa Lavil localities. During clashes, an unspecified number of gang members were killed, as well as a member of the Jean Denis Coalition, and several civilians. The gangsters set fire to several businesses and houses, and injured several residents. The attack blocked access to emergency services and caused residents to flee the area. The attack had been announced several days ago. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 27 May 2025, in Jean Denis, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang attacked residents and farmers in the area, and set fire to their homes. Several civilians were killed or injured by gunshots. The gang offensive was a reprisal for the killing of civilians by the Jean Denis Coalition in Preval on 20 May (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
actor2: Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang
source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 28 May 2025, in Jean Denis, Artibonite, the Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang clashed with the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang as the latter attacked residents and farmers, and set fire to houses and a radio station. The gang members stole the statue of a sacred ox head and took it to Savien. Properties were also burned in the nearby Beaux Forts (Beufort) area. Several people were injured and killed. During clashes, several members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang were killed. The gang offensive was a reprisal for the killing of civilians by the Jean Denis Coalition in Preval on 20 May (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 21 April 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, the police clashed with gang members during a security operation, killing several. The police also seized three weapons. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 23 May 2025, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, hundreds of teachers and students protested against the assault of a colleague at the hands of the police during a mobilization held on the occasion of the Flag Day, on 18 May (coded separately). The protesters called for a public apology from the officers involved and demanded appropriate disciplinary action.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 23 May 2025, in Malpasse, Ouest, armed gang members led by alias Benbenn (Benbenn Gang) attacked the Malpasse customs office and assaulted customs agents and employees. They also destroyed official documents and hijacked several trucks that had been previously seized by the authorities, as well as other merchandise trucks. The assault took place after the seizure of three trucks transporting lithium batteries by the authorities several days prior. The police was present but unable to resist the attack. The gang members set up a toll station at the customs office. According to BINUH, the assault was the authorship of a self-defense group. There were no fatalities.

On 24 May 2025, in Delmas - Musseau, Ouest, dozens of Haitians living with HIV marched to the prime minister's office to protest a critical shortage of HIV medication following the Trump administration's drastic cuts to USAID funding, affecting 90% of Haiti-related contracts. Activists warned the country faces a deadly health crisis that would affect over 150,000 people living with HIV, and likely many more not officially counted. Experts also say the medication shortage, in a context of rampant poverty and gang violence, could lead to a spike in new infections, drug resistance, and preventable deaths, especially as many cannot afford the nutrition needed to support their immune systems. A similar protest was carried out on 18 May (coded separately).

source: Haiti Press Network; Haiti Standard; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 28 May 2025, in Delmas - Pele Simon, Ouest, the police shot and killed a court bailiff man while they were clashing with members of the Viv Ansanm Gang along the Airport Road. The victim was leaving home in Pele Simon neighborhood to attend his workplace when he was hit by the stray bullets. 1 fatality.

On 27 May 2025, in Kenscoff - Furcy, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members, killing several of them. One police officer was also injured during the clashes. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3. 1 injured.

Around 27 May 2025 (as reported), in Kenscoff - Furcy, Ouest, gang members attacked farmers and residents in Platon Furcy, setting fire to their houses and killing an unspecified number of civilians. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 23 May 2025, in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) clashed with members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang, affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition) and used explosive drones during anti-gang operations in Pernier and Torcelle neighborhoods (coded separately), killing several gangsters. Gunshots were heard in Freres. Several weapons and equipment were seized. The gang leader, who managed to escape, was later confirmed wounded. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3. At least 1 injured.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 29 May 2025, in Petion Ville - Vivy Mitchell, in the morning, police forces supported by members of the population clashed with the Kraze Barye Gang as the criminals set fire to residents' houses in the neighborhood, including that of a journalist and former government spokesperson. 12 houses were ransacked by the criminals. Gunshots were heard from Descolines. Casualties unknown.

Security measures: On 30 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the government declared a three-month State of Emergency (SOE) on the national territory as a result of the increasing violence and to facilitate the work of law enforcement bodies across the country. The national SOE expired on 31 July. The measure was then imposed in the Ouest, Centre, and the Artibonite communes (coded separately).

source: Amerique Info 7; Haiti Press Network; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 25 May 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Cite de Dieu, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched several drone airstrikes in Village de Dieu (Cite de Dieu neighborhood) against bases of the Base 5 Secondes Gang (a.k.a. Village de Dieu Gang). At least 30 gang members were killed and around 100 were injured. Several weapons, ammunition, and a vehicle were destroyed by the drones. Rumors stating that the leader of the gang had been injured were later denied. At least 30 fatalities, at least 100 injured.

On 26 May 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Debussy/Haut-Turgeau, Ouest, a group of teachers held a sit-in protest in front of the Ministry of National Education (MENFP) to demand better working conditions and justice for a colleague who was physically assaulted on May 18 during a teachers' protest on the occasion of the Flag Day celebration in Cap-Haitien (coded separately).
Property destruction: On 26 May 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Pacot, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang set fire to several houses in the neighborhood.

On 22 May 2025, in Tabarre - Torcelle, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) clashed with members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang, affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition) and launched several drone airstrikes during anti-gang operations in Torcelle and Pernier neighborhoods (coded separately). At least 15 gang members were killed and several were injured. Several weapons and equipment were seized. At least 15 fatalities split across two events. 8 fatalities coded here.

On 23 May 2025, in Tabarre - Torcelle, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) clashed with members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang, affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition) and used explosive drones during anti-gang operations in Torcelle and Pernier neighborhoods (coded separately), killing several gangsters. Several weapons and equipment were seized. The gang leader, who managed to escape, was later confirmed wounded. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 23 May 2025, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, public employees at the Departmental Direction of Social Affairs and Labor protested by shutting down the Southeast office to denounce administrative injustice, accusing the minister of appointing new staff without considering workers' needs or seniority.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 11 May 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, the police, supported by the area's self-defence brigade, carried out an operation in the commune, especially in the Viard area, killing around 20 gang members and injuring several others. During the operation, they were also able to free hostages in Kenscoff commune, as well as in Furcy (coded separately). They were also able to recover several homes that gang members had been occupying. Despite the police's efforts, several locations still remain under gang control, including Sousay. At least 20 fatalities. Several injured.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 20 May 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, the police clashed with affiliates of the Viv Ansanm Gang during an operation in the Dlo Chod area, near Carrefour Peligre. 11 gang members were killed and several were injured. One of the deceased was the leader of the Base Nan Tokyo Gang (a.k.a. Chale Gang), from La Saline neighborhood, who had expanded his activities to Mirebalais. Another of the deceased was a member of the Taliban Gang. The police seized three assault rifles. The operation was part of a national strategy to fight gang violence. 11 fatalities, several injured.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 22 May 2025, in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) clashed with members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang, affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition) and launched several drone airstrikes during anti-gang operations in the Pernier and Torcelle neighborhoods (coded separately). At least 15 gang members were killed and several were injured. Several weapons and equipment were seized. At least 15 fatalities split across two events. 7 fatalities coded here.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 23 May 2025, in the Saint-Louis du Sud commune, Sud, the police killed two members of the Simon-Pele Gang during a security operation in a rural area known as La Sucrerie Henry. They also seized a weapon. 2 fatalities.

source: Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 21 May 2025, in Limonade, Nord, the police, supported by civilians, arrested the leader of the 30 Dinozo Gang, who died hours later from a malaise in hospital. Two other gang members were also arrested.

source: Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 8 May 2025, in Barriere Bouteille, Nord, the police arrested a member of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) who was the leader of the Tabarre 43 and Dumornay neighborhoods. He was involved in the killing of a police officer on 1 March 2022 (coded separately).

actor1: Police Forces of Haiti (2024-) Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP)
source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 16 May 2025, in Cayes-Jacmel, Sud-Est, a BSAP police agent opened fire during a traffic altercation with a motorcyclist who tried to cross through an area the officers were securing for a school parade, in the Raymond-les-Bains neighborhood. Eight people, including moto-taxi drivers, parents, and residents, were shot and injured. Four BSAP agents were injured during the altercation (nature of injuries unclarified). The BSAP coordinator claimed that the assigned BSAP officers were not armed and that it was another backup officer who opened fire into the air to disperse people. He also highlighted that some residents were armed, although he did not confirmed whether they used the mentioned arms (of unknown nature) against the officers. A BSAP agent was arrested in connection with the incident. 12 injured.

On 2 June 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Pacot, Ouest, police forces supported by armed members of the population (self-defence group) clashed with gang members in the neighborhood, killing several of them. Gunshots were heard in Pacot and in nearby neighborhoods (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: On 1 June 2025, around Port-au-Prince - Nord Alexis, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members on Poupelard Avenue, Ruelle Sylvia, and in Widmaye street, killing several of them. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 4 June 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Pacot, Ouest, the police clashed with members of the Viv Ansamn Gang during a security operation in Pacot. During clashes, a police officer was shot and killed. 1 fatality.

Around 31 May 2025 (between 30 May - 1 June), in Petion Ville - Metivier, Ouest, members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang), supported by the 400 Mawozo Gang, carried out an attack in the neighborhood, injuring at least one person. The attack took place as the Kraze Barye Gang attacked several areas in Petionville, including the Pernier neighborhood (coded separately). 1 injured.

Around 31 May 2025 (between 30 May - 1 June), in Petion Ville - Centre Ville (Ouest), members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang), supported by the 400 Mawozo Gang, attacked residents in the Kebreau area, killing and injuring several civilians at their homes. The gangsters also set fire to several houses. Gunshots were heard in the area. The attack seemed a reprisal for police anti-gang operations against the Kraze Barye Gang (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 1 June 2025, in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang), supported by the 400 Mawozo Gang, attacked residents in the Gwo Jan area (Pernier), killing more than 10 civilians, including four children from a family. There were six women and a baby among the victims. They were burned at their homes. The attack seemed a reprisal for police anti-gang operations against the Kraze Barye Gang (coded separately). At least 10 fatalities.
Other: On 2 June 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 30. There is no information on the circumstances and the authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 2 June 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the metropolitan area, including in the Nazon and Christ-Roi neighborhoods. There is no information on the circumstances and the authorship of the gunshots.

On 4 June 2025, in Delmas - Fragneau Ville, Ouest, directors of schools and Members of the Group of Victim Schools (REV) held a sit-in protest in front of the Ministry of National Education and Vocational Training (MENFP), in the vicinity of the Delmas 83 Road, to demand compensation for the damage suffered by school centers vandalized by gang members.

On 2 June 2025, in Verrettes, Artibonite, residents held a protest and erecting barricades (nature unclarified) on the Verrettes road leading to Mirebalais to demand that the police dismantle the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang operating in the area.

On 5 June 2025, in Gros-Morne, Artibonite, residents held a protest and set up barricades with tree branches, stones, and other materials along the National Road 1 to demand the intervention of the authorities in the handling of increasing gang violence and dismantling of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. Protesters, also using signs, insulted different government authorities and demanded the return of the former departmental police chief, whom they believe was more efficient at fighting gang violence. Barricades were also set up in Pont Sonde and Saint-Marc (coded separately).

On 5 June 2025, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, residents held a protest and set up barricades with tree branches, stones, and other materials, along the National Road 1 to demand the intervention of the authorities in the handling of increasing gang violence and dismantling of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. Protesters, also using signs, expressed insults towards different government authorities and demanded the return of the former departmental police chief, whom they believe was more efficient at fighting gang violence. Barricades were also set up in Pont Sonde and Gros-Morne (coded separately).

On 6 June 2025, in Petion Ville - Centre Ville (Sud), Ouest, members of an organization held a sit-in protest in front of the Provisional Electoral Council (CEP) office against the government's referendum project and to demand the holding of elections. They also demanded to use the funds dedicated to the project toward the country's security instead.

source: Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 2 June 2025, in Delmas - Kernizan, Ouest, former employees at the National Center of Equipment (CNE) demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Public Works, Transport and Communications (MTPTC), along Delmas 33 Road (Kernizan neighborhood), to demand the payment of 10 months of unpaid wages. They erected barricades of burning tires, blocking circulation around the premises. During the mobilization, security agents from the Ministry fired shots, injuring one of the demonstrators in a foot. Police forces were not present. 1 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; UNSC
notes: On 19 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Saint Gerard, Ouest, in the morning, armed members of the Grand-Ravine Gang kidnapped six nuns (women) belonging to the Saint Anne Sisters Catholic Congregation from a bus, on the Chili Avenue. The bus driver and a teacher were also abducted. One source identified the abductors are Base 5 Secondes affiliates, although no other media backed this. Kidnappers asked for a ransom of 3 million dollars. The victims were released on 24 January under unclarified circumstances.

source: France Info; Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; UNSC
notes: On 13 January 2024, near Gros-Morne, Artibonite, Ti Bwa gang members kidnapped at least 35 passengers (up to 45 according to other sources) from a bus belonging to the Patrick Tours company, in the Tibwadom village. Among the victims, there was a rapper artist, who was later released. A ransom of 1 million gourdes was demanded as a condition for the release of each abducted victim. The whereabouts of the rest are unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 30 January 2024, in Petion Ville - Freres, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang engaged in armed clashes with members of the Vitelhomme Gang (a.k.a. Kraze Barye Gang) in Pernier (coded separately) and Freres neighborhoods. Only in Pernier, at least four people were killed (coded separately). Between 30 and 31 January, dozens of civilians were killed and an unknown number were injured by the gangsters in Petionville. Among the wounded, there was a man who was shot while picking up his son from school. Several hundred residents left their homes and took refuge elsewhere. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; UNSC
notes: On 30 January 2024, in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang engaged in armed clashes with members of the Vitelhomme Gang (a.k.a. Kraze Barye Gang) in Pernier and Freres neighborhoods (coded separately). Only in Pernier, at least four people were killed. A school teacher got his eyes gouged by the Kraze Barye Gang. Between 30 and 31 January, a dozen civilians were killed and an unknown number were injured by the gangsters in Petionville. Among the wounded, there was a man who was shot while picking up his son from school. Several hundred residents left their homes and took refuge elsewhere. At least 4 fatalities.

On 31 January 2024, in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, for the second consecutive day, the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) clashed with rival gang members (likely from the 400 Mawozo Gang, as they had clashed in the area the day before -coded separately-). During clashes, the Kraze Barye Gang killed 11 rival gangsters and 36 other people, including women and children. Between 30 and 31 January, dozens of civilians were killed and an unknown number were injured by the gangsters in Petionville. Some residents fled their homes, while others were prevented to do it by the gangsters, who fired into the air. Police forces intervened and forced the gangsters to withdraw. 47 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Haiti Progres; Loop News Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Undisclosed Source; UNSC
notes: On 10 February 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, members of the Chien Mechant Gang engaged in armed clashes with rival gangsters from the Terre Noire Gang and the Pierre VI Gang on the National Road 1 and in La Plaine du Cul-du-Sac area. The clashes lasted for several days. An unknown number of civilians, including relatives of gang members, were killed. Between 8 and 12 February, clashes between the Chien Mechant and Canaan Gang (from G-Pep La Gang coalition) against their rivals from the Pierre VI and Terre Noire Gangs (from G-9 Gang coalition) resulted in at least 127 civilians killed in Cite Soleil, Tabarre, and Croix-des-Bouquets communes (coded separately). These clashes were part of the Chien Mechant Gang's efforts to avenge the killing of an allied gang leader on 26 September 2023 (coded separately). At least 127 fatalities split across four events, 32 fatalities coded here.

On 30 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - La Saline, Ouest, for the fourth consecutive day, gang members from different factions of the G-9 alliance that operate in La Saline and Wharf Jeremie clashed in La Saline neighborhood and nearby areas as part of a fight for territory and for the control of passage fees imposed on trucks leaving Varreux Oil Terminal. The Base Project La Saline Gang, whose members engaged in the clashes, killed the leader of the Base Nan Chabon Gang (Marc), as part of an internal plot against this leader. Other reports suggest that members of Base Nan Tokyo and Base Krache Dief participated in clash (all affiliated with the G-9). Between 27 and 30 January, more than 20 fatalities were counted among the gang members. At least 9 civilians were killed, and more than 30 were injured as a result of clashes between gangsters from Wharf Jeremie and La Saline. At least 29 fatalities and 30 injured split across four related armed clash events coded between 27 and 30 January. 8 coded here.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Progres; Loop News Haiti; PNH: National Police of Haiti; UNSC
notes: On 19 January 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, police forces shot and killed three members of the Grand-Ravine Gang on Mgr Guilloux Road (Champs de Mars neighborhood). According to police, the armed gangsters were transporting ammunition in a vehicle to the Belair neighborhood when they opened fire on the police patrol, leading to a clash as the policemen returned fire. A fourth gangster who was in the vehicle managed to flee. 3 fatalities.

On 19 January 2024, in Carrefour - Mariani, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members as they intervened to expel the criminals from the commune. At least seven children were shot and injured during the crossfire. At least 7 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Standard; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; Undisclosed Source; UNSC
notes: On 12 February 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, members of the Belair Gang and the Grand-Ravine Gang opened fire in the vicinity of a carnival parade being held in Champs de Mars, injuring by gunshots several people participating in the parade. The Grand-Ravine Gang kidnapped five people. Their whereabouts are unknown. Gunshots were also heard in Bel Air neighborhood. On the same day, a medical center was evacuated as an exchange of fire took place nearby. The perpetrators were not clarified. Several injured.

source: Le Filet Info; Rezo Nodwes; UNSC
notes: On 18 November 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 44, Ouest, in the morning, armed individuals dressed in police uniforms shot and killed a member of the Democratic and Popular Sector party (SDP) near the Altagrace Church (Delmas 44 neighborhood). According to witnesses, the perpetrators took the victim's body. Political figures denounced that the attack was ordered by members of the Transitional Presidential Council (CPT) after the militant refused to follow their order to start negotiations with gang members. 1 fatality.

source: FCN: Fact Checking News; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Trip Foumi
notes: On 10 May 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 75, Ouest, overnight, armed individuals killed a woman epidemiologist after breaking into her home. They tied up the relatives who were present at the house before stabbing her multiple times. The motivation for the attack was not clarified, although the killing seemed a direct attack. The victim was a prominent medical figure and an education rights defender from the Haitian civil society. 1 fatality.

On 12 May 2025, in Petit-Goave Ouest, residents protested to demand financial accountability from the local authorities due to deteriorating local security conditions. They marched near the home of the director of the city hall's council, where security personnel of the director fired gunshots to disperse the crowd, injuring two people who were not involved in the protest. It is unclear whether the private security or police officers injured the victims. 2 injured.

Property destruction: On 18 January 2024, in Delmas - Cite Numero Un, Ouest, members of the Belair Gang, armed with heavy weapons, entered the Port-au-Prince Christ Church and destroyed it, in Delmas 18. Some witnesses stated that they were looking for a Belair gangster who was hidden in the church, although this information was not confirmed.

Property destruction: On 27 October 2024, in Tabarre - Mais Gate/Clercine 2, Ouest, police forces and Kenyan agents from the Multinational Security Support Mission (MMSS) started demolishing properties near the Toussaint Louverture Airport to reinforce the airport's security from the activity of gangs. The demolished buildings had been home to gang members who used them to carry out attacks against the airport. Over 350 properties were demolished as part of the plan.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 7 February 2024, in Gonaives, Artibonite, for the third consecutive day, government opponents held a demonstration demanding the departure of Prime Minister Ariel Henry. During the mobilization, rioters burned tires and set fire to three buildings, one of them being the departmental office of the Planning and External Cooperation Ministry and the Peace Court. Two vehicles from the institution were calcined. They also looted several businesses, including a food warehouse belonging to a police officer. Agents of the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP) were witnessed alongside the looters (the nature of their participation is unknown). In response, police forces fired tear gas to disperse them. This was part of anti-government mobilizations called by Guy Philippe (a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti).
On 18 February 2024, in Dieudon, Ouest, armed gang members shot and injured a police officer on his back as they opened fire on a police patrol in the Duval area. 1 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Loop News Haiti; Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 4 July 2024, in Carrefour - Arcachon/Mon-Repos, Ouest, armed members of the Viv Ansanm Gang shot and killed two police officers and a civilian (described as a close person to the officers) on Genet Street, in Arcachon 32 (Arcachon/Mon-Repos neighbourhood). Several people were injured. The gangsters took away the officers' bodies. One source stated that the killed officers used to collaborate with the Caravane Gang and that they were killed for stop supporting it. There were police officers (affiliated to the Caravane Gang) among the perpetrators of the attack. 3 fatalities, several injured.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; UNSC
notes: On 12 January 2024, in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang kidnapped 14 passengers (eight men and six women) from a public transport vehicle travelling from Port-au-Prince to Gonaives. Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 12 January 2024, in Carrefour, Ouest, members of the Caravane Gang took a 12-year-old boy to a cemetery and killed him (methods unclarified) after having intercepted him in a public transport vehicle carrying firearms in a backpack for the Grand-Ravine Gang. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 31 May 2025, in Gros-Morne, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang kidnapped a hotel owner man at his home, in Morne Marguerite (city center), as well as two other people, including another entrepreneur from the area. The hotel owner was killed on 9 June (coded separately) despite the payment of at least two ransoms by his family (up to 300,000 USD), and the transfer of several vehicles to the criminals. The police arrested a man in connection to the abduction and killing on 10 June. The other victims' whereabouts are unknown.

On 8 June 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched several drone strikes. The strikes were likely against gang-controlled areas, as they were part of security forces interventions against gangs. Casualties unknown.

On 9 June 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Cite de Dieu, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched drone strikes in Village de Dieu (Cite de Dieu) and the Grand Ravine neighborhoods (coded separately), likely against Viv Ansanm Gang-controlled areas (also targeted on 10 June). Between 9 and 10 June, at least 100 gang members were killed and others were injured as the police launched 14 drone strikes in Cite de Dieu and Grand Ravine. None of the victims were identified as gang leaders. No civilian casualties were registered. At least 100 fatalities split across four events. 25 fatalities coded here.

On 9 June 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Grand Ravine, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched drone strikes in Grand Ravine and Village de Dieu (Cite de Dieu) neighborhoods (coded separately), likely against Viv Ansanm Gang-controlled areas (also targeted on 10 June). Between 9 and 10 June, at least 100 gang members were killed and others were injured as the police launched 14 drone strikes in Cite de Dieu and Grand Ravine. None of the victims were identified as gang leaders. No civilian casualties were registered. At least 100 fatalities split across four events. 25 fatalities coded here.

On 10 June 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Cite de Dieu, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched drone strikes against Viv Ansanm Gang-controlled areas in Village de Dieu (Cite de Dieu) and the Grand Ravine neighborhoods (coded separately). Several gang members were killed. Between 9 and 10 June, at least 100 gang members were killed and others were injured as the police launched 14 drone strikes in Cite de Dieu and Grand Ravine. None of the victims were identified as gang leaders. No civilian casualties were registered. At least 100 fatalities split across four events. 25 fatalities coded here.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 10 June 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Grand Ravine, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched drone strikes against Viv Ansanm Gang-controlled areas in Grand Ravine and Village de Dieu (Cite de Dieu) neighborhoods (coded separately). In one of the targeted areas, the leader of the Grand-Ravine Gang was building a hospital. Several gang members were killed. According to BINUH, the leader himself was injured during one of the drone strikes carried out likely by the Task Force in June (coded here). Between 9 and 10 June, at least 100 gang members were killed and others were injured as the police launched 14 drone strikes in Cite de Dieu and Grand Ravine. None of the victims were identified as gang leaders. No civilian casualties were registered. At least 100 fatalities split across four events. 25 fatalities coded here. 1 injured.

On 7 June 2025, in Dumay, Ouest, the police fired shots at a convoy where the leader of the Kraze Barye Gang was traveling with accomplices, during a security operation aimed at capturing him. The gang members managed to escape. The police recovered weapons and other objects from two vehicles the gangsters left behind. There were no fatalities.
On 7 June 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 65, Ouest, the police shot and injured a gang member during an operation in Delmas 57. The injured, as well as another gang member, were arrested. 1 injured.

On 7 June 2025, in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, the police shot and killed several members of the Kraze Barye Gang at the group's base. They also seized weapons and other objects. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 8 June 2025, around Marassa, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang killed a newly installed Chien Mechant local gang leader. Clashes erupted as the now deceased was trying to halt lootings (likely by the 400 Mawozo Gang) in the area. The killed gangster had been installed as Chien Mechant gang leader after the killing of his predecessor on 6 June in Marassa (coded separately). An unknown number of civilians were killed and injured, although this information has not been independently confirmed so far. At least 1 fatality.

On 9 June 2025, in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, the police shot and killed several members of the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) during a security operation. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

Around 11 June 2025 (between 10 - 12 June), in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, the police, supported by self-defense brigades, shot and killed several gang members during anti-gang operations in Delmas 30, Christ-Roi, Solino, and Fort National (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

Around 11 June 2025 (between 10 - 12 June), in Port-au-Prince - Christ-Roi, Ouest, the police, supported by self-defense brigades, shot and killed several gang members during anti-gang operations in Christ-Roi, Delmas 30, Solino, and Fort National (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

Around 11 June 2025 (between 10 - 12 June), in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, the police, supported by self-defense brigades, shot and killed several gang members during anti-gang operations in Fort National, Christ-Roi, Delmas 30, and Solino (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

Around 11 June 2025 (between 10 - 12 June), in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, the police, supported by self-defense brigades, shot and killed several gang members during anti-gang operations in Solino, Christ-Roi, Delmas 30, and Fort National (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 9 June 2025, in Gros-Morne, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang killed a hotel owner man whom they had kidnapped on 31 May (coded separately). He was found dead near his home. The police arrested a man in connection to the abduction and killing on 10 June. 1 fatality.

On 9 June 2025, in the Kenscoff commune, Ouest, overnight, gang members attacked residents in the Sourcailles communal section (Kenscoff 3rd communal section). They set fire to several houses. Despite the police's success in repelling the gangs from certain areas of the commune, they are still present in localities such as Lakou Konbit, Kafou Badjo, and Kafou Bet. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: Property destruction: On 8 June 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, members of the Canaan Gang ransacked the Mirebalais communal market (a.k.a. 'Mache Neuf') and set it on fire, causing local vendors major losses. The market was empty when the attack took place, since vendors had abandoned it due to the gang presence in the commune. The market had previously been burned during an attack in the area on 31 March (coded separately).
Property destruction: On 11 June 2025, in the Kenscoff commune, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang looted and set fire to a house in Viard 2 (Viard neighborhood).
On 9 June 2025, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, contractor workers at the National School Canteen Program (PNCS) protested by closing the institution's offices to demand the payment of nine months of due salary.

On 12 June 2025, in Verrettes, Artibonite, residents protested to demand the resignation of the commune's interim executive officer. The protesters, who closed the city hall's entrance, denounced the officer's poor management at the institution.

On 9 June 2025, in Delmas - Gerald Bataille, Ouest, a group of people held a demonstration to decry the decision to change the head police officer in charge of the area's police antenna. Demonstrators erected barricades of burning tires and blocked the circulation. They claimed to support the current officer in charge.

On 8 June 2025, between Petion Ville - Pernier and Tabarre - Torcelle (coded to Petion Ville - Pernier), Ouest, for a second consecutive day, the police clashed with the Kraze Barye Gang as part of anti-gang operations carried out between Pernier (Petion Ville) and Torcelle (Tabarre) neighborhoods. Several gang members were shot and killed. The police seized weapons and ammunition. The leader of the gang managed to escape for a second time in a row after similar clashes with the police the day prior (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

Property destruction: Around 9 June 2025 (weekend of), in Kenscoff - Furcy, Ouest, gang members set fire to several houses in the Furcy neighborhood. The targeted properties had been under the gangs' control before being burned (empty of residents). This was described as part of gang reprisals for police operations against them.
Property destruction: On 9 June 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, gang members set fire to a part of the Gymnasium Vincent, on La Roumain Street, and several nearby houses.

On 11 January 2024, in Croix-des-Bouquets, Ouest, unidentified individuals kidnapped four pastors. One of them was released without payment of a ransom. There is no information on the perpetrators, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang related. The whereabouts of the hostages are unknown.

Around 17 February 2024 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour Feuilles, Ouest, police forces clashed with the Grand-Ravine Gang in the neighborhood. A child was shot and killed during the crossfire. His partially burnt body was left on the street. It was partially devoured by dogs. 1 fatality.

Around 7 January 2024 (between 1 - 14 January), in Port-au-Prince - Gabelliste/Grand Cimetiere, Ouest, unidentified members of armed groups engaged in clashes in the Gabelliste area, forcing the displacement of thousands of civilians. Casualties unknown.

On 30 January 2024, in Cite Soleil - Nanraguette/Drouillard, Ouest, members of the Ti Gabriel Gang (a.k.a. Brooklyn Gang) killed at least seven people and injured 30 others as they attacked the Nanraguette neighborhood (a.k.a. Nan Raket). This was not ruled out to be part of clashes between affiliates of the G-9 Gang and rival gangsters affiliated to the G-Pep La Gang. Hundreds of people fled their homes to take refuge elsewhere. At least 7 fatalities, 30 injured.
Looting: On 10 February 2024, in Carrefour - Riviere Froide, Ouest, Ti Bwa gang members assaulted and took over the Riviere Froide police station. No further details were mentioned.

actor1: Police Forces of Haiti (2024-) Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP)
source: Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 2 April 2025, in Les Cayes, Sud, two armed men on a motorcycle shot and killed a man when he was driving along the Grossin street (drive-by). Two BSAP police agents were arrested as suspected perpetrators of the attack. The motivation for the killing is unknown. The victim was the brother of a lawyer who was later killed in similar circumstances on 19 June (coded separately). 1 fatality.

source: Gazette Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 20 May 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Grand Ravine, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched four drone airstrikes against the base of the Grand-Ravine Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang), killing at least 25 gang members and injuring around 40. At least six of the severely injured criminals were identified as members of the Grand-Ravine Gang. At least 25 fatalities, at least 40 injured.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 9 June 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched several drone strikes against gang targets as part of police anti-gang operations. Casualties unknown.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: AP; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 28 April 2025, in Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite, Artibonite, police forces supported by the Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang (a.k.a. Jean Denis Coalition) clashed with the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang as they intervened to expel the criminals from the commune, which was under gang attack since the morning (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; PNH: National Police of Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Trip Foumi
notes: On 3 May 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, police forces supported by armed members of the population clashed with gang members in the commune, killing several. Several others were arrested, while a firearm was seized. At least seven gangsters were killed during police operations in Mirebalais between 3 and 4 May (coded separately). At least 30 gang members were killed during three separate police operations in Mirebalais, Tabarre, and Kenscoff in early May (coded separately). 30 fatalities split over three locations. 5 coded here.

source: Alterpresse; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 20 February 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Fort National, Ouest, for a third consecutive day, police forces and armed members of the population (self-defense group) clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang in Fort National. A police officer was killed, while a self-defense group member and several civilians were injured. 1 fatality, several injured.

source: Metropole; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 7 September 2024, in Gressier - Nan Reserve, Ouest, police forces engaged in armed clashes with gang members. A police officer was shot during clashes in La Colline. He died from his wounds the following day as he did not receive adequate care on time. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 15 August 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, armed members of the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked the Solino neighborhood, injuring several civilians as they vandalized their houses. Police forces intervened and clashed with the criminals. A police officer and several gang members were killed. One source stated that the criminals came from Delmas 2 and Bel Air neighborhoods. The gang members attacked Solino, Fort National, and Delmas 24 simultaneously (coded separately). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 4, including the officer killed.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 15 August 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, armed members of the Viv Ansanm Gang fired shots as they attacked Delmas 24 (Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28 neighbourhood). Police forces intervened and clashed with the criminals. Several gang members were killed. Several civilians were injured and houses were looted. One source stated that the criminals came from Delmas 2 and Bel Air neighborhoods. The gang members attacked the Delmas 24, Fort National, and Solino neighbourhoods (coded separately) simultaneously. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 7 September 2024, in Verrettes, Artibonite, unidentified armed men dressed as officers of the anti-gang police unit killed a former police officer who was suspected to be involved in the killing of an artist on 3 November in Cite Soleil (coded separately). The former officer was tortured before being killed. One sourced stated that the killers were members of the population. 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Info Fiable; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 6 May 2025, 2025, in Kenscoff - Furcy, Ouest, gang members kidnapped three farmers and took them to a property in the mountains of Viard area. While in captivity, the victims were beaten up, tortured, and forced to participate in sexual violence against a woman. The police freed the hostages during an operation in the Kenscoff commune on 11 May (coded separately). The victims were found with visible signs of injuries. 3 injured.

On 8 May 2025, in Kenscoff - Fond Ferier, Ouest, overnight, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents in Carrefour Badio (near Fond Ferier) and the Furcy neighborhood (coded separately). Gunshots were heard. Casualties unknown.

On 28 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Pacot, Ouest, gang members (likely from the Viv Ansanm Gang who also attacked nearby areas of Turgeau) attacked residents on Charlotte street. At least two civilians (up to three according to other versions) were killed and at least five were abducted at their homes. Other sources reported close to 10 people kidnapped. The victims' whereabouts are unknown. At least 2 fatalities.

source: Le Filet Info; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 28 April 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Turgeau, Ouest, in the morning, the Viv Ansanm Gang attacked residents on Cochotte and Babiole streets. At least three members of a family, including a 17-year-old boy and his father, were killed at their home, at least six were abducted, and an unknown number were injured. Some properties were set on fire. The criminals had been seen in the vicinity of the Sacred Heart Church of Turgeau the day prior. They also attacked nearby areas of Pacot neighborhood on that day (coded separately). Four of the six abducted victims were released, while the whereabouts of the other two are unknown. At least 3 fatalities.

source: Amerique Info 7; Haiti Press Network; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: Property destruction: On 15 April 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, Canaan gang members, including their leader, looted, set fire, and used sledgehammers to demolish the Mirebalais police station, which had been abandoned by security forces amidst increasing gang violence in the commune since 31 March (coded separately). One source stated that the Taliban and the 400 Mawozo Gangs took part in the police station destruction.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Property destruction: On 22 March 2025, in Terre Rouge, Centre, the Kanaran Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang) set fire to the local police sub-station (abandoned by police forces more than a year before) after having occupied the facility the day prior. The criminals invited the local population to stay, although dozens of families fled the area after the gang attack. The Kanaran Gang installed a base in the Platon community. Additional sources stated that the Canaan, Taliban, and 400 Mawozo Gangs took part in the attack. Affiliates of both gangs also participated in the assault of nearby Trianon and Mirebalais over these days (coded separately).

Other: On 11 May 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Thomassin and along the Freres Road. Although there is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots, they are likely related to ongoing gang activity in the area.

On 16 June 2025, in Peligre, Centre, residents held a protest in front of the hydroelectric central to denounced the authorities' abandonment in the face of increasing violence and demand that they resume anti-gang operations in the area.

On 19 June 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, the police clashed with gang members during an operation in Carrefour Peligre aimed at regaining control of the area. They killed several gangsters. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 13 June 2025, in the Milot commune, Nord, overnight, the police shot and killed a gang member during a clash along the National Road 3 in the Pont Blanc locality. They also seized a weapon, ammunition, and the motorcycle the shooter was traveling on. 1 fatality.

source: Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 15 June 2025, in Kenscoff - Furcy, Ouest, the police, supported by self-defense groups, shot and killed several gang members during a clash in the neighborhood. The police managed to regain control over two areas previously occupied by the gangs. They killed around 20 gangsters. Weapons and other materials were also seized during this operation. At least 20 fatalities.

On 18 June 2025, in Kenscoff - Godet, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang ambushed four police officers moving in an armored vehicle, forcing them to abandon the vehicle and flee the area. No one was injured. The vehicle got stuck in a hole on the road between Godet and Belo. The gangsters seized the vehicle and several weapons that they found inside. There were no casualties.

Around 16 June 2025 (as reported), in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour Feuilles, Ouest, gang members ambushed the police and self-defense brigade members, injuring at least one officer and one brigade member. The police, supported by the self-defense groups, were providing support to residents trying to get back clothes from their homes. At least 2 injured.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 3 June 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched drone airstrikes against gang targets in the Centre Ville neighborhood as part of police anti-gang operations. Casualties unknown.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: Around 10 June 2025 (between 9 - 11 June), in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched several drone strikes against gang targets in the Solino neighborhood as part of police anti-gang operations. Casualties unknown.

On 6 May 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Cite de Dieu, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched at least eight drone strikes against gang-controlled areas in Village de Dieu (Cite de Dieu neighborhood). Several gang members were killed and others were injured. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.
On 9 May 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 32, Ouest, police forces supported by armed members of vigilance brigades clashed with armed individuals in Delmas 32. Casualties unknown.

On 4 May 2025, in Mirebalais, Centre, police forces supported by armed members of the population clashed with gang members in the commune, killing several. Several others were arrested, while a firearm was seized. Between 3 and 4 May, at least seven gang members were killed during police operations in Mirebalais (coded separately). 7 fatalities split across two events. 2 coded here.
On 14 May 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Pacot, Ouest, police forces clashed with unidentified armed individuals in the Pacot and Turgeau neighborhoods (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 14 May 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Turgeau, Ouest, police forces clashed with unidentified armed individuals between Avenue Christophe, Rue 6 and Lundi Streets (Turgeau) and in nearby Pacot neighborhood (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
notes: On 15 August 2024, in Tabarre - Carrefour Fleuriot, Ouest, police forces clashed with armed individuals during a security operation in Clercine 14, near the Anvayi Hotel. During clashes, two police officers were killed. 2 fatalities.
On 6 May 2025, in Delmas - Barbancourt, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang member on the Airport Road near the Autoplaza S.A. company facilities (Barbancourt neighborhood). Casualties unknown.

On 10 May 2025, in Kenscoff - Drouette, Ouest, there were armed clashes in the Platon Cafe area (Drouette neighborhood). These clashes likely involved the police against gang members. On that day, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) also carried out drone airstrikes in Kenscoff areas that had been taken over by gang (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 4 May 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police forces shot and killed a woman gang member. She was the partner of a gang member who had been killed by police forces earlier that day in Mirebalais (coded separately).
