On 19 July 2025, in L'Estere commune, Artibonite, a mob of residents lynched to death several members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang when the criminals tried to retrieve their leader's body to bury him. The gang leader had been killed during clashes with the police and self-defense groups in the Kapenyen locality earlier that day (coded separately). Civilians also set fire to houses where the criminals had taken refuge after the clashes. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.
Other: On 23 July 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 19 and nearby neighborhoods. They were likely the authorship of gang members in the area.

On 24 July 2025, in Port-de-Paix, Nord-Ouest, nursing students, health workers, and other hospital staff members held a protest to demand the release of two doctors who were arrested on 22 July. One version stated that they were arrested in connection to a drug case, while another version indicated they were arrested in connection to a killing. Protesters denounced the negative impact of their arrest on the local health system.

On 23 July 2025, in Baraderes, Nippes, several dozens of citizens, led by the Tet Kole Ti Peyizan Ayisyen farmers organization, held a protest with banners to demand justice for 139 farmers who were killed during the Duvalier regime in Jean Rabel on 23 July 1987. Protesters also denounced the Transitional Presidential Council's (CPT) referendum project and demanded security in the country. The mobilization was part of several commemoration activities planned by the mentioned organization on the anniversary of the massacre.

On 22 July 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, members of sociopolitical organizations held a protest against ongoing insecurity and to demand the resignation of the government. Protesters also denounced foreign intervention in Haiti's politics and the poor work of the current national government.

On 23 July 2025, in Gonaives, Artibonite, citizens protested to demand the resignation of the departmental police director whom they accuse of being passive in the handling of gang violence and providing assistance to police officers, including the retrieval of their bodies after fatal shootings. Protesters also denounced the complicity between the authorities and the gangs, and the increasing insecurity in the country. This mobilization came after three police officers were killed in Liancourt the previous day (coded separately).

On 22 July 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bourdon, Ouest, displaced residents from the Solino neighborhood held a protest by erecting barricades with stones and blocking circulation to decry poor living conditions at the facilities of the Office for the Citizens Protection (OPC), in Bourdon, where they have been taking refuge since they fled gang violence in Solino. The police used tear gas and threw stones to disperse protesters, preventing them from reaching the protest's destination (Primature building). Protesters also demanded the restoration of security in their neighborhoods.

On 21 July 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bicentenaire, Ouest, a group of around 10 lawyers held a demonstration in front of the Palace of Justice and set up barricades of burning tires demanding the departure of the government commissioner, whom they accused of corruption.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Non-violent activity: Around 15 January 2024 (month of), in Carrefour Paye, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang set up a checkpoint along the roadway to extort drivers and to control the traffic of illicit goods.

On 13 July 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched at least seven drone strikes against gang positions in several localities in the commune. The strikes were a response to an attack against the Furcy police station by the Base 5 Secondes Gang on 11 July (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 17 July 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, police forces engaged in clashes with unidentified armed individuals in the Viard area in the commune. The police managed to expel the criminals. Casualties unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 15 August 2024 (month of), in Fonds-Parisien, Ouest, a local self-defense group (known as 'Brigad'), supported by foreign armed individuals providing security for private actors, engaged in clashes with the 400 Mawozo Gang as members of this gang were trying to take control of the commune. There were no casualties related to the armed clashes. There were no casualties.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 1 May 2025 (as reported), near La Ville, Artibonite, the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang attacked a joint strategic base from the National Police of Haiti and the Multinational Security Support Mission (MSS) in Segur (Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite's 2nd communal section). Security forces were forced to flee the base due to the lack of equipment to fight the gang. Casualties unknown.

On 14 July 2025, in the Croix-des-Bouquets commune, Ouest, rival armed group members engaged in clashes in areas within the Plaine Du Cul-de-Sac zone. This was likely part of clashes between the 400 Mawozo Gang and the Chien Mechant Gang, whose members' presence and deployment were noticed in Marassa, Lilavois, and Santo on that day. The mentioned gangs engaged in clashes in Marassa and Santo on 15 July (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 15 July 2025, in Marassa, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang engaged in clashes with the Chien Mechant Gang in Marassa and Santo 25 (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 15 July 2025, in Santo, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang engaged in clashes with the Chien Mechant Gang in Santo 25 and Marassa (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 15 July 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 19/Joseph Janvier, Ouest, police forces clashed with gang members in Delmas 19. The criminals fired tear gas against the officers. Casualties unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 10 December 2024 (between 9 - 12 December), in the Petite Riviere de l'Artibonite commune, Artibonite, self-defense group members killed around 28 civilians in the Ti Rouge area over accusations of being accomplices or collaborators of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. Among the victims, there were women and young girls who were suspected of being partners of gang members. Between 9 and 12 December, 67 civilians were killed by self-defense groups in Bois Laville (coded separately), Passe Barque, (coded separately), and Ti Rouge. 28 fatalities coded here.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 21 April 2025, in La Chapelle, Artibonite, the Canaan Gang attacked residents in the commune and set up a checkpoint along the National Road 11. Casualties unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 23 June 2025 (between 22 - 25 March), in Martina, Artibonite, the Canaan Gang attacked residents in the village. Casualties unknown.

Property destruction: On 13 July 2025, in Kenscoff - Obleon, Ouest, gang members looted and set fire to several houses in the Obleon neighborhood. The gang members were seen returning to Carrefour carrying people's belongings.

actor1: Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang
source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Non-violent activity: Around 15 September 2024 (month of), in Pont Sonde, Artibonite, members of the Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang (a.k.a. Jean Denis Coalition) set up a roadblock at the Pat-Chwal zone (Ouest zone of Pont Sonde) to divert drivers from passing through a ransom point set up by the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang along the roadway (coded separately).

Other: On 12 July 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, unidentified individuals set up a roadblock by parking a truck in the middle of the roadway in the Delmas 48 neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up.

Other: On 12 July 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard near Delmas 65 and at the height of Delmas 33 towards Faustin 1er. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 12 July 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, in the morning, gunshots were heard near the Police Academy (Academie neighborhood). There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 15 July 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, overnight, gunshots were heard in the commune. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.

Non-violent activity: Around 18 July 2025 (as reported), in Thomazeau, Ouest, the leader of the 400 Mawozo Gang was seen distributing money. The scene was recorded on video and shared on social media.

Other: On 18 July 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Diegue neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots, although they were likely related to armed clashes registered in several nearby neighborhoods on that day (coded separately).

On 13 July 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Christ Roi - Lalue, Ouest, a group of people held a demonstration over unclarified claims and burned tires along the Martin Luther King Avenue at its intersection in Lalue.

source: Aid Worker Security Database; Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; International Crisis Group
notes: On 7 July 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, the Grand-Ravine Gang kidnapped six employees of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund (UNICEF) during a mission in an area under the control of armed groups. One of the victims was released the following day, while the rest of the group was freed on 28 July. It is unclear if a ransom was paid in exchange for their release.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti
notes: Around 1 August 2025 (as reported), around Liancourt, Artibonite, the police clashed with members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang during an operation that allowed them to regain control of the commune. The criminals had installed themselves in Liancourt after they attacked the area on 22 July (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 3 May 2025, in Kenscoff - Fermathe, Ouest, gang members opened fire on a vehicle convoy where the mayor of Kenscoff was traveling in with the local government's administrator and three police officers. Everyone managed to escape unharmed. There were no casualties.
Around 17 July 2025 (as reported), in Jean Denis, Artibonite, the Savien Gang launched an armed offensive against residents in the village. No further information was available. Casualties unknown.

On 29 July 2025, in Delmas - Pele Simon, Ouest, unidentified armed individuals shot and injured two public employees at the Office of Insurance for Work Accidents, Illness, and Maternity (OFATMA) in the Pele Simon neighborhood while on their way to work. There is no information on the perpetrators and motivation of the attack. 2 injured.

On 29 July 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 75, Ouest, armed gang members shot and killed a police officer (likely off-duty, as he was dressed in civilian clothes) in a targeted attack. The attackers circled the victim's personal vehicle before opening fire and shooting him in different parts of his body. They then fled the scene. 1 fatality.
On 26 July 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, gang members carried out an attack against the Viard area. Casualties unknown.

Property destruction: Around 15 November 2024 (month of), in the Nord department (coded to Limbe), Nord, police forces seized 5 kg of marijuana and arrested three men from the Bahamas in an area known as Banndino. 3,000 USD dollars were seized from the arrested men.
Property destruction: On 18 June 2025, in the Sud department (coded to Les Cayes), Sud, police forces seized 922 grams of marijuana and arrested a man.

On 31 July 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, hundreds of displaced residents from the Solino neighborhood protested to demand action from the authorities to restore safety in their neighborhood. They also denounced the poor living conditions in shelters and the rising insecurity.

On 25 July 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Christ Roi - Lalue, Ouest, displaced residents from the Solino neighborhood held a protest in Lalue to decry poor living conditions at the facilities where they have been taking refuge since they fled gang violence in Solino.

source: Bon Nouvel9; Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 29 July 2025, between Port-au-Prince - Bourdon and Delmas - Delmas 40b (coded to Delmas - Delmas 40b), Ouest, members of a political movement, the so-called Bois-Caiman movement, held a protest against the Transitional Presidential Council (CPT) demanding the resignation of its members. The protesters used religious symbols, chanted traditional songs, erected barricades, and marched along the Delmas highway. At some point, they interrupted the mobilization due to low turnout. The police was mobilized to contain the activity, which the protesters believe prevented a larger participation. At some point, the police dispersed the crowd using tear gas.

On 29 July 2025, in Les Cayes, Sud, hundreds of citizens, called and led by the Struggling People's Organization party (OPL), held a protest with banners against rising insecurity and the poor work of the Transitional Presidential Council (CPT) in governing the country. They demanded the resignation of the council. The police intervened (methods unspecified) to disperse the protesters.

On 22 July 2025, in Delmas - Puits Blain, Ouest, unidentified individuals kidnapped a man who was near the Espoir Hospital while he was in his vehicle. The man was a public employee at the National Book Directorate (DNL). He was released six days later after a ransom was paid.

source: AFP; Aid Worker Security Database; Alterpresse; AP; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Gleaner; Jamaica Observer; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trinidad and Tobago Guardian; Trip Foumi; Vi Free Press
notes: On 3 August 2025, in Kenscoff - Obleon, Ouest, the Base 5 Secondes Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition) kidnapped eight people at the Sainte-Helene Orphanage (run by the Our Little Brothers and Sisters NGO), in the Tete Bois-Pin locality. Among the victims, there was an Irish missionary woman, a three-year-old child, and six employees from the orphanage. The kidnappers made a hole in the building's wall before taking the victims who were asleep. The Ireland national confirmed the abduction via telephone, although it was not possible to confirm anything else about the incident. There has not been a ransom request. By 19 August, five of the hostages had been released. The rest of the victims were released on 29 August.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Standard; Juno 7; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Trip Foumi
notes: On 7 August 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Champs de Mars, Ouest, in the early morning, members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang and the Grand-Ravine Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition) attacked the National Palace, leading to clashes with on-site police forces who managed to repel the attack and killed dozens of criminals. Their bodies were scattered on the street. The gang members also attempted to invade the Port-au-Prince police station and to set the Ministry of the Interior on fire in the same neighborhood. The police prevented it. This was part of a broader coordinated gang offensive against the designation of the new president of the Transitional Presidential Council (coded separately). The offensive included the burning of security forces' armored vehicles in Kenscoff (coded separately). At least 12 fatalities.

On 7 August 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, armed clashes were registered in the neighborhood. The identity of the involved armed actors was not clarified, although based on residents' claims that drones were launched in the area, it is likely that the clashes involved police forces trying to expel gang members, who attacked several neighborhoods in Port-au-Prince on that day as part of a coordinated offensive against the designation of the new president of the Transitional Presidential Council (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 29 July 2025, in Delmas - Pele Simon, Ouest, police forces engaged in clashes with gang members in Pele Simon neighborhood. During clashes, an employee at the University of the State of Haiti (UEH) was killed by stray bullets fired by the gangsters. 1 fatality.
On 2 August 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, the police carried out a security operation, killing two gangsters. They also seized a weapon and a motorcycle. 2 fatalities.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 2 August 2025, in Tabarre - Truitier, Ouest, the police shot and killed two gang members during a clash in the neighborhood. The clash erupted as they conducted a security operation in the area. The police also seized a weapon and a motorcycle. 2 fatalities.
On 7 August 2025, in Lascahobas, Centre, the police engaged in clashes with gang members, killing several of them. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 7 August 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, armed clashes were registered in the commune. Gunshots were heard. There is no information on the actors involved in the clashes, although it happened as the Viv Ansanm Gang carried out a broader gang offensive across several communes of the Port-au-Prince arrondissement against the designation of the new president of the Transitional Presidential Council (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Vant Bef Info
notes: On 2 August 2025, in Piatre, Artibonite, armed residents from two rival neighborhoods (the Anba Kanal locality and the Anwo Kanal locality) engaged in clashes in Piatre and Pierre Payen (coded separately), resulting in the killing of at least two people and the injuring of several others. Around 50 houses were set on fire. The clashes were part of a soccer-related dispute that started in April 2024 (nature of the dispute unspecified), and that resurfaced after the killing of man at the beginning of the month (coded separately). 2 fatalities spread across two events. 1 coded here.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Vant Bef Info
notes: On 2 August 2025, in Pierre Payen, Artibonite, armed residents from two rival neighborhoods (the Anba Kanal locality and the Anwo Kanal locality) engaged in clashes in Pierre Payen and Piatre (coded separately), resulting in the killing of at least two people and the injuring of several others. Around 50 houses were set on fire. The clashes were part of a soccer-related dispute that started in April 2024 (nature of the dispute unspecified), and that resurfaced after the killing of man at the beginning of the month (coded separately). 2 fatalities spread across two events. 1 coded here.

source: Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Juno 7; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 4 August 2025, in Tabarre - Chateau Blond, Ouest, according to witnessing residents, gang members engaged in clashes with the police near the US Embassy, forcing the institution to shut down its doors. Gunshots were heard across the area. Casualties unknown.

actor2: MSS: Multinational Security Support Mission in Haiti (2023-2025)
source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Jamaica Observer; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vi Free Press
notes: On 7 August 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, in the early morning, police forces supported by the Multinational Security Support Mission (MSS) clashed with the Viv Ansanm Gang during an anti-gang operation in the commune. Three MSS members were injured, while a gang member was killed and an unspecified number of other gangsters were injured and fled the scene. The incident forced the security forces to abandon two armored vehicles to which the gang members set fire using Molotov cocktails. They posted an online video showing the incident. Gunshots were heard in the area and a house was burnt down. This was part of a broader coordinated gang offensive against the designation of the new president of the Transitional Presidential Council (coded separately). The mentioned offensive included an attack against the National Palace (coded separately). 1 fatality, at least 3 injured.

actor1: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
notes: On 31 July 2025, in Drouet, Artibonite, members of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang attacked residents, injuring several of them. Many residents were forced to flee the area. Several injured.

On 3 August 2025, in Jean Denis, Artibonite, members of the Coalition of Revolutionaries to Save the Artibonite Gang (a.k.a. Jean-Denis Gang coalition) killed a man who was intercepted transporting weapons for the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang. The gang members also set fire to a house in connection to the matter, and held two women, including the concubine of the now deceased. 1 fatality.

On 6 August 2025, in the Gros-Morne commune, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang carried out an attack, shooting and killing two people, and injuring a third one near the Jacques Roumain school, in the Pay Kann locality. The motivation for the attack is unknown. 2 fatalities. 1 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Vi Free Press
notes: On 7 August 2025, in Carrefour, Ouest, police forces on an armored vehicle opened fire on unclarified targets, killing a woman passenger and injuring a public transport driver who were at a bus terminal. The circumstances of the shooting remain unclear. 1 fatality, 1 injured.

On 7 August 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 30, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang carried out an attack against the Delmas 30 and Delmas 32 (coded separately) neighborhoods, causing residents to flee their homes. This was part of a broader coordinated gang offensive against the designation of the new president of the Transitional Presidential Council. Several gang attacks were registered in the Port-au-Prince arrondissement on that day (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 7 August 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 32, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang carried out an attack against the Delmas 32 and Delmas 30 (coded separately) neighborhoods, causing residents to flee their homes. Roadblocks were erected in Delmas 32, likely by the gang members. This was part of a broader coordinated gang offensive against the designation of the new president of the Transitional Presidential Council. Several gang attacks were registered in the Port-au-Prince arrondissement on that day (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
Property destruction: On 27 July 2025, in Petite-Anse, Nord, in the early morning, police forces seized 425 kg of marijuana during an anti-drug operation. A man and two women were arrested.

source: Alterpresse; Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Vi Free Press
notes: Other: On 7 August 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, a businessman, known for frequent traveling and being discreet, was unexpectedly nominated as the new president of the Transitional Presidential Council (CPT). Concerns arise over his possible ties to corruption and gangs as part of the private sector, along with an unclear inaugural speech at Villa D'Accueil, casting doubt on political transparency and the prospects for a genuine democratic transition, and highlight foreign intervention in Haitian politics, including with the original creation of the CPT.

Other: On 7 August 2025, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Drouillard. The authorship of the gunshots was not clarified, although they were not ruled out to be gang-related. Several gang-related incidents were registered in the arrondissement of Port-au-Prince on that day (coded separately) as part of a broader coordinated gang offensive against the designation of the new president of the Transitional Presidential Council, announced by the Viv Ansanm Gang leader hours earlier.

Other: On 7 August 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 19, Delmas 31 (Maguana neighborhood), and Christ-Roi, causing residents to flee their homes. The authorship of the gunshots was not clarified, although they were not ruled out to be gang-related. Several gang-related incidents were registered in the arrondissement of Port-au-Prince on that day (coded separately) as part of a broader coordinated gang offensive against the designation of the new president of the Transitional Presidential Council, announced by the Viv Ansanm Gang leader hours earlier.

Other: On 7 August 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard on the Freres Road near the Police Academy, and the Juvenat neighborhood. The authorship of the gunshots was not clarified, although they were not ruled out to be gang-related. Several gang-related incidents were registered in the arrondissement of Port-au-Prince on that day (coded separately) as part of a broader coordinated gang offensive against the designation of the new president of the Transitional Presidential Council.

On 7 August 2025, between Petionville and Delmas 60 (coded to Delmas - Delmas 60), Ouest, dozens of residents and government supporters marched from Petionville towards Villa D'Accueil (Delmas 60) in support of the new president of the Transitional Presidential Council (CPT). They wore t-shirts with the face of the presidents.

actor2: Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang
source: Haiti Press Network; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 11 August 2025, in Liancourt, Artibonite, police forces supported by members of a self-defense group clashed with the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang during an anti-gang security operation. During clashes, a police officer was shot and killed, while a self-defense group member and several gangsters were shot and injured. The officer was in an armored vehicle when he was shot in the head. 1 fatality, several injured.

On 13 August 2025, in Delmas - Kernizan, Ouest, the police shot and killed at least three armed individuals during an intervention that thwarted the kidnapping of several public employees near the La Paix University hospital. The victims had been intercepted by the kidnappers moments. Some of the abductors managed to flee the scene. The kidnapped victims were released unharmed. At least 3 fatalities.
On 8 August 2025, in Tabarre - Clercine, Ouest, the police shot and killed two gang members during an operation. 2 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Standard; Jamaica Gleaner; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 12 August 2025, in Kenscoff - Obleon, Ouest, overnight, the police clashed with members of the Viv Ansanm Gang near the former Teleco base, in the Morne Tranchant area. After digging a hole to ambush a police patrol, the gangsters attacked their armored vehicle, killing two police officers and injuring three others before they managed to escape. Two civilians were also injured. The gangsters set fire to the deceased officers' bodies inside a house. They also set fire to an armored vehicle and houses, and took weapons and ammunition from the scene. They posted videos of the scene. At least five gangsters were also killed during the clash. The police did not intervene on time to prevent the incident, despite calls from residents. The police later regained control over the area. At least 7 fatalities. 5 injured.

Around 1 August 2025 (as reported), in Pierre Payen, Artibonite, armed members of the population killed a man during a funeral wake. Two men were accused of the attack, although both denied the accusations. The man's family claimed that they had been receiving threats. The attack happened in the framework of a conflict between armed residents from the Anba Kanal and Anwo Kanal rival localities. The conflict was linked to a soccer-related dispute that started in April 2024 (nature of the dispute unspecified). Later in August, the same conflict led to the killing of at least two people and the burning of around 50 houses (coded separately). 1 fatality.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Vi Free Press
notes: Security measures: On 8 August 2025, in the Artibonite department (coded to Gonaives), the government declared a three-month state of emergency (SOE) in the Artibonite, Ouest, and Centre departments (coded separately). The measure was an extension of a SOE originally imposed nationwide on 30 April 2025 (coded separately). The SOE aims at fighting gang violence and insecurity, as well as handling the agricultural and food crisis.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Vi Free Press
notes: Security measures: On 8 August 2025, in the Centre department (coded to Hinche), the government declared a three-month state of emergency (SOE) in the Centre, Artibonite, and Ouest departments (coded separately). The measure was an extension of a SOE originally imposed nationwide on 30 April 2025 (coded separately). The SOE aims at fighting gang violence and insecurity, as well as handling the agricultural and food crisis.

source: Alterpresse; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Vi Free Press
notes: Security measures: On 8 August 2025, in the Ouest department (coded to Port-au-Prince), the government declared a three-month state of emergency (SOE) in the Ouest, Centre, and Artibonite departments (coded separately). The measure was an extension of a SOE originally imposed nationwide on 30 April 2025 (coded separately). The SOE aims at fighting gang violence and insecurity, as well as handling the agricultural and food crisis.

On 9 August 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 60, Ouest, women, led by a feminist organization and carrying banners, protested to demand justice and protection for victims of sexual violence. The protesting women demanded a judicial reform and accountability, especially in a context where gangs use sexual violence as a weapon of terror. The march, which set out for Villa d'Accueil (Musseau), was blocked by the police and was forced to turn back, ending instead at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Delmas 60).

On 18 August 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 33, Ouest, unidentified armed individuals kidnapped a person from a car in Delmas 33. There is no information on the perpetrators, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victim's whereabouts are unknown.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; Jamaica Gleaner; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)
notes: On 19 August 2025, in Kenscoff - Obleon, Ouest, the Base 5 Secondes Gang (affiliated to the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition) kidnapped three employees from the Sainte-Helene orphanage (run by the Our Little Brothers and Sisters NGO). The gang members also stole an ambulance and food from the orphanage premises. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

Around 22 July 2025 (as reported), in Kenscoff, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched drone strikes in the Viard area. Three explosions were heard. Similar drone strikes targeting gang-controlled areas were registered in the Kenscoff commune on previous days (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 31 July 2025, in Kenscoff, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) suspectedly launched drone strikes in the commune. Two explosions were heard. Similar explosions were heard in the Centre-Ville neighborhood of Port-au-Prince earlier that day (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 31 July 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) suspectedly launched drone strikes in the neighborhood. Five explosions were heard. Similar explosions were heard in the Kenscoff commune later that day (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 19 August 2025, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, the security guard of the director of the National Old Age Insurance Office (ONA) was shot and killed. The shots were described as fired from a police patrol. Several police institutions were under investigation over their involvement in an operation that might have caused the death of the officer, although the circumstances of the attack are still unclear. 1 fatality.

Around 25 July 2025 (between 25 - 26 July), in Petion Ville - Soissons, Ouest, the police opened fire on unidentified targets as they conducted a security operation in the Ti Ga area, near the Notre Dame de Lourdes Church. The operation was conducted after being informed of suspected activity in the area. Gunshots were heard. Casualties unknown.

Around 18 August 2025 (as reported), in Kenscoff - Obleon, Ouest, the police clashed with gang members near the Teleco base (Morne Tranchant area). This was the continuation of armed clashes registered between the police and gang members in the area since 16 August (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 18 July 2025, in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, in the early morning, armed clashes were recorded between unidentified individuals in areas near the Freres Road, including the Pernier, Corvette, and Metivier neighborhoods, and the Impasse Gracien area (Freres neighborhood) (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 18 July 2025, in Petion Ville - Metivier, Ouest, in the early morning, armed clashes were recorded between unidentified individuals in areas near the Freres Road, including the Metivier, Pernier, and Corvette neighborhoods, and the Impasse Gracien area (Freres neighborhood) (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 18 July 2025, in Petion Ville - Corvette, Ouest, in the early morning, armed clashes were recorded between unidentified individuals in areas near the Freres Road, including the Corvette, Metivier, and Pernier neighborhoods, and the Impasse Gracien area (Freres neighborhood) (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 18 July 2025, in Petion Ville - Freres, Ouest, in the early morning, armed clashes were recorded between unidentified individuals in areas near the Freres Road, including the Impasse Gracien area (Freres neighborhood), and the Corvette, Metivier, and Pernier neighborhoods (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

source: Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 16 August 2025, in Kenscoff - Obleon, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang set fire to houses and threw Molotov cocktails against an armored police vehicle near the Teleco base (Morne Tranchant area), from where the police resisted to the attack. The gangsters also blocked several roads, cut access to the area, and poured oil on the streets to prevent police forces from intervening. Gunshots resulting from the clash between the police and the gangsters were heard in the area throughout the day, as the security forces tried to regain control over the area. Security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) used drones to attack the gangsters in addition to firing shots. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 16 August 2025, in L'Estere, Artibonite, members of the Kokorat San Ras Gang traveling on motorcycles attacked a funeral procession, killing four people (two men and two women) and injuring five others (two men and three women) (drive-by). The gang accused the victims of belonging to a self-defense brigade from Kapenyen. The affiliation of the victims was not clarified. 4 fatalities, 5 injured.

Around 15 July 2025 (between 14 - 17 July), in Grande Saline, Artibonite, armed group members launched a coordinated offensive against Grande Saline, Liancourt, Jean-Denis, Desarmes, and Montrouis (coded separately). An unspecified number of casualties were registered (nature of casualties unclaried), while homes and vehicles were destroyed. Casualties unknown.

Around 15 July 2025 (between 14 - 17 July), in Montrouis, Artibonite, armed group members launched a coordinated offensive against Montrouis, Grande Saline, Liancourt, Jean-Denis, and Desarmes (coded separately). An unspecified number of casualties were registered (nature of casualties unclarified), while homes and vehicles were destroyed. Casualties unknown.

Around 15 July 2025 (between 14 - 17 July), in Desarmes, Artibonite, armed group members launched a coordinated offensive against Desarmes, Montrouis, Grande Saline, Liancourt, and Jean-Denis (coded separately). An unspecified number of casualties were registered (nature of casualties unclarified), while homes and vehicles were destroyed. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 17 August 2025, in Petion Ville - Pelerin 2, Ouest, armed individuals riding a motorcycle shot and killed a former presidential candidate and businessman while he was in his car in Pelerin 2, near Morne Calvaire (drive-by). The motivation for the attack are unknown, although the victim was associated with a 2021 murder case in which his son was a suspect. The now deceased had posted a message the previous day questioning the aspirations of the political class. The victim was also known as a nationalist who supported state authority and social progress. 1 fatality.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti; SG Alert (Whatsapp)
notes: On 29 July 2025, in Delmas - Carrefour Drouillard/Parc Industriel, Ouest, members of the Simon-Pele Gang attacked a business establishment on Monplaisir Avenue, and abducted nine employees inside. The gang members opened indiscriminate fire, killing five people. Heavy gunfire was heard. The abducted employees were later released. 5 fatalities.

source: Gazette Haiti; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes
notes: Detonation: On 19 August 2025, in Kenscoff - Corail, Ouest, two police officers were killed and at least five others were injured (up to six according to other sources) by the accidental explosion of a drone in the Carrefour Maroca area (close to the Kenscoff police station, in Corail neighborhood). The drone was launched against gangs, but as it failed to explode due to technical issues, the population brought it to the police, where it exploded. The accident motivated a demonstration by police officers later that day (coded separately). 2 fatalities, at least 5 injured.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Standard; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: On 18 August 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Musseau-Delmas 48, Ouest, a dozen of trainee teachers held a sit-in protest in front of the Ministry of National Education and Vocational Training (MENFP) to demand their inclusion in the educational system. An agent from the ministry's security personnel fired shots to disperse the crowd, hitting and killing a student (unrelated to the protest) who was passing through on the back on a motorcycle. A security guard from the Ministry was arrested in connection to the incident. 15 others who were present on the day of the incident were also suspended by the Ministry. 1 fatality.
Property destruction: Around 27 July 2025 (as reported), in L'Estere, Artibonite, the Kokorat San Ras Gang looted and set fire to the MIVO Foundation (private entity) Orthopedic Hospital.
On 14 August 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bourdon, Ouest, members of the population burned a man alive after he had looted and vandalized several vehicles in the area. 1 fatality.

Other: On 22 July 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, roadblocks of unspecified materials were set up on Dalencourt street (Canape-Vert neighborhood), while roadblocks of flaming tires were erected in the Debrosse neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances of these roadblocks or who set them up. In the nearby Bourdon neighborhood, a protest against insecurity involved the erection of barricades (coded separately), although it was not confirmed if the barricades in Canape-Vert and Debrosse were related to that protest.

Other: On 19 July 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Musseau neighborhood, likely coming from the nearby Delmas 60 neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 22 July 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Pacot and Carrefour-Feuilles neighborhoods. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 26 July 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Pacot and Carrefour-Feuilles neighborhoods. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 31 July 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Delmas 30 and Pele Simon neighborhoods. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 1 August 2025, in Carrefour, Ouest, in the early morning, gunshots were heard. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 2 August 2025, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard on National Road 1, in Carrefour Vincent, and the Sarthe neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 5 August 2025, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Sarthe neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 5 August 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard along the Airport Road at the entrance of the Delmas 19 neighborhood. Unidentified armed men were seen on the road.

Other: On 5 August 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Tabarre 41 (Chateau Blond neighborhood). There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots, although it is known that clashes between gangs and the police were recorded in the area the day before (coded separately).

source: Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Prensa Latina; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi
notes: Non-violent transfer of territory: Around 20 August 2025 (as reported), in Kenscoff - Obleon, Ouest, Viv Ansanm gang members took over the Teleco base (Morne Tranchant area), occupied the facilities, and gave the authorities a 48-hour ultimatum to negotiate with them before destroying equipment. Online videos showed members of the Base 5 Secondes Gang at the site after the takeover. The demands of the gangsters were unclear. The incident put all types of communication channels at risk. The occupation persisted for several days. The police regained control on 25 August during an operation (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Standard; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes
notes: On 21 August 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Musseau-Delmas 48, Ouest, hundreds of citizens, including influencers, bloggers, and family members protested in front of the Ministry of National Education and Vocational Training (MENFP) to demand justice for a student and influencer guy who was killed on 18 August during the police repression of a teachers' protest (coded separately). Protesters denounced the police excessive use of force and demanded accountability. They demanded the arrest of the agent who shot the students and the resignation of the minister.

On 21 July 2025, in Leogane, Ouest, internally displaced residents from Gressier held a protest to demand the resignation of the commune's police commissioner. Protesters claimed that he was not actively fighting against gang activity in Gressier.

On 23 July 2025, in Les Cayes, Sud, residents held a protest on the Arms Square to demand that the Antoine Simon Airport be accredited to receive international flights, and against certain airlines and related companies.

On 30 July 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Musseau-Delmas 48, Ouest, unidentified citizens held a protest outside of the Prime Minister's residence (a.k.a. Villa D'Accueil or Prime Minister's Primature), over unclarified claims.

On 31 July 2025, in Petion Ville - Centre Ville (Ouest), Ouest, residents protested outside of the Organization of the American States (OAS) headquarters, at the intersection of Darguin and Clerveau streets. The motivation for the protest was not clarified, although it was likely linked to a roadmap for Haiti released by the OAS the day prior, that aimed at bringing stability to the country.
On 4 August 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Musseau-Delmas 48, Ouest, unidentified citizens held a small protest in front of the Prime Minister's residence over unclarified claims.

On 15 August 2025, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, in the morning, several activists held a protest in front of the Cap-Haitien cathedral against the Transitional Presidential Council (CPT). Protesters denounced the CPT poor governmental work. They accused the government of stealing money and complained about the amount of garbage in the city. The protest was held during the patron saint's day celebration in the city. Protesters claimed that the CPT members were not welcomed.

source: Haiti Press Network; Haiti Standard; Juno 7
notes: On 19 August 2025, in Tabarre - Clercine, Ouest, around 10 police officers held a demonstration in front of the General Directorate of the Haitian Police (DGPNH) to decry the killing of two police officers and the injuring of at least five others by a drone that accidentally exploded in Kenscoff earlier that day (coded separately). The demonstrating officers threw unidentified objects against the DGPNH building. They also fired shots. One version stated that shots were fired in the air, while another version stated that they were directly fired against the DGPNH building.

On 21 August 2025, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, overnight, residents erected barricades of burning tires to demonstrate against the newly nominated Interim Executive Board. They blocked roads, interfering with night activities in the city. Demonstrators expressed their disagreement with the exclusion of a specific individual from the communal board and demanded his assignment as the board's president.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 14 June 2025, in Cabaret, Ouest, unidentified armed individuals abducted four teachers inside a school. There is no information on the perpetrators, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 7 June 2025, in Santo, Ouest, the 400 Mawozo Gang burned down a house, killing a 15-year-old girl and her parents, who were inside. The attack was carried out in the framework of a conflict between the 400 Mawozo Gang and the Chien Mechant Gang. Clashes had erupted between these gangs as the Chien Mechant Gang refused to remove a gate at a toll station that the 400 Mawozo gang deemed no longer necessary. Both gangs were allies due to affiliation to the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition. 3 fatalities.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 9 May 2025, off the Coast of Mariani, Ouest, the Grand-Ravine Gang abducted 20 civilians (15 merchants and five crew members) traveling in a sailboat. Their whereabouts are unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 2 April 2025, in Leogane, Ouest, a member of the Ti Bwa Gang killed a self-defense group member during an attack on a public market in the Jasmin neighborhood. 1 fatality.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 20 June 2025, in Leogane, Ouest, members of the Ti Bwa Gang shot and killed a man as he tried to resist the robbery of his motorcycle in the Jasmin neighborhood. 1 fatality.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 26 May 2025, in Carrefour - Mariani, Ouest, the 103 Zombies Gang beat up an abducted man after interrogating him and holding him hostage at their stronghold (in Mariani neighborhood). The victim was a man who had been taken to the gang's base by residents who witnessed how he killed his partner on the streets of Merger earlier that day. The gang members asked for the payment of a 500,000 gourdes ransom as a condition for his release. His whereabouts are unknown. His health state was not clarified.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 15 February 2025 (month of), in Cite Soleil, Ouest, members of the National Police of Haiti engaged in sexual violence against an unspecified number of civilians (gender unclarified). One survivor denounced the sexual assault in April.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 18 April 2025, in Cite Soleil - Brooklyn, Ouest, gang members controlling the neighborhood (likely the Ti Gabriel Gang, a.k.a. Brooklyn Gang) killed 22 people (15 men and seven women) in reprisal for the victims' participation in acts of ransacking and robbery in the Mirebalais commune the week prior. 22 fatalities.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 28 May 2025, in Cite Soleil - Waaf Jeremie, Ouest, members of the Micanord Gang, under the orders of their leader, killed 15 elderly men during a voodoo ceremony in the neighborhood. Their throats were slashed, and the killings were presented as a sacrifice in the context of the voodoo ceremony. The victims' bodies were burned once the ceremony was over. 15 fatalities.

Around 6 August 2025 (as reported), in Delmas - Delmas 19/Joseph Janvier, Ouest, unidentified armed individuals kidnapped an unspecified number of people in Delmas 19. There is no information on the circumstances and the authorship of the abduction, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 3 May 2025, in Delmas - Delmas 19/Mackandal, Ouest, UTAG police agents executed five women in Delmas 19. The victims were killed for being the sentimental partners of members from the Delmas 6 Gang, and over accusations of collecting information for the gang. Their affiliation was not confirmed. 5 fatalities.

Around 6 August 2025 (as reported), in Delmas - Delmas 65, Ouest, unidentified armed individuals kidnapped an unspecified number of people in Delmas 65. There is no information on the circumstances and the authorship of the abduction, although latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 15 May 2025, in Delmas - Pele Simon, Ouest, gang members controlling the neighborhood (likely from the Simon-Pele Gang) raped two women and shot them dead. Their bodies were then set on fire. The victims were intercepted as they were returning from the nearby Boston neighborhood, which had been recently declared off-limits to the residents of the Pele Simon neighborhood by the gang leader due to tensions between the gangs controlling these two neighborhoods (likely referring to Simon-Pele Gang and Nan Boston Gang). 2 fatalities.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: Around 15 April 2025 (month of), in Gressier, Ouest, gang members abducted several women when they travelled in a public transport vehicle and took them to the gang's stronghold, where they were raped. One of the women was shot and killed. Her body was found the day after. The other victims were still held as hostages by the end of June. Their whereabouts are unknown. 1 fatality.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 8 June 2025, in Gressier - Santo, Ouest, police forces arrested a man after the population accused him of being a gang member trying to take refuge at a property in the Santo neighborhood. After being arrested, the man was shot and killed in nearby La Colline area. His affiliation was not clarified. 1 fatality.
On 3 August 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, citizens called by the Committed Democrats Movement for a Strong and Inclusive Haiti (DEHFI) held a march calling for national unity.

source: Amerique Info 7; BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 21 June 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Martissant, Ouest, security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) launched drone strikes in Martissant 2A, not far from Village de Dieu (in nearby Cite de Dieu neighborhood). The drones were targeting gang-controlled areas, although they killed two women and injured seven civilians (four men and three women) by mistake. One of the killed women was shot while selling her products on the street. Another one was killed inside her home, where two gang members, chased by a drone, had taken refuge. It was not clarified whether the gang members were hit. 2 fatalities, 7 injured.

source: BINUH: United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti
notes: On 5 April 2025, in Tabarre - Butte Boyer, Ouest, the Chien Mechant Gang shot and killed five residents over accusations that they were suspectedly collaborating with police forces deployed in the area. The victims were killed at their homes in Clercine 22. Dozens of houses were ransacked. 5 fatalities.

On 18 August 2025, in Delmas - Peligre, Ouest, in the morning, unidentified individuals abducted a man from his vehicle along the Delmas 33 Road at the intersection with Lafontant street (Peligre neighborhood). Police had thwarted a kidnapping attempt three days prior in the vicinity of Delmas 33, near La Paix Hospital (coded separately). The whereabouts of the victim are unknown.

On 11 August 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, in the morning, a drone strike by security forces (likely the Task Force coded as Police forces) hit a house located between Nicolas street and Magloire Ambroise (Bas Peu de Choses), killing four gang members who were inside. An adjacent building housing a lottery outpost was destroyed. 4 fatalities.

source: Alterpresse; AP; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Press Network; Haiti Standard; Jamaica Gleaner; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); PNH: National Police of Haiti; Rezo Nodwes; Trip Foumi; Vi Free Press
notes: On 25 August 2025, in Kenscoff - Obleon, Ouest, in the early morning, the police and the Multinational Security Support Mission (MSS) clashed with the Base 5 Secondes Gang (affiliated with the Viv Ansanm Gang) at the Teleco base in the Morne Tranchant area, killing several gangsters and arresting several others. Four bodies of gang members were collected, although the official number of total fatalities was not confirmed. The police was able to regain control over the area after the gangsters occupied it on 20 August (coded separately). Several weapons and materials were seized, and several roadblocks were removed, restoring circulation. A former congressman candidate publicly claimed that he did not believe that the security forces managed to repel the gangsters but, instead, paid them to leave the premises. This would have responded to the gang members' request to negotiate with them to avoid the destruction of communication equipment. He claimed that the official images and reports were fabricated. At least 4 fatalities.

On 27 August 2025, in Petion Ville - Fort Jacques, Ouest, the police, supported by self-defense brigades, clashed with the Kraze Barye Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang in Fort Jacques, Bois Greffin, Metivier, Doco, and Gros Jean (coded separately). Seven gang members were killed and several others were injured. The police seized communication equipment. Gunshots were also heard in Puits Blain. 7 fatalities split across four events. 1 coded here. Several injured.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Haiti Press Network; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 27 August 2025, in Petion Ville - Bois Greffin, Ouest, the police, supported by self-defense brigades, clashed with the Kraze Barye Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang in Bois Greffin, Metivier, Fort Jacques, Doco, and Gros Jean (coded separately). Seven gang members were killed and several others were injured. Two gang members were killed near the Greffin market, where they had set fire to more than three houses before the authorities intervened. The police seized communication equipment. Gunshots were heard in Puits Blain. 7 fatalities split across four events. 2 coded here. Several injured.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Trip Foumi
notes: On 27 August 2025, in Petion Ville - Metivier, Ouest, the police, supported by self-defense brigades, clashed with the Kraze Barye Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang in Metivier, Bois Greffin, Fort Jacques, Doco, and Gros Jean (coded separately). Seven gang members were killed and several others were injured. Two gang members were killed near the Metivier Road. The police seized communication equipment. Gunshots were also heard in Puits Blain. 7 fatalities split across four events. 2 coded here. Several injured.

source: Alterpresse; Amerique Info 7; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Metropole; PNH: National Police of Haiti; Trip Foumi
notes: On 27 August 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, the police, supported by self-defense brigades, clashed with the Kraze Barye Gang and the 400 Mawozo Gang in the Doco and Gros Jean localities, as well as along the Freres Road, and the Bois Greffin, Metivier, and Fort Jacques neighborhoods (coded separately). Seven gang members were killed and several others were injured. The police seized communication equipment. Gunshots were also heard in Puits Blain. 7 fatalities split across four events. 2 coded here. Several injured.
On 7 August 2025, in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, police forces supported by members of a self-defense group clashed with unidentified gang members. Casualties unknown.

On 16 August 2025, in Marassa, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition clashed with security forces in Marassa. Clashes were also registered in the vicinity of the nearby Tabarre bridge (Tabarre 27 neighborhood) (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 16 August 2025, in Tabarre - Tabarre 27, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition clashed with security forces in the Tabarre bridge area (Tabarre 27 neighborhood). Clashes were also registered in the nearby Marassa neighborhood (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 14 August 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Christ-Roi, Ouest, the Viv Ansanm Gang coalition clashed with members of an unidentified self-defense group. Casualties unknown.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 24 August 2025, in Gros-Morne, Artibonite, the Kokorat San Ras Gang shot at residents in the downtown area, killing at least five civilians (up to six according to other versions) and injuring several others. Dozens of families were forced to flee. Among the injured victims there was an entrepreneur who was shot at his residence before being abducted. The gang members requested a ransom in exchange for his release. A second entrepreneur was also kidnapped. On 31 August, one of the businessmen was freed after the payment of a ransom by the family. The whereabouts of the other victim are unknown. At least 5 fatalities. 1 injured.

On 13 December 2024, in the arrondissement of Port-au-Prince, Ouest, unidentified armed men attacked the house watchman at the residence of an off-duty police officer. The police officer disappeared and was presumed to have been abducted by the armed attackers, who also stole nine AR-15 rifles from a car at the residence. The abducted victim had previously served as a liaison for American military contractors hired by the government to fight gangs. His whereabouts are unknown, although he was presumed dead.

On 16 December 2024, in Petion Ville - Vivy Mitchell, Ouest, unidentified armed men dressed in police uniforms and traveling in two vehicles, including a police vehicles, opened fire on a car transporting a Haitian/American man who had served as a liaison for American military contractors hired by the government to fight against gangs, and his friend. The man was abducted from the vehicle, while his friend was shot and injured but survived the attack. The abducted victim is the cousin of a police officer who had also worked with the military contractors and who had disappeared three days prior following an attack by unidentified armed men (coded separately). The whereabouts of the victim are unknown, although he was presumed dead. 1 injured.

On 25 August 2025, in the Lascahobas commune, Centre, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang carried out an attack, setting fire to several houses and stealing farmers' livestock in the Saint Martin locality. Casualties unknown.

Other: On 9 August 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, barricades of flaming tires were set up in the Turgeau neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances of the roadblock or who set it up. Simultaneously, residents demonstrated in the nearby Canape-Vert neighborhood to demand the release of a person (coded separately). It was not clarified if the barricades in Turgeau had something to do with the mobilization in Canape-Vert.

Non-violent activity: Around 25 August 2025 (between 25 - 26 August), in Mirebalais, Centre, members of the Taliban Gang joined a cultural celebration on the occasion of the Saint Louis patron Saint's day, at the Mirebalais public square. The gang members were seen distributing money among people. The participants wore t-shirts with pictures of the Taliban gang leader. The presence of gang members showed the control the gangs hold on the city, which remained desert as residents refused to share with gangsters. Residents had previously held protests to demand the intervention of the authorities, including the closing of the Peligre hydroelectric central (coded separately), without success.

Other: On 6 August 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, for a second consecutive day, gunshots were heard on the October 15 Boulevard at the height of Tabarre 41 (Chateau Blond neighborhood). There is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots, although it is known that clashes between gangs and the police were recorded in the area on 4 August (coded separately).

Other: On 7 August 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Turgeau and Christ-Roi neighborhoods. The authorship of the gunshots was not clarified, although they were not ruled out to be gang-related. Several gang-related incidents were registered in the arrondissement of Port-au-Prince on that day (coded separately) as part of a broader coordinated gang offensive against the designation of the new president of the Transitional Presidential Council.
Other: On 9 August 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, in the early morning, gunshots were heard. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 10 August 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Tabarre 41, near the US Embassy (Chateau Blond neighborhood), and near the Tabarre bridge (Tabarre 27 neighborhood). There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 13 August 2025, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Pernier neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 13 August 2025, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in the Torcelle neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.
Other: On 17 August 2025, in Delmas, Ouest, in the evening, gunshots were heard in the Delmas 32 neighborhood. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 18 August 2025, in Cite Soleil, Ouest, in the morning, gunshots were heard in the Drouillard neighborhood, likely originating from Hubert Street near Carrefour Vincent (Sarthe neighborhood). There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 20 August 2025, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard on the road to Canape-Vert, notably along the Lamartiniere Avenue. There is no information on the circumstances or the authorship of the gunshots.

On 24 August 2025, in Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13, Ouest, hundreds of displaced residents from the Solino, Nazon, Delmas 24, and Delmas 30 neighborhoods marched from Bourdon to Carrefour Aeroport to denounce the poor living conditions at the shelters for displaced people. They also expressed their desire to return home after they were forced to leave their neighborhoods due to gang violence.
On 11 August 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Musseau-Delmas 48, Ouest, a small group of residents protested in front of the Villa d'Accueil over unclarified claims.
On 27 August 2025, in Les Cayes, Sud, dozens of residents took to the street in support of the government commissioner, Ernst Muscadin, and to protest against rumors stating his possible dismissal.

On 22 August 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Musseau-Delmas 48, Ouest, supporters and signatories of the Caribbean Agreement held a sit-in protest front in front of Villa D'Accueil to demand the departure of the Presidential Transitional Council (CPT). Protesters decried rising insecurity.

location: Delmas - St Louis de Gonzague- Henfrasa -Palais de l'art
notes: On 13 August 2025, in Delmas - St Louis de Gonzague- Henfrasa -Palais de l'art, Ouest, internally displaced residents held a demonstration and set tires on fire in front of Saint Louis de Gonzague. Their claims were not clarified, although they were likely demonstrating in relation to forced displacement from their neighborhood due to rising insecurity and gang violence.

On 9 August 2025, in Port-au-Prince - Canape-Vert, Ouest, residents erected barricades of flaming tires on the streets and in the Canape-Vert square to demand the release of a person who had been arrested in Aquin.

On 12 August 2025, in Dufort, Ouest, residents set up barricades and blocked circulation to demonstrate against the possible transfer of a police commissioner. During the mobilization, demonstrating rioters threw rocks and bottles, and sporadic clashes were reported. The police was deployed, but no specific action on their side was mentioned.

On 12 October 2024, in Petion Ville - Pernier, Ouest, overnight, the Kraze Barye Gang (a.k.a. Vitelhomme Gang) opened fire in the so-called 'Kamay' and 'Gwojan' areas, in Pernier. Armed members of the population (self-defense group) clashed with the gang members as they tried to resist the offensive. A self-defense group member was injured. 1 injured.

On 14 October 2024, in Limonade, Nord, students from the Haiti State University held a protest at the Henry Christophe Campus demanding the departure of the de facto Management Council, among other claims. Police forces and armed individuals (identified as security guards from the campus) fired shots and tear gas against the students. There were no casualties.

source: Ordre des Defenseurs des Droits Humains (ORDEDH); Trip Foumi
notes: On 14 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bois Verna, Ouest, a police officer shot and killed a woman when sanitary kits were distributed among displaced residents sheltering at the Marie-Jeanne High School Campus. According to witnesses, the woman was a displaced resident who was forced to move because of gang violence and killed when police forces engaged in a brawl with a resident accused of stealing some kits. 1 fatality.

On 16 October 2024, in Carrefour Zaboca, Grande-Anse, supporters of Guy Phillipe held a protest against the national government by blocking the National Road 7 with big stones and a truck. Guy Phillipe is a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti in early 2024.

On 17 October 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, supporters of Guy Phillipe held a protest against the national government and calling for the departure of Prime Minister, Garry Conille. Guy Phillipe is a former police officer, senator, convict, paramilitary leader, and warlord who had called on taking the streets and leading a revolution in Haiti in early 2024.

Other: On 17 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Poste Marchand and Bois Verna neighborhoods. The gunshots were likely to be the authorship of the Belair Gang, as members of this gang attacked several Port-au-Prince's neighborhoods on that day (coded separately).

On 10 October 2024, in Fonds Baptiste, Ouest, members of the Taliban Gang coming from Canaan area opened fire on the population and set fire to houses as they launched an armed offensive in Fonds Baptiste, Bercy, Arcahaie, and Vignier villages (coded separately). During the attack, an unspecified number of people were killed and injured. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 22 October 2024, near Vignier, Ouest, police forces shot and killed around 15 gang members during clashes in Tamand, Carrefour Pois, and Vignier (coded separately) localities. At least 15 fatalities split across two events. 7 fatalities coded here.

source: Ordre des Defenseurs des Droits Humains (ORDEDH); Trip Foumi
notes: On 19 October 2024, in Delmas - Cite Militaire, Ouest, gang members shot and killed a 17-year-old woman as they attacked and fired shots in Cite Militaire. The victim was at her home when she was hit by a stray bullet. 1 fatality.
On 19 October 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, armed gang members (likely from Viv Ansanm Gang) invaded residential areas in Delmas 24. Casualties unknown.
Other: On 19 October 2024, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Vivy Mitchell. It is suspected that the gunshots were fired by gangs.

source: Amerique Info 7; Ordre des Defenseurs des Droits Humains (ORDEDH)
notes: On 19 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Nazon, Ouest, police forces shot and killed six members of the Chien Mechant Gang in the Nazon neighbourhood. The deceased were in the area to support the Viv Ansanm Gang. 6 fatalities.
Property destruction: On 23 October 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bel Air, Ouest, overnight, police forces destroyed the house of the Belair Gang leader.

On 31 October 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 33, Ouest, police forces beat up a militant man during a political conference organized by a former police officer from the Protected Areas Security Brigade (BSAP). The beating seemed to have happened as police forces tried to arrest the conference's organizers. No further details were mentioned. There were no fatalities.

Around 26 October 2024 (between 25 - 26 October), in Port-au-Prince - Cite Marc I, Ouest, gang members (likely members of the Viv Ansanm alliance) attacked residents and invaded the neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.

source: Amerique Info 7; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Trip Foumi
notes: On 2 November 2024, in Les Cayes, Sud, police forces shot and killed a gang member in the Quatre Chemin Avenue. The killing took place by order of the Mirebalais police commissioner, Ernst Muscadin. It was described as an extrajudicial execution. The deceased had escaped from prison on 3 March. 1 fatality.
On 7 November 2024, in Jacmel, Sud-Est, students from the Pinchinat High School held a protest demanding the reconstruction of the school building. The compound was damaged by an earthquake in 2012.

On 9 March 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Bas Peu de Choses, Ouest, there was a clash between an unidentified gang and police forces. A man not involved in the clash was killed when the people inside an armored vehicle that was protecting the premises of Radio Television Caraibes on Chavennes street mistaken him. 1 fatality.

On 8 March 2024, in Carrefour - Cote Plage, Ouest, rioters set fire to burning tires around the Cote Plage 16 street. Rioters were demanding better security measures and calling on Prime Minister Ariel Henry, who was outside of the country at the time, to not return to Haiti.

On 11 November 2024, in Cite Soleil - Sarthe, Ouest, gang members (likely from the Viv Ansanm Gang) attacked Carrefour Vincent, in the Sarthe neighbourhood. This was likely part of the Viv Ansanm Gang offensive launched after the Presidential Transitional Council (PTC) announced the replacement of the head of the Transitional Government, Garry Conille, by Alix Didier Fils-Aime (coded separately). Casualties unknown.

On 14 November 2024, in Petion Ville - Vivy Mitchell, Ouest, gang members (likely from the Kraze Barye Gang) attacked residents and set fire to a dozen houses on Flamboyant and Lauriersin streets, in the Vivy Mitchell neighbourhood. Gunshots were heard. Some residents fled their homes. Casualties unknown.

On 8 November 2024, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, gang members kidnapped four children and the man who was driving them to school. The man was a former cameraman for Tele Ginen. The kidnapping took place in the Port-au-Prince metropolitan area. The victims were released on 13 November. The leader of the Viv Ansanm gang announced that he was the one who decided to release the hostages and that no ransom had been paid; however, according to sources close to the families of the hostages, a ransom was paid.
On 18 November 2024, Tabarre - Chateau Blond, Ouest, the Kraze Barye Gang engaged in armed clashes with rival gang members in the vicinity of the US Embassy. Casualties unknown.

On 22 November 2024, in Saint-Marc, Artibonite, residents from Pont Sonde held a protest demanding justice for the victims of the 3 of October gang massacre in Pont Sonde (coded separately). Protesters called on authorities to take measures for the dismantling of the Baz Gran Grif de Savien Gang.

On 22 November 2024, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, students from the Haitian Higher Institute of Medical Technology (ISTMECH) held a march to request the integration of the school under the UEH and to study for 4 years.

On 18 November 2024, near Miragoane, Nippes, police forces shot and killed a leader of the Grand-Ravine Gang along the Morne Preval Road. The killing was ordered by the Miragoane police commissioner, Ernst Muscadin. 1 fatality.

On 22 November 2024, in Delmas - Musseau, Ouest, in the morning, a mob of residents coming from Bourdon used sticks, machetes, axes, and stones to lynch a member of the Viv Ansanm Gang in front of the Villa d'Accueil and the Primature premises, in Musseau neighbourhood. The victim was decapitated and his body was burned. He was captured after having escaped hospital. 1 fatality.
Other: On 19 November 2024, in Petionville, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 95 and Delmas 66 (Morne Hercule) neighborhoods. The authorship of the gunshots is unknown.
On 21 November 2024, in Delmas - Carrefour Aeroport/Delmas 13, Ouest, gang members fired shots as they attacked the Carrefour Aeroport neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.
On 21 November 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 17, Ouest, gang members fired shots as they attacked the Delmas 17 neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.
On 21 November 2024, in Delmas - Delmas 32, Ouest, gang members fired shots as they attacked the Delmas 32 neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.
On 21 November 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, gang members fired shots as they attacked the Delmas 24 neighbourhood. Casualties unknown.
On 15 November 2024, in Delmas - Village Solidarite, Ouest, gang members attacked and occupied the Village Solidarite neighbourhood. A man went missing. People fled the area. Casualties unknown.

On 30 April 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, the police, traveling in an armored vehicle, tried to stop armed individuals who were trying to invade the Bas Delmas and Solino (coded separately) neighborhoods. Gunshots were heard in Delmas 24 (Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28 neighborhood). Casualties unknown.

On 30 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Solino, Ouest, the police, traveling in an armored vehicle, tried to stop armed individuals who were trying to invade the Solino and Bas Delmas (coded separately) neighborhoods. There is no information on the specific actions taken during the confrontations. Casualties unknown.

On 29 April 2024, in Delmas - Sylvio Cator/Delmas 28, Ouest, several civilians were killed in Delmas 24. Armed individuals were seen in the area, but there is no information on the circumstances of the attacks. Many residents were forced to flee the neighborhood. Casualties unknown.

Property destruction: On 25 April 2024, overnight, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, members of the Viv Ansanm Gang looted the offices of the Le Nouvelliste newspaper at Rue du Centre. They also broke and stole everything they could on the premises including furniture and printing material.

On 20 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, unidentified individuals looted the offices of the National Press at Rue du Centre by seizing all office materials and supplies. During the incident, the perpetrators held the director hostage and seized the money he was carrying with him. He was released shortly after. As the director, he continues to ask the protection of the police to preserve the institution.

Around 11 April 2024 (week of), in Port-au-Prince - Turgeau, Ouest, three people were kidnapped in the perpetrators' vehicles. There is no information on the circumstances or perpetrators of the abductions, but latest reports suggest that most abductions are gang-related. The victims' whereabouts are unknown.

Other: On 18 April 2024, in Tabarre, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Caradeux, Petite Place Cazeau, and Mais Gate. Although the police intervened with unknown methods to control the situation, there is no information on the circumstances or authorship of the gunshots.

Other: On 3 April 2024, in Delmas, Ouest, gunshots were heard in Delmas 17, 19, 30, and 33. Although armed individuals were seen walking down the streets in Carrefour Aeroport, there is no information on the circumstances of the gunshots.

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Progres; Jamaica Observer; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vi Free Press
notes: Property destruction: On 1 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Poste Marchand, Ouest, armed gangsters entered the Saint-Martial Minor Seminary School, burned several vehicles and destroyed some materials, although no casualties among the present colleagues were mentioned. This happened amidst clashes involving police officers and soldiers against gang members near the National Palace (coded separately).

source: Alterpresse; Gazette Haiti; Haiti Progres; Jamaica Observer; Juno 7; Le Nouvelliste (Haiti); Rezo Nodwes; SG Alert (Whatsapp); Vi Free Press
notes: Property destruction: On 1 April 2024, in Port-au-Prince - Centre Ville, Ouest, armed gangsters The armed gangsters looted and robbed the National Library. This happened amidst clashes involving police officers and soldiers against gang members near the National Palace (coded separately).

Property destruction: On 31 March 2024, in Roche Blanche, Ouest, unidentified individuals looted the Digneron industrial park by setting fire to several of the buildings and destroying the warehouses, machines, and other materials.

Movement of forces: On 25 June 2024, in Tabarre - Aeroport Toussaint Louverture, Ouest, 400 Kenyan police officers were deployed to Haiti and arrived at the international airport in the capital as part of an international force that aims to support the fight against gang violence.
